webTitle: England's elite set for pay struggle

fields.headline: England's elite set for pay struggle
fields.trailText: England's cricketers face a major fight to secure central contracts after Nasser Hussain yesterday signalled a hardline approach following the disappointing tour to South Africa.
fields.body:
England's cricketers face a major fight to secure central contracts after Nasser Hussain yesterday signalled a hardline approach following the disappointing tour to South Africa.

Although the exact number of contracts that will be offered has yet to be finalised, it seems certain to be significantly fewer than the 16 suggested by the England and Wales Cricket Board chairman Lord MacLaurin only two weeks ago.

The budget for contracts has been slashed from £1m to £750,000 which, on a pro rata basis, suggests that around 12 will now be available.

The cost-cutting measures reflect the problems that the board is facing in attracting income. Last month Cornhill announced it was ending its sponsorship of Test cricket after 23 years.

Although the ECB's chief executive Tim Lamb stressed yesterday that the upper threshold of 16 contracts is still available to Hussain, it seems inconceivable that that maximum will now be achieved. The board is also under pressure from the counties, who are concerned that under the contract system money will be handed out to too many players with no guarantees of improvement in team performance.

"If you give out contracts simply as jobs for the boys and throw them away willy-nilly then they immediately become devalued," said Hussain. "I think you have to earn a contract."

The captain has held talks with the coach Duncan Fletcher and Simon Pack, the ECB's international teams director, over the highly sensitive issue. Yesterday Hussain stressed that although he has his own ideas, a firm decision on numbers will not be made until the chairman of selectors David Graveney joins the tour in Zimbabwe early next month.

"The principle of contracts is sound," Hussain said. "Rather than going off to play in various county matches and then turning up two days before a Test, getting reacquainted, asking how everyone is playing and what the fitness is like, you go off a week before a Test, you do your fitness and get the cricket right with whichever coach you want.

"I want to see us getting together and making sure everything is absolutely spot on. You know how you are bowling or batting, talk about the opposition, do the fitness, relax together and then we go out and take people on.

"I think contracts will help enormously, in particular with the bowlers. So, without giving any names away, we could keep an eye on the fitness of the likes of Gough or Flintoff or Tudor, and have some control over the development of future young bowlers."

But Hussain said that contracts will have to be sweated for. "It would be nice to have an elite squad with a contract that has not just been thrown at them, that has been well-earned so that county players can aspire to them.

"You have to have something where people say: 'I'm going to work bloody hard and make sure I get a contract with England because that is what I want. I don't want to do a little bit of this and a bit of that, play the odd Test and a one-day game here and there. I want to be a contracted England player'."

However, Hussain warned that it was essential to select the right players worthy of contracts. "If we don't it could prove divisive," he said, "so we have to make sure we do. Everything we have done on this trip, such as giving days off or making someone play, is potentially divisive if you don't get it right. We will be looking at fitness in detail and in April we have put together a fitness-testing weekend, where people will have to be physically fit and also go through a stringent medical to make sure they are internally fit as well. Anyone with ability will be considered."

Hussain also revealed that, after another washout on the fourth day of the final Test at Centurion Park yesterday, South Africa had turned down his suggestion to play a one-day game today if conditions again make Test cricket impossible.

He stressed that the idea was nothing more than an initiative to provide cricket for the paying public, and was not intended as a substitute for the Test match. "We would rather play the Test," he said, "but if that was not possible we would have been happy to play a 40-over match or whatever - starting later, bowling round the wicket if necessary, with a white ball or red, just to try and do something for the public."

webTitle: Robson puts his job on the line

fields.headline: Robson puts his job on the line
fields.trailText: Bryan Robson said yesterday he would consider resigning if his expensive Middlesbrough side continued their season of underachievement.
fields.body:
Bryan Robson said yesterday he would consider resigning if his expensive Middlesbrough side continued their season of underachievement.

A contingent of the club's supporters demanded his removal during Saturday's 4-1 home defeat by Derby County. Support from the boardroom appears undiminished, but it is clear Robson will not be satisfied with anything less than an improvement on last season's ninth position.

"I will assess whether I want to stay at the club depending on how well we have done at the end of the season," he said.

"We've been talking about finishing in the top half of the table and that is still our target. Only time will tell if we can do that, but that's when people should judge me. It's about what we achieve over the season, not one match".

But he added: "The way we've been playing, we have to be looking at the other end of the league and say there's a realistic chance of us getting dragged into the relegation zone if we don't do something about it.

"I understand the fans' disappointment but no one is more disappointed than me. Expectations were very high at the start of the season and that's the way I want it. We must not panic. It's now about us getting down to our next game. It's a tough game, against Liverpool away."

Despite an extended break over the holiday period, Boro are still racked with injuries, and Robson admitted his decision to bring back Gary Pallister and Paul Ince on Saturday had backfired.

"We had a couple who hadn't played for seven or eight weeks in Gary and Paul, and maybe I got it wrong there," he said. "Maybe I should have put a reserve game in there before I put them back in the side.

"But I hope it was just because we hadn't played for such a long time and there was a lot of rustiness in a lot of the lads."

Robson has spent more than £60m since his appointment in May 1994 and the modest return on his expenditure has seen the feelgood factor on Teesside replaced by open hostility.

His side have managed only one point against three clubs in the Premiership's bottom five in recent weeks, as well as being humbled by Wrexham and Tranmere Rovers in the two cup competitions.

They have dropped to 14th place, one below a resurgent Newcastle, although Boro's chief executive Keith Lamb reiterated his support for Robson at the weekend, claiming he had become "a victim of his own success".

webTitle: Old Firm lobby to replace Uefa Cup

fields.headline: Old Firm lobby to replace Uefa Cup
fields.trailText: Celtic and Rangers are at the forefront of a scheme to create a second-string European League which would effectively replace the Uefa Cup.
fields.body:
Celtic and Rangers are at the forefront of a scheme to create a second-string European League which would effectively replace the Uefa Cup.

The Old Firm will lobby the Scottish Football Association and Uefa to propose the pan-European competition, which would run alongside the present Champions League. The Glasgow clubs already have support from Portugal, the Netherlands, Belgium, Sweden and Norway.

If the competition is launched the clubs who would qualify for the Uefa Cup will effectively contest a second-division Champions League, which may involve each in as many as 30 matches. "We await specific proposals, but we are taking it seriously," a Uefa spokesman said yesterday.

Roger Mitchell, the chief executive of the Scottish Premier League, claimed that such a league is "inevitable" and that it may be in place by 2003. The proposal was high on the agenda at a recent meeting of the European Professional Leagues that he attended.

Uefa awards Germany, Italy, Spain, France and England more Champions League places than most. The feeling among many other countries is that an elite is being created based largely on the television income that can be generated. The original idea was to establish an Atlantic league for nations in similar predicaments, but that would have taken the clubs outside of the Uefa umbrella.

Celtic, with an average gate of almost 60,000, claim to be the world's fifth-best supported club while Rangers are looking at ways to increase Ibrox's 50,000 capacity. Both find it hard, however, to compete in television deals: Sky's Sunday coverage of the Premier League is worth only £10m a year.

"The SFA view is that this might happen but we would want to be convinced that the criteria is based on good sense and not just commercially driven," a spokesman said.

Motherwell's Shaun Teale, out of contract in the summer, has been told he will never play for the club again. After being informed that he would not be offered a new deal, the former Aston Villa defender, 35, put his name to a newspaper article claiming that the club has owed him £10,000 in relocation expenses since 1998.

"I cannot stand by and have this club treated with impunity," said the chairman John Boyle. "His agent has been notified and he will be given a free transfer. The facts are that Shaun has lost half-a-yard of pace and has been finding it difficult."

webTitle: Babbel to check in at Anfield

fields.headline: Babbel to check in at Anfield
fields.trailText: Gérard Houllier placed another piece in his expensive Liverpool jigsaw yesterday when he persuaded the Germany defender Markus Babbel to move to Anfield.
fields.body:
Gérard Houllier placed another piece in his expensive Liverpool jigsaw yesterday when he persuaded the Germany defender Markus Babbel to move to Anfield.

Three years after Babbel's proposed £5m transfer from Bayern Munich to Manchester United was halted due to personal terms, the 27-year-old agreed to join the Merseyside club on a Bosman free transfer at the end of this season.

Babbel, who has won 45 caps, has signed a pre-contract agreement which will be upgraded into a four-year deal on June 1, when he lowers the curtain on a Bayern career which began when he signed schoolboy forms shortly before his ninth birthday.

Although Babbel made his name as an uncompromising centre-back in the Bundesliga, he is a versatile performer and will almost certainly begin on the right of the defence. "To sign for Liverpool really is a dream for me because I have wanted to play in England for many years," he said.

Houllier stressed that he had not broken the club's wage structure to complete the deal. "He has not become our top earner," the manager said. "I'm very, very happy because you do not normally get players of his calibre on free transfers. He is a player of quality and vast experience and one we have been interested in for the best part of two years.

"We tried to get him last summer but Bayern simply refused to sell him. We have beaten off competition from Real Madrid and from a number of leading Italian clubs. "I think he'll do well in the Premiership; he is a winner and he has a very good character. He knows the challenge which lies ahead for him," he added.

Houllier defended his policy of flooding Anfield with new players, insisting it represents value for money. "Everybody keeps saying that we have spent £30m but, after sales, the net balance is £14m and for that figure we have reshaped an entire team," he said.

The League Managers Association is calling on the prime minister Tony Blair to "publicly censure" the four Labour MPs who last week called for the removal of Danny Wilson, Sheffield Wednesday's manager, and who have since declared that there will be no let up in their campaign.

The LMA's chief executive John Barnwell yesterday wrote to the sports minister Kate Hoey in an effort to halt the campaign being waged by David Blunkett, Joe Ashton, Clive Betts and Bill Michie.

The letter emphasises the LMA's "massive disappointment" over the issue. "This is totally unacceptable to us," Barnwell wrote. "The least we expect now is some form of public censure from the government over the scheming actions of these MPs. Danny Wilson has dealt with the matter in a professional manner, which cannot be said of them."

Nigeria have ruled out any chance of Nwankwo Kanu being released to play for Arsenal during the the African Nations Cup, which it is co-hosting with Ghana. The Nigeria Football Association claims the Gunners had asked for the striker to be made available between matches. "Arsenal are irresponsible," said its chairman Anthony Williams. "There's no way we are going to release Kanu."

 Leeds United have signed Australia's Olympic goalkeeper Danny Milosevic from Perth Glory for £100,000.

 The Argentina defender Jose Antonio Chamot has joined Milan from Atletico Madrid for £2.3m on a 2-year contract.

fields.headline: For Muralitharan read MacGill
fields.trailText: Sri Lanka's spin-bowling wizard Muttiah Muralitharan yesterday confirmed the worst fears of Lancashire fans by announcing that he will be unavailable for the county next season because of international duties.
fields.body:
Sri Lanka's spin-bowling wizard Muttiah Muralitharan yesterday confirmed the worst fears of Lancashire fans by announcing that he will be unavailable for the county next season because of international duties.

Lancashire are now pursuing the Australian legspinner Stuart MacGill but they will rue the loss of Muralitharan, whose 66 wickets in seven first-class games last season ignited the county's campaign and took him to second in the national bowling averages.

The offspinner is unable to fulfil the first season of his new two-year contract because Sri Lanka are hosting a tour by Pakistan in June, as well playing another series against South Africa, which will prevent him meeting the minimum requirement of 10 championship matches.

"I sincerely regret this situation," said Muralitharan, who has captured 227 Test wickets despite ever-present concerns about his bowling action. "I thoroughly enjoyed my last season and would love to play for Lancashire again in 2001."

Lancashire's chairman Jack Simmons admitted Muralitharan had been a "great asset" and would be missed. "I am very disappointed that he will not be joining us and we must now start the search for an equally top-class replacement."

Although he did not play in the Australian summer Tests because of Shane Warne's return from injury, MacGill has taken 59 wickets in only 12 Tests and is ranked among the world's top 20 bowlers.

 Pakistan want the inquiry into Shoaib Akhtar's suspect bowling action brought forward so that he can be "mentally prepared" for next month's three-Test home series against Sri Lanka. They have asked the International Cricket Council's advisory panel to hold a teleconference to decide Shoaib's Test fate ahead of their next meeting on February 9, which is four days after the tour begins.

webTitle: All padded up with nowhere to go

fields.headline: All padded up with nowhere to go
fields.standfirst: A one-man investigation has uncovered cricket's greatest whodunnit: where have all the pitches gone?
fields.trailText: David Hopps meets cricket statistician Peter Wynne-Thomas, the man who has uncovered cricket's greatest whodunnit: where have all the pitches gone?
fields.body:
Mysterious sightings throughout Nottinghamshire of a strange figure muttering to himself in cow fields, wheeling his arms down supermarket aisles, and occasionally emerging remorsefully through a hedge into private gardens, can now be properly explained.

When Peter Wynne-Thomas, one of the country's most renowned cricket statisticians, was moved to investigate the disappearance of cricket grounds in his beloved county, he approached it with the dedication befitting an amateur historian.

Opinion pollsters might believe they can judge the result of an election, or proclaim Britain's favourite soap powder, on the basis of a couple of hundred telephone calls and half an hour with a clipboard in a couple of town centres. But Wynne-Thomas, like many cricket stalwarts, can call on a finer quality: obsession.

He has set aside one day a week for the past two years to study the decline of club cricket in Nottinghamshire, introducing his fiancee to the delights of clambering over gates and tramping around new housing estates in the name of saving the game he loves.

The results horrified him. He has concluded that of the 364 pitches hosting matches in 1950, only 174 remain active half a century later.

While cricket grounds have halved, football fields have doubled. PG Wodehouse might have teased in Piccadilly Jim, back in 1918, about "cricket being simply a social necessity in England" but football took over that role forever with the erection of the first satellite dish.

The Nottinghamshire county cricket board, which is now responsible for all cricket in the county, will hear Wynne-Thomas's report tonight. It could not lay out their obligations more starkly.

"On average we are talking about four cricket pitches that have ceased use every winter for the past 50 years," he said. "You can doctor statistics to say anything you like, but at that rate of decline cricket would cease in Nottinghamshire in another 50 years' time. That's frightening."

To make his survey, Wynne-Thomas would select a few square miles on the map, pause only to grab his coat and a handful of vital accessories, and head off. If the ground still existed, he photographed and measured it. If it did not, then unsuspecting natives would be quizzed about its fate.

These encounters often took place in the neighbouring pub, where Wynne-Thomas would invariably order a ploughman's. "We frequently terrified villagers in mid-January by asking for the whereabouts of a cricket ground that had vanished years ago," he said.

One time-worn fast bowler informed Wynne-Thomas that his run-up was now the wine aisle at Morrisons supermarket, where the bounce was probably much more reliable than it used to be. The longdeparted Raleigh cricket ground was now Torvill Drive and Jayne Close - streets named after the ice dance champion. In the village of Leverton, the cricket ground had given way to a power station. The examples multiplied.

"The England and Wales Cricket Board claim that more cricket is being played than ever before, but I reckon that's nonsense," Wynne-Thomas concludes. "Just before the war, the number of football and cricket clubs in Nottinghamshire were about equal. Now there are four times as many football clubs. In the 60s the council advertised 35 pitches for hire in three public parks; now there is just one."

One consequence is that much of the development work carried out by schools in Nottinghamshire is wasted. Youngsters whose interests have been fired find little opportunity to progress.

So, assuming Wynne-Thomas's findings reveal a nationwide trend, what conclusions can be drawn for the future? Are things as bleak as they sound? Are England condemned to a life near the bottom of the Test rankings until, one day, the sport becomes an anachronism?

Two points need to be aired. One is that the era of council grounds is over. Clubs and leagues dislike the vandalised facilities, scarred outfields and dangerous pitches. Modern-day councils no longer countenance the upkeep that their own ground requires.

When four council pitches were provided in Mansfield Woodhouse, they lay unused. West Indian Cavaliers still use a public pitch, but as the Nottinghamshire Premier League champions they deserve better and it would be a wise council that leased them the facilities at a peppercorn rate.

Councils also continue to put smaller clubs in financial jeopardy with crushing rate demands. Many small-time football clubs merely have to find kit sponsorship, whereas the tiniest cricket club must inevitably balance its books with fundraising activities. Many have given up the ghost.

But as far as club cricket is concerned, the priority is that the enlightened survive. The old village cricket clubs taught much about a sense of community, but many were largely worthless in terms of player development. Younger players were often denied opportunities out of sentiment towards old George, who had built the pavilion singlehanded.

Since the county boards came into being three years ago, there is now the chance to follow up development work in the schools by restructuring club cricket: demanding safer pitches, proper development and rewards for the ambitious. Quality, not quantity, should be the watchword.

Cricket needs more like Wynne-Thomas to blow the whistle. But all he has discovered is that the England of PG Wodehouse, of Rog and Outside Edge, and of high-spending councils, no longer exists. We knew that anyway. If English cricket is awakening to the fact, it is not before time.
fields.bodyText: Mysterious sightings throughout Nottinghamshire of a strange figure muttering to himself in cow fields, wheeling his arms down supermarket aisles, and occasionally emerging remorsefully through a hedge into private gardens, can now be properly explained. When Peter Wynne-Thomas, one of the country's most renowned cricket statisticians, was moved to investigate the disappearance of cricket grounds in his beloved county, he approached it with the dedication befitting an amateur historian. Opinion pollsters might believe they can judge the result of an election, or proclaim Britain's favourite soap powder, on the basis of a couple of hundred telephone calls and half an hour with a clipboard in a couple of town centres. But Wynne-Thomas, like many cricket stalwarts, can call on a finer quality: obsession. He has set aside one day a week for the past two years to study the decline of club cricket in Nottinghamshire, introducing his fiancee to the delights of clambering over gates and tramping around new housing estates in the name of saving the game he loves. The results horrified him. He has concluded that of the 364 pitches hosting matches in 1950, only 174 remain active half a century later. While cricket grounds have halved, football fields have doubled. PG Wodehouse might have teased in Piccadilly Jim, back in 1918, about "cricket being simply a social necessity in England" but football took over that role forever with the erection of the first satellite dish. The Nottinghamshire county cricket board, which is now responsible for all cricket in the county, will hear Wynne-Thomas's report tonight. It could not lay out their obligations more starkly. "On average we are talking about four cricket pitches that have ceased use every winter for the past 50 years," he said. "You can doctor statistics to say anything you like, but at that rate of decline cricket would cease in Nottinghamshire in another 50 years' time. That's frightening." To make his survey, Wynne-Thomas would select a few square miles on the map, pause only to grab his coat and a handful of vital accessories, and head off. If the ground still existed, he photographed and measured it. If it did not, then unsuspecting natives would be quizzed about its fate. These encounters often took place in the neighbouring pub, where Wynne-Thomas would invariably order a ploughman's. "We frequently terrified villagers in mid-January by asking for the whereabouts of a cricket ground that had vanished years ago," he said. One time-worn fast bowler informed Wynne-Thomas that his run-up was now the wine aisle at Morrisons supermarket, where the bounce was probably much more reliable than it used to be. The longdeparted Raleigh cricket ground was now Torvill Drive and Jayne Close - streets named after the ice dance champion. In the village of Leverton, the cricket ground had given way to a power station. The examples multiplied. "The England and Wales Cricket Board claim that more cricket is being played than ever before, but I reckon that's nonsense," Wynne-Thomas concludes. "Just before the war, the number of football and cricket clubs in Nottinghamshire were about equal. Now there are four times as many football clubs. In the 60s the council advertised 35 pitches for hire in three public parks; now there is just one." One consequence is that much of the development work carried out by schools in Nottinghamshire is wasted. Youngsters whose interests have been fired find little opportunity to progress. So, assuming Wynne-Thomas's findings reveal a nationwide trend, what conclusions can be drawn for the future? Are things as bleak as they sound? Are England condemned to a life near the bottom of the Test rankings until, one day, the sport becomes an anachronism? Two points need to be aired. One is that the era of council grounds is over. Clubs and leagues dislike the vandalised facilities, scarred outfields and dangerous pitches. Modern-day councils no longer countenance the upkeep that their own ground requires. When four council pitches were provided in Mansfield Woodhouse, they lay unused. West Indian Cavaliers still use a public pitch, but as the Nottinghamshire Premier League champions they deserve better and it would be a wise council that leased them the facilities at a peppercorn rate. Councils also continue to put smaller clubs in financial jeopardy with crushing rate demands. Many small-time football clubs merely have to find kit sponsorship, whereas the tiniest cricket club must inevitably balance its books with fundraising activities. Many have given up the ghost. But as far as club cricket is concerned, the priority is that the enlightened survive. The old village cricket clubs taught much about a sense of community, but many were largely worthless in terms of player development. Younger players were often denied opportunities out of sentiment towards old George, who had built the pavilion singlehanded. Since the county boards came into being three years ago, there is now the chance to follow up development work in the schools by restructuring club cricket: demanding safer pitches, proper development and rewards for the ambitious. Quality, not quantity, should be the watchword. Cricket needs more like Wynne-Thomas to blow the whistle. But all he has discovered is that the England of PG Wodehouse, of Rog and Outside Edge, and of high-spending councils, no longer exists. We knew that anyway. If English cricket is awakening to the fact, it is not before time.

fields.headline: The best omen scene
fields.standfirst: Summer of Sam
fields.trailText: The Bronx, 1977. Recent punk convert Ritchie (Adrien Brody) sits with his longtime friend and serial adulterer Vinny (John Leguizamo) in the latter's car. Vinny, having witnessed serial killer Son of Sam's last murder, is convinced he has been the recipient of a divine pointer.
fields.body:
The Bronx, 1977. Recent punk convert Ritchie (Adrien Brody) sits with his longtime friend and serial adulterer Vinny (John Leguizamo) in the latter's car. Vinny, having witnessed serial killer Son of Sam's last murder, is convinced he has been the recipient of a divine pointer.

"Now," he explains, "it's bad enough that I balled Dionna's cousin, right? But then some sick part of me had to drive back, right past the place I was sticking it up her ass. And that's where I saw the bodies, right there. And you know what? That was God. He spared me."

By now, Ritchie is trying not to laugh.

"I'm serious, man. He spared me. This is a fucking omen. He let me go, you know? I mean ...what could this mean?"

Ritchie can't help sniggering.

"I don't know, what do you think it means?"

"I think it means God's telling me that I'm going to burn in hell if I don't stop cheating."

"Didn't I tell you not to get married?"

"Yeah..."

"So why didn't you listen?"

"'Cause I thought I was going to stop cheating when I got married."

Angst-ridden, Vinny rolls his eyes to the heavens.

"And now I'm just fuckin' cheating a lot more than I ever did."

See also: The Man With Two Brains, The Ten Commandments, The Omen, The Omen II

Don't see also: Oh! God, The Omen III

Pointless trivia: In February 1982, John Leguizamo was accepted to study under Lee Strasberg at the legendary Actor's Studio; Strasberg died the following day.

webTitle: The patent importance of our genetic blueprint

fields.headline: The patent importance of our genetic blueprint
fields.standfirst: Guardian science editor Tim Radford explains why genes patenting matters.
fields.trailText: Guardian science editorTim Radford explains why genes patenting matters.
fields.body:
Science is about knowledge, and understanding. It has steadily changed the way we see ourselves, and our place in the universe. It is about to do so again: a massive concerted effort by scientists in Britain, Europe, Japan and the US is beginning to decipher the complete book of life, the DNA code which holds the secrets of the 100,000 or so genes that describe the human condition. The code will reveal the secrets of evolutionary history.

Each new discovery demonstrates, over and over again, human connections with the rest of creation.

Humans share some of their genes with yeasts, with fugu fish and with fruit flies. They share 30 per cent of their genes with a lettuce, and 98.6 per cent of their genes with chimpanzees. This extraordinary story is unfolding because 12 years ago scientists employed by universities, government laboratories and charities began looking for the thousands of genes that cause wretched hereditary diseases and realised, quite quickly, that to understand a few they needed to understand them all.

The entire effort has been backed by taxpayers, and the charities anxious to overcome suffering.

The question is: who owns these astonishing discoveries? The British, European and official US position is that such knowledge was paid for by everybody, to benefit everybody: it should be freely available to whoever can make good use of it. So nobody should own it, nobody should charge others for using it.

But there is a catch. Genes are just part of the story: environment and lifestyle matter too. If a vulnerability to cancer, or to diabetes, or to osteoarthritis or cardiovascular disease or schizophrenia is based on a genetic mutation you have inherited, then would it not help to know that, so you could take remedial action?

So somebody needs to sit down and devise a reliable diagnostic test for the problem gene. It takes time, money and costly trials to get such things right: no biotech company would begin the task without some kind of patent protection. Even better, if you understand the problem, perhaps you could devise a treatment, or even a cure? That takes more time, more money and even more costly trials. These too will only happen with some kind of patent protection.

So there has to be a compromise, and to make sense, it had better be the same compromise the world over. Right now, the patent bureaucracies in Europe and the US seem to have different philosophies. If you are an American biotech business, it looks like a winner's strategy to bag as many bits of the gene as you can, and it seems (for the time being) possible to at least try to do that in the US. The British and US governments saw the problem coming almost a decade ago. It isn't clear that they have done anything about it.

webTitle: German opposition crisis as party meets on scandal

fields.headline: German opposition crisis as party meets on scandal
fields.trailText: The beleaguered leader of the German opposition will today face the biggest challenge yet to his survival, when he confronts fellow-party bosses at an emergency meeting to discuss who should be sacrificed to quell the scandal raging through the party about widespread illegal funding.
fields.body:
The beleaguered leader of the German opposition will today face the biggest challenge yet to his survival, when he confronts fellow-party bosses at an emergency meeting to discuss who should be sacrificed to quell the scandal raging through the party about widespread illegal funding.

The Christian Democrat Union (CDU) said last night that there was no agenda for the talks. But the DPA news agency, quoting senior party officials, said it had been called to discuss the "personal consequences" of the affair.

The conservatives' leader, Wolfgang Schäuble, has so far held out against a barrage of demands for his resignation, but it was clear that his future would be under discussion. Reports last night said that at least one party baron who has admitted being involved in the scandal will be told to go.

The latest revelations in the scandal, touched off by the former chancellor Helmut Kohl, focused on the region of Hesse, where former party officials admitted at the weekend that they had channelled millions of marks into the party's treasury from a Swiss bank account. In a sick twist, the regional party treasurer concealed the source of the funds by saying that the donations were from grateful Holocaust survivors with accounts in offshore tax-havens. Michel Friedman, a Frankfurt Jew and member of the CDU, called the ploy "disgusting".

The man last night earmarked for an early political execution was the party chairman in Hesse, Manfred Kanther. Ironically, as Mr Kohl's interior minister he was a leading proponent of tough law-and-order measures.

Whether his head will satisfy the growing number of critics baying for blood is doubtful. Mr Schäuble, who was booed and heckled at a rally at the weekend, faces a press which is all but united in demanding his departure, and a swelling phalanx of increasingly authoritative party critics.

Two leading conservative dailies, Die Welt and Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, yesterday demanded that Mr Schauble quit. Die Welt ran a front-page headline screaming "Resign", while the Frankfurter Allgemeine said the well-being of democracy was at stake.

Last week, he confessed to taking a donation in cash from the German-Canadian businessman whose disclosures set off the scandal. Yet in an earlier statement to parliament, in which he acknowledged having met the man, he made no mention of the fact that the businessman had given him a bag stuffed with banknotes the following day.

Prosecutors in three German cities are investigating the CDU's finances. Still to come is potentially the most damaging inquiry of all - an all-party parliamentary investigation into whether the decisions of Mr Kohl's governments were swayed by the money that party officials were taking in secret. Mr Schäuble and most of the CDU's present leaders sat in those governments.

"We will have to part ways with all those entangled in this affair," said Christian Wulff, a deputy national chairman. "I certainly don't exclude expulsions of party members."

Prosecutors in Hesse yesterday opened a fraud inquiry into two senior CDU officials after Mr Kanther admitted that DM13m (£4.4m) was diverted to the local Christian Democrat party between 1989-96.

webTitle: A high not to be sniffed at

fields.headline: A high not to be sniffed at
fields.trailText: OK, so England had to rely on a declaration to win, took just eight wickets in the match, and were up against an attack lacking its best bowler (Allan Donald) and its only spinner of worth (Paul Adams, who fractured his finger while fielding). But a Test win is not to be sniffed at - especially in South Africa, who last lost a home Test two years ago, against Pakistan, and were widely expected to whitewash England as they had done to West Indies the previous year. And if you'd offered Nasser Hussain 2-1 at the start of the series, he'd have taken it before you could say Bloemfontein - even if he'd never admit that in public.
fields.body:
OK, so England had to rely on a declaration to win, took just eight wickets in the match, and were up against an attack lacking its best bowler (Allan Donald) and its only spinner of worth (Paul Adams, who fractured his finger while fielding). But a Test win is not to be sniffed at - especially in South Africa, who last lost a home Test two years ago, against Pakistan, and were widely expected to whitewash England as they had done to West Indies the previous year. And if you'd offered Nasser Hussain 2-1 at the start of the series, he'd have taken it before you could say Bloemfontein - even if he'd never admit that in public.

So England end the Test series on a high - as they often do against better opposition when it's all too late - even if the last day was more of a glorified one-day international in whites. This isn't such a bad thing, with the one-day series round the corner, but did it devalue Test cricket? Hussain thought not, and he was right: the game would have been devalued more if Lance Klusener had helped himself to a century off Chris Adams and Darren Maddy. And there was even a deferential doff to the Laws, when England's first innings was officially registered as 0 for 0 declared, rather than forfeited (Law 14 makes no provision for a first-innings forfeiture).

England may be jubilant, but how much did they learn? Today reminded us that Chris Adams hasn't got the technique for Test cricket; that Mark Butcher is still susceptible when the bowling is anything less than fast-medium (Klusener got him with his slower ball); that Alec Stewart, who passed 6,500 Test runs, is our best attacking batsman (shame on you, if you thought he shouldn't have been picked in the first place); and that England usually wobble in sight of the victory post.

One new, and priceless nugget, however, is that Michael Vaughan is capable of stepping up a gear. Some of his cover-driving and pulling - even the manner of his dismissal, stepping away as he tried to mow Hayward through the covers - was more than the usual text-book we have come to expect. And, hallelujah, he became the first player other than the big three (Mike Atherton, Stewart and Hussain) to pass 50 for England in the series. We even discovered that, like that trio, Vaughan is not averse to the odd clich. 'Cricket was the winner', he intoned. Captaincy material, or what?

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: Just you wait
fields.standfirst: Hundreds of academic dreams rest on the current spending review.  Donald MacLeod weighs hope and despair
fields.trailText: Hundreds of academic dreams rest on the current spending review. Donald MacLeod weighs hope and despair
fields.body:
Universities' efforts to convince the government that they need more money for teaching students as well as research are running into stiff opposition from the Treasury.

With the whole of Whitehall gearing up for the heavyweight bouts of bargaining that will decide public funding up to 2004, leading figures in the higher education sector seem optimistic that research - especially in science - will do reasonably well in the Comprehensive Spending Review because ministers see this as a priority.

But is the promised expansion of higher education to the point where half of all 18- to 30-year-olds participate by 2009 to be paid for by the taxpayer and student fees? Or is it to be funded by squeezing the universities and their staff who have seen salaries decline by 30% in real terms?

As the Association of University Teachers today publish their pay claim for a 30% catch-up rise over the period of the review, there is anxiety that universities will continue to have their costs forced down. Spending per student has been slashed by more than 40% in real terms in the past two decades, and currently the sector is required to make cuts of 1% a year.

If sceptical Treasury officials have their way, students are likely to encounter bigger classes and less contact with tutors, more frustration in computer access and getting hold of books.

The lecturers' unions and the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals have now made their cases to the department for education and employment, along with a myriad competing groups for education cash, and next month the department will put its bid to the Treasury.

To back up its case, the CVCP has commissioned a study on how much research benefits the economy, and next month will publish a further study on staff recruitment and retention which it believes is becoming a problem.

Four of the CVCP's five priority areas for investment relate to teaching, including maintaining the level of funding per head and improving staff pay and conditions. While the sector is uniting in calling for between £4bn and £5bn extra, divisions have opened up between the old universities and the National Association of Teachers in Further and Higher Education, which represents staff in the new universities and higher education colleges.

Tom Wilson, the union's higher education officer, pointed out large disparities in the amount of money for teaching in different universities, ranging from more than £11,000 per head at University College London to £3,200 at Luton.

University heads dismissed this as simply a reflection of the different subject mix at old and new universities - an institution with a medical school and capital intensive science departments was bound to be more expensive than one with large numbers in business studies or vocational subjects.

But Wilson believes this is only part of the explanation and that older universities can draw on endowments and conference income and use research funding to improve facilities for students. He believes ministers have been shocked by recently published figures on drop-out rates and the questions about teaching quality, but that it would be hard to make a case for increased funding across the board. Funding needed to be targeted on institutions struggling with problems like drop-out rates that would respond to increased staff resources.

Natfhe's proposal to channel any extra money into the new universities and colleges by giving them the extra student numbers will infuriate the Russell Group of elite universities who are already talking about charging top-up fees to maintain quality.

"I think more could be done to remedy the present ludicrous inequality," said Wilson. "If they want to sell UK education overseas they are going to be tarred by the same brush if there are failures. It is short-sighted to take an elitist attitude."

fields.headline: The one that got away
fields.standfirst: One education officer has solved many of Liverpool's problems so quickly that its Third Way privatisation has been shelved. John Carvel explains
fields.trailText: One education officer has solved many of Liverpool's problems so quickly that its Third Way privatisation has been shelved
fields.body:
By the middle of last year, ministers had not a shadow of doubt that Liverpool was going to be the ideal place for a showpiece experiment in the privatisation of the education service. Shortly before Christmas, after much agonising at the education department and in Downing Street, they quietly changed their minds.

The cause of this uncharacteristic about-turn was an exceptionally able chief education officer who was parachuted in from Wigan to manage the city's schools in the wake of a devastating report from Ofsted.

By the next election, experiments in the privatisation of education will not have reached critical mass.

It began in June after Ofsted identified serious deficiencies in the authority's relationship with schools. That included calling in consultants from KPMG, who began work on a plan to contract out the entire education service of England's fourth largest metropolitan district. This would have dwarfed schemes under way in two London boroughs and could have become a model for the future.

One of the early casualties of the crisis was Frank Cogley, the director of education who stepped down within days of the Ofsted report. After a rapid clear-out of most of the top management tier, he set about building relationships with councillors and headteachers. Henshaw, the chief executive, pushed through a move to new premises that was completed in six weeks as Clark reorganised the department into three inter- communicating divisions with 15% fewer staff.

The education department kept them under close scrutiny. One or more of its officials was constantly on patrol in Liverpool and visits were paid by Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, Sir Michael Bichard, the permanent secretary, and Michael Barber, head of the standards unit.

They found morale rising and reform proceeding at a relentless pace. Liverpool was meeting fortnightly targets set by KPMG. New senior staff were appointed. Development plans were rewritten. Even more surprisingly, the headteachers started showing appreciation.

John Smartt, chairman of the Liverpool association of secondary heads, said Clark listened and gave them confidence. "We reached a point last term when we saw things were changing. We told KPMG it was too early to go for outsourcing. We wrote to ministers saying we were grateful for all the government had done, but the new system being put in place by the local education authority had to be given a chance." The consultants advised ministers to put privatisation plans on ice.

Accounts differ about what happened next. The perspective from Liverpool was that education ministers were fearful of denying Blair the privatisation prize he wanted. But according to senior education department sources, Blair was as good as gold, telling David Blunkett, the education secretary, to do whatever was best for raising standards.

Chris Woodhead was understood to be apoplectic, arguing that Liverpool was being let off the hook. But he was beaten back when Prof Barber told Downing Street that the result was the best possible advertisement for government intervention. Blair backed the settlement. It was a victory for pragmatism.

Clark shares the credit for that victory with Henshaw, the chief executive, who convinced ministers that education was Liverpool's top priority. As Henshaw now puts it: "Education will never be the same again here. It is now at the heart of the change agenda for the city council."

But Neil Fletcher, education director of the Local Government Association, says Clark's contribution was pivotal. "He went through the Liverpool education service like a knife through butter. He reorganised it on an epic private-sector scale. He motivated headteachers. He got good relations with councillors and he put together a new team that was utterly committed to carrying through a vision of how local government could work in Liverpool."

Fletcher thinks the Liverpool story has far-reaching political implications. "The government had started moving down the privatisation road, but now it has turned aside. Local education authorities don't yet have a completely clean bill of health. But David Blunkett has acknowledged we have made a significant response. We are heading for a stage where we can expect a more light-touch regime."

Estelle Morris warns against reading too much into the Liverpool decision. "The Tories would have forced through privatisation there for privatisation's sake. But we kept our eye on the ball. I don't believe the Liverpool solution could have worked in Islington. Authorities are different. I am delighted about the outcome in Liverpool, but this doesn't mean we will not outsource services elsewhere. I believe there will be a need to do that in future. What drives us is what works."

Bob Clark says the government deserves credit for intervening to force change in Liverpool, but in future there should be more support to help local education authorities act before crisis strikes. In a challenging speech to the North of England education conference in Wigan earlier this month, he asked: "Where are the early intervention strategies of the education department or Ofsted? What plans do they have to prevent failure? Where is the workforce that can help local education authorities that are already known to be in difficulties?"

If ministers do not want to drive education into the private sector, they should be doing more to help local education authorities help themselves.

fields.headline: Feel the quality
fields.standfirst: As MBAs become ever more popular, the aim for the potential student must be to find the best course
fields.trailText: As MBAs become ever more popular, the aim for the potential student must be to find the best course
fields.body:
Business and management disciplines now dominate British universities as never before. The latest figures released by the Association of Business Schools, which represents 100 institutions, indicate that about 12% of undergraduates are studying business and management degrees, while in the postgraduate sector the number is higher than 16%. More students opt for business than any other subject. This week's MBA Fair is a clear sign of how vibrant the sphere has become.

The possession of a Master's in Business Administration is now widely accepted by employers internationally as evidence of managerial competence, as long as the holder also has relevant work experience and the qualification comes from a respected business school. These points should not be overlooked by potential MBA students, because prospective employers appear to be paying increasing attention to them, and the trend looks set to continue.

In an effort to recruit participants on to MBA programmes, some providers are willing to accept entrants with little, or even no, work experience. But without this essential ingredient, a programme becomes too theoretical. The most respected MBAs insist on a minimum of about five years' working background, which lifts the average age of their students to around 30.

The latest intake on to Manchester Business School's full-time MBA is 21% up on the previous year, yet the quality of the class, in terms of academic achievement and employment record, surpasses any other group in the institution's 34-year history. Andy Dyson, Manchester's director of academic services, says this development reflects a determined effort to move up-market.

"Over the past few years, the GMAT [Graduate Management Admissions Test] scores of those accepted on to the programme have gone up by about 6%, and the proportion with 2:1 degrees and above has increased by almost a third."

He reckons that Manchester - alongside Cranfield, London and Warwick - belongs to an elite group of UK institutions that compete with the best schools worldwide. "In European league tables, Manchester usually claims a position somewhere between fourth and eighth place," he claims.

Over the past three years, entrants for the various part-time MBAs have more than doubled, out-stripping the performance of the full-time version. "The key to the part-time success is flexibility, which students welcome with open arms. We used to run a fixed three-year programme with specific dates of attendance and a single entry point in the autumn. Now we offer a choice of class dates, a course length of up to five years, and three entry dates in any year."

Dyson also discerns a shift in the attitude of employers towards MBA programmes. "They have been moving away from liking more theoretically based academic courses with exams. Instead, they are showing a strong preference for those MBAs which are action-based, contain lots of interaction with real companies, and allow students to undertake project work. Firms want MBA graduates who can be productive from their first day on the payroll."

For those intending to self- finance a full-time MBA course - which can easily involve an outlay of £30,000 or more - Dyson recommends exhaustive research, including visits to schools where staff and students should be quizzed. "Such self-funders should look carefully at the more expensive institutions because those are precisely the ones whose qualifications are more likely to lead to a suitable job afterwards. Our full-time fees are £21,000, but the returns from that investment can be huge."

Melissa McCrindle, marketing and development manager at Strathclyde Business School, reports many of the same observations expressed at Manchester. The Scottish institution has seen a similar expansion of its part-time MBA and clear student demand for greater flexibility in delivery. Strathclyde's programmes, in common with Manchester, are accredited by the Association of MBAs, whose kitemark is widely respected. "Applicants are far more aware than they used to be, and AMBA approval is one of the most important indicators of quality that they look for," she says.

As chief executive of the Association of Business Schools, Jonathan Slack sees the part-time sector as the main engine for MBA growth in the UK. "Overall, I'd predict an expansion of about 10% a year in part-time numbers. Full-time increase will prove more modest at around half that."

He is outspoken on the topic of whether the MBA is essentially a generalist qualification, as originally conceived, or whether it can be legitimately extended to embrace specialist forms that have become popular more recently. "Our view is that the MBA is definitely generalist. We would prefer the current specialist versions of it to become MAs or MScs, which is where narrower specialisms properly belong. We want to protect the purity of the MBA brand, which is best served by promoting it as a generalist qualification in strategic management," he explains.

He is no less outspoken on MBA accreditation: "There is no doubt that AMBA-approved courses are very good, but others outside that scheme can be just as good or better. Some schools don't bother with AMBA because they object to their criteria of assessment. There is a new accreditation body emerging called EQUIS [The European Quality Improvement System] run by the European Foundation for Management Development in Brussels. Places including London, Ashridge, Henley and Aston have already been recognised by it - and it could become a major force in international validation."

This week's MBA event in London is an ideal place to check out what's available up and down the country under a single roof. Around 116 institutions offer MBAs in the UK.

fields.headline: The whole story
fields.standfirst: Louis Sachar's Holes is an unlikely mixture of adventure, compassion and humour that adds up to a riveting and perceptive story about self-respect.
fields.trailText: Holes is an unlikely mixture of adventure, compassion and humour that adds up to a riveting and perceptive story about self-respect.
fields.body:
Holes
By Louis Sachar
Published by Bloomsbury
Price £10.99
Age 10+

Buy it at BOL

Set in a detention centre for juveniles, Holes is an unlikely mixture of adventure, compassion and humour that adds up to a riveting and perceptive story about self-respect. Totally undidactic, it interweaves the world of the contemporary juvenile offenders around a story from the past, revealing how outsiders were treated then.

Stanley is sent to Camp Green Lake for a crime he didn't commit. He accepts his punishment as just another example of the bad luck that has dogged his family for generations. At the camp, every boy has to dig a hole 5ft wide and 5ft deep in the dried-up bed of a lake. Why? Because it's good for their character, they are told.

Like all new inmates, Stanley's first days are spent just coping with digging the hole and his raging thirst. Gradually he begins to work with his fellow diggers. Each has their own bad-luck story. Under an uncaring regime, their relationships with each other are vital for their survival and emotional development. Together they begin to question everything, leading to a convincing unravelling of both the story from the past and the reasons for the holes.

fields.headline: Plus points
fields.standfirst: Choosing the right course and college is complex but now there are hard facts to go on, says  Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Choosing the right course and college is complex but now there are hard facts to go on
fields.body:
The student consumer's factual guide to the country's 170 universities and higher education colleges is unveiled this month by the academic sector's official number crunching outfit, the Higher Education Statistics Agency. What are the hardest universities to get into? Where are you most likely to secure a first-class honours degree? Which institutions promise the best graduate job prospects? Insight 2000, a statistical guide to undergraduate study, has all the answers.

"We hope that this guide will help you in your quest to find the right place to study," says an introduction to the booklet. "We shall not be telling you about the nightlife, the price of beer or whether the buildings (or the other students) are attractive. The role of this book is simply to give you the facts and figures." But as with any shopping expedition, choosing a university or college is complex as there are so many facts and figures.

Some institutions do demand much tougher A-level grades if you want to get onto their degree courses, but they may offer bettter chances of getting a good degree after three or four years of study.

Others may be less stringent about entry qualifications but boast some of the country's best-staffed courses. Others produce some of the most employable graduates in the sector.

The dilemmas being faced by the newly informed student customer are summed up by a look at the country's foremost academic universities - Oxford and Cambridge.

The figures confirm the Oxbridge institutions as the hardest to get into: 99.5% of new students at Oxford and 99.6% of new students at Cambridge have higher than average A-level or Scottish Higher grades. Yet 86.6% of students graduate with first or upper-second-class degrees at Cambridge, compared with only 78.9% at Oxford.

When it comes to employment Oxford comes out on top, registering only 1.5% of students on the dole six months after graduating, against 3.5% of Cambridge graduates.

Then again, if contact with academic staff is most important to you, Cambridge seems a better bet, with 12 students for every staff member, compared with 13 at Oxford.

Shopping rule one is to find the university or college best suited to your needs. Each institution is characterised by its own special set of aims. Some older institutions, like Cambridge and Oxford, consider research to be just as important as teaching and offer very traditional academic courses.

Others, particularly the former polytechnics, or modern universities, spend less time on academic research, and focus on other niche higher education markets. These include vocational, part-time degrees and access courses for mature students, and under-represented students from poor backgrounds.

Shopping rule two, a corollary to rule one, is to interpret the statistics carefully. Even for institutions as similar as Oxford and Cambridge, the figures obscure subtle but significant differences in degree subjects.

Disciplines, as the statistical guide reveals, are characterised by different A-level scores, degree results, employment prospects and student-staff ratios. A medical school, for example, is likely to improve the overall employment figures for a university because medical students face little difficulty finding jobs.

Also, as the student-staff ratios compiled in the guide are based on university returns for teaching and research staff, research-oriented institutions are likely to look better, even though in many cases research staff have little interaction with students.

The use of higher-education statistics is now one of the most sensitive issues for universities. And signalling the growing tensions, the University of North London vetoed the Hesa guide.

So, with a few of the consumer pitfalls in mind, where are the best buys? For anyone heading for top A-levels or Scottish Highers and wishing to take a traditional academic degree course, the figures suggest that you could do a lot worse than King's College, London, or the University of Glasgow. King's and Glasgow are part of small cluster of universities, also including Edinburgh, Nottingham, Oxford and Cambridge, where over 70% of undergraduates get first or upper-second class degrees.

Yet Glasgow is the only university in the group which enrols less than four-fifths of students with above average A levels (18.3 points where A=10 and E=2) and Scottish Highers (16.3 points). While at King's this proportion is slighter higher, at 83.8%, the London university registers only 1.8% of its graduates as being unemployed six months after finishing degrees, less than any of the other institutions in the group. King's also benefits from one of the best student-staff ratios, with 10 students for every academic staff member.

If, on the other hand, you are destined, for whatever reason, for less good A levels, or you have vocational qualifications instead, Bournemouth or Abertay Dundee may be the university for you. Among universities with the least demanding academic entry requirements are Abertay Dundee, Bournemouth, Greenwich, Luton, Paisley, South Bank and Thames Valley. Fewer than 10% of students enrolled at these institutions have higher than average A-levels or Scottish Highers. Yet at only Abertay, Paisley, and Bournemouth, do over two-fifths of graduates still leave university with first and upper-second degrees.

On top of this, Bournemouth and Abertay both record under 7% of graduates on the dole after finishing university. The student customer should also be aware that degree subject is a big influence on academic and employment prospects.

The guide reveals, for example, that for most humanities subjects more than 60% of graduates get first or upper-second degrees, compared with only about 50% of graduates in the physical sciences.

Often 10% of graduates in the creative arts are on the dole after six months. In the mathematical sciences less than 5% of graduates are still seeking jobs after university.

When it comes to employment Oxford comes out on top, registering only 1.5% of students on the dole six months after graduating, against 3.5% of Cambridge graduates. Then again, if contact with academic staff is most important to you, Cambridge seems a better bet, with 12 students for every staff member, compared with 13 at Oxford. Shopping rule one is to find the university or college best suited to your needs. Each institution is characterised by its own special set of aims. Some older institutions, like Cambridge and Oxford, consider research to be just as important as teaching and offer very traditional academic courses. Others, particularly the former polytechnics, or modern universities, spend less time on academic research, and focus on other niche higher education markets. These include vocational, part-time degrees and access courses for mature students, and under-represented students from poor backgrounds. Shopping rule two, a corollary to rule one, is to interpret the statistics carefully. Even for institutions as similar as Oxford and Cambridge, the figures obscure subtle but significant differences in degree subjects. Disciplines, as the statistical guide reveals, are characterised by different A-level scores, degree results, employment prospects and student-staff ratios. A medical school, for example, is likely to improve the overall employment figures for a university because medical students face little difficulty finding jobs. Also, as the student-staff ratios compiled in the guide are based on university returns for teaching and research staff, research-oriented institutions are likely to look better, even though in many cases research staff have little interaction with students. The use of higher-education statistics is now one of the most sensitive issues for universities. And signalling the growing tensions, the University of North London vetoed the Hesa guide. So, with a few of the consumer pitfalls in mind, where are the best buys? For anyone heading for top A-levels or Scottish Highers and wishing to take a traditional academic degree course, the figures suggest that you could do a lot worse than King's College, London, or the University of Glasgow. King's and Glasgow are part of small cluster of universities, also including Edinburgh, Nottingham, Oxford and Cambridge, where over 70% of undergraduates get first or upper-second class degrees. Yet Glasgow is the only university in the group which enrols less than four-fifths of students with above average A levels (18.3 points where A=10 and E=2) and Scottish Highers (16.3 points). While at King's this proportion is slighter higher, at 83.8%, the London university registers only 1.8% of its graduates as being unemployed six months after finishing degrees, less than any of the other institutions in the group. King's also benefits from one of the best student-staff ratios, with 10 students for every academic staff member. If, on the other hand, you are destined, for whatever reason, for less good A levels, or you have vocational qualifications instead, Bournemouth or Abertay Dundee may be the university for you. Among universities with the least demanding academic entry requirements are Abertay Dundee, Bournemouth, Greenwich, Luton, Paisley, South Bank and Thames Valley. Fewer than 10% of students enrolled at these institutions have higher than average A-levels or Scottish Highers. Yet at only Abertay, Paisley, and Bournemouth, do over two-fifths of graduates still leave university with first and upper-second degrees. On top of this, Bournemouth and Abertay both record under 7% of graduates on the dole after finishing university. The student customer should also be aware that degree subject is a big influence on academic and employment prospects. The guide reveals, for example, that for most humanities subjects more than 60% of graduates get first or upper-second degrees, compared with only about 50% of graduates in the physical sciences. Often 10% of graduates in the creative arts are on the dole after six months. In the mathematical sciences less than 5% of graduates are still seeking jobs after university.

fields.headline: DiCaprio considering Anakin Skywalker role
fields.standfirst: Also today, Whitney flees police after drugs bust, and Next Friday rules at the US box office
fields.trailText: Whispered rumours that Leonardo DiCaprio is considering signing up to the next Star Wars prequel stepped up an octave last night as news broke that the Titanic star has been discussing the project with creator George Lucas.
fields.body:
Whispered rumours that Leonardo DiCaprio is considering signing up to the next Star Wars prequel stepped up an octave last night as news broke that the Titanic star has been discussing the project with creator George Lucas.

DiCaprio was spotted travelling to the film-maker's Skywalker ranch in California late last year, yet insisted that he was only visiting to attend a private screening of The Phantom Menace. But promoting his forthcoming role in The Beach on Entertainment Tonight, the 25 year-old actor admitted that he had already discussed the possibility of playing the teenage Anakin Skywalker with Lucas. DiCaprio confirmed that he would like to take the role, yet insisted that no firm decisions had yet been made.

The casting of Lucas's Star Wars series is traditionally a heavily guarded process. When Ewan McGregor committed to The Phantom Menace back in 1997, he was asked to sign a contract promising to tell nobody of the decision, not even his wife. DiCaprio has long been tipped for a role in Lucas's next installment (provisionally titled Star Wars 2), yet most industry insiders felt him to be too old and established to play the part of Anakin Skywalker.

Last November, a leaked Lucasfilm memo called for a 19-year-old actor who was "self-determined, extremely intelligent, and forthright". Speaking on CNN last week, George Lucas confessed that he was still finishing the script, with a view to starting production in the summer.

 Star Wars 2 is tentatively scheduled for a US release in the summer of 2001.

Whitney flees police after drugs bust

Actress and singer Whitney Houston allegedly fled Hawaii last week after the discovery of 15.2g of marijuana in her luggage. Local newspaper the Hilo Herald Tribune reports that the discovery was made by security at Hawaii's Kahole-Kona international airport.

Officials detained Ms Houston and notified the police, only for the Bodyguard star to board a United Airlines flight to San Francisco without her luggage, leaving Kahole-Kona a full 45 mins before police arrived.

Hawaii police will refer the case to the local district attorney with a view to a possible prosecution. The penalty for possession of marijuana in Hawaii is 30 days imprisonment and a $1,000 fine.

Affleck 'embarrassed' by directorial debut

Currently ensconsed on the Hollywood fast track, actor Ben Affleck is finding himself embarrassed by past history, in the form of a little seen film with an unwieldly title. The Dogma star has confessed his irritation over the abrupt re-appearance of the 15 minute short film, entitled I Killed My Lesbian Wife, Hung Her on a Meathook, and Now I Have a Three Picture Deal at Disney.

Affleck admits that he directed the film back in 1994 as a favour to his then-girlfriend Kamala Lopez-Dawson, the picture's producer. But he claims that Lopez-Dawson ("a woman ten years my senior") was "crazy" and later cut him out of the editing process. "I was glad to get shut of her," Affleck says. But he is upset that she is now crediting him as the film's director.

Writing on his own official website, Affleck accused Lopez-Dawson of cheap opportunism. "I wouldn't mind all this so much if she weren't now selling the thing to websites by using my name as a director," he says. "It is frustrating as I feel she is willing to misrepresent and embarrass me for her own (financial) gain."

Next Friday rules at the US box office

The Ice Cube vehicle Next Friday has dumped Stuart Little off the number-one slot at the US box office.

Initial reports estimate the rollicking urban comedy pulled in $15m on its opening weekend. Stuart Little slipped to second place, although its weekend takings of $12.6m did nudge the popular family outing above the crucial $100m mark. The Hurricane, starring Denzel Washington, was placed third with $10.7m.

In brief

Mary Harron's adaptation of the Brett Easton Ellis novel American Psycho has been hit with a prohibitive NC-17 rating by the American censors (MPAA). The NC-17 rating - still widely viewed as the box-office kiss of death has been given on account of an explicit sex scene. American Pyscho tells the tale of a yuppie psychopath in Manhattan, and premieres this Friday at the Sundance International Film Festival. Distributor Lion's Gate are appealing the decision.

Old hands Luc Besson and Patrice Leconte were in pole position when the nominations for France's 25th César Awards were announced in Paris last night. Besson's The Messenger (aka Joan of Arc) and Leconte's Girl on the Bridge both head the field with eight nominations apiece, including Best Film and Best Director. Leconte has already scooped both for Ridicule back in 1997; Besson won Best Director last year for The Fifth Element.

webTitle: 'No question' of a decision on Pinochet today

fields.headline: 'No question' of a decision on Pinochet today
fields.standfirst: "It remains a matter of fair process": statement by Amnesty International
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw confirmed this afternoon there was "no question" of him making his final decision today on whether to allow General Augusto Pinochet to go free.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw confirmed this afternoon there was "no question" of him making his final decision today on whether to allow General Augusto Pinochet to go free.

Human rights campaigners formally told Mr Straw they "strongly opposed" his intention to declare the former Chilean dictator unfit to stand trial. The home secretary set a 5pm deadline today for appeals against his announcement last week that he was "minded" to release Gen Pinochet.

"I've seen some of the submissions - literally seen them. They are very bulky and will require the most careful consideration," Mr Straw said. "There's no question of my making a decision today. I've got to give proper consideration to all the representations which I've received.

"Once we've seen the size of the representations and the nature of the arguments then we'll give an indication of when it is likely that I'll announce a decision, but it's certainly is not going to be a matter of hours - nothing like that," he added.

But speculation that Gen Pinochet's release is a mere formality increased when the ministry of defence confirmed that a Chilean plane will fly into RAF Brize Norton sometime tomorrow. It will be used to take Gen Pinochet back to Chile if the extradition case against him is dropped.

Amnesty International, the Redress Trust, the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture and the Relatives of the Disappeared in Chile lodged a written submission with the home office.

They expressed concern that the decision would be based on secret medical evidence that "may not reflect the General's true condition".

Amnesty spokesman Richard Bunting said its submission highlighted "medical and legal concerns about Mr Straw's preliminary decision and the doctors' report on which it was based.

"Our submission contains independent expert medical opinion which we feel highlights deficiencies in the examination to which Gen Pinochet was subject," he said. He confirmed Amnesty was looking at the possibility of asking for a judicial review, but that would depend on how Mr Straw treated the submissions.

In an afternoon statement, the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture said it had called on Mr Straw to reverse his provisional decision to release Gen Pinochet.

It said all interested parties should have access to the medical reports on which Mr Straw based his decision, and should also have the right to conduct a fresh medical examination.

In its representations, the organisation challenged the suggestion that medical evidence about the general could not be made public because of doctor-patient confidentiality considerations.

The Foundation also complained that the medical team which examined the Gen Pinochet did not include anyone with specific expertise in dementia.

In letters accompanying the Foundation's representations, Dr Robert Howard, of the Institute of Psychiatry at the Maudsley Hospital in London, and Dr Nori Graham, president of the International Alzheimer's Society - both eminent old-age psychiatrists - stated that the medical tests to which Pinochet was apparently subjected were insufficient to arrive at a diagnosis of dementia.

Ms Bamber said: "To allow Gen Pinochet home now without giving all interested parties the chance to examine the evidence, and conduct new tests, would be to fly in the face of natural justice, and make a mockery of the continued suffering of the thousands of people tortured and bereaved by his regime."

fields.headline: Tesco's silence refuels M&S rumour
fields.trailText: Tesco yesterday failed to dampen speculation that it might bid for Marks & Spencer when it failed to issue any denial in its Christmas trading statement.
fields.body:
Tesco yesterday failed to dampen speculation that it might bid for Marks & Spencer when it failed to issue any denial in its Christmas trading statement.

Anxiety about a possible bid depressed the grocer's share price, even though it said margins had been maintained and like-for-like sales in Britain were up a respectable 5.5% in the seven weeks to January 8.

Claiming to be the world's largest internet grocer, Tesco said it had experienced a ten-fold increase in e-sales over last year, and now had 250,000 regular e-shoppers.

The retailer - which at present offers its online service from 100 stores in London, the south-east, the M1 corridor and Newcastle - will roll out the service throughout the UK later this year.

The online shop - which for the first time at Christmas included books, gifts and homeware - is already making a profit for Tesco, which is able to service around 2,000 e-shoppers from each store. Its Tesco personal finance operation, a joint venture with Royal Bank of Scotland, is also available on the internet.

The group said overall sales for the 21 weeks since its half-year results had increased by 10.2%, while total like-for-like sales in the seven weeks to January 8 were up 11.8%.

It pointed to a "strong" performance in its British operation, diversification away from food and expansion overseas as helping to fuel the growth in sales.

It claimed its market share in the UK was continuing to increase, and said 17m shoppers had visited its stores in the week before Christmas, compared with a more usual 12.5m average number.

"In the week leading up to Christmas we served over 17m customers who welcomed our price cuts and enjoyed the cheapest Christmas for years," Tesco said.

The group made £380m of price cuts last year, which might have helped sales in comparison with Sainsbury, which last week reported like-for-like sales up by 2% in the 12 weeks to January 8 - although Morrison, operating from a smaller base, reported a 15.1% rise in sales and Safeway a 6% rise.

Tesco, which now has 38 international "hypermarkets", has plans to open 28 more during the year, and revealed yesterday that the biggest grossing store in its entire chain, including the UK, is in Thailand.

Its shares fell by 6p to 169p after the trading statement - apparently on general concern about margin pressure in the retailing sector and mounting anxiety that it might be considering a "rescue" bid for M&S, which Philip Green, the retailing financier, has set his sights on.

Tesco made no mention of M&S in its trading statement, neither confirming nor denying its interest in the retailer.

"Tesco, in not denying the talk about M&S, have shown they might be interested. That's making people nervous as it would be relatively dilutive for the shares," one retail analyst said yesterday.

The takeover panel, which polices takeovers, is understood to have discussed the need with Tesco to clarify the position with regard to M&S but concluded that a statement was not needed.

While this might suggest that Tesco had not considered a bid for the troubled store it also indicated that it was not prepared to rule itself out from making a bid. A public denial to the stock exchange would rule out a bid for six months.
