webTitle: Irving claims mad or mendacious, court told

fields.headline: Irving claims mad or mendacious, court told
fields.trailText: No "sane" person could conclude that hundreds of thousands of Jews were transported to the middle of nowhere on the Russian border during World War Two to "restore their health", the high court Holocaust libel trial was told today.
fields.body:
No "sane" person could conclude that hundreds of thousands of Jews were transported to the middle of nowhere on the Russian border during World War Two to "restore their health", the high court Holocaust libel trial was told today.

Richard Rampton QC, defending American academic Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books against a libel claim brought against them by historian David Irving, told the court in London that anyone making such a suggestion was either "mad or a liar".

Mr Rampton made his comments during his cross-examination of 62-year-old Mr Irving, who claims that Professor Lipstadt's 1994 book, Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory, has generated waves of hatred against him.

Mr Irving is suing over a claim that he is a "Holocaust denier". He says the book alleges he has distorted statistics and documents to serve his own ideological purposes and reach historically untenable conclusions.

The author of Hitler's War says he has never claimed that the Holocaust did not take place. He does, however, question the number of Jewish dead and denies there was a systematic extermination of Jews in concentration camp gas chambers.

Mr Rampton asked him what the hundreds of thousands of Jews transported to "little villages in the middle of nowhere" on the Russian border in eastern Poland in 1942 were going to do there.

Mr Irving replied: "The documents do not tell me."

Counsel asked him to try to construct in his own mind a convincing explanation. Mr Irving said: "There could be any number of convincing explanations. What is the point of that exercise?" Mr Rampton said it was to "show the scale of the operation and in due course to demonstrate that anybody who suggests that these hundreds of thousands of Jews were sent to these tiny villages in order to restore their health is either mad or a liar".

Mr Rampton told Mr Justice Gray that Mr Irving's position on what happened at those villages on the Russian border - Treblinka, Sobibor and Belzec - appeared to be an acceptance that hundreds of thousands of Jews were intentionally killed at those places, "but not as the consequence of any policy or system" and that he was not satisfied "that was their dedicated purpose".

Mr Irving told the judge, who is hearing the case without a jury, that this was "a very fair summary" of his position.

The hearing was adjourned until tomorrow.

webTitle: Moratti joins GMG in venture capital firm

fields.headline: Moratti joins GMG in venture capital firm
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The Italian businesswoman who had a furious argument with Rupert Murdoch and quit as head of his European media interests after only 10 months in the job has emerged as one of the major shareholders in a new London-based internet venture capital fund.
fields.body:
The Italian businesswoman who had a furious argument with Rupert Murdoch and quit as head of his European media interests after only 10 months in the job has emerged as one of the major shareholders in a new London-based internet venture capital fund.

Letizia Moratti, who is based in Milan, and the Guardian Media Group - owner of the Guardian newspaper - are the two largest shareholders in Spectrum Venture Management, which completed its first round of financing two weeks ago and is on target to raise a total of £35m by the end of the year.

Ms Moratti, 50, is known as a consummate networker and was described by Mr Murdoch as "a distinguished citizen ... known throughout the broadcasting establishment in Europe" before their disagreement about the company's strategic direction in September last year, when she resigned as president of News Corporation Europe.

Prior to working for Mr Murdoch she was chairman of Italian public broadcaster RAI.

Ms Moratti will act as an adviser to SVM, which hopes to invest in around eight net related start-ups each year and then help them devise strategies and business plans.

The impetus behind the fund has come from London-based Spectrum Strategy Consultants, which specialises in the internet and converging communication systems.

Spectrum's board is chaired by Lord Puttnam; its deputy chairman is Don Cruickshank, who is overseeing the government review of the banking sector. The founders of the online travel and entertainment firm, Lastminute.com - Brent Hoberman and Martha-Lane Fox - both previously worked for Spectrum.

Ross Fitzgerald, managing director of SVM, said: "As the first year marketing costs to successfully build internet businesses escalate beyond 10m, it is critical for entrepreneurs to rapidly create win-win marketing alliances with strategic corporates.

"SVM will provide its investee companies with access to Spectrum's worldwide network of corporate contacts to reduce marketing expenditure by up to a third."

Bob Phillis, the chief executive of Guardian Media Group, said: "We are delighted to be one of the founder investors in Spectrums' new fund.

"We view our participation as being an important part of our group's ambitious internet growth strategy."

Around 40% of the Spectrum group's investment is likely to be made in business to consumer start-ups, with the remainder in business to business companies.
fields.bodyText: The Italian businesswoman who had a furious argument with Rupert Murdoch and quit as head of his European media interests after only 10 months in the job has emerged as one of the major shareholders in a new London-based internet venture capital fund. Letizia Moratti, who is based in Milan, and the Guardian Media Group - owner of the Guardian newspaper - are the two largest shareholders in Spectrum Venture Management, which completed its first round of financing two weeks ago and is on target to raise a total of £35m by the end of the year. Ms Moratti, 50, is known as a consummate networker and was described by Mr Murdoch as "a distinguished citizen ... known throughout the broadcasting establishment in Europe" before their disagreement about the company's strategic direction in September last year, when she resigned as president of News Corporation Europe. Prior to working for Mr Murdoch she was chairman of Italian public broadcaster RAI. Ms Moratti will act as an adviser to SVM, which hopes to invest in around eight net related start-ups each year and then help them devise strategies and business plans. The impetus behind the fund has come from London-based Spectrum Strategy Consultants, which specialises in the internet and converging communication systems. Spectrum's board is chaired by Lord Puttnam; its deputy chairman is Don Cruickshank, who is overseeing the government review of the banking sector. The founders of the online travel and entertainment firm, Lastminute.com - Brent Hoberman and Martha-Lane Fox - both previously worked for Spectrum. Ross Fitzgerald, managing director of SVM, said: "As the first year marketing costs to successfully build internet businesses escalate beyond 10m, it is critical for entrepreneurs to rapidly create win-win marketing alliances with strategic corporates. "SVM will provide its investee companies with access to Spectrum's worldwide network of corporate contacts to reduce marketing expenditure by up to a third." Bob Phillis, the chief executive of Guardian Media Group, said: "We are delighted to be one of the founder investors in Spectrums' new fund. "We view our participation as being an important part of our group's ambitious internet growth strategy." Around 40% of the Spectrum group's investment is likely to be made in business to consumer start-ups, with the remainder in business to business companies.

fields.headline: Peak Practice sex claims criticised
fields.trailText: The medical drama series Peak Practice was criticised today for offending and misleading viewers by wrongly suggesting that sexual intercourse presents a high risk of passing the liver disease hepatitis C.
fields.body:
The medical drama series Peak Practice was criticised today for offending and misleading viewers by wrongly suggesting that sexual intercourse presents a high risk of passing the liver disease hepatitis C.

In a report published today, the Independent Television Commission upheld 16 complaints from viewers about the edition of the long running ITV drama series.

Several objections came from specialist organisations including the British Liver Trust. The broadcasting regulator ruled that Carlton Televi sion, producers of the series, overstated the risk of contracting the disease through sexual contact, as it is relatively unusual and hepatitis C is predominantly passed on through blood to blood contact.

Carlton said its medical adviser to the series had revealed that sexual contact was linked to the disease and denied the programme was likely to mislead viewers.

However, the ITC found that the storyline had caused "considerable, and avoidable, distress" to viewers and it went on to critise the programme makers for failing to provide a helpline.

Channel 4's late-night satirical series, The 11 O'Clock Show, was also criticised in the report for a number of items about the murder of the Armenian prime minister and a number of MPs on the day of the massacre. Nine viewers complained.

"No apparent purpose lay behind the humour. Its effect was simply to dwell on recent tragedy and to mock Armenia and the Armenian people," the regulator said.

Complaints from viewers about two storylines from Brookside last summer were also upheld.

A racism plot was criticised for using a particularly offen sive term, "nigger lover", and a scene of a couple having sexual intercourse in a shower was also deemed unsuitable for screening before the 9pm watershed.

And 14 viewers complained about a commentator during ITV's coverage of the Rugby World Cup.

During the live coverage of the match between France and Fiji in October, a French player threw the ball at a Fijian player and was described by an ITV commentator, Steve Smith, as "a stroppy little frog". The ITC ruled that the comment constituted a racist term and was in breach of the programme code.

webTitle: Baddiel and Skinner back for ITV

fields.headline: Baddiel and Skinner back for ITV
fields.trailText: ITV has signed a multi-million pound deal with comedians David Baddiel and Frank Skinner for a 12-part series with no script, no format and no subject matter.
fields.body:
ITV has signed a multi-million pound deal with comedians David Baddiel and Frank Skinner for a 12-part series with no script, no format and no subject matter.

The half-hour show, which will launch in the spring, is loosely described as a sequel to the pair's Fantasy Football League, but without the key football element.

ITV's director of programmes David Liddiment has commissioned three series of Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned on the strength of a paper proposal.

There will be no guests, no autocue and no structure for the primetime programme, which is expected to be broad cast after the 9pm watershed. Skinner yesterday summed up the series concept as "two blokes sitting on a sofa, talking to a bunch of strangers about whatever comes up. There is no script, no rehearsal. Honest, it's not a con".

The former flatmates, who have not appeared on television together since their Fantasy World Cup, tried the format at last summer's Edinburgh Festival.

They react to suggestions of topics from the audience - and the only control over the subjects covered is a blackboard on which they mark issues they have discussed, which can't be brought up again.

Skinner said the experiment was successful. "People loved it. But live on TV? Are we out of our minds? Are ITV out of their minds? We'll soon find out."

Baddiel added: "I've noticed that as I get older the thing I like doing less and less is working. For the sake of not working, myself and Frank are prepared to go on live television without writing a single thing. And don't think there'll be any kind of improvisational games either - much too much like hard work."

Both the comedians, who are represented and produced by the comedy group Avalon, have signed high profile deals with broadcasters following the success of their Fantasy Football format.

Baddiel signed a £5.5m deal with Sky to produce a 22-part sitcom last year, and Skinner has transferred his chat show, The Frank Skinner Show to ITV from BBC1 after the corporation walked away from negotiations over a new contract when the price hit £20m.

The fourth series of the show will go out on ITV this autumn.

Announcing the deal at its annual presentation to advertisers yesterday, ITV executives pledged they would increase their share of younger audiences this year.

The channel's chief executive, Richard Eyre, said that it would attract 1% more 16- to 34-year-old viewers, as he lowered ITV's overall audience targets for the year.

Instead of aiming for 40% of the available audience, ITV predicted it would receive 38.5%, allowing for the growth of digital television.

fields.headline: Top 10 health websites
fields.trailText:
healthfinder
US government site. Useful gateway to respectable American health sites. Fun, easy-to-understand layout, and not squeamish about exciting headlines ("Monkeys cloned by splitting embryos").
fields.body:
healthfinder
US government site. Useful gateway to respectable American health sites. Fun, easy-to-understand layout, and not squeamish about exciting headlines ("Monkeys cloned by splitting embryos").

NHS Direct
The NHS site. Steady rather than exciting in the determination to be reliable and because it was put together at speed. But already popular. An updated version is on the way.

National Electronic Library for Health
The library will live here, but hasn't moved in yet. The site is taken up with an abstruse conversation between interested parties as to what it should contain.

Patient UK
Provides a long list of patient groups in the UK and abroad. Also lists telephone helplines and patient information leaflets that can be sent for.

US National Library of Medicine: Medline
Medline, the biggest medical database in the world, was set up by the US National Library of Medicine, and is mostly free. Almost any study published by a reputable medical journal will be found here. Medline Plus is more consumer-friendly at same address.

A Doctor in Your House
Cybersurgery - the new spectator sport for the non-squeamish. Watch an operation online if you can bear it.

Contact a Family
Well-presented support network for rare diseases. The charity holds information on 1000 rare disorders and diseases and will put families in touch with each other.

Cancerhelp UK
Very comprehensive cancer information and links on Birmingham University sites, incorporating much material from CancerBacup.

Public Health Laboratory Service
Get your official statistics on flu, meningitis and any other infectious disease you care to name, at the PHLS website.

CyberDocs
A taste of the future. US-trained physicians offer online consultation for $50 to $75 to anybody (almost) anywhere in the world. One of the few sites where doctors will diagnose and prescribe medicines - but they are bound to proliferate before long.

fields.headline: Virtual healing
fields.standfirst: Anyone with a medical problem can look it up on the net. But how easy is it to find the information you need?  Sarah Boseley reports
fields.trailText: A Pandora's box has been opened and there is no closing the lid now. Medical lore has been let loose. It is no longer the secret preserve of physicians. It is out there for anybody and everybody to possess.
fields.body:
A Pandora's box has been opened and there is no closing the lid now. Medical lore has been let loose. It is no longer the secret preserve of physicians. It is out there for anybody and everybody to possess.

The internet has proved itself the ultimate democratising tool, sweeping away the old medical culture which said that although we own our bodies we are not competent to understand how they go wrong and what options there are for fixing them. Now we have access to the same information, the same published studies and the same clinical trials data that doctors have.

If the internet has filled any need, it is the need to know more about health and medicine. Health websites are proliferating faster than bacteria. These are heady times, but there are potential problems too. There is so much information that it is hard to know where to start and how to find your way around.

And alongside the highly respectable sites are the well-meaning but just plain wrong - such as some of the proponents of vitamins as a cure for cancer - and the really dodgy, who want to flog pills and potions, from herbal remedies to Viagra.

The government has gleefully embraced the cultural shift that the internet represents and hopes to take it further, for a variety of reasons, some of which are to do with encouraging people not to visit doctors if they can look after themselves at home.

Its health website, NHS Direct Online, was launched in early December by Tony Blair under a hot-air balloon adorned with Christmas decorations in a shopping centre in Bootle. Health on the net is for everyone, was the unmistakable message, not just the affluent middle classes with their dual email addresses - at home and at work. NHS Direct Online some time this year will turn up in free kiosks in hospital waiting rooms and supermarkets.

So far, it is scoring more hits than expected. Bob Gann, the man in charge, says they are averaging 100,000 a day. What took them by surprise is that the main interest is not in people working out what disease they might have from checklists of symptoms; those logging in have already been diagnosed by a doctor, and they want to know more about their medical problem.

This quest to know more is what the internet is all about. The National Electronic Health Library (NEHL) - the NHS database of approved trials and studies - will allow patients to find out even more when it finally gets up and running. They can do it now through Medline, the huge US government database, but the NEHL will be British and easily accessible through NHS Direct Online. "The idea of separate information for patients and doctors will become quite redundant really," says Gann.

But there is a big debate going on over the way information is presented by the NEHL. Who is it for? For doctors, certainly, but also for the community midwife who comes across a medical disorder she has never met before; and the mother who has been told her child has a chromosomal defect.

If NEHL is to offer an archive of approved medical texts - kitemarked is the word that has been mentioned - it will become inaccessible to the ordinary man or woman. But others argue that anything more simplistic, produced by lesser mortals than five-star academics, cannot be guaranteed accurate. Any sort of checking system would be enormously time-consuming, expensive and difficult.

It is not just worthy sites such as the NEHL that are troubled by this argument. There is a tension for all website designers between the original free and easy, anti-authoritarian atmosphere of the internet, where all information is the property of everybody, anybody can post their views and censorship is unthinkable; and the desire of many health interest groups to protect the public from sharks and the ignorant.

Look at the chat rooms on health sites for instance. Much of what is posted is banal banter and gossip, just as it is in every other chat room. But there are also people with quite desperate-sounding problems, and there are salesmen pushing "breakthrough" treatments.

Gann says he would like to look into the possibility of running a chat room on his site, but "the problem is that they are unmoderated". It would surely be unthinkable to find bad information on a government website. So the alternative is some form of screening. Patient groups think the same way. But the implicit censorship sticks in the craw of the internet purists. And how much effort are you going to put into checking people's facts before you let them put forward their views?

On the credit side, the internet has been fantastic for those who have been isolated or cut off from information they need, such as families whose children suffer from very rare diseases. In the UK, an organisation called Contact a Family has been up and running for 20 years. Its aim is to bring those isolated families and the doctors and nurses who work with them together to pool their information and support each other. The internet has transformed their lives and their hopes. The charity is now able to link people with a common interest and a real need for information across the world.

"A mum in Norway rang in November," says Harry Marsh, who heads the charity. She had a child with a chromosomal condition called Smiths-Magenis. "There are only five families in the whole of Norway with that condition. I put them in touch with the English group, which is quite sizeable." He says the impact of the internet for Contact a Family has been colossal. "For most of last year, we were getting 3,500 to 4,000 hits a week on the site. In a generous year we used to get 10,000 contacts on paper. We're getting 20 times the interest we got before."

However, he worries about the quality of information people can be given through the net. "Families, particularly where they haven't been given a clear diagnosis, are desperate for information and they are quite vulnerable. Some would say they were quite vulnerable before, when they would leaf through medical encyclopedias. But if you can sit down and access 100 horrible things in an hour, it is a different league." Entries to his organisation's site have to be approved by qualified medical personnel, he says.

There is almost certainly a middle way between the need some have for 100% non-alarmist, accurate information, and the fun free-for-all, disrespectful web others enjoy. There is more and more signposting around. NHS Direct does it, government information sites in Australia, the US and elsewhere do it, and some very respectable patient groups do it too. They all give lists of dependable sites for patients who want serious information about diseases and treatments.

Those who have a more casual, curious or voyeuristic interest in health have plenty of other options. There are hosts of sites which answer your questions about weight loss, healthy lifestyles or sexual health, and offer questionnaires to check your fitness.

The bulletin board for one of them, Onhealth, www.onhealth.com, accessed through the search engine AltaVista, gives a clue to people's priorities. Weight gain tops the list of questions and comments posted - 1,817 at the last count - with sexuality on 787, healthy eating on 495 and stress and anxiety on 403. In the subset of diseases and conditions, 545 were concerned about aches and pains, 323 asked about gastrointestinal problems, and 322 about back pain. A further 656 wanted to discuss pregnancy, and 469 were interested in alternative health.

Serious medical problem or lifestyle anxiety - there is room for all in the end. They key is to follow reliable signposts, or go browsing with a healthy scepticism.

webTitle: 'You still need to look into a patient's eyes'

fields.headline: 'You still need to look into a patient's eyes'
fields.standfirst: How has the internet changed life in the surgery and consulting room?  Bibi van der Zee  talks to four doctors with very different viewpoints
fields.trailText: Dr Paul Miller is one of the partners in a busy Glasgow general practice. He first set up their internet site two-and-a-half years ago.
fields.body:
Dr Paul Miller is one of the partners in a busy Glasgow general practice. He first set up their internet site two-and-a-half years ago.

This area is one of the poorest in the UK, but as more homes get computers we're starting to get a lot more feedback. We're going to have a repeat prescription service on this site, which will hopefully save patients some time, though not us at the moment: the emails will come straight through to me, and I'll pass them on to our prescription clerk. I'd love to get online appointment booking, but we have to think about security.

"Eventually, even registrations will be electronic: obviously you do have to physically examine the person, that will never change, but patients will be able to email us details, and we'll be able to email reminders of smear tests and so on.

"I'm a bit of an IT junky; I had a ZX81 when I was a teenager. When I did the first site, web design was still quite simple; it's certainly more complex these days, but I'm trying not to sell my soul to Microsoft. We're using computers increasingly for every aspect of clinical care. Five years from now I'll be very surprised if I'm still writing my notes by hand."

Doctor Yoosuf Ibrahim has been practising as a GP in west London for 27 years.

A few patients have mentioned things they have read about on the internet, such as the weight-reducing drug Zenical, antioxidants or other new treatments. But I explain to them that the British medical establishment has certain ways of doing things. We are a conservative people, and don't think that everything that comes with the internet is automatically good.

"I'm sure it's useful, but I don't think it could ever be used for diagnosis or prescription. If you're dealing with a patient with kidney disease or diabetes, you need to see them every couple of months: you need to look at their eyes; you need to remind patients to watch their diet - this is the human mind we're dealing with, and if you don't say it to their face, they forget. The internet can come up with some interesting diagnoses, but patients still have to discuss them with us."

Doctor Lotte Newman was president of the Royal College of General Practitioners, and still practises privately part-time.

I have to admit I'm totally ignorant of IT matters. Fortunately, my secretary can work my email. I suppose that generally I feel that the internet is a great facilitator of communication of information, but it would worry me if I thought that instead of talking to patients, one would just stare into a computer.

"The Royal College was recently involved in a research project, and decided to do without a press conference to launch the intermediate results. Instead it launched them on its internet site. I feel it might have been more successful if it had been done in person.

Perhaps I'm a fuddy-duddy about this, but I'm very worried about the dehumanisation of society. I think we're losing human contact and the ability to communicate directly. Maybe if I was younger I would be more enthused."

Dr Tim Peachey is a consultant anaesthetist at the Royal Free Hospital in London, and is a member of MITAG, the Medical Information and Technology Advisory Group.

I have colleagues who have used tele-medicine for consultation, but I don't think it's particularly useful. You actually need two doctors for a diagnosis or exam: you set it up at a GP's office and link up to a specialist. With the amount of time it takes to set up, you're looking at 20 or more minutes: the doctors could see four patients in that time. It may save the patient travelling, but the NHS faces a terrific shortage of resources, so you have to think about bringing the doctor to the patient or vice versa.

"Where the internet is brilliant is for research - it's much faster to call up a couple of pages rather than searching through miles and miles of indexes - and for communication. fields.headline: Outright quackery
fields.standfirst: The net's full of dodgy doctors and conmen. And it's people who've been let down by conventional medicine who are most at risk, says  Oliver Burkeman
fields.trailText: The search for reliable health advice is, famously, second only to pornography as a reason for using the internet. Nobody seriously argues that the net isn't shaping up to be a powerful tool for raising levels of public health, especially since its relative anonymity eliminates much of the embarrassment involved in seeking help. But there's a problem: a significant minority of healthcare sites seem to be operated by characters every bit as unscrupulous as the purveyors of online porn whom they rival in popularity.
fields.body:
The search for reliable health advice is, famously, second only to pornography as a reason for using the internet. Nobody seriously argues that the net isn't shaping up to be a powerful tool for raising levels of public health, especially since its relative anonymity eliminates much of the embarrassment involved in seeking help. But there's a problem: a significant minority of healthcare sites seem to be operated by characters every bit as unscrupulous as the purveyors of online porn whom they rival in popularity.

Type the words "cancer treatment" into any search engine and you'll be presented with a seemingly infinite list of pages - a fair number of which, according to studies of the reliability of internet health advice, won't be all they're cracked up to be. Surveys of every sector of medicine yield similar results: a recent investigation by American gastroenterologists, for example, concluded that one in 10 sites in the field contained treatment information that was "unproven or outright quackery"; a study last year from Ursinus College in Pennsylvania, meanwhile, warned that the quality of mental health advice online was "not very impressive. Many of the sites targeting the 'worried well' [contained] biased, misleading information about specific treatment options without including an objective examination of equally efficacious alternatives." For almost every health problem the situation seems to be the same. "The problem [of unreliable information] is increasing because it's getting more and more easy to purchase a domain name and set up a site," says Celia Boyer, of the Health on the Net Foundation, a Geneva-based organisation established to monitor and improve the quality of medical information on the net. "The fact that the internet is so much better-known than it was two or three years ago makes the problem of quality urgent."

In offering a platform to every variety of mountebank and snake-oil salesman the web may not be fundamentally different to junk mail, or classified advertisements in lifestyle magazines - but the scale, of course, is massive, and the relative newness of the medium means it's still easier to fool more of the people more of the time. A private surgery in a prestigious city-centre requires plenty of capital; a website that smacks of long-established trustworthiness, on the other hand, need only have required a beginner's guide to web design and a few days' work. And there are plenty of them, hawking vitamin supplements, Viagra, human growth hormone, beef tallow to treat arthritis, fish cartilage for cancer, and much more.

It isn't just a matter of small-scale charlatans out for a fast buck. Former US surgeon-general C Everett Koop - the name behind DrKoop.com, a leading health site - had his knuckles rapped by the American Medical Association last year for failing to disclose that he was taking a cut from products sold on the site. Malicious intent isn't necessarily required, either: frequently, information is just old, even if it was originally posted on the web out of nothing but a desire to help.

One area in which the web offers some of the greatest potential benefits - one-to-one online consultations - is also one of the most hazard-prone. Different countries require different levels of qualification before somebody can call themselves a doctor: if you're paying around £50 for a consultation over the web there will not necessarily be a straightforward way to tell that your doctor has a decade's medical training rather than a few weeks' experience in colonic irrigation. At the moment, according to the Health on the Net Foundation, they're usually best avoided; if you must consult online, research your doctor first - for example by searching the public access Medline database to find out if they have recently had any articles published in reputable medical journals.

If you already know what treatments you need, there are plenty of drugs suppliers eager to relieve you of your money. Some, like Drugstore.com, are recognised as reputable and law-abiding, but in the UK it's perfectly possible, though legally questionable, to order prescription drugs such as Viagra from overseas firms charging around £60 for a packet of 10 50mg tablets. Most require an online consultation, but in many cases it's a formality; a 1999 study of 46 such pharmacy sites by doctors at the University of Pennsylvania failed to turn up a single one who refused to prescribe and supply. Nine didn't even require a consultation.

But those most vulnerable to quackery online are those for whom conventional medicine has already failed. "The most fragile people are those with chronic illnesses, leukemia, cancer - they've already tried all other kinds of medicine already, and now they'll try anything else," says Celia Boyer.

Nowhere do claims of miracle cures abound more plentifully than in cancer treatment: magnets, shark cartilage and derivative of absinthe are among the unproven "remedies" offered by numerous sites. Last year, having decided that deceptive health claims on the net had reached "epidemic" proportions, the US Federal Trade Commission launched Operation Cure.All, and charged three companies - Body Systems Technology, Magnetic Therapeutic Technologies and Pain Stops Here! Inc - with making unsubstantiable claims for cancer treatments.

There are probably many more. "We wish we would get more complaints," said Richard Cleland, a senior attorney with the FTC. "If you're suffering from cancer, you may have other concerns than filing a complaint."

Conscious of the dangers of unreliable products - but also aware of the hugely lucrative commercial advantages of making the web a trustworthy place to find healthcare advice - governments worldwide are formulating guidelines for quality control. Last year the US federal health department set up Healthfinder, a website devoted to helping users navigate medical sites; the UK followed suit with Health In Focus, backed by leading health charities and the Patients Association to sift the wheat from the chaff. Meanwhile, the Health on the Net Foundation is campaigning for the adoption of site guidelines to ensure that information is accurate, up-to-date and honestly presented.

In the meantime, the foundation and others offer several rules of thumb for sorting reliable information from commercially motivated sales pitches: watch out for overzealous testimonials from "satisfied customers" and check that sites contain postal addresses or telephone numbers as well as email contact details; be suspicious of products that purport to be available from one source only; use "portal" sites - such as Healthscout.com as a starting point, since they do some filtering for you. And above all: if a remedy sounds too good to be true, it almost certainly is.

fields.headline: No 10 seizes on Ken gaffe
fields.trailText:
Ken Livingstone last night appeared to have struck a damaging blow to his campaign to become
   mayor of London when he publicly allied himself with anarchist rioters in the city of London and
   protesters at last year's Seattle trade conference.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone last night appeared to have struck a damaging blow to his campaign to become mayor of London when he publicly allied himself with anarchist rioters in the city of London and protesters at last year's Seattle trade conference.

In an interview with The Face magazine, the Brent East MP declared he had always supported "direct action".

And, in an example of dry Livingstone humour which may come back to haunt him, the leftwing MP pledged that, following the Seattle conference, he would never invite the World Trade Organisation to London "unless we get vast stocks in so we can throw stuff at them in an organised way".

Downing Street, dreading the increasingly plausible prospect of Mr Livingstone as Labour mayoral candidate, seized on the comments as evidence of the former GLC leader's unfitness to run London. Sources close to Tony Blair described it as "the sort of gesture politics the prime minister has made it absolutely clear he does not want to see the Labour party go back to". Mr Livingstone would now have to explain himself, the sources added.

In the interview Mr Livingstone said: "I've always been in favour of direct action. One of my fondest memories was chasing the inspector of the Archway Road inquiry out on to the roof at Central Hall."

Downing Street's approved candidate, Frank Dobson, said last night: "These comments are quite disgraceful from anyone seeking to be mayor of London with responsibility for the police."

webTitle: Livingstone attempts to save face after 'direct action' gaffe

fields.headline: Livingstone attempts to save face after 'direct action' gaffe
fields.trailText: London mayoral hopeful Ken Livingstone today blamed "shabby journalism" for the furore surrounding remarks he made in an interview with The Face about last summer's riots in the City of London.
fields.body:
London mayoral hopeful Ken Livingstone today blamed "shabby journalism" for the furore surrounding remarks he made in an interview with The Face about last summer's riots in the City of London.

He insisted his comments about direct action had been taken out of context, which was a light-hearted interview in the style magazine where he discussed topics ranging from his relationship with Blur's Damon Albarn to Steven Norris's sex life.

In the interview, Mr Livingstone said he supported "direct action" and joked that he would have put the World Trade Organisation - whose meeting in Seattle last year was marred by violent demonstrations - in "vast stocks" so people could throw things at its officials in an organised way.

"It's really ridiculous for papers to latch on to this - nowhere do I support violence in this," Mr Livingstone insisted today. "I simply say that if I was mayor of London I wouldn't invite the World Trade Organisation to come."

It would be a "bad deal because you'd undoubtedly have all the violence you saw in Seattle repeated here with a huge policing bill," he added.

"There's a difference between violence and direct action - direct action is usually going on a demonstration, direct action is usually most effective when it's humorous and pokes fun at the rich and powerful."

"I have never been in favour of any violence," Mr Livingstone said. "I've been on the record in so many interviews and articles over the last 30 years - you won't find a single time when I've ever supported violence, whether it was Irish terrorism or whether it's a thug that whacks an old lady over the head."

Former health secretary Frank Dobson, Tony Blair's prefered choice to be Labour's mayoral candidate, said: "These comments are quite disgraceful from anyone seeking to be mayor of London, with responsibility for the police."

"Over the last few weeks, the mask has been slipping and the true Ken Livingstone has been emerging," he added. "This interview shows why Ken Livingstone would be the wrong person to be mayor, coming as it does after his plans for an extremist kitchen cabinet and new taxes have been exposed."

Tory candidate Steve Norris, launching his campaign yesterday, said Mr Livingstone's remarks were a "disgrace" and demolished his "cuddly Ken" image.

"The idea that the mayor would approve of the criminal damage that was done in the city just a few months ago is outrageous."

 Ram Gidoomal, a millionaire Asian businessman and philanthropist who came to Britain as a penniless refugee, will formally announce tomorrow that he will be joining the battle for the mayor of London, fighting as a Christian Democrat.

Mr Gidoomal, 49, said today: "As I watched events unfold and the shenanigans around the mainstream political parties over the mayoralty issue, I felt they had failed London and Londoners, which is a tragedy and a shame. London is crying out for a candidate independent of the main parties."

webTitle: New laws to limit parents' right to smack

fields.headline: New laws to limit parents' right to smack
fields.standfirst: More about Children are Unbeatable!
fields.trailText: The government will today publish proposals to ban parents from smacking their children on the head or face, or from using belts or other implements to inflict physical punishment.
fields.body:
The government will today publish proposals to ban parents from smacking their children on the head or face, or from using belts or other implements to inflict physical punishment.

A consultation document, Protecting Children; Supporting Parents, will stop short of proposing a ban on smacking, but will recommend handing courts new powers to punish parents for hitting children.

Under the proposals, courts will be asked to decide what constitutes "reasonable chastisement". They will be told to take four criteria into account, including whether implements - such as a slipper, cane, stick or belt - were used to hit the child. Courts will have to consider the age and sex of the child, the duration of the punishment and where on the body the child was hit.

Options in the document include banning all hitting of a child around the head and the use of implements.

A further option will be to remove the defence of reasonable chastisement in incidents which cause bruising or black eyes. The thrust of the document will be geared towards the courts, reflecting government fears of accusations of a nanny state seeking to march into parents' living rooms.

A government source said last night: "There is no option under consideration of making smacking illegal - parents want to see the law tightened to protect children but they don't want guidance on the minutiae of disciplining children. We have tried to draw a careful line between two extremes."

A spokeswoman at the department of health said: "The whole document looks at where the child should be hit, questions whether or not a child should be hit with a particular implement and looks at the whole concept of 'reasonable chastisement' - how to define this and what constitutes 'excessive force'.

"There's no age limit mentioned anywhere at all."

The plans, to be unveiled today by John Hutton, health minister, are the result of a 16-month consultation prompted by a European court of human rights ruling that British law on corporal punishment in the home failed to protect the rights of children.

The finding, based on the case of a nine-year-old boy caned with a three-foot pole by his stepfather, contradicted a law, dating from 1860, which allows parents to hit children if they claim they are practising "reasonable chastisement". Juries frequently acquit parents who belt and cane their children: in the case of the nine-year-old, the stepfather was found not guilty of assault causing actual bodily harm.

After the judgment, in September 1998, the government was obliged to alter the law on the right to beat one's children. But the then health minister, Paul Boateng, was adamant that there would be no ban on smacking, though eight other EU countries have such bans. "This government believes in parental discipline. Smacking has a place within that and our law will not change in order to outlaw it," he said.

Children's societies and anti-smacking campaigners are distressed that he has stuck by his pledge without even moot ing a total ban as an option.

"Of course, these proposals are fantastic for children who are caned on their bottoms because this will prevent this, or for children who are beaten with hands elsewhere," said Rachel Hodgkin, spokeswoman for the Children are Unbeatable campaign, spearheaded by Barnardo's, the National Children's Bureau, the NSPCC, Save the Children, and the group Epoch (End Physical Punishment of Children).

"But it's also disturbing that these proposals still give out the message that hitting a child is OK: what do children learn from that?"

The charities also pointed to statistics revealing that at least one child dies in Britain every week aftert being assaulted by an adult. In Sweden, where corporal punishment has been illegal for more than 20 years, four children have died from being beaten in this period.

But the shadow health secretary, Dr Liam Fox, attacked "Labour's obsessive nannying". "Smacking children to teach them the difference between right and wrong is often a necessary, if painful, task," he said.

The finding, based on the case of a nine-year-old boy caned with a three-foot pole by his stepfather, contradicted a law, dating from 1860, which allows parents to hit children if they claim they are practising "reasonable chastisement". Juries frequently acquit parents who belt and cane their children: in the case of the nine-year-old, the stepfather was found not guilty of assault causing actual bodily harm. After the judgment, in September 1998, the government was obliged to alter the law on the right to beat one's children. But the then health minister, Paul Boateng, was adamant that there would be no ban on smacking, though eight other EU countries have such bans. "This government believes in parental discipline. Smacking has a place within that and our law will not change in order to outlaw it," he said. Children's societies and anti-smacking campaigners are distressed that he has stuck by his pledge without even moot ing a total ban as an option. "Of course, these proposals are fantastic for children who are caned on their bottoms because this will prevent this, or for children who are beaten with hands elsewhere," said Rachel Hodgkin, spokeswoman for the Children are Unbeatable campaign, spearheaded by Barnardo's, the National Children's Bureau, the NSPCC, Save the Children, and the group Epoch (End Physical Punishment of Children). "But it's also disturbing that these proposals still give out the message that hitting a child is OK: what do children learn from that?" The charities also pointed to statistics revealing that at least one child dies in Britain every week aftert being assaulted by an adult. In Sweden, where corporal punishment has been illegal for more than 20 years, four children have died from being beaten in this period. But the shadow health secretary, Dr Liam Fox, attacked "Labour's obsessive nannying". "Smacking children to teach them the difference between right and wrong is often a necessary, if painful, task," he said.

fields.headline: The people's choice?
fields.standfirst:
David McKie on why Labour voters may want to choose Steven Norris over Ken Livingstone to be London's new mayor
Plus: Engagements galore
fields.trailText: The sage old advice "begin as you mean to go on" has rarely been more meticulously observed than by the Labour party leadership in its handling of the London mayoralty.
fields.body:
The sage old advice "begin as you mean to go on" has rarely been more meticulously observed than by the Labour party leadership in its handling of the London mayoralty.

In devising the office, they apparently quite forgot that Ken Livingstone might wish to apply for it. Then having seen him approaching, they fell into a dither, wondering who they might now produce who could head him off.

For a while it was Glenda Jackson. Then Glenda wasn't up to it after all, so it had to be Nick Raynsford. Or could it be Tony Banks? No, it couldn't be Tony Banks, too unpredictable. It would have to be Nick Raynsford; who duly put himself forward. But then it couldn't be Raynsford either. Not a big enough figure. It would have to be Frank Dobson. True, he had been saying for months that he wasn't interested, but now he would have to be interested.

Now, yet another shift is reported. It looks rather unlikely to be Frank after all, since all the signs suggest that, with the mark of Downing Street upon him, he cannot recruit enough support to push ahead of Ken for the Labour nomination. So maybe it's got to be Ken after all; he will simply have to be lived with.

Meanwhile the Tories, after that unfortunate business with Lord Archer, seem at last to have done something right. They have ended up with the candidate they should have espoused in the first place - Steven Norris. The voters, on the whole, seem more forgiving of men with multiple mistresses than would once have been the case.

There is also a benefit much less discussed. Norris is the sort of Tory - open-minded, a plainly unideological transport minister, a man who, as a backbencher, famously stood up to the party whips in defence of freedom of information - who might even conjure a vote or two out of Labour supporters with working memories.

Some Labour supporters who watched Livingstone at work as leader of the GLC and as a prime mover in the left excesses which almost finished the party in the early 80s will be casting about for someone other than him to vote for in May. Nowadays he likes to present himself as a cuddly figure, the people's friend.

That is not the Ken of the early 80s. Austin Mitchell's history of that period, Four Years in the Death of the Labour Party, begins one of its chapters with a classic line from Livingstone then: "We must not compromise with the electorate." His commendably open support in an interview with the Face magazine for anti-capitalist riots in the City is a nostalgic aftertaste of those days.

And to find him being defended in the Guardian today by his former deputy John McDonnell, whose rantings at Labour conference fringe meetings made even Livingstone sound like Paddington Bear, brings it all back even more powerfully.

There must be Labour supporters who don't want a mayor as heavily backed by Downing Street as Frank Dobson, who accept that Glenda now has no chance, but who judge that Ken has too great a streak of mischief and malevolence to do the job the capital needs.

They may vote Green, as so many disaffected Labour voters did in the Euro-elections, or they may be won round to the so far rather anonymous Liberal, Susan Kramer. But if the welfare of London is the test they are setting themselves, then they can't afford to rule out Steven Norris.

Related documentaries
The London mayor: special report
Tories in opposition: special report

Engagements galore

Engagements, it seems, are booming. It's partly the thrill of what people wrongly believe is a new millennium, and partly perhaps the convention (for those who still observe these conventions, a greatly diminished band) that women may propose when it's a leap year.

Fans of marriage will no doubt be thrilled. But they need to withhold their enthusiasm for a while, until they are able to judge how long the subsequent marriages last. It may be this wave of engagements is just a fashion, whose main outcome will be a consonant increase in the rate of divorce in a few years' time.

In a shop-around society, we all get used to taking goods back if we find we don't like them. Why should marriage, increasing numbers of people seem to be asking, be any different?

fields.headline: Children are unbeatable!
fields.standfirst:
Individuals who support the alliance

An alliance of organisations and individuals seeking legal reform to give children the same protection under the law on assault as adults and promoting positive, non-violent discipline. This is a list of organisations that have agreed to join the alliance:
fields.trailText: Alliance aims and statement
fields.body:
Alliance aims and statement

The organisations listed below welcome the Government's intention to clarify the law on parental discipline. The traditional defence of "reasonable chastisement" works against the aims which we and the Government of a modern Britain share: the encouragement of positive parental discipline in all families, and assurance of effective child protection in the few cases where it is needed.

We believe it is both wrong and impracticable to seek to define acceptable forms of corporal punishment of children. Such an exercise is unjust. Hitting children is a lesson in bad behaviour.

Removing the defence of "reasonable chastisement" and thus giving children in their homes and in all other settings equal protection under the law on assault is the only just, moral and safe way to clarify the law. While technically this would criminalise any assault of a child, trivial assaults, like trivial assaults between adults, would not be prosecuted. There already exist adequate means to prevent unwarranted or unhelpful prosecutions. It would on the other hand ease prosecution in serious cases. It would eliminate the current dangerous confusion over what is acceptable and provide a clear basis for child protection.

There is ample evidence from other countries to show that full legal reform, coupled with the promotion of effective means of positive discipline, works rapidly to reduce reliance on corporal punishment and reduces the need for prosecutions and other formal interventions in families. Using positive forms of discipline reduces stress and improves relationships between children, their parents and other carers.

webTitle: Kasprowicz stars as Queensland go top

fields.headline: Kasprowicz stars as Queensland go top
fields.trailText: Australia
fields.body:
Australia

Michael Kasprowicz had match figures of 10-88 as Queensland thrashed Tasmania at the Allan Border Field in Brisbane, to move ahead of Victoria and claim the outright lead in the Pura Milk Cup. Kasprowicz followed up 5-56 in the first innings with figures of 24-11-32-5 as Tasmania collapsed twice. In between, Queensland debutant Clinton Perren, 24, a product of the Australian Cricket Academy, struck 153.

Tasmania130 and 155 (Michael Di Venuto 50) Queensland 365 (Stuart Law 53) Queensland won by an innings and 80 runs

Justin Langer was in the runs as Western Australia won a nail-biting clash against South Australia at Perth by three wickets. Langer began by hitting 120 in the first innings, adding 227 for the second wicket with opener Michael Hussey, who carried his bat for 172. Then, after Ben Johnson had made 104 for SA, Langer scored 77 as WA chased 256 for victory. WA were in trouble at 206 for 7, but Matt Nicholson held his nerve to make 30*.

South Australia330 and 317 (Greg Blewett 76) Western Australia 392 and 256 for 7 Western Australia won by 3 wickets

Langer shone again with 146 off 148 balls in the Mercantile Mutual Cup game with South Australia at the WACA, but WA still lost by 33 runs to miss the chance to go top. Chasing a massive 303 to win, WA reached 151 for 3 in the 30th over, but fell away as no other batsman passed 30.

Tasmania130 and 155 (Michael Di Venuto 50) Queensland 365 (Stuart Law 53) Queensland won by an innings and 80 runs

New South Wales, bottom of the Pura Milk Cup, took advantage of WA's slip-up and stole first place with an easy win against whipping-boys Canberra.

New South Wales252 for 9 in 47 overs Canberra 136 New South Wales won by 116 runs

South Africa

West Indian Vasbert Drakes continued his fine form for Boland, but his side still went down to an eight-wicket defeat against Border at Paarl. Drakes began with 52 as he helped Boland recover from 32 for 7 to 110 all out, and then claimed 5-26 to make Boland struggle themselves. But seamer Bradley Parker (4-19) ensured that Border collapsed a second time, and Boland made no mistake in the fourth innings.

Border110 (Henry Williams 4-20) and 105 Boland 139 and 79 for 2 Boland won by 8 wickets

A partnership of 218 for the first wicket between Adam Bacher (128), on the fringes of the Test squad, and Sven Koenig (104) set up Gauteng's win over Western Province at Cape Town. Hylton Ackerman, who has won four Test caps himself, replied with 119, but received little support. And when Gauteng closed their second innings on 164 for 6, they left WP needing 334 for victory. It proved too much, despite a fighting 57* from Alan Dawson.

Gauteng 411 for 6 decl. and 164 for 6 decl. Western Province 240 and 242 Gauteng won by 93 runs

Gerry Liebenberg, who couldn't get a run opening the innings against England in 1998, hit 67 from No.4 as Free State overcame Eastern Province at Port Elizabeth. FS's first innings of 296 also contained 62 from No.9 Herman Bakkes. Dave Callaghan responded with 100*, but 5-58 from quick bowler Dewald Pretorius kept EP in check. They were eventually set 296 to win, but folded to 26 for 5, and never recovered.

Free State296 and 226 for 6 decl. Eastern Province 227 for 8 decl. and 110 (Mark Rushmere 52*) Free State won by 185 runs

The game between KwaZulu-Natal and Northerns at Durban went the same way as the fifth Test in Centurion and was ruined by the weather.

Northerns139 for 2 v KwaZulu-Natal Match drawn

Kenny Benjamin had figures of 9-1-17-3 as Gauteng's strong seam attack skittled North West for 76 in the one-day Standard Bank Cup. Only two men made double-figures. Gauteng knocked off the runs in 12.5 overs in a match that lasted just 39.4 overs in all.

North West 76 in 26.5 overs Gauteng 77 for 1 in 12.5 overs Gauteng won by 9 wickets

Morne van Wyk hit 69 and Boeta Dippenaar, who played two Tests against Zimbabwe in October and November, scored 61 to usher Free State to a seven-wicket victory over Griqualand West at Kimberley. Earlier, Griquas had subsided from 130 for 1 after 31.2 overs to 184 for 7 in 45, as Dewald Pretorius finished with 4-39.

Griqualand West 184 for 7 in 45 overs (John Arthur 63) Free State 188 for 3 in 43.5 overs Free State won by 7 wickets

The game between Border and Easterns at East London was abandoned.

West Indies

Forgotten Test opener Philo Wallace made 117 for Barbados against Guyana in the first round of matches in the first-class Busta Cup, but Guyana held on for the draw with two second-innings wickets remaining.

Barbados 272 (Hendy Bryan 76*) and 252 for 6 decl. Guyana 198 (Marshall 6-51) and 206 for 8 Match drawn

Another forgotten Test opener, Stuart Williams, struck 84 in the Leeward Islands' rain-ruined draw with Trinidad and Tobago at the Wilson Recreation Ground, as T&T's Mukesh Persad took 5-63.

Trinidad and Tobago 114 Leeward Islands 263 Match drawn

And Laurie Williams, of Jamaica, who has made six ODI appearances for West Indies, hit 135 in the draw with the Windward Islands at St Vincent. Junior Murray, yet another Test discard, replied with 55, before Chris Gayle made 86* to set up a Jamaican declaration. The Windwards never attempted to chase 271 in 57 overs.

Jamaica 280 and 143 for 5 decl. Windward Islands 153 and 106 for 1 Match drawn

India

Legspinner Mandar Sane claimed 11-146 in Mumbai's draw with Gujarat at Ahmedabad in the Western Zone of the Duleep Trophy; it was enough for Mumbai to qualify for the next stage. Sane claimed 7-83 in the first innings, and then 4-63 as Gujarat, following on, clung on at the close. Earlier, Mumbai's total of 501 for 7 centred on a third-wicket partnership of 286 between Abhijit Kale (219) and Shantanu Sugwekar (137).

Mumbai 501 for 7 decl. Gujarat 309 and 194 for 8 Match drawn

Prakash Bhatt hit 158 for Saurashtra, but Baroda's Connor Williams replied with 237* as the game at Rajkot ended in a draw. It meant both sides progressed to the Super League stage.

Saurashtra 437 and 127 for 4 Baroda 487 Match drawn

Orissa crushed Tripura thanks to 193 from Rashmi Parida. Legspinner Jagannath Das then took 5-31 as Tripura followed on. Orissa qualified from the Eastern Zone.

Orissa 454 for 8 decl. Tripura172 and 191 Orissa won by an innings and 192 runs

Avinash Kumar took 11-117 to help Bihar beat Assam and take them into the next stage as well. Set 163 to win, Assam crumbled to 163 as Kumar took 6-43 to go with his first-innings 4-74.

Bihar 258 and 343 Assam 247 and 163 Bihar won by 191 runs

New Zealand

Scott Styris, who appeared for New Zealand in the recent one-day series against West Indies as a bowler, starred with the bat as Northern Districts beat Otago in the latest round of matches in the limited-overs Shell Cup. Styris hit 123 in 128 balls and then took 2-28 as ND triumphed by 23 runs. He had earlier made 64 as ND were thrashed by Auckland, who went top, Barnes making 107*.

Matthew Bell, who toured England last summer, set up a 12-run win for Wellington over Canterbury with 100*. Craig McMillan made 52 in vain as Canterbury stuttered to 205. But they recovered with a four-wicket win over bottom-placed Central Districts, as Stephen Fleming guided them home with 79*. Mathew Sinclair, a double-centurion on Test debut against West Indies, made 93 for CD. He had also scored 59 in an earlier defeat by Otago.

Otago 227 for 7 in 50 overs (SR Mather 74) Central Districts 188 in 47 overs (Aaron Gale 4-35) Otago won by 39 runs

Northern Districts 192 for 7 in 48.4 overs (Grant Bradburn 51, Chris Drum 4-27) Auckland 195 for 2 in 44.2 overs Auckland won by 8 wickets

Wellington 217 for 7 in 50 overs Canterbury 205 in 49.3 overs Wellington won by 12 runs

Central Districts 190 in 49.1 overs Canterbury 191 for 6 in 47.5 overs Canterbury won by 4 wickets

Northern Districts 222 for 8 in 50 overs Otago 199 in 48.4 overs ND won by 23 runs

Wellington 150 in 45.5 overs Auckland 156 for 4 in 35 overs Auckland won by 6 wickets

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: Attitude with a difference
fields.standfirst: She learnt to play it tough with the boys, but wants to make it with England's women. Tanya Aldred on Laura Harper, the 15-year-old off spinner who's not afraid to speak her mind
fields.trailText: When England's women fly out to Australia this Friday, they will be leaving behind the most naturally talented female cricketer in the country. The most talented and also the most difficult. Another tale of English cowardice and fear of the extraordinary? For once, no. Laura Harper,16, has been left behind not for any sinister reason, but because she has to go to school and work for her GCSE exams in June.
fields.body:
When England's women fly out to Australia this Friday, they will be leaving behind the most naturally talented female cricketer in the country. The most talented and also the most difficult. Another tale of English cowardice and fear of the extraordinary? For once, no. Laura Harper,16, has been left behind not for any sinister reason, but because she has to go to school and work for her GCSE exams in June.

Harper made the headlines last summer when she was selected for the boys' West of England side (to play in trials for England U-15s), only to turn down the opportunity because the dates clashed with the women's County Championship in Cambridge.

When the West of England squad was first announced, selectors had to deal with complaints from disgruntled parents who thought that Harper had been picked ahead of their sons for publicity reasons. Sadly for the male spinners of the West, the only criterion used was ability - and she was the best. An outstanding sportswoman, who also plays badminton and netball for her county (Cornwall), Harper, an off spinner, turns the ball more than any other woman Paul Farbrace (England Women's coach) has ever seen. Kevin Shine, of Somerset, has said that had she been a boy he would have recommended her for the Somerset Academy.

Despite enjoying the challenge and pressure of male cricket, Harper has decided that her future lies with the women (though she still hopes to play for West of England U-16 boys this year and, eventually, for a minor county). But the years spent in boys' cricket have had an effect, not just on her ability but also her attitude. Harper plays cricket to win, she is determined, single-minded and not one to hold her tongue. She has intense ambition and believes, knows, that she will play for England. Oh, and she isn't shy about telling other players quite how they rate in comparison.

In the relatively sedate, comfortable world of women's cricket, this has put a few noses out of joint - especially those of the senior management. Other players have been lauded at such a young age - Charlotte Edwards made her England debut when only 16. But Edwards is a quieter and shyer character, who tended to appeal to the maternal instinct rather than the throttling one.

The road to male England mediocrity is paved with the stunted careers of so-called difficult characters: Chris Adams, Andy Caddick, Mark Ramprakash, even Nasser Hussain. Paul Farbrace is determined that Harper will not suffer a similar fate. He sees her attitude not as a problem, but as something that should be nurtured. It is the sort of tough, ultra-competitive outlook not encouraged by the women's county game, which he describes as "diabolical".

"The softness of our domestic competition breeds mediocrity and means that players find the jump to international cricket massive. It is very different in Australia." So we have got equality in one area, then.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Baltimore secures $150m buy
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Baltimore Technologies, the internet security firm which was one of last year's best performers on the stock market, made its first acquisition in the United States yesterday with the $150m (£92m) purchase of GTE CyberTrust.
fields.body:
Baltimore Technologies, the internet security firm which was one of last year's best performers on the stock market, made its first acquisition in the United States yesterday with the $150m (£92m) purchase of GTE CyberTrust.

The company's share price in London - which rose by more than 1,000% last year - gained another 20% yesterday to close at £67.50.

The Dublin-based company entered the FTSE 250 towards the end of last year and is now worth £2.7bn.

The e-security industry is expected to grow exponentially over the coming years as companies become increasingly concerned about online confidentiality. Large corporations want much more sophisticated security systems which demand more than simple passwords to accept users.

Paddy Holahan, marketing director for Baltimore, said the all-share acquisition of CyberTrust gave the company the necessary scale to compete in the US market. "As the deals got larger and larger we needed scale in the US to take on new projects," he said.

CyberTrust's clients include American Express, Mastercard and Deutsche Telekom.

Baltimore - which is also listed on Nasdaq - made a loss of $39.2m in the first nine months of last year on turnover of $25.6m, compared with a loss of $33m on revenues of $15m for CyberTrust.

fields.headline: Affair inspires winning poetry
fields.trailText:
How do you think I feel

when you make me talk to you

and won't let me stop

till the words turn into a moan?

Do you think I mind

when you put your hand over my mouth

and tell me not to move

so you can 'hear' it happening?
fields.body:
How do you think I feel

when you make me talk to you

and won't let me stop

till the words turn into a moan?

Do you think I mind

when you put your hand over my mouth

and tell me not to move

so you can 'hear' it happening?

And how do you think I like it

when you tell me what to do

and your mouth opens

and you look straight through me?

Do you think I mind

when the blank expression comes

and you set off alone

down the hall of collapsing columns?

- Rhetorical Questions by Hugo Williams

Hugo Williams, the Peter Pan of British poetry, last night won its most heavyweight prize with a revelatory book about an extra-marital affair.

Billy's Rain follows his unhappy five-year fling with an unnamed younger woman and is full of the minor joys and humiliations of phone sex, snatched sex, and idle daydreams of coupling over "the arm of that chair". It also contains what one critic called "as fine a description of female orgasm as a man can". After reading the collection, his wife, a French performance artist, famously laughed and quipped, "Five years' work then?"

Williams, 57, a handsome Old Etonian whose effortless line in self-deprecation is one of the reasons he has been so underrated, said he was a "little woozy" at winning the £5,000 TS Eliot Award "after all these years".

webTitle: Straw dodges MPs' rotten eggs over Pinochet

fields.headline: Straw dodges MPs' rotten eggs over Pinochet
fields.standfirst:
Life in parliament: special report
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Though he was virulently anti-Pinochet while a young man, to the extent that over the past week he must have been sorely tempted to pelt himself with rotten eggs, you have to remember that Jack Straw is basically a Goody-Two-Shoes. He has as much revolutionary fervour as a plaster flamingo.
fields.body:
Though he was virulently anti-Pinochet while a young man, to the extent that over the past week he must have been sorely tempted to pelt himself with rotten eggs, you have to remember that Jack Straw is basically a Goody-Two-Shoes. He has as much revolutionary fervour as a plaster flamingo.

At the time of life when Mo Mowlam was toking merrily away, he, as a students' union official, was busy campaigning against the use of pot at Leeds university.

And no doubt picketing Rolling Stones concerts, shouting "Druggies, druggies, druggies! Out, out out!" while holding up placards which read: "We want Cliff! And the Shads waving their right feet in unison, because they know how to have fun in a clean, manly way!"

So the last seven days must have been difficult for him. He not only plans to send home to his family a man who gave orders for his political opponents to have their bellies slit open before being thrown from planes, but felt obliged to admit into this country a rapist who treats people's ears like crisps.

His inner turmoil must have been wondrous to see, rather like those old-fashioned television ads that showed stomach acid churning round inside its victim like a laundrette.

But the curious way the Commons does its business - questions have to be tabled two weeks in advance - meant that there was nothing about either General Pinochet or Mike Tyson on the order paper. And the order paper is like holy writ, without the loopholes.

So we had the bizarre sight of the home secretary using the monthly grilling by his colleagues and opponents as an hour's relaxation, away from the pressures of office and public opinion.

There were questions on CCTV, on police radios, on prisons and wheelclamping, but nothing at all about Messrs Pinochet or Tyson.

Paul Boateng, the prisons minister, fought Ann Widdecombe to a standstill on the topic of overcrowding. (She was very worried that too many convicts were crammed into cells and that the practice of slopping-out had returned. You have to remember that Miss Widdecombe is actually more liberal than the present home office. Her slogan: "Prison should not be a holiday camp. It should be much nicer than that!")

Mr Boateng accused her of "casting strictures", whatever that means. He clearly did not know the answer to any of her questions, so instead he accused the Tories of "getting aerated", and, once again, of "casting strictures". (This sounds like a medieval punishment: prisoners would be hung, drawn and have their strictures cast.)

We moved on to police radios and their cost. One of Miss Widdecombe's understrappers, John Greenway, made a desperate attempt to drag the subject round to boxing.

"Unless the home secretary punches his weight more effectively with the chancellor, he'll be on the canvas and counted out." Mr Straw replied vaguely that he thought that was a ropey question.

Mr Greenway could not try any harder, because the Speaker would have thrown his strictures to the circling crows.

We moved on to CCTV. David Ruffley wanted to know why they didn't have closed-circuit cameras in Stowmarket. Mr Ruffley is not popular with Labour members, and the minister, Charles Clarke, gave him a flip answer.

"I go through Stowmarket by train many times on my way to London from Norwich, and as I flash past..."

"You could be arrested," a Tory shouted at him.

"As I flash past, I shall try to glean what I can from the town, and decide what its crime needs are," continued Mr Clarke, rather rudely.

At least we now know what CCTV stands for: "Charles Clarke's Todger Visible".

webTitle: My life on the net: Alan McGee

fields.headline: My life on the net: Alan McGee
fields.trailText:
Football365
I love this site. It updates me on all the latest football information. I know the people behind it; I've known Danny Kelly for 15 years. When they floated it, they cited an article I'd written about how the internet was going to revolutionise the music business. They used that article to help articulate the Football 365 philosophy. The site represents what I love about the web - the medium's speciality is information-flow, and this site has really current news about what's happening in football.
fields.body:
Football365
I love this site. It updates me on all the latest football information. I know the people behind it; I've known Danny Kelly for 15 years. When they floated it, they cited an article I'd written about how the internet was going to revolutionise the music business. They used that article to help articulate the Football 365 philosophy. The site represents what I love about the web - the medium's speciality is information-flow, and this site has really current news about what's happening in football.

Clickmusic
I own a percentage of this site. Every five minutes, music news is updated on it from around the world. They trawl through all the music sites, like nme.com or Rolling Stone and at least 15 different music places, and post up the news instantly. It's a brilliant way for me to find out what all my protegés are up to.

april skies - an unofficial Jesus and Mary Chain site
The Jesus and Mary Chain are the first band I managed, and I love to keep up with its ex-members and to see what people are saying - there's a chat forum that keeps me entertained. It's run by Jesus and Mary Chain fanatics, and there are a group of about 50 who're always there. I've got a link to this site from my own "McGee's List" on the Creation site, which I'm proud of, too, because I set it up against the prevailing anti-technology tide at the company a couple of years ago. It was recently voted Britain's second-best music site.

www.malcolm4mayor.com
We're designing it this weekend. Malcolm McLaren is the only true independent candidate in the London mayoral election. We don't believe that the mayor should have any political allegiance. The site will be useful for anyone who wants to follow our campaign - there'll be newspaper articles up there, and bulletins about what Malcolm's up to and where he is at any given time.

 Alan McGee leaves his job as head of Creation records in June.

webTitle: Football is not a matter of life and death

fields.headline: Football is not a matter of life and death
fields.standfirst: it's less important than that, says WSC.
fields.trailText: It's less important than that.
fields.body:
"Football's only a game, but it's life and death to me." So says Gianluca Vialli, according to the latest T-shirts in fashion around Stamford Bridge. It makes a change from Bill Shankly at least, but the sentiment hardly suggests that football is moving towards a more downbeat sense of its own importance.

Vialli's boss made his own contribution to football inflation (inflation of itself, that is) in his newspaper column last Sunday. Referring to the recent administrative changes at the FA, Ken Bates wrote: "Without exaggeration, for English football that bloodless coup ranks in importance in some respects with the fall of the Berlin Wall or majority rule in South Africa." That's without exaggeration.

Not wishing to be outdone when it comes to getting things in proportion, the four Sheffield MPs who called for the sacking of Wednesday manager Danny Wilson contrived to make themselves look even more self-righteous than Bates, which is saying something. Their concern with the running of the football club is commendable - a lot of clubs could benefit from their local representatives taking a much closer interest in their finances.

However, the public way they went about it and the clumsy attack on Wilson rightly brought the wrath of almost every commentator down on their heads. Until recently MPs would have run a mile from any controversy involving the performance on the pitch of their local team. But now, perhaps partly because of the success of football phone-ins, everyone believes their opinion on the game is worth broadcasting to the widest audience possible. Members of parliament, you might argue, should know better. But no doubt they felt it did their credentials as true fans no harm to exercise their "right" to slag off the manager.

It's a two-way process. While Mr and Mrs Beckham can command the front pages and the chat shows more or less at will, it is hard to see football's profile dipping. That kind of attention helps breed the notion that what happens in football matters more than it really does.

It should hardly need saying, but the losing streak of any football club does not merit the time of MPs who are hardly short of pressing issues to deal with. Nor should the significance of breakthroughs at Lancaster Gate be confused with those at the Brandenburg Gate.

Football is not a matter of life and death. It is less important than that. But that hardly makes for a striking T-shirt.
