webTitle: Human rights groups challenge Straw on Pinochet

fields.headline: Human rights groups challenge Straw on Pinochet
fields.trailText:
Human rights groups today formally challenged home secretary
Jack Straw's conclusion that General Augusto Pinochet is unfit
to stand trial.
fields.body:
Human rights groups today formally challenged home secretary Jack Straw's conclusion that General Augusto Pinochet is unfit to stand trial.

Amnesty International, the Redress Trust, the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture and the Relatives of the Disappeared in Chile lodged a written submission with the home office in a last-ditch bid to reverse Mr Straw's decision to release the former Chilean dictator.

They expressed concern that the decision would be based on secret medical evidence that "may not reflect the general's true condition". When Mr Straw said last week he was "minded" to release the general - effectively because he is senile - he set a deadline of 5pm tonight for representations from interested parties.

Today's submission includes independent expert medical opinion highlighting deficiencies in Gen Pinochet's medical examination. It argues that interested parties were denied the opportunity to challenge the medical opinion on which Mr Straw's decision was based. The groups argue that a decision at this point on the general's fitness to stand trial pre-empts the normal legal process in the UK and the right of the Spanish courts to consider the matter.

"Even someone accused of mass torture has the right to a fair legal process. But the procedure followed by Jack Straw over Pinochet's medical tests has been totally irregular and flouts natural justice," Amnesty said.

One of the four medical experts who examined Gen Pinochet has questioned the accuracy of Mr Straw's assessment that the general in effect is senile and so unfit to stand trial. Professor Sir John Grimley Evans is quoted by the Observer as saying that he and the three other doctors who examined Pinochet on 5th January listed the medical facts, but that the determination that he was unfit for trial was outside their field of competence and responsibilities.

He is also reported as having said that Gen Pinochet's chances for recovery were slim but not impossible.

Mr Straw is unlikely to make a final decision tonight, leaving all parties of the legal battle that has raged for 15 months dangling. The Spanish government has already lodged a request for the general to undergo further medical tests to get a second opinion on the "unanimous and unequivocal" verdict of a team of eminent home office-picked medics that the 84-year-old was unfit to stand trial.

The petition was prompted by Judge Baltasar Garzon, who issued an extradition order for Gen Pinochet in October 1998 on charges of human rights abuses. The Spanish Government has indicated its reluctance to mount a legal challenge against Mr Straw's final decision.

Mr Straw has insisted his hands have been tied by lawyers for the general who have refused to allow the confidential reports to be distributed.

If Mr Straw frees the general, the director of public prosecutions will have to say whether he believes there is a case for the general to answer under UK law before he can leave the country. The Metropolitan police are also said to be considering action against him.

fields.headline: Drivers face road tolls
fields.standfirst: Transport in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A proposal for an unprecedented charge of 2p a kilometre for motorists on busy trunk roads is expected to be announced today as part of a series of measures to reduce road congestion.
fields.body:
A proposal for an unprecedented charge of 2p a kilometre for motorists on busy trunk roads is expected to be announced today as part of a series of measures to reduce road congestion.

The plan, which will be revealed by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is backed by another to impose charges of 4p a kilometre on congested motorways.

Under the plan, it would cost about £3 for the journey along the A38 between Bristol and Birmingham, and £1.50 to drive down the A23 from London to Brighton.

The government scheme is one of several to deal with road congestion over the next 10 years. In an introduction to the report, Mr Prescott says the need for improvement will differ substantially across the country.

Motoring organisations reacted angrily last night, saying the government would force traffic on to B or even C class roads to avoid the charges.

Edmund King, executive director of the RAC foundation, said that introducing toll booths on motorways or main trunk roads was not an option for the government because of the wasteful use of land space.

It is unclear how the government would levy the charges, although it is testing methods of congestion charges.

Mr King said the only realistic alternative for the government would be a costly scheme to introduce a smart card system for motorists. When they drove past a certain point on a motorway or road, their journey would be recorded by an electronic device, and they would be billed every month in the same way as if they held a credit card.

The government's plan concedes that road traffic levels will still be above 1996 levels 10 years from now, and that they cannot be reduced. But Mr Prescott is confident that the introduction of congestion charging will cut car usage by a third in busy urban areas.

His plan envisages a rise in rail use by 130% above 1996 levels by 2010. Ministers hope that as well as more passengers, already up more than 20% since privatisation, commercial outlets such as the Post Office and supermarkets will increasingly use rail.

fields.headline: History on trial
fields.standfirst:
David Irving may be isolated in his high court battle, but a growing number of respectable academics are criticising what they have dubbed the 'Holocaust industry'.

Special report: the David Irving libel trial
fields.trailText: David Irving may be isolated in his high court battle, but a growing number of respectable academics are criticising what they have dubbed the 'Holocaust industry'.
fields.body:
At times during his legal battle in the high court, David Irving, a man of natural military bearing, resembles a beleaguered Wehrmacht general in some god-forsaken pocket on the eastern front, desperately trying to beat off the Jewish-Bolshevik hordes. At least, one suspects, that is rather how he sees it.

He stands or sits alone on one side of the courtroom, while the large defence team occupies most of the rest of it. In his opening statement he referred several times to the existence of an "international endeavour" to destroy his name and career as a writer. He menacingly promised that "the Jewish community, their fame and fortunes, play a central role in these proceedings".

Lest there be any doubt about that particular role, he avers that he was "the target of a hidden international attempt" to silence him. Naming names, Irving has pointed the finger at the American Jewish Anti-Defamation League and its equivalents in Britain, Canada, and Australia. Bizarre as they may be, these accusations will resonate beyond the odd collection of his supporters huddled in the Irving corner of the public gallery.

To the young man clad in a black parka, black roll-top sweater, black trousers and black baseball cap sitting among them, the notion, no matter how paranoid, of an international Jewish conspiracy to destroy a hero of the far right will appear just so much common sense. Rather more worryingly, it may feed into the growing backlash against the so-called "Holocaust industry" which, for very different reasons, is taking hold in mainstream media and academic circles.

Few reasonable people will dispute the right of Jews in this country and elsewhere to join forces with other Jews, as well as legions of non-Jewish anti-fascists, in opposing neo-nazism and the Holocaust denial that is associated with it. But some are questioning whether memorialisation of the Holocaust, as well as Holocaust studies in schools and universities, are not being used wrongly, or simply getting out of hand.

They are asking if it deserves a special, protected place in the public consciousness.

The government's announcement in October 1999 that it was considering the establishment of a Holocaust Memorial Day in the UK gave evidence both of the heightened intensity of Holocaust awareness and the reaction to it. Richard Ingrams in the Observer complained that "not a day goes by without the Holocaust being mentioned in one context or another".

Earlier in the year the announcement that the Imperial War Museum North was planning a joint venture with the Manchester Shoah Centre provoked Brian Sewell in the Evening Standard to condemn the "bandwagon" effect. "Can we not say to the Jews of Manchester," he asked, "that enough has been made of their Holocaust and they are too greedy for our memories."

Most recently, Sam Schulman in the Spectator warned that "a new kind of anti-semitism may emerge in the 21st century, in reaction to the attempt to make 'the Holocaust' central to our civilisation." As with all such journalistic provocations there is more than an element of the self-fulfilling prophecy, but the critique is not confined to columnists hungry for a topic that will trigger an avalanche of letters to the editor.

Worse, it's self-defeating: "It was not until it emerged as an iconic event that it was perceived to be an event which was deemed to be worth denying." Mem-orialisation provokes denial.

The intellectual backlash has been more prominent and problematic in the US. Next month will see the publication in Britain of The Holocaust In American Life by the respected US historian Peter Novick, in which he maintains that "it was Jewish initiative that put the Holocaust on the American agenda". The story of Jewish martyrdom was used by American Jewish leaders from the 70s on to provide a narrative that could unite the diverse American-Jewish community and deter assimilation, he argues. It was also a handy way to clobber anti-semitism and justify US support for Israel.

Novick uncovered many policy statements by leaders of the American Jewish Committee, the American Jewish Congress and the Anti-Defamation League to sustain his thesis. He was on more speculative ground when it came to explaining the receptivity of American society to a tale of Jewish misery in Europe, although this was the most interesting part of his argument.

The 60s saw the end of the melting-pot ethos in American society and the rise of the "new ethnicity". It became fashionable to be a hyphenated American. This "particularism" enabled American-Jews, and specifically Holocaust survivors, to tell their stories for the first time. Moreover, their experience harmonised with America's self-image as a sanctuary for history's victims. Victimhood proved especially useful to American Jews who wanted to defend their privileges against other ethnic groups, notably African-Americans, without appearing too powerful or greedy.

Americans accepted the prioritisation of the Holocaust because it made them feel good: they stood shoulder to shoulder with the people who had endured the worst of the 20th century. Remembering genocide in a "warm glow of virtue" became a vicarious alternative to actually doing anything about it.

These arguments are echoed in a more reductive form by Norman Finkelstein in his forthcoming book The Holocaust Industry, which was prefigured by his hostile review of Daniel Goldhagen's Hitler's Willing Executioners in the New Left Review in mid-1997. Finkelstein, a left-wing and anti-Zionist political scientist, claims that the "Holocaust industry" was created by the pro-Israel lobby in the US after 1967 to justify aid for Israel. "'The Holocaust' is in effect the Zionist account of the Nazi holocaust. It was seized upon and methodically marketed because it was politically expedient." It is at this point that the backlash against the so-called Holocaust industry collides disturbingly with the events in the high court and their background.

On the far left throughout the 70s and 80s it was common to find the argument that Jews cultivated knowledge of the Holocaust to buttress Israel's right to exist at the expense of the Palestinians and repel criticism of its occupation policies. These themes lay at the heart of Jim Allen's 1987 play Perdition, tellingly resurrected last year. In this drama, based coincidentally on a libel trial, the defence counsel argues that "Israel is a paid watchdog: a nation built on the pillar of Western guilt and subsidised by American dollars."

Similar reasoning was located on the far right. It found expression in Irving's introduction to the Leuchter Report, which purported to show that there were no gas chambers at Auschwitz. According to Irving, "Since 1949 the state of Israel has received over DM90bn in voluntary reparations from West Germany, essentially in atonement for the 'gas chambers of Auschwitz'", which he declared a "myth".

Of course, there is a world of difference between this and the unease felt in many quarters about the prominence of the Holocaust in society, culture and politics today. But in their efforts to chart the origins of the "Holocaust industry", its critics fall into the trap of ascribing too much influence and power to the Jews, while the motives they ascribe to Jewish organisations are reductive and harmful.

The Holocaust is the object of fascination today not just because it is a gripping chapter of history, but because it has stunning contemporary relevance. In a Europe that has recently witnessed "ethnic cleansing", the past has become the present. As events in Rwanda showed, genocide is not just a matter of academic research. The routine violation of human rights and the benighted treatment of refugees inevitably evoke past experiences and call for these to be studied and, with respect for all the crucial variations of scale and character, recalled as a warning.

For it is too easy to dismiss reference to the Holocaust as an easy way of demarcating good and evil. The issues that the Holocaust throws up, such as racism, eugenics and biological politics, are precisely the dilemmas we face today. It was for this reason that the British historian Michael Burleigh concluded his study of Nazi "euthanasia" policies, Death and Deliverance, with a passionate discussion of what the Australian philosopher Peter Singer currently says about the right to life.

In the global marketplace of moral values, the Holocaust seems one instance of applied evil that everyone can agree about. The globalisation of media has made the Holocaust a ubiquitous subject, not the other way round.

The struggle for compensation for slave and forced labourers of the Nazi era would not have won such support were it not, partly at least, for the inclination to hold multinational corporations to account for their treatment of employees. The ethical standards that are being demanded from big business have given a reciprocal relevance to conduct of business under the Third Reich. Such interest hardly existed a few years ago.

Most importantly, the impatience with Holocaust memorialisation rests on a continuing, stubborn resentment of Jewish difference. Behind Peter Novick's criticism of "particularism" is an assimilationist agenda. In Finkelstein's anti-Zionism this is quite explicit. The critics of the proposed Holocaust Memorial Day who instead want a "genocide day" seem unable, or unwilling, to comprehend the specificity of the Jewish fate in the 20th century and the right of a people to commemorate its suffering after decades when it was all but ignored by the world.

Jews are still living with the pain of that silence. It was not of their making or choosing. webTitle: Keeping your promises? So last century

fields.headline: Keeping your promises? So last century
fields.standfirst:
Charlotte Raven on: why we don't want Blair to keep his word; and the man who (let's be honest) won't be mayor

New Labour in power: special report
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Charlotte Raven on: why we don't want Blair to keep his word; and the man who (let's be honest) won't be mayor
fields.body:
If 1999 was the year of New Labour delivery, what is the year 2000? The year of sitting smugly? Or the year of living dangerously as ministers, having more or less got the better of their in-trays, step boldly forth into the unknown?

If I know this administration, it will stick to the road most travelled. Nearly three years into its term of office, its primary political concern remains the "fulfillment" of election promises that no one but they can recall.

Remember that neat little credit card containing the fabled "five pledges"? They were, as Blair told us, a binding contract with the electorate - a way of holding his government to account and the means by which his integrity might be judged. Remember "we don't make promises we can't deliver"? Good for you, we thought. If only those bastard Tories had been so honest, they wouldn't need teaching a lesson. So we voted him in, then forgot all about the damn things.

Which rather begs the question - why is the prime minister still defining his "dos and don'ts" with reference to some back-of-the-envelope programme set down in May 1997? When David Frost asked Blair on Sunday if he planned to reduce the waiting times for patients' first appointments with consultants, the prime minister was taken aback. "We didn't pledge that," he said. Which is of little comfort to my auntie Jean, the pain of whose operable condition has so far failed to make the distinction between an unassessed wait for the clinic and a pledge-accountable wait for treatment. The fact that she has recently had her June appointment put back three times is unfortunate but, as I tell her, none of Blair's business.

Unfortunately for her and thousands like her, no target pertains to her present state and no goal, however small, will be achieved by its alleviation. Not even permitted the dignity of being one of Tony's tough choices, my poor aunt will be forced to spend much of 2000 languishing in unsanctioned agony while Labour gets on with the job of making sure every seven-year-old can spell "particularly".

Someone should have told Mr Blair that we never really expected him to spend all his years in office working to cut class sizes. His apparent inability to see the pledges, and the programme from which they were distilled, for what they were - a skilful spin doctor's response to a particular political question - has given him the curious distinction of being the only person in Britain still holding Labour to its promises.

The rest of us were rather more circumspect. For most of the British electorate, the pledges were a means of establishing trust, less important in themselves than suggestive of the spirit behind them. Like a prenuptial agreement, they reassured us that whatever might happen between us, New Labour would neither rip us off nor seek to make political capital from any future disagreements. In this sense they were never intended as a blueprint for the actual relationship. Rather, they were articles of faith intended to provide the foundation for the project's evolution.

If New Labour was an electoral contrivance born out of bleak necessity, a Labour government was a wholly different matter. No longer mortgaged to the whims of the electorate, it could have spent the past few years defining its political identity. At least, that's what some of us hoped. Like one of those rockets which has shed its outer casing as it finally leaves the earth's atmosphere, Labour was meant to ditch the tools by which it had convinced us of its competence and start exploring other possibilities.

Instead, it has stood still while the rest of the world has moved on. Ironically for a party whose often stated ambition was to hitch a lift from the forces of modernity, New Labour looks distinctly passe. Its unadaptability has had the paradoxical consequence of making it lose touch with the zeitgeist. Its dated commitment to change - so last century - is starting to look as outmoded as the tedious "interactives" in the dome.

Slowly but surely, a party that once had a genius for speaking the popular mind is losing step with our aspirations. Its refusal to rule out tax cuts at a time when millions of people are saying they would pay more taxes if the money went on public services has made them look quite tragically out of synch. Blair's rejoinder, that people don't tell the truth in opinion polls, is neither here nor there. Labour has always dealt with the seeming; it has never been the party of hearts' desires and therefore has to worry when the things people think they want don't correspond with what they're getting.

Blair's mistake in all this is to think that because tax and spend was unfashionable for the past couple of decades, that will always be the case. For someone devoted to taking the pulse of the nation, he is weirdly unaware of the process by which history distinguishes the dated from the apt. Like someone still obsessed with the Bay City Rollers while the rest of us are into speed garage, Blair will continue to plough his own furrow - whatever the consequences and however dumb it makes him look. When a government that used to look so subtle exposes the inner workings it once took such pains to conceal - as it did last week in the public dressing down of Lord Winston - it can't be very much longer before "spin" and related concepts go the way of beards and bandanas.

Dobson and the art of losing gracefully

Whatever the cynics might say, there is still something Labour is good at. They may not be able to solve the crisis in the NHS or force people to visit the Dome but at least they can still win elections. Can't they? Well, yes and no. They could, in theory, still be an unstoppable electoral juggernaut as long as their opponents were discreditable Tory no-marks who spent other people's money and made promises they couldn't deliver. If, on the other hand, they found themselves locking swords with a lovable friend of the people whose penchant for the finer things was funded from his MPs salary - Ken Livingstone, for instance - well, that might be a little bit more difficult.

It shouldn't have been impossible. Given the depths to which the Blairites have been happy to stoop to create a safe environment for their candidate, you cannot help but wonder at the awesome inability of Frank Dobson to capitalise on this advantage. His campaign, revised and retuned though it may be, would still discredit an embryonic student careerist. Where, for example, is the slogan? What are we meant to put on the T-shirts?

As the mood in the Ken camp turns from cautiously optimistic to cautiously triumphant, what might Blair's next move be? Having lost the T&G so spectacularly, there now seems every reason to suppose that Dobson may do less well than expected in the rest of the union section. For Blair, it is all so unthinkable that he has failed to grasp the nettle and set about some damage limitation. If Ken is going to win whatever happens, they could, at least, make sure that dear old Dobbo doesn't lose. Fearing humiliation if Dobson is defeated by the process that was designed to enable him to win, sources close to Blair suggest that they are planning to cut their losses by encouraging him to quit.

Instead of an embarrassing and damaging defeat, they will just have an embarrassing victory to contend with. Ken will win, much less excitingly, and although it will symbolise the rupture between New Labour and the people, at least the people won't be laughing in the streets.

fields.headline: La pilule sans médecin
fields.trailText: Beginners' French
fields.body:
La France a mis en vente
libre dans les pharmacies la pilule du lendemain. Et depuis peu, les élèves des lycées et collèges peuvent la trouver dans l'infirmerie de leur
établissement scolaire.

Les jeunes filles qui sont
inquiètes à la suite d'un rapport sexuel peuvent aller voir l'infirmière de l'école. Elles peuvent lui demander cette contraception d'urgence si elles ont peur d'être enceintes et ne veulent pas avoir d'enfant. Il n'est pas nécessaire d'avoir l'ordonnance d'un médecin.

Et même si l'élève est mineure, elle n'a pas besoin de l'accord de ses parents. La décision de prendre cette pilule se fait entre l'infirmière et l'élève.

Actuellement en France, il y a environ dix mille adolescentes qui tombent enceintes chaque année et six mille sept cents qui se font avorter. Le gouvernement a décidé de donner accès à la pilule du lendemain dans les lycées et les collèges pour faire baisser le nombre de grossesses et d'avortements.

Il y a des avis très differents sur cette mesure. Ceux qui sont pour pensent qu'il est plus facile pour les adolescentes d'aller voir l'infirmière de leur lycée ou
collège plutôt que d'aller chez un médecin ou d'en parler avec leurs parents. Ils pensent aussi que l'infirmière est bien placée pour informer l'élève sur la vie sexuelle.

D'autres jugent qu'il vaut mieux encourager les jeunes gens à porter des préservatifs dans leurs rapports sexuels: cela permet d'éviter en même temps une grossesse et les maladies sexuellement transmissibles. En Grande-Bretagne, le nombre de filles mineures qui tombent
enceintes est beaucoup plus élevé qu'en France. Mais jusqu'à présent, il faut toujours une
ordonnance pour pouvoir obtenir la pilule du lendemain.

La France est pour l'instant le seul pays d'Europe qui ait décidé de distribuer cette contraception d'urgence dans les établissements scolaires.

webTitle: Crime figures rise for the first time in six years

fields.headline: Crime figures rise for the first time in six years
fields.trailText: The government's battle against crime suffered a setback today with new home office statistics showing the first rise in offences for six years.
fields.body:
The government's battle against crime suffered a setback today with new home office statistics showing the first rise in offences for six years.

Violent crimes were up with a huge increase in the number of robberies, which showed a 19% rise compared with a fall of nearly 6% over the previous 12 months.

Most of the robberies were muggings, and major crime rises were recorded in some of Britain's biggest cities.

Overall, in the 12 months ending September 1999, police in England and Wales recorded a total of 5.2 million offences - an increase of 2.2% compared with the previous 12 months.

Home secretary Jack Straw said: "The government is committed to cutting the long-term growth in crime.

"Although crime has risen slightly in the 12 months to September 1999, today's figures show a dramatic variation in crime rates across the country."

Violent crime up

Violent crime saw its largest rise of 6.3% since 1995/1996 when attacks increased by 10%, according to the figures.

They account for 13% of all recorded offences at 663,800, compared to 624,500 the previous year and include attacks, sex offences and robbery.

Sexual offences showed a rise of 2.2%, which was less than the average increase during the last 10 years. Recorded rapes have increased sharply partly owing to a growing willingness by women to report the crimes.

Sexual offences, theft and criminal damage were all up with fraud and forgery showing a near 30% increase.

The only falls were for burglary, drug offences and theft of or from vehicles, according to the home office statistics.

Total property crime, which makes up 84% of the crime figures with 4.4 million offences, increased by 2% after a fall in the previous five years.

Crime by region

The figures are broken down into divisional areas of police forces for the first time, showing the biggest rise in crime - 22% - recorded by the city of London force. This is followed by the West Midlands force, where recorded crime increased by 16%, and Bedfordshire, up by 12%.

The breakdown in the figures showed that there were more attacks on people per head of population in the Bishopsgate area of central London than any other place in England and Wales. But there is only a population of 562 with most people travelling into one of Britain's biggest business centres to work and tourists visiting the heart of London.

It showed there were nearly 350 attacks per 1,000 population compared with the next highest, Newcastle Central where there were 127 attacks per 1,000 population. It again showed that only 4,211 people lived there.

The figures showed 24 forces - more than half of the total - cut crime, although that was fewer than the year before.

But the bad figures recorded in major urban areas meant that there was a total rise in crime across England and Wales.

Britain's largest force, the Metropolitan police, saw its total number of offences top the million mark with an 80,000, or 9%, rise in offences.

Of the metropolitan forces only two showed crime cuts, West Yorkshire and Northumbria which achieved its seventh consecutive fall.

The prime minister's spokesman defended the decision to publish a closer breakdown yesterday: "The figures do raise questions for forces to answer and show the importance of spreading best practice," he said. "This is not about naming and shaming. It's about highlighting areas where particular focus has to be put."

But the Police Superintendents' Association of England and Wales warned against close comparisons.

President chief superintendent Peter Gammon said: "As with all league tables, their value is not in the raw statistics but in the discussion they generate."

The cause of crime

Home office criminologists published projections towards the end of last year that suggested Britain was on the brink of a sharp rise in crime partly owing to increased personal wealth.

Most offences are committed by men aged under 24 and the 1980s baby boom also contributed to officials' warnings of forthcoming problems.

The publication of the figures coincides with the first meeting today between Tony Blair and the incoming commissioner of the Met, Sir John Stevens, who takes over from Paul Condon in a fortnight.

fields.headline: L'école se met au jour
fields.standfirst: In French chemists, the morning-after pill is available over the counter. It is now also available in schools. This development has provoked a huge debate. Zoé Eisenstein finds out more
fields.trailText: Secondary French
fields.body:
La France est le premier et le seul pays au monde où la pilule du lendemain soit en vente libre. Et depuis seulement deux semaines, cette contraception d'urgence a fait son apparition dans les lycées et les collèges à travers le pays.

Les jeunes filles inquiètes à la suite d'un rapport sexuel peuvent donc se procurer cette pilule auprès de l'infirmière scolaire sans en parler à leurs parents. Ce dernier développement suscite une véritable agitation dans le monde de l'enseignement et dans les familles. Rassurés, réticents ou carrément opposés, les avis sont tranchés.

J'ai parlé avec Martine Nawrat du Mouvement français pour le planning familial, Philippe, père de famille et Isabelle, étudiante âgée de 13 ans.

Que penses-tu de cette mesure ?

Martine: C'est un excellent projet. On s'est battus pour que la pilule du lendemain soit distribuée à l'école. Maintenant on veut que les infirmières soient formées pour la donner, qu'elles ne soient pas juste des distributeurs de pilules. Ce qu'il faut, c'est que les filles soient accompagnées. Si on prend cette pilule, c'est qu'on a pris un risque - il faut savoir pourquoi on a pris ce risque et comment on peut se protéger.

Philippe: C'est une mauvaise réponse à une vraie question ; ça ne participe pas à une responsabilisation des adolescents. Il y a une vraie question sur l'avortement chez les jeunes mais je ne pense pas que ça soit à l'état de décider pour les individus. C'est une affaire privée.

Isabelle : C'est bien pour les personnes qui ont des relations sexuelles et qui ont oublié leur pilule habituelle. Elles auraient peut-être pas le courage d'aller à la pharmacie. Maintenant, elles pourront aller à l'infirmerie de l'école.

Y a-t-il une raison d'être contre ?

Martine: Les gens qui sont contre cette pilule étaient également contre les distributeurs de préservatifs dans les lycées. C'est toujours les mêmes arguments. Je pense qu'il vaut mieux apporter l'information là où il y a des jeunes. Si les jeunes doivent se déplacer pour chercher des préservatifs ou la pilule du lendemain, il vont se dire "c'est peut-être pas la peine" tandis que les avoir sur leur lieu de vie, c'est un pas énorme.

Philippe: Ça serait mieux de promouvoir le port de la capote. Si vous voulez assumer votre vie sexuelle, soyez responsable : mettez des préservatifs. J'ai l'impression qu'avec ce projet, on sabote toutes les campagnes qui encouragent les jeunes à porter des capotes.

Isabelle : La pilule à l'école, ça ne va pas remplacer le préservatif, qui est plutôt contre le sida. On sera obligatoirement obligé de l'utiliser. En plus, il paraît que la pilule du lendemain n'est pas sûre à 100 %.

Est-ce que les adolescentes qui prennent la pilule du lendemain ont besoin d'un soutien psychologique ?

Martine: Il faut former les infirmières pour qu'elles écoutent ce que les filles disent et pour pouvoir donner un max d'informations. Mais ce n'est pas juste donner une info, c'est déjà voir un peu où elles en sont par rapport à la connaissance de leur corps et par rapport à la contraception en géneral.

Philippe: Il faudrait leur dire qu'elles feraient mieux de prendre la pilule la veille plutôt que le lendemain ! Je me demande si les infirmières d'écoles sont vraiment adaptées à aider les jeunes filles ? Par contre, c'est vrai que c'est beaucoup plus simple de parler à quelqu'un qu'on ne connaît pas qu'avec ses parents.

Isabelle : Ça dépend des gens. Je pense qu'il y en a qui en ont besoin, mais ça dépend des personnalités. Moi, je ne demanderais pas de conseils à une infirmière à l'école.

Que penses-tu de l'éducation sexuelle à l'école ?

Martine: Le plus tôt on est informé, mieux ça sera pour se préparer dans sa vie sexuelle. On n'est pas obligé d'attendre que les adolescents aient déjà une vie sexuelle - des fois, ça peut être trop tard. Si on est déjà informé, ça permet de commencer sa vie sexuelle sans risque.

Philippe: Il faut dire aux enfants que s'ils veulent avoir une vie sexuelle active, il faut mettre des capotes. La pilule du lendemain, ça veut dire quoi ? - c'est un avortement quand même. En plus, les filles qui vont aller voir l'infirmière ne savent même pas si elles sont enceintes.

Isabelle : On fera l'éducation sexuelle plus tard dans l'année. Mais on n'en a encore jamais fait, ça sera la première fois. C'est bien parce que je pense qu'il y a aussi des relations sexuelles à l'école.

une capote (colloq.) condom
être enceinte to be pregnant
être inquiet to be worried
une infirmière nurse
un max (colloq.) maximum
la pilule du lendemain morning-after pill
un préservatif condom
saboter sabotage
le sida Aids
un soutien psychologique counselling, support
la veille the day before
en vente libre on sale over the counter, freely available

fields.headline: Clinton Cards
fields.trailText: Clinton Cards is one of those ubiquitous high-street frontages that, with the passage of time, has become very much part of the landscape.
fields.body:
Clinton Cards is one of those ubiquitous high-street frontages that, with the passage of time, has become very much part of the landscape.

Indeed, rather too much so, if yesterday's trading update from the company is anything to go by.

The good news is that like-for-like sales in the four weeks to Boxing Day increased 5.1% on a year earlier.

In other words, a 650-shop group specialising in selling greetings cards and associated paraphernalia can bring in some money at Christmas, by far the nation's greatest single card-sending and receiving event.

The bad news is that poor conditions in the autumn - which saw like-for-like sales dip by 4.8% - wiped out any real gain for the whole of 1999, and pre-tax profit is likely to be "broadly similar" to that achieved in 1998, which was £15.8m. Clinton's shares plunged 30p to 203p, a vertiginous 12.8% drop, although volatility is no stranger to Clinton; in the grinding slump of a decade back, the shares tumbled from about 90p in 1990 to about 20p in 1992, back up to the 50p area in 1993 and on down to just above 20p again in 1995.

Who would have thought the greetings-card industry could prove so exciting?

Yesterday, Clinton pointed out, firstly, that results up to September had been very good and, secondly, that it had been hardly alone in feeling the autumn chill - "many retail organisations" did so too.

The jury remains out on the precise reasons why, with price deflation and the internet the top two suspects.

With regard to the latter, Clinton has already launched its own website and is "currently developing, in collaboration with one of our suppliers, an e-commerce operation which will be ready during 2000".

Ordering cards over the net doubtless makes good sense, although, in the age of email, Clinton must be hoping its customers do not decide to send them that way as well, a development that could cut out Clinton and its cardboard cards for good.

fields.headline: Creaming them off
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Specialist schools, Tony Blair declared at the weekend, are meant to sort out the comprehensive system. It sounds great but, as with so much of this government's policy, closer inspection suggests presentation may be more important than policy coherence. Specialist schools inevitably imply selection, yet the government says it is committed to eliminating selection.
fields.body:
Specialist schools, Tony Blair declared at the weekend, are meant to sort out the comprehensive system. It sounds great but, as with so much of this government's policy, closer inspection suggests presentation may be more important than policy coherence. Specialist schools inevitably imply selection, yet the government says it is committed to eliminating selection.

Specialist schools, for those who have not already met them, are comprehensives which receive additional funding and resources - a combination from private business matched by government cash - to develop extra facilities and teaching in certain subjects. This allows schools to select a proportion of students on what is euphemistically called "aptitude".

It is widely recognised by parents and teachers that the main characteristic of these schools is their ability to attract more pupils from the top 25% ability range. Surprise, surprise, this usually means children from middle-class families, lured by extra teaching and facilities and the way the selection process confers a sense of "specialness" on their child.

Last autumn's league tables revealed these schools were improving at twice the rate of all schools. So perhaps this is just what our comprehensives need, an effective way to staunch the haemorrhage of middle-class children from the state sector while generally improving standards for everyone. Unfortunately, the practice doesn't live up to the theory. Overall pupil numbers to independent schools have not been falling; they've been increasing. Meanwhile, on the available evidence, "aptitude" tests, by forcing new forms of selectivity into the comprehensive system, are creating additional layers of inequality.

Recognising "aptitude" often translates into exams, tests or interviews which, inevitably, involve 11-year-olds in competitive processes. Maybe it is marginally better being told you are not suitable than being described as a failure. But it is hardly consoling when the alternative is still the sink school down the road. Aptitude is also a shorthand for social selection. For example, it is known that the sexes develop at different rates in different subjects. So for technical or mathematical specialisms, where girls are ahead at 11 but behind at 16, co-educational schools will have to select boys who will "probably" develop as strongly as the girls. Will they choose the boys from the nice middle-class homes or the boys from the troubled estates, I wonder?

The London borough of Wandsworth ought to act as a warning here. In the flagship Tory borough, several comprehensives acquired specialist status. Alongside other schools operating a policy of selecting 50% of their intake purely by academic ability, they created divisiveness and rancour. Individual schools transformed themselves, but at some cost. Children despaired at failing tests to all local schools. Neighbouring schools and boroughs complained that brighter children were being creamed off, seriously disadvantaging those schools which were still genuinely comprehensive. This deregulated chaos led to a high court challenge, aimed at curtailing numbers selected by the schools operating with a purely academic criterion.

Overtly, the government is putting a clear distance between its own specialist schools policy and that operated by Wandsworth. It backed the court action against that council. It is also making clear that selection for new specialist colleges is not meant to be about conventional academic ability and that funding will depend on the school's plans to cater for other local non-specialist schools. These are to be centres of excellence which reach out and support neighbouring schools rather than operating competitively and in isolation.

Privately, though, there must be huge government relief that the court's initial decision against the Wandsworth selection process has been overturned. Two of the schools threatened by the high court action had been awarded "beacon status" by the government's beloved Ofsted for the example they set to other schools. With Tony Blair's declared intention "not to let good schools be damaged" the last thing he'd want is a public clash with them over their selection process. Nor would it be desirable to have the whole issue of selection coming under scrutiny just as the government launched a new initiative based on covert selection.

So instead of an open and clear debate about selection and its role in a comprehensive system, we will have to make do with a highly packaged presentation which carefully sidesteps the issue. When the plans for the new specialist schools are unveiled this week, we'll hear fine words about improvement targets, standards, excellence, and aptitude. But just for once, wouldn't it be nice to have a clear and honest answer to a simple question: is there to be selection at the secondary level or not?

Specialist schools, for those who have not already met them, are comprehensives which receive additional funding and resources - a combination from private business matched by government cash - to develop extra facilities and teaching in certain subjects. This allows schools to select a proportion of students on what is euphemistically called "aptitude". It is widely recognised by parents and teachers that the main characteristic of these schools is their ability to attract more pupils from the top 25% ability range. Surprise, surprise, this usually means children from middle-class families, lured by extra teaching and facilities and the way the selection process confers a sense of "specialness" on their child. Last autumn's league tables revealed these schools were improving at twice the rate of all schools. webTitle: Recruitment crisis may be caused by misconceptions on pay, poll shows

fields.headline: Recruitment crisis may be caused by misconceptions on pay, poll shows
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: One root cause of the recruitment crisis in the public sector, including in Britain's hospitals and classrooms, may lie in the fact that the public massively underestimates the amount that nurses, teachers and other key staff are paid, according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll.
fields.body:
One root cause of the recruitment crisis in the public sector, including in Britain's hospitals and classrooms, may lie in the fact that the public massively underestimates the amount that nurses, teachers and other key staff are paid, according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll.

The survey on public sector pay shows that people believe nurses earn £3,000 a year less than they are actually paid, but they think they deserve to get a pay increase which would take their average salary up to £23,000 a year - more than the pay award announced yesterday.

The gap between what the public thinks nurses are paid and what they actually receive may account for some of the recruiting problems experienced by the NHS and other parts of the public sector, such as the police.

The poll shows that the public believes that teachers, hospital porters, ambulance staff, doctors and police officers should all get substantial pay increases. But in many cases, including those of the police and teachers, the public consistently underestimates how much such public servants are paid and how much they ought to earn.

For example, a primary school teacher is generally believed to earn £18,700 a year, the survey shows, and the public thinks they should be paid £3,300 more to take them up to £22,000.

Unfortunately for primary school teachers, and the pay campaigns waged by the teaching unions, this figure is £500 below what the average primary school teacher is currently paid.

The survey also shows that while some sections of the public sector are underpaid, adult voters believe that senior civil servants, MPs and cabinet ministers are overpaid.

This is underlined by the findings of the question asking voters to rank various occupations on a scale of one to 10 in terms of how much they are respected. Nurses, doctors and, perhaps surprisingly, schoolteachers come out as the top three, with university lecturers and police officers also commanding a high respect rating.

Civil servants and politicians find themselves halfway down the league table. But their occupations are still ranked significantly above those of soap stars and footballers. Journalists just creep in at the bottom ahead of that other notorious profession - the estate agent.

But if the poll shows that the public's view of pay in health and education is more complex than might have been assumed, its results contain a stark warning for the government on the national minimum wage.

An overwhelming 85% believe that the government should not, as planned, freeze the minimum wage at £3.60 an hour until its impact on jobs becomes clear, but should increase it in line with inflation. Only 13% believe it should remain frozen at £3.60 an hour.

The survey also shows that a clear majority is willing to pay extra tax to fund increases to close the pay gap between the public and private sector for nurses and teachers.

A third of voters say they are unwilling to do this. Nearly 40% of Tory voters say they are unwilling to pay extra tax to fund such pay increases. There is also strong but not majority support for such rises to be tied to performance related pay.

ICM Research interviewed a random selection of 860 adults aged over 18 by telephone between January 14 and 16 2000. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Meet the mates, the minders and the man called Crocodile

fields.headline: Meet the mates, the minders and the man called Crocodile
fields.trailText:
Lloyd Honeyghan, friend
The former world welterweight champion has been a regular visitor since Tyson arrived in London, acting as a guide to the city for the man he first met more than a decade ago. Yesterday he described Tyson as "in the best shape I've seen him for 10 years" and said Tyson had told him he still loved Britain, despite the adverse publicity of the last week.
fields.body:
Lloyd Honeyghan, friend
The former world welterweight champion has been a regular visitor since Tyson arrived in London, acting as a guide to the city for the man he first met more than a decade ago. Yesterday he described Tyson as "in the best shape I've seen him for 10 years" and said Tyson had told him he still loved Britain, despite the adverse publicity of the last week.

Steve 'Crocodile' Fitch, 'cheerleader'
Tyson's motivator-in-chief has served five years for manslaughter, a fact not lost on the opponents it is his job to intimidate. Clad in trademark combat fatigues, the Crocodile has been at ringside for all Tyson's big fights, for which he earns £150,000. In 1996 he was chased across a casino floor in Las Vegas by British fight fans after he stared at Frank Bruno while drawing a finger across his throat. Fitch also shouted "It's time to bite" shortly before Tyson took a chunk out of Evander Holyfield's ear.

Jay Bright, corner man
Bright met Tyson when the pair were taken in as teenagers by Cammille Ewald, a friend of the legendary trainer Cus D'Amato, the man who set Tyson on the road to the world heavyweight crown. Bright never showed much aptitude as a fighter, but has remained close to Tyson and took over as his corner man when Tyson was released from prison. He was in the corner when he knocked over Frank Bruno in 1996. Sacked after Tyson was defeated by Holyfield, but could now be reinstated to the key post.

Darryl Francis, 'personal assistant'
Francis has served time for assault and was recently implicated by animal welfare groups in the death of a ferret at the boxer's home. One of Tyson's oldest friends, Francis helps him avoid boredom at training camp.

 Also with Tyson are his manager Shelly Finkel, trainer Tommy Brooks and a dozen minders. A further 18 people, including Tyson's wife, Monica, will arrive in the next week, swelling the camp to nearly 40 by the time it reaches Manchester.

webTitle: Before the big fight, the big PR offensive

fields.headline: Before the big fight, the big PR offensive
fields.trailText: From the luxurious surrounds of one of London's most elegant and expensive hotels, Mike Tyson yesterday embarked on the first of a flurry of PR stunts aimed at staunching the flow of adverse publicity that greeted his arrival in Britain at the weekend.
fields.byline: Paul Kelso, John Rawling  and David Ward
fields.body:
From the luxurious surrounds of one of London's most elegant and expensive hotels, Mike Tyson yesterday embarked on the first of a flurry of PR stunts aimed at staunching the flow of adverse publicity that greeted his arrival in Britain at the weekend.

As a high court protest against the home secretary's decision to admit the boxer to Britain was launched less than three miles from the five-star Grosvenor House hotel, where Tyson will be based for the next 10 days, the former world heavyweight champion left on a West End shopping trip that his handlers hoped would help cast the convicted rapist in a more favourable light.

Earlier in the day, in another move to appease his critics, a member of Tyson's entourage had emerged to pluck four fans from among a scrum of photographers outside the hotel and took them to watch the boxer's first training session in a gym hastily built in the hotel's £10,000-a-day Park Suite at a cost of £15,000.

In the next week Tyson plans private visits to children's hospitals, shunning the publicity that would inevitably accompany them. An insider said: "Mike is good with children, but he wants to go to the hospitals to be with the kids, not to turn it into some kind of crazy media circus."

Tyson also plans to visit Brixton in London and Moss Side in Manchester, saying yesterday: "I love those people more than the upper echelons who only want to use me."

Among the fans admitted to the training camp was Lisle Britton, 12, from Newmarket, Suffolk, who emerged to reveal that that he had been in the ring with Tyson for a bit of sparring. Carrying mementoes including signed photographs, a blow-up boxing glove and a T-shirt, he said: "He was very nice. He was practising in the ring and I got in there and messed about a bit."

Another, Kamran Ahmed, 24, from Shepherds Bush, west London, said he and Tyson, who converted to Islam while serving a six-year sentence for the rape of beauty queen Desiree Washington in 1991, had recited a prayer together.

After the training session Tyson visited the McLaren showroom and attempted to buy a 225mph McLaren F1, a limited edition road-going race car that is the fastest production vehicle ever sold to the public. He was told by the manager that all 100 vehicles made, including the gleaming model on display, had been sold.

Tyson then made the short trip to Aston Martin, only to be frustrated once again when he was told their top-of-the-range car does not conform to US emission regulations.

He was then driven in the promoter Frank Warren's Bentley to Old Bond Street, where he visited Versace, Cartier and Gucci, where he tried on a pair of shoes, but did not buy them. Thus far the £5m purse he is getting to face British heavyweight champion Julius Francis in Manchester on January 29 remains unspent.

Only the presence in the Grosvenor lobby of four burly security men sporting lounge suits and tell-tale earpieces suggested that London's most infamous visitor and his bizarre entourage had settled in for a stay that will produce a near six-figure bill.

The boxer and his troupe of corner men, trainers and hangers-on, some of whom have criminal histories almost as chequered as that of their boss, have taken five suites and more than 20 rooms on the seventh floor, with a dozen security men ensuring that only those in the inner circle are able to gain access.

A hotel concierge said: "He's actually far nicer than you expect. He takes the time to stop and say hello, unlike some guests who don't have his reputation."

Weight sets, punch bags and a speed ball have been installed in the Park Suite, more usually used for hospitality and business functions, as well as a boxing ring smaller and lower than normal so that it can fit under a cut-glass chandelier and between the room's four Corinthian pillars.

Tyson's only quibble was that the training ring is too small, apparently by just 18 inches. In the circumstances, with the security problems that would be caused by moving to another gym, it seems that as with the unsuccessful car-buying jaunt, he will have to live with what he's got.

While Tyson remained outwardly cheerful, the brooding resentment over the way he believes he has been wrongly treated in the past is close to the surface.

He spoke of the letter the gangland murderer Reggie Kray had written him while he was serving his jail term for rape and said: "I don't condone what Kray did but he wrote to me at the lowest point in my life. He understood what I was feeling."

fields.headline: The walking wounded of Wonderland
fields.standfirst: Director Michael Winterbottom tells Stuart Jeffries about his sour vision of London - and the world
fields.trailText: Director Michael Winterbottom tells Stuart Jeffries about his sour vision of London - and the world
fields.body:
What does London look like? Like the film Notting Hill - verdant bowers in private squares and next to no black people? Like Sliding Doors - sunny porticos, chic restaurants, Gwyneth Paltrow's English simper? Or like Nil by Mouth, a brutalist Peckham never imagined even in Del Boy Trotter's philosophy?

In his new film Wonderland, Michael Winterbottom has tried to depict another London. This is not some touristic confection, nor an unremitting hell hole - it's a London that you may actually recognise in all its splendid grubbiness and tatty grandiosity.

At the start, for instance, Gina McKee does a runner from a blind date in the Pitcher and Piano bar in Dean Street. And who can blame her? She towered over this ageing troll of a man as they shouted awkward pleasantries at each other in the beery crush. It was never going to work, not even for one night. You watch her walk, vulnerable, hunched and with a daft hairdo, through Soho.

And then three things happen. First, you become conscious of the press of people, the yellow London brick, the neon. The colours drizzle and glisten wetly, like they do when Scorsese films New York at night, although here the density of the crowds and the buildings, as well as the grainy film stock that Winterbottom uses, give this scene a cherishable London specificity.

Then Michael Nyman's sumptuous, romantic soundtrack starts up, full of emotional import that you can't quite yet account for, but that nonetheless helps lift this quotidian scene out of glum English realism.

Then, thirdly, the film speeds up. In this stop-frame section, the colours blur and McKee is transported through the streets as though she's got a jet pack in her duffel bag. Winterbottom says that he was influenced in these scenes by Wong Kar-Wai's Chungking Express, and here he has created a visual parallel to Kar-Wai's seedily beautiful neon-and-noodles Hong Kong. Yet at the same time he shows what London looks like to his characters: a rush of poignant colours and noise, a floating world that signifies all too much.

Winterbottom takes a pull on his beer. We're sitting in a London touristic confection, a poncy hotel bar opposite the BBC. Around us men in black ties and kilts, and women in ball gowns mill in preparation for some Scottish corporate nightmare of an evening. In Wonderland, Winterbottom sullied this same hotel by setting a scene in an upstairs room. There, a couple from Manchester have a weekend birthday shagfest under the doubtless encouraging gazes of Eric Gill's reliefs on Broadcasting House opposite.

Winterbottom explains what he was aiming for with Wonderland. "I was trying to bring out a London that I felt I hadn't seen on film before. London is a restless place and people have to struggle to keep their heads above water. I wanted to show that. I think the basic issues are the same wherever you live, but you're going to be more conscious in a city of 7m of how many people you see during the day who you don't know. The techniques came out of what we were trying to do with the film." London was captured by vérité, documentary-style techniques: a tiny crew working with a hand-held camera, natural lighting, no boom microphones, no clapperboard, real locations.

"We put the characters among real people in London to be more true to the place. What normally happens in a film is that you'll shoot an 11pm pub scene at 11am in the morning. The pub will be empty and you'll fill it with extras saying 'rhubarb' to each other. And then you'll edit out all the 'rhubarbs' and put over talking tracks, which feel false. Instead, we decided to film the scene in the pub at 11pm when it's full of people who are drunk and are preparing to go home."

Wonderland is set over a Bonfire Night weekend and mostly concerns the struggles of three sisters to make human connections in a dislocating city. But Winterbottom denies that the drama is at all Chekhovian: "Initially the script was like Short Cuts [Robert Altman's LA-set film] and the connections between the stories were purely down to geography. But as we talked about it we came round to the idea that actually they should be three sisters, with a family built around them. The story of one sister tells you something about the other two."

The problem with the film stems from the inability of Laurence Coriat's script to create convincing characters. Typical is Gina McKee's waitress Nadia, who can only find dates through lonely hearts columns and is prey to every oaf she thus encounters. But how did Nadia get this way? We are given no insight into her struggles or her grinning social ineptitude. And in the cast of sad and incompetent humans who populate Wonderland, we are never really encouraged to understand why these people are unable to master their fates. As a result, the film often becomes alienating and infuriating.

Worse, Coriat's script presumes to represent London as it is. And Winterbottom is in league with this presumptuousness. Near the end, the camera pulls back from a tower-block flat to reveal a dense wall of similar flats. It withdraws further to disclose a cityscape of tower blocks and St Paul's shimmering in the night. This, the syntax of this sequence suggests, is what London is like: hopeless people striving ineptly in bite-sized flats. And yet it's a lie, just like the tacked-on happy ending that follows.

A few scenes nonetheless ring true. When Nadia returns home after a jaw-dropping piece of post-coital cruelty, she sits on the top deck of the 171 bus from Aldwych to the Elephant. Down the front a group of drunk friends are laughing loudly and photographing each other, forcing their good time on her. It's Saturday night and the condensation she wipes from the window is made up of her fellow travellers' beer breath and bonhomie. Through the window, it's the fag end of the night, and nothing's ever going to be right. The scene goes on for ages, but I didn't mind. Who hasn't had that experience of being out of joint with happiness?

There aren't a lot of laughs in Wonderland. But then, it would be hard to imagine a Michael Winterbottom comedy. Since his feature film debut in 1995, his Winterbottomland has been a grim place, perhaps as you'd expect from one who cut his teeth on a documentary about Ingmar Bergman.

First there was Butterfly Kiss (1995), a serial killer road movie set in north England starring Amanda Plummer and Saskia Reeves; then Jude (1996), a properly grim adaptation of Hardy's novel with Christopher Eccleston and Kate Winslet; next Welcome to Sarajevo (1997), a film substantially based on ITN reporter Michael Nicholson's adoption of a Bosnian child, starring Stephen Dillane and Woody Harrelson; then I Want You (1998) with Rachel Weisz in and out of love in Hastings - hardly a laugh riot.

His next project, the western Kingdom Come, which he starts shooting in a purpose-built town in the Canadian Rockies in three weeks' time, will star Nastassja Kinski, Peter Mullan, Milla Jovovich and Wes Bentley (soon to be seen and admired as a voyeuristic teen in American Beauty). It will be a story set in a gold rush town - typically, after the gold rush.

Whatever Wonderland's shortcomings, Winterbottom does elicit some terrific performances, not just from McKee or Ian Hart (himself a wonderland of Scouse dysfunction). Both Jack Shepherd's weak husband and Kika Markham's embittered wife are desperately affecting. None of the leading actors is from London, though, and it grates to hear rough stabs at estuary English being made by Canadians, Scots and northerners. Though, to be fair, not as much as when Paltrow opened her gob in Sliding Doors.

Wonderland has a sour vision of the world. Even the title is clunkingly ironic: baby Alice is born to one of the sisters during the weekend, into a city that seems anything but a wonderland. Winterbottom, 38, suggests that London becomes progressively unliveable as you get older: "The new-born baby has all these endless possibilities. You even worry for the 11-year-old son, Jack, because his opportunities seem fewer," he says. "As people get older you have that gradual reduction of where you can go. I suppose you could say that the older the people get the less happy they are."

On the continent Winterbottom's work is regarded with a seriousness he despairs of ever finding here. At Cannes and Berlin the films of this Blackburn-raised, Oxford-educated auteur have been properly appreciated. "In Europe, generally people are more interested that cinema should be judged in a respect other than box office returns," he says bitterly. "Here people are more paranoid about box office: critics are more concerned about being seen to have an understanding of popular taste, rather than being a voice in the wilderness saying this is what you should watch."

And perhaps, despite its many failings, we should watch Wonderland. There are some lovely human cinematic moments. When Jack goes to a firework display, there is a very upsetting scene. In the darkness we can just make out that something covert and cruel is happening: a little boy is getting mugged for his Walkman and rucksack by big vague adults. It's in the affecting shock of such scenes, when cinema is allied to everyday, eternal human suffering and not exploited to serve some bogus end, that Winterbottom gets beyond the inept conceits betrayed by the film's title.

fields.bodyText: What does London look like? Like the film Notting Hill - verdant bowers in private squares and next to no black people? Like Sliding Doors - sunny porticos, chic restaurants, Gwyneth Paltrow's English simper? Or like Nil by Mouth, a brutalist Peckham never imagined even in Del Boy Trotter's philosophy? In his new film Wonderland, Michael Winterbottom has tried to depict another London. This is not some touristic confection, nor an unremitting hell hole - it's a London that you may actually recognise in all its splendid grubbiness and tatty grandiosity. At the start, for instance, Gina McKee does a runner from a blind date in the Pitcher and Piano bar in Dean Street. And who can blame her? She towered over this ageing troll of a man as they shouted awkward pleasantries at each other in the beery crush. It was never going to work, not even for one night. You watch her walk, vulnerable, hunched and with a daft hairdo, through Soho. And then three things happen. First, you become conscious of the press of people, the yellow London brick, the neon. The colours drizzle and glisten wetly, like they do when Scorsese films New York at night, although here the density of the crowds and the buildings, as well as the grainy film stock that Winterbottom uses, give this scene a cherishable London specificity. Then Michael Nyman's sumptuous, romantic soundtrack starts up, full of emotional import that you can't quite yet account for, but that nonetheless helps lift this quotidian scene out of glum English realism. Then, thirdly, the film speeds up. In this stop-frame section, the colours blur and McKee is transported through the streets as though she's got a jet pack in her duffel bag. Winterbottom says that he was influenced in these scenes by Wong Kar-Wai's Chungking Express, and here he has created a visual parallel to Kar-Wai's seedily beautiful neon-and-noodles Hong Kong. Yet at the same time he shows what London looks like to his characters: a rush of poignant colours and noise, a floating world that signifies all too much. Winterbottom takes a pull on his beer. We're sitting in a London touristic confection, a poncy hotel bar opposite the BBC. Around us men in black ties and kilts, and women in ball gowns mill in preparation for some Scottish corporate nightmare of an evening. In Wonderland, Winterbottom sullied this same hotel by setting a scene in an upstairs room. There, a couple from Manchester have a weekend birthday shagfest under the doubtless encouraging gazes of Eric Gill's reliefs on Broadcasting House opposite. Winterbottom explains what he was aiming for with Wonderland. "I was trying to bring out a London that I felt I hadn't seen on film before. London is a restless place and people have to struggle to keep their heads above water. I wanted to show that. I think the basic issues are the same wherever you live, but you're going to be more conscious in a city of 7m of how many people you see during the day who you don't know. The techniques came out of what we were trying to do with the film." London was captured by vérité, documentary-style techniques: a tiny crew working with a hand-held camera, natural lighting, no boom microphones, no clapperboard, real locations. "We put the characters among real people in London to be more true to the place. What normally happens in a film is that you'll shoot an 11pm pub scene at 11am in the morning. The pub will be empty and you'll fill it with extras saying 'rhubarb' to each other. And then you'll edit out all the 'rhubarbs' and put over talking tracks, which feel false. Instead, we decided to film the scene in the pub at 11pm when it's full of people who are drunk and are preparing to go home." Wonderland is set over a Bonfire Night weekend and mostly concerns the struggles of three sisters to make human connections in a dislocating city. But Winterbottom denies that the drama is at all Chekhovian: "Initially the script was like Short Cuts [Robert Altman's LA-set film] and the connections between the stories were purely down to geography. But as we talked about it we came round to the idea that actually they should be three sisters, with a family built around them. The story of one sister tells you something about the other two." The problem with the film stems from the inability of Laurence Coriat's script to create convincing characters. Typical is Gina McKee's waitress Nadia, who can only find dates through lonely hearts columns and is prey to every oaf she thus encounters. But how did Nadia get this way? We are given no insight into her struggles or her grinning social ineptitude. And in the cast of sad and incompetent humans who populate Wonderland, we are never really encouraged to understand why these people are unable to master their fates. As a result, the film often becomes alienating and infuriating. Worse, Coriat's script presumes to represent London as it is. And Winterbottom is in league with this presumptuousness. Near the end, the camera pulls back from a tower-block flat to reveal a dense wall of similar flats. It withdraws further to disclose a cityscape of tower blocks and St Paul's shimmering in the night. This, the syntax of this sequence suggests, is what London is like: hopeless people striving ineptly in bite-sized flats. And yet it's a lie, just like the tacked-on happy ending that follows. A few scenes nonetheless ring true. When Nadia returns home after a jaw-dropping piece of post-coital cruelty, she sits on the top deck of the 171 bus from Aldwych to the Elephant. Down the front a group of drunk friends are laughing loudly and photographing each other, forcing their good time on her. It's Saturday night and the condensation she wipes from the window is made up of her fellow travellers' beer breath and bonhomie. Through the window, it's the fag end of the night, and nothing's ever going to be right. The scene goes on for ages, but I didn't mind. Who hasn't had that experience of being out of joint with happiness? There aren't a lot of laughs in Wonderland. But then, it would be hard to imagine a Michael Winterbottom comedy. Since his feature film debut in 1995, his Winterbottomland has been a grim place, perhaps as you'd expect from one who cut his teeth on a documentary about Ingmar Bergman. First there was Butterfly Kiss (1995), a serial killer road movie set in north England starring Amanda Plummer and Saskia Reeves; then Jude (1996), a properly grim adaptation of Hardy's novel with Christopher Eccleston and Kate Winslet; next Welcome to Sarajevo (1997), a film substantially based on ITN reporter Michael Nicholson's adoption of a Bosnian child, starring Stephen Dillane and Woody Harrelson; then I Want You (1998) with Rachel Weisz in and out of love in Hastings - hardly a laugh riot. It will be a story set in a gold rush town - typically, after the gold rush. webTitle: Straw right to allow Tyson in - judge

fields.headline: Straw right to allow Tyson in - judge
fields.standfirst: Women's group fails in challenge to home secretary
fields.trailText: A high court judge ruled yesterday that it would be unfair to thousands of boxing fans, businesses in the Manchester area and Mike Tyson's opponent to cast further doubt on the future of his fight in the city on January 29.
fields.body:
A high court judge ruled yesterday that it would be unfair to thousands of boxing fans, businesses in the Manchester area and Mike Tyson's opponent to cast further doubt on the future of his fight in the city on January 29.

Rejecting an application for judicial review of the home secretary's decision to allow Tyson into the country, Mr Justice Sullivan said the court had to take into account the "potential adverse circumstances for many entirely innocent third parties".

The Justice for Women group was seeking a review of Jack Straw's ruling, claiming that he had acted outside the immigration rules by giving Tyson permission to enter the country because of exceptional circumstances.

The group also claimed that by admitting the convicted rapist the government was sending out a message that was inconsistent with its policy on combating sexual violence against women.

The judge said: "The fact is that Mr Tyson is here. The fight is due to take place on Saturday week. Clearly, a great deal of arrangements will have been made by his opponent and by third parties. The court would be bound to have regard to the interests of innocent third parties, along with many thousands of people who have bought tickets. It would be inconvenient that the fight should be cancelled."

Nick Blake QC, representing Justice for Women, argued that Mr Straw had no right to overlook immigration rules and had not carefully examined the circumstances surrounding Tyson's criminal record.

The former world champion is due to fight Julius Francis at the end of this month but the bout was thrown into doubt by immigration rules stating that Tyson should not be allowed into the country because of his 1992 conviction for rape.

Justice for Women claimed that Mr Straw had based his decision on commercial, not compassionate, grounds.

The judge ruled that, like Mr Straw, he was concerned that small businesses in Manchester could be bankrupted if Tyson's bout against Francis were to be cancelled.

Mr Justice Sullivan added: "Tyson's opponent is also facing bankruptcy [if the fight were cancelled]. This just has to be grappled with. What is the court going to say to the secretary of state? You must throw him out? I find it difficult to accept how one could expect that to be realistic."

The judge said it was unrealistic to suggest that Mr Straw, in exercising his discretion, had not borne in mind the strong public policy against "the abhorrent crime of rape".

But despite the fact that the rules state it is up to the immigration officer at point of entry to decide whether someone should be allowed into the country, Mr Justice Sullivan said Mr Straw did have the right to admit somone because of exceptional circumstances - even though, in this case, the home secretary did not accept that strong compassionate grounds existed.

Julie Bindel, head of Justice for Women, said after the hearing: "We are very disappointed and we are considering taking the matter further.

"The judge was extremely concerned about what he called innocent third parties. We are concerned about the women who are victims of rape."

Ms Bindel is deputy director of Leeds Metropolitan university's research centre for violence, abuse and gender, which scans the whole remit of threats to women - from muttered comments in the street to Tyson's criminal record. Fired partly by personal experience, on top of disk-loads of data about other women's experiences, she and her colleagues have made the centre the leading edge of research and pilot schemes in Britain.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Our daily round-up of all the tittle-tattle and transfer talk from the tabloids. And the Independent too.
fields.trailText: The Independent: Leeds are set to make an £8m bid for Wimbledon striker Carl Cort. Cort, 22, has scored 12 goals this season, and fits into David O'Leary's 'buy British' policy.
fields.body:
The Independent: Leeds are set to make an £8m bid for Wimbledon striker Carl Cort. Cort, 22, has scored 12 goals this season, and fits into David O'Leary's 'buy British' policy.

Daily Mirror: Manchester United have joined the chase for Bari's 18-year-old striker Antonio Cassano who has scored twice in Serie A this season, both absolute belters.

Either Rangers' out-of-contract Jorg Albertz or £5m Ben Thatcher will fill Liverpool's problem left-back spot this summer.

Daily Star: Manchester United are following Barnet teenagers Danny Brown and Marlon King. King, a striker, has scored five goals in nine appearances for the Bees, while Brown has scored three times in two matches from midfield.

Sunderland have sent scout Andy King to watch Moroccan international defender Nooron Jakal. Reid is also looking at a move for Portuguese defender Paulo Torres.

The Sun: Mark Fish will leave Bolton if they don't get promotion. "I want to play football at the highest level," he said.

Daily Mail: West Ham are likely to cut their losses on Costa Rican striker Paulo Wanchope this summer.

Dean Holdsworth may make a cut-price return to Wimbledon from Bolton.

Wimbledon co-owner Sam Hammam has admitted the Dons will lose keeper Neil Sullivan this summer. "It's a tragedy for this club," he said. "He is a very special man but he wants to play for huge club, and it's my moral duty to accept that."

Tottenham have signed 20-year-old Dulwich Hamlet striker Dave McEwan.
