fields.headline: Read the small print
fields.standfirst: TV and the internet have never really been easy bedfellows - lovingly designed web pages tend to lose a lot in translation to the small screen. But  Dave Green  reckons television is finally learning to tame the beast
fields.trailText: TV and the internet have never really been easy bedfellows - lovingly designed web pages tend to lose a lot in translation to the small screen. But Dave Green reckons television is finally learning to tame the beast
fields.body:
It's odd we don't see more of the internet on TV, when it fulfils so many channels' programme-making criteria: it's cheap, it's zeitgeisty - and did I mention how cheap it is? But, sooner or later, every TV show about the internet hits the same problem - after a while, it has to display the show's raison d' être, the web pages themselves. And, to paraphrase the old Kit-Kat slogan, they can't dance, they can't sing, and they look awful.

For some reason, even the most exhaustively overdesigned website, when displayed on TV, magically transforms itself into a bunch of brightly coloured boxes with little bits of writing on them. As a bonus, they're often little bits of writing that are way too small to read, probably due to the fact that people usually sit a couple of metres away from their TV (to ward off the childhood-ingrained hazard of "making your eyes go funny"), instead of within arm's length of their computer screen (all the better to wipe the spittle off it, many office workers find).

Consequently, the basic "here are some web pages" TV format has been forced to take on some pioneering new forms. Sky 1 has a three-hour Saturday-night slot (admittedly, incorporating episodes of The Simpsons, Futurama and The PJs) called Sky Rocket, outwardly old-fashioned in its sci-fi setting and chirpy presenters with 'borg-like "devices" clamped to their faces. But, innovatively, something about the way it's filmed means that it does indeed resemble something you've downloaded off the net, while the presenters interrupt each other with a casual ferocity rarely seen outside online chatrooms.

Some of the content, too, provides a scathing riposte to those who accuse prime-time TV of "dumbing down" - last Saturday, at 7.51pm, while BBC1 was revelling in The National Lottery and ITV was in the final throes of Blind Date, the Sky Rocket "build your own web page" feature was wooing ratings with a brief introduction to hexadecimal RGB triplets and hypertext markup language.

But, ultimately, it still relies on that old mainstay of showing viewers websites and their hilariously unwieldy addresses. Thank Gutenberg, you find yourself thinking, that the printing press was invented before television, otherwise there'd be shows where people hold pages of their favourite magazines up against the camera, while page numbers appear fleetingly on the screen for anyone who feels the need to go look up the article themselves.

Carlton World's Net.Comedy (9.30pm, Thursdays) takes a different tack - recognising that web pages themselves don't make especially gripping viewing, they're used as starting points for stand-up comedy routines. Perhaps disappointingly, the gags aren't typically based around the web-surfing experience - "Don'tcha just hate it, ladies and gentlemen, when you're trying to stream Real Audio from behind a corporate firewall?"

Still, by using websites the same way that Have I Got News For You uses headlines and news stories, it's a promising sign that viewers can accept the net as a recognisably banal part of their lives. Of course, the true masters of this are the ever-topical writers of Neighbours who, in their usual wholesale pilfering of the human condition, have recently conjured up email romances, someone posting a picture of their flatmate on a web page (whereupon it gets stuck on the body of a glamour model) or, as happened only last week, Harold Bishop discovering printouts of net anarchist propaganda while going through someone else's bins.

Sadly, this attitude hasn't permeated very far at the BBC, which traditionally balances its "Computers Don't Bite" or "Webwise" educational campaigns with more cautionary fare, invariably following them with computers-gone-mad films like Westworld, The Demon Seed, or Terminator 2. But once websites come to be regarded as just another part of the media landscape, this opens up opportunities for Hello-style "masthead" programming. Admittedly, definitive online muck-raker Matt Drudge (of The Drudge Report) recently parted company with his Fox Network TV show, but Channel 4's new late-night conspiracy fest, Disinfo Nation, is the UK's first to be based on an original website - specifically, host Richard Metzger's disinfo.com.

And by using his site as a template, Metzger, perhaps unintentionally, has captured one of the vital differences between TV and the net. TV shows are filled with what the producers think the audience wants (or ought) to see, but the best web pages are filled with what the webmaster happens to find interesting - in this case, a subcultural freakshow of fringe artists and other assorted wackos. At the same time, by tracking them down and interviewing them in their natural habitats, the show delivers a far more TV-friendly experience than simply showing you pictures of their web pages which, if you think about it, is really just swapping one kind of TV screen for another.

fields.headline: Russian troops 'reach centre of Grozny'
fields.trailText:
Russian troops have reached the centre of the Chechen capital Grozny after breaking through rebel lines early in the
morning, Moscow's Itar-Tass news agency said today.
fields.body:
Russian troops have reached the centre of the Chechen capital Grozny after breaking through rebel lines early in the morning, Moscow's Itar-Tass news agency said today.

In recent weeks Russian forces have fought fierce street battles against Chechen rebels, suffering many casualties. Moscow has been saying since Christmas that Grozny was about to fall, but Chechen rebels hiding out in basements and ruins have resisted stubbornly.

Even now, although the Russian military claims to have penetrated the city centre, it stressed that it would need three to four days to establish control over the shattered city, where up to 40,000 civilians remain trapped in cellars with little food or heat.

Itar-Tass said Russian troops were gradually strengthening their grip on Grozny on the second day of concerted attacks to flush out Islamic rebels. The news agency quoted Russian officers in the region as saying fierce fighting was raging elsewhere in Grozny after a night of heavy artillery and aerial bombardment.

A previous drive to seize the capital ran into trouble in early January when troops encountered fierce resistance from rebels who had dug in while the Russian army was advancing through the Chechen plains. Acting President Vladimir Putin, the strong favourite in early presidential elections to be held on March 26, has said the military will have to take Grozny before moving to eliminate rebel bases in the mountains to the south.

Russian opposition to the war has grown as casualties mount. The soldiers' mothers committee, a charity that promotes servicemen's rights in Russia, claims that 3,000 troops have been killed in the conflict, well above the official figure of 600 dead. General Anatoly Kulilov, who commanded Russian forces in Chechnya in the first half of 1995, yesterday called on the military to halt its advance and consolidate its gains.

The final push to subdue Grozny came as the new Russian parliament opened its first session. Mr Putin urged MPs to end years of bitter wrangling with the presidency and tackle the country's problems. His mere presence in the chamber and his conciliatory speech contrasted vividly with his predecessor, Boris Yeltsin, who fought bitter disputes with parliament throughout his administration.

"The executive power is prepared for fruitful cooperation with the new duma [lower house of parliament]," Mr Putin said. "We must put an end to the policy of confrontation and mutual ambitions."

The duma is due to elect a speaker today, a key position in determining how the legislature handles its daily business. The communists, who dominated the last duma, were fighting to retain control of the post.

But the new duma is dominated by centrists after four moderate parties performed strongly in parliamentary elections in December. MPs are expected to be more willing to implement pro-market reforms and work with the government in tackling Russia's massive economic and social problems.

In recent weeks Russian forces have fought fierce street battles against Chechen rebels, suffering many casualties. Moscow has been saying since Christmas that Grozny was about to fall, but Chechen rebels hiding out in basements and ruins have resisted stubbornly. Even now, although the Russian military claims to have penetrated the city centre, it stressed that it would need three to four days to establish control over the shattered city, where up to 40,000 civilians remain trapped in cellars with little food or heat. Itar-Tass said Russian troops were gradually strengthening their grip on Grozny on the second day of concerted attacks to flush out Islamic rebels. The news agency quoted Russian officers in the region as saying fierce fighting was raging elsewhere in Grozny after a night of heavy artillery and aerial bombardment. A previous drive to seize the capital ran into trouble in early January when troops encountered fierce resistance from rebels who had dug in while the Russian army was advancing through the Chechen plains. Acting President Vladimir Putin, the strong favourite in early presidential elections to be held on March 26, has said the military will have to take Grozny before moving to eliminate rebel bases in the mountains to the south. Russian opposition to the war has grown as casualties mount. The soldiers' mothers committee, a charity that promotes servicemen's rights in Russia, claims that 3,000 troops have been killed in the conflict, well above the official figure of 600 dead. General Anatoly Kulilov, who commanded Russian forces in Chechnya in the first half of 1995, yesterday called on the military to halt its advance and consolidate its gains. fields.headline: The crime figures
fields.standfirst:
Patrick Barkham explains what conclusions can be drawn from today's new statistics
Reported crime figures 1998/99 (pdf format)
fields.trailText: Since 1918, recorded crime has increased on average by 5.1% each year.  500,000 crimes were recorded in 1950, rising to 2.5m in 1980 and more than 5m in 1999. fields.body:
Since 1918, recorded crime has increased on average by 5.1% each year. 500,000 crimes were recorded in 1950, rising to 2.5m in 1980 and more than 5m in 1999. But it is hard to know how accurately crime figures reflect the true picture of crime in Britain. It is made all the harder by the vastly different interpretations which can be spun from the same figures by opposing politicians.

What are the crime figures out today?

The crime figures published today cover crimes recorded by the police in the 12 months to September 1999. They are compiled by part of the home office's research, development and statistics directorate, from figures returned by the 43 police forces across England and Wales.

How have they changed?

In the 12 months ending September 1999, police in England and Wales recorded a total of 5.23m offences - an increase of 2.2% compared with the previous 12 months. Violent crime saw its largest rise - 6.3% - since 1995-96, from 624,500 the previous year to 663,000. Robberies were up by 19%.

Are the figures accurate?

It is impossible to calculate the real level of crime in any country. The two main methods available in Britain are offences recorded by the police and crimes calculated by the British Crime Survey. Police figures are based on crimes reported to them and crimes they uncover in their investigations. These are influenced by changing patterns of reporting crime. For instance, the increase in domestic violence recorded by the police in recent years is believed to be due to women's greater readiness to report such offences by their partners.

The 1998 British Crime Survey interviewed 15,000 adults. It can measure crimes unreported to the police, but is based on households and subject to the usual sampling inaccuracies of any opinion poll.

How has the way crime figures are calculated changed?

In April 1998, the Labour government changed the way annual crime figures are calculated. This has appeared to "increase" crime.

The main change is an attempt to better record crime as it affects the victims, which will bring police crime figures into line with "victim" studies, such as the British Crime Survey. For example, if a vandal breaks into five cars in a car park it is now treated as five crimes because five motorists are affected, whereas before it was viewed as a single offence because it was perpetrated by a single criminal on a single occasion.

The home office says that the main impact of the changes is on reported cases of fraud and criminal damage. Before April 1998, credit card fraud was recorded only if reported. Now, if a police investigation reveals fraud it is officially noted. Minor cases of criminal damage, valued at under £20, are also now recorded.

The classification of crime has also been changed. The category of "violence against the person" has been broadened to include crimes such as cruelty to or neglect of children. In the 12 months ending September 1998, 240,779 offences were calculated under the old rules; when the category was broadened, 524,929 offences were recorded over the same 12 months, a 118% increase.

The new system of counting crime revealed 5.11m offences for the year ending April 1999. Under the old system, 4.48m offences would have been calculated over the same period.

Has this change affected today's figures?

No. Today's figures are important because they are the second set of crime statistics compiled using the new calculations. This means that the 1998 and 1999 figures, calculated the same way, can be meaningfully compared. The 2.2% rise, from 5.11m to 5.23m has not been distorted by any changes in the categories.

What will the impact of today's figures be?

Today's statistics are more detailed than in the past and are broken down by police force. As the government stresses, crime fell in 24 of the 43 police areas. But with crime rising overall, this means there were big increases in some areas. These were predominantly urban areas, such as London and the West Midlands, which suggests recorded crime is becoming concentrated in Britain's cities.

Why is recorded crime rising?

Home office criminologists published projections in late 1999 anticipating that Britain was on the brink of a sharp rise in burglary and other offences. This was partly because of increased personal consumer spending and partly because of an increase in the numbers of men aged under 24, who commit most offences.

The main interpretation drawn by Conservative critics, such as shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe, is that the number of violent offences is up because of the decline in police "stop and search" tactics after the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report, which was part of a debate suggesting such searches unfairly targeted the black community.

Such critics can use the figures broken down by police force to support their case. They point to the Metropolitan police, which recorded a 9% increase in crime - 80,000 more offences - in the 12 months to September 1999.

Use of stop-and-search in London has fallen from 337,309 incidents in 1997-98 to 296,072 in 1998-99. But the link between that and the rising crime figures is hard to prove: it can only be suggested.

What conclusions can be drawn from crime figures?

Almost any you want, on the evidence of the spinning of rival politicians. Clearly, the crime figures are most useful as an indication of broad trends, such as the fact that the vast majority of crime is against property. But you can fairly safely assume that Britain has not got 5.1% more dangerous with every passing year.

webTitle: Toyota threat to quit UK over euro

fields.headline: Toyota threat to quit UK over euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The head of one of the world's biggest car companies reignited the debate over the single currency yesterday with a warning for the government that its £1.5bn investment in the UK would be at risk if Britain stayed out of the euro.
fields.body:
The head of one of the world's biggest car companies reignited the debate over the single currency yesterday with a warning for the government that its £1.5bn investment in the UK would be at risk if Britain stayed out of the euro.

Executives of Japan's biggest car manufacturer, Toyota, which employs thousands of workers at plants in Derbyshire and Clywd, said they could no longer sit on the fence as Britain decides whether or not to enter Emu.

"Waiting for a decision is really hurting us and it is time to state very clearly to the British public that we want Britain to join the single currency," said Shoichiro Toyoda, honorary chairman and former chief executive officer of Toyota.

The comments are sure to increase the pressure on the government and come days after the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, admitted that big business was telling ministers that they must make a decision on the euro early in the next parliament.

Toyota's broadside echoes earlier calls by senior figures from industry to sign up to the single currency. The chairman of Rover Group, Prof W Samann, told reporters recently that full membership of the euro would "consolidate BMW's investment" in Britain.

Naoyuki Akikusa, the president of Fujitsu, went further last year. "If the UK were to join in 2002, that would be OK. But if 2020 - that would pose a big problem."

Toyota managers said yesterday that its UK operations, including a new £200m plant at Burnaston, Derbyshire, would be at risk if the strong pound continued to push its British operations deep into the red. The company said its British operation had suffered its worst performance ever last year as a result of the sharp strengthening of sterling against the euro. This currency fluctuation hurts the competitiveness of the 200,000 Toyota cars produced each year in the UK, 70% of which are sold elsewhere in Europe.

"The figures are not yet available, but we posted a very significant loss in the UK last year," said Shinro Iwatsuki, di rector in charge of European operations. "I would imagine that Ford, Vauxhall and Rover are in a similar position."

He said Toyota sent a senior delegation to Mr Byers last month to express its concerns.

"We told him that if the present situation continues, then at the very least it will be impossible to expand our operations in the UK. If there is no change in the long term, then we will have to decide whether even our existing operations should continue."

The comments, which represent the clearest indication yet of Japanese frustration with Britain's prevarication on the euro, will send shudders through manufacturing industry. Trade union figures show that more than 1m jobs could be lost unless the government signs up for the single currency within 30 months.

Since its opening in 1992, Toyota's Burnaston factory has expanded rapidly and its output almost doubled last year to 200,000 cars. The Deeside plant in Clywd is one of the world's largest engine plants. Together, they have created 3,300 jobs directly, as well as four times that amount among suppliers, in two of Britain's employment blackspots.

Even if Toyota decides only to freeze its current scale of operations, it would be a setback for Britain. Any hesitancy it expresses about the UK is bound to trigger doubts among other Japanese investors.

webTitle: UN names Baghdad foe to head new arms inspection team

fields.headline: UN names Baghdad foe to head new arms inspection team
fields.standfirst:
HM Customs and Excise
Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: The UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan, moved to end the impasse over Iraqi sanctions last night by nominating the Swedish diplomat Rolf Ekeus, a former Iraqi weapons inspector, to head a new weapons monitoring body.
fields.body:
The UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan, moved to end the impasse over Iraqi sanctions last night by nominating the Swedish diplomat Rolf Ekeus, a former Iraqi weapons inspector, to head a new weapons monitoring body.

The nomination, after a month of wrangling, nudges forwards a British-inspired process aimed at lifting sanctions on Iraq and getting a UN weapons inspectorate back into Baghdad.

But Mr Ekeus is high on the list of people the Iraqis object to and he may be vetoed in the UN Security Council by Russia and China, both sympathetic to Iraq.

Mr Ekeus has been chosen to head the UN monitoring, verification and inspection commission, which will replace the one refused entry by Iraq. The body has to take the key decision on whether Iraq has done enough to reduce its armaments since the Gulf war to allow for the lifting of sanctions.

Iraq was told at the time it had to destroy all banned nuclear, biological, chemical and missile programmes.

A British resolution to create the body was agreed by the security council on December 17. A deadline was set to find a leader for it by midnight on Sunday, but Mr Annan failed by a day to make this deadline.

Mr Ekeus, the Swedish ambassador to Washington, was the first chief UN weapons inspector from 1991 to 1997.

But Russia and China, two of the five permanent council members, voiced opposition to him after protests from Iraq.

If Mr Ekeus is rejected, Mr Annan has lined up the Finnish ambassador to Israel and Cyprus, Pasi Patokallio. Brazil's former UN ambassador Celso Amorim, opposed by the US and Britain, was reported to have withdrawn.

Before last night's nomination, Iraq's deputy foreign minister, Nizar Hamdoon, said Iraq was not responsible for difficulties among council members in choosing a candidate. "It's their problem and not our problem. They have created this problem and they have to deal with it."

Iraq has said that it does not matter who is nominated because Iraq does not intend to cooperate. The threat was repeated by its state-controlled press on Sunday.

But sources in London close to the Iraqi government claim that privately it is prepared to swallow a deal if there is some compromise.

The main Iraqi objection to the UN resolution is not the person who will head it but the power it hands over to security council members. A decision on lifting sanctions would be open to review every 120 days, and it would require just one security council member, such as the US, to declare that Iraq had infringed the UN weapons agreement for sanctions to be restored.

Dr Burhan al Chalabi, an Iraqi specialist at the London-based Institute for Strategic Studies, said that a compromise on the trigger could see Iraq agree to let the UN body in. "If the trigger mechanism is changed, that will eliminate much of the mistrust," he said.

Last week Iraq reported attacks by allied planes along its border. The British foreign office said these tended to be on radar and rocket positions. Mr Chalabi said 18,500 sorties had been flown by the US and Britain last year.

fields.headline: A very public privatisation
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Smithers reports on Islington's 'historic' contracting-out of education services
fields.trailText: Rebecca Smithers reports on Islington's 'historic' contracting-out of education services
fields.body:
It was dubbed "a historic moment" by school standards minister Estelle Morris last Friday, as the ink dried on the contract marking the biggest and most high-profile privatisation in the history of state education. The symbolically important borough of Islington, in north London - formerly home to Tony Blair and whose secondary schools he famously rejected for his own children - overnight became the test bed for the future involvement in education of the private sector.

The stakes are high because none of the parties involved can afford failure. But the real hope at the Department for Education and Employment is that if private-sector operators can engineer an improvement, then other councils will volunteer to outsource services.

With Islington, years of declining standards following the break-up of the Inner London Education Authority in 1990 culminated in a highly critical report last spring from the watchdog, Ofsted.

Islington council itself is at pains to stress that neither the schools nor their services are being privatised. Instead, in the first contract of its kind, most of the local education services provided by the council - such as school improvement, personnel, payroll, inspection and governor support and special educational needs - are being "outsourced" to the private firm Cambridge Education Associates.

And as Estelle Morris herself makes clear, "as far as parents are concerned, they will continue to deal with the same teachers, and there will be no change of signs outside their children's schools".

But there is no time to lose. Initially, an interim management arrangement is in place because of the urgency of work required on initiatives such as the Education Action Zone and Excellence in Cities, before the full contract runs from April for a maximum of seven years at a cost of £11.5m. And on Friday, Cambridge Education Associates announced the appointment of a new director of schools, having lured Vincent McDonnell from his post as chief education officer at the London Borough of Richmond-upon-Thames, the highest achieving local education authority for key stage 1 and 2 in national tests.

The question on many people's lips will undoubtedly be "what is in it for CEA?" Managing director Brian Oakley-Smith explains that the company, which has an established track record in providing other educational services such as school inspectors to Ofsted - sees the contract as an opportunity to gain a footing in what is clearly going to be a developing market.

Fears that the company stands to make unlimited money out of state education are unfounded, as it has agreed to a profit cap of £600,000 per annum. Around half its forecast profit is subject to financial penalties if it fails to meet a series of tough targets. Among these, for example, not a single school must fail its Ofsted inspection during the contract period; all schools currently in special measures must come out of them (currently four) and 39% of pupils must achieve five or more GCSEs with grades A to C by the year 2002.

CEA stands to lose up to £75,000 on each target it misses, although some flexibility is given through a sliding scale of penalties that will apply if targets are missed by a narrow, but improving, margin. And headteachers will be asked to fill in regular satisfaction surveys. But the timetable is a gruelling one. The new attainment targets must be met from September next year, so the company has only a four-term lead-in.

Reorganisation of the education service seems - to outsiders at least - to have resulted in a complicated, multi-layered structure, which includes a new Education Commission headed by Birmingham's chief education officer Professor Tim Brighouse. And Estelle Morris admits the new contract is extremely and possibly too detailed, because it is important to get right something that will be a model for wider use.

One of CEA's priorities is to win over local parents who are sceptical about the new arrangements. And Oakley-Smith says it will be devising strategies to persuade parents to support the local schools - particularly the secondaries where the massive exodus out of the borough means they are packed with the poorest ability pupils. He is the first to admit it is a very tough challenge.

And Estelle Morris admits the new contract is extremely and possibly too detailed, because it is important to get right something that will be a model for wider use. One of CEA's priorities is to win over local parents who are sceptical about the new arrangements. And Oakley-Smith says it will be devising strategies to persuade parents to support the local schools - particularly the secondaries where the massive exodus out of the borough means they are packed with the poorest ability pupils. He is the first to admit it is a very tough challenge.

fields.headline: Prescription kills the patient
fields.standfirst: New Labour's desire for innovation in schools may be smothered by a 'culture of diligence'
fields.trailText: New Labour's desire for innovation in schools may be smothered by a 'culture of diligence'
fields.body:
After nearly three years in office two things are clear about Tony Blair and his government. They are keen on the entrepreneurial spirit and innovation. And they are interested, genuinely interested in education. Indeed they have even gone so far as to suggest that the two might be linked. Yet they appear confused as to how this might actually be achieved in schools.

On the one hand David Blunkett has made the very welcome comment that more creativity was to be encouraged amongst teachers and pupils. Citing work carried out over a number of years at King's College London known as Cognitive Acceleration in Science Education (CASE), in which analytic thinking and problem solving are emphasised, Blunkett announced that this scheme was to go national.

Or at least he implied it, but, inexplicably he did not include the same scheme (CAME) for Maths. Rather, for maths and English there was to be an extension of the primary literacy and numeracy hours and yet a further raft of tests for 12-year-olds. Schools will also have to target-set for the key stage 3 tests for 14-year-olds.

Now it is not that target setting is of necessity bad, and public accountability is important. Testing has its place. Guidance, which is all that the numeracy and literacy hour are, officially, is helpful. It is the climate that all these measures creates in schools that is so damaging, for it is slowly eroding that spirit of enterprise that new Labour seems so keen to encourage.

As Carol Adams, the chief education officer for Shropshire, was moved to comment to the commission on creativity headed by Professor Ken Robinson, "Teachers are caught up in a culture of diligence." Not, she argues, because teachers have no ideas of their own but because they so conscientiously implement all the reforms they are asked to.

To find a way forward perhaps Blunkett should study the Robinson report, "All Our Futures". Published in May, it is possibly the best document to come out of the education department since Labour took office. Defining creativity as "imaginative activity fashioned so as to produce outcomes that are both original and of value", the report advocates the need rigorously to foster creativity in the classroom, for the teacher and pupil alike.

Teachers can, of course, deviate from the new Labour script if they want to, but the culture of diligence makes this less and less likely even amongst secondary English teachers who have traditionally resisted prescription.

At the end of last year the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority released draft materials for a complete scheme of work for key stage 3 English. The finished version is due out around Easter. How these materials are compatible with Blunkett's latest proposals is also far from clear. While unobjectionable, if somewhat dull in themselves, their significance lies in their smack of state-written lesson plans.

Such a perception matters if we are serious about encouraging innovation, especially as the curriculum is already so constrained, and set to become more so, by the demands of examinations. Of course the majority may well ignore any one these "voluntary" proposals, but their very existence means that schools and departments anxious to do well at Ofsted and in the league tables feel pressured to implement them.

If Blair and his colleagues are genuine in their desire to create an innovative and creative economy through a high-quality educational system, and I believe they are, then they must be more rigorously consistent in the measures they introduce and resist the temptation of further prescription in our schools.

If they do not, recruitment figures into the teaching profession may continue to fall, as only the most vocationally dedicated are motivated to sign up; many of the talented will leave, frustrated at the lack of room for manoeuvre, and pupils will be left with an increasingly rigid but testable diet. Of course, letting go is a risk - but then genuine innovation always is.

fields.headline: Teacher's special helpers
fields.standfirst: By allowing the teacher to concentrate on small groups, or through giving individual attention to a child with special needs, a parent can prove to be a valuable partner and assistant in the classroom, says  Phil Revell, in the second of our series on parental involvement in education
fields.trailText: A parent can prove to be a valuable partner and assistant in the classroom.
fields.body:
St Matthew's Junior School in Donnington, Shropshire serves one of the most troubled estates in the area, with drug taking, alcoholism and crime acknowledged as serious problems. Yet headteacher Glenn Calcutt has no doubt that local parents can make an invaluable contribution to the primary classroom.

"The policy is to bring in parents, to train them effectively, use their skills, and to work together to ensure that, whilst the children are here, they feel they are valued."

Less than 300 yards from the school there are boarded-up houses, used needles left lying around and disaffected young men eyeing the passing cars. And yet... "We have 90% attendance," says Calcutt. "Over 80% of parents come to parents' evenings. This is an oasis." It doesn't take long to work out just how the school has managed to insulate itself from the problems beyond the playground.

Lou Wall is a classroom assistant trained to work with statemented children. She's also the site manager, a lunchtime supervisor - and an ex-parent. Jan Jenkins is also a lunchtime super, a classroom assistant, health and safety officer - and an ex-parent. Nearly all the ancillary helpers in the school are parents and everyone seems to have a double or triple role. Chris Hughes is the cook, but she's also a governor, whilst Sandra Bowen is a classroom ancillary, a lunchtime supervisor, and at 3:30 she'll don her overalls and fulfil a third role as the cleaner in charge.

Like most of the adult helpers, Lou started by coming in to hear children read. She spent a year going to evening classes to take a City and Guilds qualification in learning support. Jan Jenkins took the course with her.

"When I see the achievements of the children with severe learning difficulties," says Jan, "I have to get up from the table and move away or I wouldn't be able to contain the emotion. It's not just a job, it's very personal and very rewarding."

Calcutt strongly believes in having teachers supported wherever possible, and one of the main advantages in having parental assistance is the opportunity it presents for teachers to work with a smaller group or arrange individual support for a particular child. Simply having an extra pair of hands can be invaluable.

Parents crossing the classroom threshold was unheard of not so very long ago. In the classroom, the teacher held sway and parents were expected to deliver their charges at the front gate and then make themselves scarce. A few teachers wish it were still so.

"It's supposed to be a partnership," said one (not at St Matthews). "But sometimes I think - why do we bother, wouldn't it be easier to lock the doors?"

Christmas nativity plays can bring out the worst in parents, who behave like paparazzi as they jostle to get the ideal video shot of their offspring's star performance as the third shepherd. Last year, Dewi Tomos, deputy head of Ysgol Bro Lleu in Gwynedd, complained after a minority of parents had chatted and wandered about during the school's nativity concert.

"The concert was spoilt by the behaviour of a number of parents," he wrote in a letter sent home from the school. The current head, Arwen Owen, is keen to stress the importance of good home-school links. Over the past 12 months, she has worked hard to involve parents in the school and the 1999 performance by the children was a "huge success". The contrast illustrates the difference between teachers who see parents as consumers - and those who see them as partners.

"I listen to children read and help out with artwork," says Lesley Skeoch, who spends two or three hours a week at Barnes Farm Junior School near Chelmsford, Essex. "We've been doing paper-weaving and last term I helped the children make some 'stained glass' windows using tissue paper."

Skeoch has two children, Matthew, 8 and Rebecca, 5. Both are at Barnes Farm and Lesley helps out in Matthew's year 4 class. He welcomes her presence.

"That may change when he gets a little older," says Skeoch, highlighting the fact that parental support in the classroom is a primary phenomenon. "I couldn't imagine doing the same thing in a secondary school."

This isn't just a result of children's desire for independence. Practical constraints limit the opportunities for parents to help secondary teachers. Many are at work, the school is often farther away and the buildings are often a maze of corridors and levels. But there are other hurdles.

"It's a different culture," said one primary head. "Less open, less accessible, less welcoming." His opinion is supported by a research study carried out by Gill Crozier of Bath Spa University College. Crozier found that primary parents felt a part of the school community. "They knew the teachers better and tended to know other parents... at secondary school there was a greater tendency to be marginalised."

But even in the primary phase, curriculum developments have complicated the situation for parents who just want to drop into their school and help out.

John Bowers is head of Barnes Farm and, whilst welcoming the time given by parents like Lesley Skeoch, he points out that literacy and numeracy initiatives have changed the tempo of the primary day.

"It can be very intense, for the children as well as the teacher," he says. Teachers may not have the time to brief a parent on the work being covered and the role they need to fill. "To suddenly arrive on the doorstep unannounced is impractical," he says. "The ideal is the parent who comes in regularly at a set time."

There are few horror stories to tell about parent helpers, "usually parents select themselves," said one head. One well-meaning parent decided to discipline a pupil whose bad behaviour the teacher seemed to be ignoring. A few seconds into a stern talking-to, the child launched into a violent tantrum, chairs were thrown around the room and the aftermath occupied the rest of the morning. "The teacher knew that Simon would settle down, she also knew that to confront him would be a mistake - something the parent found out the hard way."

Lesley Skeoch seems confident that she is unlikely to make the same mistake. Whilst happy to supervise a small group of readers, she emphasises that discipline is the teacher's responsibility. Like most parents who help in the classroom, she does so because she enjoys it, and she might carry on with the work after her children have moved on to secondary school.

"I do this for my own enjoyment and for what I get out of it," she says. "Hopefully the school gets something out of it as well."

Parents thinking of volunteering to help in the classroom should consider the following ground rules:

 Be prepared to set aside a regular time each week.

 Ask the headteacher how you could best support the school.

 Respect the teacher's authority in the classroom - it's their class.

 Do not discuss children's progress or behaviour with other parents.

 Spend some time getting to know the teacher before starting to help in the class.

 Your child may benefit from your involvement but do not expect to support them directly.

Next week in the third part of our series for parents - parent governors

fields.headline: Key stages on disc
fields.trailText: Teachers will be able to compile their own classroom tests for key stages 1, 2 and 3 with the help of sophisticated software developed by the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority.
fields.body:
Teachers will be able to compile their own classroom tests for key stages 1, 2 and 3 with the help of sophisticated software developed by the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority.

The new TestBase CD-Rom being sent free to state schools next month is what the QCA boasts is "the complete key stage test and resource package", designed as a flexible tool to support classroom revision and preparation for the crucial tests.

It's more than just a database of questions, for at its heart is the past five years' test material, commentary on how pupils have answered the questions, plus the QCA's own national test standards reports for maths, English and science at key stages 1, 2 and 3. But critically, teachers can adapt the database, select questions by topic, level and type, print out selected material and personalise it, and assess with the help of mark schemes. Tailor-made tests can be used to help children improve in those areas where their performance is weakest, and compare their results to the national picture.

The software has been developed by TestBase project manager Laura Lassman, a former secondary school science teacher, who says teachers have been key to the design. "When I was a teacher I saw so much material that hadn't been anywhere near a teacher. It was important to get teachers to tell us what they wanted that was useful and practical".

It comes with basic instructions, and the QCA is training local education authorities to train teachers to use it. Lassman says it is easy and quick to use, and once teachers know the system, they will discover added benefits - such as its scope to target the differing needs and abilities of individual pupils - giving one more tuition in algebra and another in angles, for example. She believes it will also provide help in the classroom in other ways, eg assisting teachers taking "cover lessons".

The CD-Rom includes a demo version of the software, but to access each TestBase subject and key stage you need a registration number, which costs £25.

fields.headline: Talents not being tapped
fields.standfirst: Teachers' assistants are bringing about great results in classrooms all over the country, but they need more support, says  John Bald
fields.trailText: Teachers' assistants are bringing about great results in classrooms all over the country, but they need more support
fields.body:
One of Ann Wood's pupils with hearing difficulties recently made three years' progress in maths in a year, according to an independent assessment. As a teaching assistant at Olga Primary School in Tower Hamlets, London, she has completed the government's Specialist Teacher Assistant course, an additional City and Guilds Certificate in work with special needs, and has had further mathematics training through BEAM, a group of consultants associated with the national numeracy strategy.

With the school's deputy head, Wood devises programmes in mathematics finely tuned to individual needs, and teaches them with a close focus on the development of each child.

Assistants like Wood, often drawing on the parental experience that led to the derisive epithet Mums' Army, are playing a key part in meeting government targets in literacy and numeracy, but are not getting the credit or opportunities they deserve. The growth in the number of assistants employed during the past 10 years has been phenomenal - the last estimate by the Department for Education and Employment was that 90,000 were employed in all types of school, and 5,000 new posts were promised last Easter through the Additional Literacy Support scheme.

However, most assistants have no employment security whatsoever, and can and do lose their jobs through squeezes in school budgets, or even simply because one pupil with special educational needs has left their school. The government's promise that training to an approved standard would be available to all assistants and the most able and committed could go on to qualify as teachers has not begun to happen. It is time to ask why, and to do something about it.

The assistants' predicament is a prime example of the effects of Tony Blair's "forces of conservatism", led, on this occasion, by the education department. The department supervised the original training course for Specialist Teacher Assistants in infant schools, which offered assistants training to university standard, including credits towards degrees or other qualifications, including NVQs. This was assessed by HMI and generally found to be effective, and commonsense would have suggested expansion of the work to assistants in junior and secondary schools.

However, Sir Humphrey dug his heels in, prevented any expansion of the scope of the training and in effect ensured that there was no nationally approved training available for assistants working with children older than seven. This was followed by a turf war between the department and the Teacher Training Agency, which prevented any significant contribution to the work from that quarter, including any new schemes for qualified teacher status. Those of us whose main concern was to ensure that assistants had the training they needed were amazed at this bone-headed obstructionism, and are more amazed yet that it should still be in place.

The department's attitude, however, has been complemented by resistance - often covert - from professional associations determined to defend existing hierarchies, and by teacher training institutions that are fighting to retain as much of their autonomy as possible in the face of government policies to which many of their leaders are personally opposed.

It would, for example, be a very simple operation to devise a distance-learning course for assistants that could be carried out, with external support, in their own school, with minimal disruption to their working hours and families. Units could be based on specific teaching skills, linked to the national literacy and numeracy strategies, and complemented by more advanced reading supervised by a tutor to degree standard.

Special arrangements would be needed to ensure initial qualifications in GCSE English and mathematics for those who did not already have them - although a surprising number of assistants are now graduates - and the service could look forward to a small but steady stream of experienced, qualified and highly motivated teachers. This would be particularly helpful in areas such as Newham in London, where the stability of school staffing is threatened by property prices and where incomers do not always have the same understanding of local children as people who have brought up their own children in the community.

Because most assistants, like Ann Wood, have family commitments that would prevent them from qualifying as teachers through the normal full-time route, the course needs to be brought to them, and integrated into the work they are doing.

This would, however, take a strong lead from a central authority with a clear vision of what assistants can achieve, and the means to put the necessary courses into place. If existing authorities and providers can't or won't do it, the government should create new ones that will.

David Blunkett has shown he is prepared to drive new ideas forward. If he really wants to release the full potential of assistants for the benefit of children in schools, he will have to take forceful personal action, and not let up until he has shaken the hands of the first batch of graduates.

This would, however, take a strong lead from a central authority with a clear vision of what assistants can achieve, and the means to put the necessary courses into place. If existing authorities and providers can't or won't do it, the government should create new ones that will. David Blunkett has shown he is prepared to drive new ideas forward. If he really wants to release the full potential of assistants for the benefit of children in schools, he will have to take forceful personal action, and not let up until he has shaken the hands of the first batch of graduates.

fields.headline: Virtually there
fields.trailText: One of the most intriguing attractions at last week's BETT show was the live demonstration of a lesson given by Britain's first "virtual" teacher.
fields.body:
One of the most intriguing attractions at last week's BETT show was the live demonstration of a lesson given by Britain's first "virtual" teacher. Even a few technical hitches failed to take the gloss off the event, which even got a mention by technology and learning minister Michael Wills in his opening speech at the show.

Wills stressed that even the rapid pace of new technology will never see computers replace teachers. In fact, he said, new technology would in many ways allow teachers to return to their original role in the classroom and "liberate" them to teach.

Maths teacher Catharine Darnton, the "guinea pig" teleported live from the exhibition hall in Olympia to a classroom at her school in Tooting, south London, agreed "virtual" teaching had its drawbacks. "You could not use it where discipline was an issue," she said. "And you couldn't take a pupil aside for a quiet word in their ear!"

That apart, visitors flocked to internet provider Edex's stand to peer at the screen picture of Ms Darnton's maths pupils at Graveney School simultaneously gawping at her. Her image - technically not a hologram but a life-size "deep 2-dimensional" outline against a dark background - was being shown to her pupils on a screen at the front of a classroom. She talked and gestured as if she were standing before them, held two-way question and answer sessions and even made eye contact with pupils. She also read and correct their written work via an interactive monitor.

The prototype project has been developed by Edex, initially with help from Graveney, an academically highly successful school at the cutting edge of new technology and raising classroom standards. Edex's marketing director Neil McGhee says they aim to refine the technology and reduce the bulk of the kit so that it can be fitted into a portable suitcase. Local authorities could then buy it for schools and colleges to share at minimal cost.

fields.headline: Young at heart
fields.standfirst: Tory MP Quentin Davies encounters parties and postmodernism as he takes up media studies at Luton University; Dai John, Luton's vice-chancellor, replies
fields.trailText: Tory MP Quentin Davies encounters parties and postmodernism as he takes up media studies at Luton University; Dai John, Luton's vice-chancellor, replies
fields.body:
A Tory MP at Luton University studying - guess what? - Media Arts. Clearly a BBC producer had had a brainwave.

When I received the invitation to spend three days at Luton living in a hostel, and being treated like any other student, I hesitated for about two minutes. Was I being "set up"? Almost certainly yes. Was that a reason to turn down the opportunity to see a new university from the inside, to look at a new subject, to get a feel for modern student life, and to see the world from the vantage point of today's 20-year-old? Almost certainly not.

The first night started well. We were kindly cooked a meal by some of our flatmates in the hostel where we were staying. The conversation flowed with increasing naturalness and good humour. But there was little chance of sleep. Until 4 in the morning the courtyard outside the hostel reverberated to the sounds of revelry - students returning from parties or clubs. Most surprisingly, this was only Monday and there seemed no special cause for celebration.

I could only hope that after one sleepless night I would be sufficiently tired the next night not to notice. I was.

Lectures the next morning were based on clips of various TV drama series and soap operas. Many of the points made were technical - why a particular camera angle was chosen rather than another, or how figures were composed within the frame of the camera. I had never looked at television that way before and I enjoyed it.

The course seemed to shy away from analysis of substance - even in the case of classic feature films that would have warranted it. There seemed to be little attempt to develop a rigorous critical faculty in the students. One lecturer conceded publicly that, since most of his students aspired to a career in television, he would risk demotivating them if he encouraged them to see how superficial and unoriginal so much of the content of television is. That of course was depressing - I'd have hoped he would aspire to help a new generation raise its game.

Another lecturer was clearly - I think largely unconsciously - in the grip of postmodernism: it all depended on what you liked, it was impossible to make objective value judgments or establish a hierarchy of quality.

There was one venture into content: a very politically correct discussion of racial and sexual stereotypes. Almost as many cliches were expressed in the lecture room as in the soap opera clip on which the discussion was based. On a measure of value added, the session would not have scored high.

The practical classes that afternoon and the next day made good sense. We were trained to write a press release, read the news, audition for parts and conduct an audition ourselves. One former actress brought immense flair and enthusiasm to her teaching. No one noticed the passing of time.

Did I learn anything from my brief immersion in media studies? Yes - both about the subject itself and the way it is taught.

Did I gain any insight into the psyche or life styles of the modern student? Yes: most things don't change - and human nature certainly doesn't. Is Luton University doing an honest job, and would passing a degree there in media studies be a good foundation for a career in the sector? Yes, on both counts.

Could they do better? Yes, again. And I think they should start by increasing the pace and the workload, setting rigorous and regular tests, and teaching their students not to be afraid to second-guess the current standards of composition, production and editing, in journalism and television.

Quentin Davies is MP for Grantham and Stamford.

Dai John: Should the University of Luton allow three MPs to experience a three-year course in just three days? Almost certainly not. Though Media Arts was rated "excellent" by the Quality Assurance Agency, there was a danger that the MPs would make definitive judgments about an ephemeral experience.

All modules in our media courses are rigorously structured on a 50-50 theory-practice basis, and we would have liked the BBC to film the theoretical components of the degree programme. But the BBC has made a lively political documentary.

fields.headline: Oxford calling
fields.standfirst: Some of Oxford's more forward-looking colleges are making a bid to woo further education students, while resisting the temptation to lower their standards
fields.trailText: Some of Oxford's more forward-looking colleges are making a bid to woo further education students, while resisting the temptation to lower their standards
fields.body:
In a society in which rewards are increasingly unequal, it becomes ever more important to equalise opportunities. All societies have elites: healthy societies have several.

The populist notion that we can live in a world without elites is as fatuous and as dangerous as the notion that we can live in a world without power. But an open society needs open elites, and modern Britain's elites are nothing like open enough. We no longer live in the world of Hilaire Belloc's Lord Lundy:

We had intended you to be The next Prime Minister but three The stocks were sold; the press was squared The Middle Class was quite prepared But as it is!... My language fails! Go out and govern New South Wales!

But we still have a long way to go before we satisfy the basic democratic imperative that careers should be open to talent.

Oxbridge has a central role to play in satisfying it. Oxford and Cambridge are unashamedly - and rightly - elite universities. They may well be the last universities in Europe capable of challenging the dominance of the American ivy league; and it would be a disaster for European, as well as British culture if they lost their ability to do so.

They provide a superbly good undergraduate education - how good, only those who have taught elsewhere in the British university system can appreciate - and no one would gain if it were allowed to deteriorate. They nurture talent and give it room to flower. Though their graduates no longer dominate our elites in the way that they did as recently as 50 years ago, an Oxbridge degree still opens more doors than most.

By any standards, then, access to Oxford is a rich prize. We have an obligation to make it available to those most likely to benefit from it, irrespective of their means or background or schooling. We try to do that now. But, with the best will in the world, we are not as successful as we ought to be. Two-thirds of the sixth-formers who get three As at A level are in the state sector, yet only half our entrants come from that sector. This is not due to deliberate discrimination on the part of admissions tutors.

The notion that admission to Oxford is controlled by snobs from public schools, anxious to down the state sector, is a fantasy. The foolish anti-elitism that sometimes accompanied the comprehensive revolution and the widening gap between the private and public sectors have both played a part. But it is too easy to sit back and blame social trends, or economic forces, or previous governments. What matters is that there is a large pool of talent in state schools which Oxford does not tap at present, and which we ought to tap - for the university's sake as well as for the sake of the wider society and of the young people who would benefit.

Part of the problem is that in a collegiate university, in which 30 self-governing institutions admit and teach undergraduates, it is difficult to mount major, and inevitably risky, new advances from the centre. All too often, the need for consensus dampens enthusiasm and slows the pace of reform. Progress is more likely to come from radical initiatives at the periphery, which will be imitated elsewhere if they succeed.

After a lot of careful thought, Mansfield College (fully supported by the university) recently decided that it was time for it to take just such an initiative. The college has always been committed to widening access to Oxford. As a congregationalist foundation, originally set up in the wake of Gladstone's legislation breaking the Anglican monopoly of the ancient universities, its ethos has always been open, democratic and iconoclastic. And having become a full college of the university four years ago, it is now in a better position to break new ground.

Accordingly, we have now launched an ambitious access initiative, designed to raise our own state-sector entry by around 15% over six years, without lowering standards. At 58% of the total, our state-sector entry is already much higher than the university average, but we are confident that we can raise it well above that without quotas or "positive discrimination" and without sacrificing our commitment to academic excellence.

We plan to do this by targeting further education colleges, the sector with the lowest Oxford application rate. Four other Oxford colleges - Harris Manchester, Hertford, Keble and St. Hugh's - have so far agreed to join us; and we are now looking for a fifth. We see ourselves as a lever of change in the university as a whole, not just as collegiate entrepreneurs.

Applications to Oxford from FE colleges - not including sixth-form colleges - for the year 1999-2000 totalled 379; the success rate was just under 30%. Applications from independent schools for the same year totalled 3,778, with a success rate of 44.5%. Of course, special factors need to be taken into account. Some FE colleges have few A-level students and specialise in vocational and recreational courses. But that is not a reason for doing nothing.

After surveying selected FE colleges and holding a remarkably productive workshop with relevant FE teachers, we are convinced that there is an untapped pool of suitable talent in the sector, and that the chief reason why it is untapped is that the application rate to Oxford is too low. We are also convinced that we can and should take positive steps to break down the barriers created by habit, ignorance, lack of self-confidence and (in some cases) negative stereotyping which have kept the rate low in the past.

We shall offer places to FE candidates on the same basis that we offer places to all other candidates: because we believe, on the basis of the evidence available to us, that they have the potential to benefit from the special kind of education that Oxford offers. The object is to attract more candidates from the sector. We have no intention of offering places to unworthy candidates.

How will it work? Three aspects of the scheme seem to us crucial. In the first place, we want to raise funds to employ a dedicated access officer, with experience of the FE sector, to act as an assistant to the admissions tutor. He or she would act as a kind of missionary, making personal approaches to selected colleges, visiting them and meeting interested students.

Second, we want to establish individual mentoring links, by mail or email, between existing Mansfield students and FE students who are wondering whether to apply.

Third, and perhaps most important, we are seeking funding to enable us to mount a special induction programme for candidates who have received an offer of a place and gained the expected grades, before they take up their places.

All of these will require resources which, as the poorest college in the university, we do not yet possess. But it is the hinge on which our newly launched development campaign turns, and we are looking to the future with confidence.

 David Marquand is principal of Mansfield College, Oxford.

fields.headline: Rising stars
fields.standfirst:
Some universities are seeing results from their attempts to invest in research programmes, says Lee Elliot Major
The rankings can be viewed in the research services area on this ISI web page
fields.trailText: Some universities are seeing results from their attempts to invest in research programmes
fields.body:
Counting citations of academic research papers often reflects emerging scientific fields and new experimental techniques, rather than the most influential scientific thinkers of the day, yet the UK's citation superstars make an interesting list, none the less.

Compiling the numbers of references to research publications for UK academics over the last decade, the newsletter for the US-based Institute of Scientific Information has come up with two tables of the country's 30 most cited researchers in the biomedical and physical sciences.

According to the analysis by the publication Science Watch, Salvador Moncada from University College London is the most cited UK researcher over the last decade, highlighting the growing influence of nitric oxide-based studies in the biomedical sciences in recent years. Moncada's joint 1991 Nitric Oxide Paper, with Richard Palmer (sixth on the list), in Pharmacological Reviews has now been cited more than 6,500 times and is one of the decade's most-cited papers. Two scientists at the University of Dundee, David Lane and Philip Cohen, come second and third in the ranking for biomedical citation heavyweights.

"Officials at Dundee took the very un-British tack of investing substantially and calculatedly in building research programmes and attracting talent to the university," comment the accompanying notes by Science Watch. "The present list suggests that, at least in terms of scientific influence as measured by citations, the effort may be paying off."

Cambridge, meanwhile, registers strongly on the physical sciences ranking, fielding nearly a third of the list and three of the five top-cited researchers. Richard Friend of the Cavendish Laboratory, whose research on light-emitting polymers and other materials has attracted over 7,000 citations during the decade, heads the list for physical scientists. Other famous scientists ranked include the discoverer of the third form of carbon, buckminsterfullerene, Harry Kroto, at the University of Sussex.

In all, chemistry, or the multidisciplinary area of chemical-physics, predominates in the physical sciences rankings. Exceptions include astrophysics or cosmology.

To identify the citation superstars, Science Watch used the ISI database of 10m published research papers worldwide to identify researchers with UK affiliations whose papers published since 1990 have been collectively cited more than 1,000 times.

Nearly all the most-cited researchers in the physical sciences table collected fewer citations during the 1990s than those in the biomedical sciences table.

Biomedical stars

Biomedical scientists ranked by total citations to papers published and cited between 1990 and June, 1999

(Rank, Name, Affiliation, Citations):

1. Salvador Moncada (FRS), University College London, 30,081.

2. David P Lane (FRS), University of Dundee, 16,857.

3. Philip Cohen (FRS), University of Dundee, 14,208.

4. Richard S J Frackowiak, Institute of Neurology, 13,932.

5. Peter J Barnes, Imperial College, 13,507.

6. Richard M J Palmer, Alizyme, 13,501.

7. A Barry Kay, Imperial College, 10,656.

8. Stephen T Holgate, University of Southampton, 8,728.

9. Christopher J Marshall (FRS), Institute of Cancer Research, 8,622.

10. Andrew H Wyllie (FRS), University of Edinburgh, 8,333.

Physical science stars

Physical scientists ranked by total citations to papers published and cited between 1990 and June, 1999.

(Rank, Name, Affiliation, Citations):

1. Richard H Friend (FRS), University of Cambridge, 7,204.

2. Andrew B Holmes, University of Cambridge, 6,427.

3. Donal D C Bradley, University of Sheffield, 5,612.

4. J Fraser Stoddart (FRS), University of Birmingham, 5,295.

5. Andrew C Fabian (FRS), University of Cambridge, 5,184.

6. Harold W Kroto (FRS), University of Sussex, 4,812.

7. George Efstathiou (FRS), University of Cambridge, 4,518.

8. Roger Taylor, University of Sussex, 4,448.

9. Michael B Hursthouse, University of Southampton, 4,362.

10. David J Williams, Imperial College, 4,347.

Dr Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight

webTitle: A good year for university customers

fields.headline: A good year for university customers
fields.trailText: One or two familiar faces are missing from lectures as we return to what has now become a familiar routine. Perhaps they're still recovering from Hogmanay or flu, but I suspect that certain of my fellow oldies may have decided that student life is not for them.
fields.body:
One or two familiar faces are missing from lectures as we return to what has now become a familiar routine. Perhaps they're still recovering from Hogmanay or flu, but I suspect that certain of my fellow oldies may have decided that student life is not for them. New Year is traditionally a time to make decisions and I must admit I had some doubts myself.

Perhaps, like many older students, I had read too many novels set in universities without realising how much had changed. Forget Brideshead Revisited, with eccentric tutors quoting Ovid over sherry. Forget the History Man, with sedition in the student bar. A modern university provides a service for its customers. It is a market for degrees. The facilities are excellent; libraries with all the latest books alongside ancient tomes last borrowed in the 1890s; access to computers and rooms equipped for study. There are even certain lecturers who know how to teach. But the customer hould not expect much personal attention.

With one term down and 11 to go, I am just beginning to understand the system. Choose essay subjects early, before the vital books go. Ridicule the views of academics only when you know they work for other universities. Quote as much as possible, ideally from sources that exist. However tedious the lecture, try not to snore. And bear in mind that sometimes, mercifully far off in the future, there will be exams. This is a detail that, for first-year students, can easily be overlooked.

But despite this awakening, I have also discovered the addictive joys of study. In the small hours of the morning, I am oblivious of the quite reasonable demands of my partner or bank manager. Life is reduced to basic needs; whisky, cigarettes and books, as I pursue the golden thread of some arcane idea through layers of argument and theory.

At times like these, I cannot conceive a life of greater privilege. It's tough here in the marketplace, but nothing would induce me to give up and go home empty-handed.

Hamish Scott is studying archaeology at Edinburgh University

webTitle: No sugar coating on NHS pill

fields.headline: No sugar coating on NHS pill
fields.standfirst: Student Lisa Watkinson was shocked to discover that she must pay for vital medication
fields.trailText: Student Lisa Watkinson was shocked to discover that she must pay for vital medication
fields.body:
The days when students were completely subsidised by the government are long gone. But is forcing students to pay for essential health care taking things a step too far? Lisa Watkinson, a second year nursing student at University of Wales, Cardiff, thinks so. She has had severe asthma for 13 years and requires daily medication to keep her condition stable. Last month Lisa was informed by the health benefits division that she would now have to pay for her vital prescriptions. She fails to meet the NHS Low Income Scheme's criteria for financial help, despite being a full-time student.

Lisa is being penalised because she, in common with most students, is eligible for a student loan. The loans from the Student Loans Company are considered income when calculating eligibility for benefits. In an attempt to avoid debt, Lisa chose not to take out a loan. She then discovered that her NHS appraisal still considered the potential income of the loan regardless of whether or not she withdrew the money.

Once students reach the age of 19 they need to apply to the health benefits division for lower cost health care. The NHS determines the charges each student must pay by comparing weekly income to weekly needs. Most students who have a low income have the option of taking out a student loan. Like Lisa, many are then accountable for medical costs, such as dental treatment and prescription charges.

Every six weeks Lisa requires three different prescriptions. The income figure used in Lisa's appraisal included a sum of £23.59 from the loan she did not have. As a result she was informed that her weekly income was £3.28 above her outgoings. Providing her condition does not deteriorate further, she now has to pay £2.96 a week for her prescriptions, a difference of just 32p.

Lisa and her family are outraged by the way the system treats students. "I just could not believe that I was being asked to pay for my prescriptions. It seems ridiculous," Lisa said. "I don't want to take out a student loan just so I can pay for medication. It doesn't seem fair because I'm going to have to pay that loan back." Peter Watkinson, Lisa's father, feels students are being forced into debt. "I've encouraged my daughter not to borrow money and now she gets penalised!" he complained.

The health benefits division has defended its assessment criteria. A spokesperson for the NHS said, "Students are not obliged to take up a loan if they feel no need to do so, but they are made available from public funds for student support and cannot be ignored in calculating entitlement to further help from public funds. In general, student loans are counted as income because that is how the DSS operate. We conform with them and there are no plans at present to change."

Both benefit agencies base their assessment criteria on regulations set more than 10 years ago. Since 1987, any loan used to meet living costs was treated as a source of income. When the government introduced student loans in 1990, the loans were subsequently defined as a resource to cover the cost of student living. For nine years they have been assessed as a form of income, causing severe financial problems for students in Lisa's position.

The national union of students has been campaigning against the benefits system for more than a decade. An NUS spokesperson said: "Student loans are legally defined as income. We cannot argue against that. We can however argue for all students to be completely exempt from all medical charges." She added: "This is a battle we've been fighting for a long time and it affects a sizeable minority."

Lisa's cause has now been taken up by Cheltenham MP, Nigel Jones. She is also being supported by sabbatical officers at Cardiff Students' Union, who are currently planning a campaign on her behalf. Lisa said: "I think it's totally wrong that any student should have to pay towards health care. We are not earning money on a regular basis."

 Jess Boulton is studying English literature at Cardiff University.

fields.headline: Future vision
fields.standfirst: Cash for teachers, royalty and instant, broadband technology were among the draws at last week's Bett 2000 show
fields.trailText: Cash for teachers, royalty and instant, broadband technology were among the draws at last week's Bett 2000 show
fields.body:
The government dipped into its ICT treasure chest again last week, when the technology and learning minister Michael Wills announced that teachers in England can apply for a 50% subsidy towards the cost of buying their own computers, up to a limit of £500. The whole package is worth £20m and comes on a first come, first served basis.

At a packed opening ceremony at the biggest Bett show yet, the minister also announced the first stage of the national roll-out in fast-speed (broadband) internet technology across 80 local education authorities in England, and invited tenders to produce courses using multimedia technologies at key stage 3 as part of a drive to create whole courses with ICT.

He said that with computer power doubling every 18 months, ICT skills had to be constantly refreshed. "These technologies offer vital weapons for democratic empowerment and civic activism for the excluded and the illiterate. If [the digital divide] is not tackled, it will entrench existing inequalities for generations."

Bett's organisers, however, cannot be blamed for a lack of new ideas to encourage teachers. This year, some 600 Birmingham teachers paid a subsidised return fare on two specially chartered trains to Olympia, including ICT training on one.

"It was a brilliant idea," said Ken Morris, deputy head of Harborne Hill Secondary School, Birmingham. "Where I sat down, I got chatting to people about a range of things."

He enjoyed the Birmingham Grid for Learning launch on the Cisco stand. "You can log on to Aston Hall, a stately home which local schools visit. Kids can get background information before they go there."

He was also impressed with IBM's voice facility, which decodes speech to display it as text on screen.

Among the glitz of more than 350 exhibitors this year, software launches all took second place to that of the Home Farm Trust and its partner, special needs software publisher Semerc. Its patron, HRH Princess Anne, arrived for a low-profile, high-security launch of Out and About, a radical piece of software for adult learners. It differs from many programs that treat children and adults the same. "You might have the mental ability of a 10-year-old but you still go to a pub and have a pint," said Semerc's Wendy McHugh. The CD-Rom puts learners in real-life situations such as a shop, a restaurant and a college to teach basic skills in familiar surroundings.

"You're setting a standard here that does not exist anywhere, not even in the States," said the princess. "That's quite a revolution. I hope it will be advertised and well used."

Elsewhere, new software included AngliaCampus's first A-level modules, focusing on Russian history and offering immediate feedback to the student. The first units in English and modern languages should be available by mid-March. Its HomeCampus service, currently subscription-based, will be free on the net from next month. The spring should also see Anglia's Number Spiral, a 3D mental calculator to improve key skills within the national numeracy strategy.

Buying software could become much easier now that Compaq has launched its NonStop Learning Store at Teachers tap in what they need and are then directed to the appropriate vendors' sites that together offer 12,000 titles. The eventual aim is to enable all titles to be downloadable from the net.

Microsoft previewed the final version of Windows 2000, which is due here in late February and is claimed to be more robust and secure than Windows 95 and 98. Meanwhile, Red Hat, a company promoting the free Linux operating system downloadable from the net, says Microsoft has a fight on its hands. The advantage, claims Red Hat's Colin Tenwick, is that Linux can be run on most 486 and 386 machines, often left redundant when new Windows versions come in. "Also, why pay $3-4,000 per server when you can get a Linux product for $150?" This debate will run and run.

Operating systems apart, Microsoft was also showing its impressive e-book technology, due in the UK this summer. Not only is it possible to download thousands of full texts of your favourite authors onto a paperback-sized screen, but they can be read in comfort thanks to a special font known as ClearType, with which the company claims to have solved the problem of screen resolution.

E-books save on paper while Tiny Computers saves on PCs. The company is offering a two-in-one computer, known as the Synchro - one hard disk, but two screens, two keyboards, two headphones and two sets of speakers - at £849 all in. The Synchro screens can be placed side by side or in different rooms, and they behave like separate machines.

Interactive digital TV drew a lot of interest, not least from government, partway through its GCSE pilots. NTL launched its Knowledge Channel aimed at home learning, Granada was there with its Result service, while Espresso impressed the Bett award judges to win the innovation category (runner-up was Teachers Evaluating Educational Multimedia). Using satellite links, a mere single click on screen brings up instant, TV quality video. Broadband is coming - with a vengeance.
