fields.headline: No 10 seizes on Ken gaffe
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone last night appeared to have struck a damaging blow to his campaign to become mayor of London when he publicly allied himself with anarchist rioters in the city of London and protesters at last year's Seattle trade conference.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone last night appeared to have struck a damaging blow to his campaign to become mayor of London when he publicly allied himself with anarchist rioters in the city of London and protesters at last year's Seattle trade conference.

In an interview with The Face magazine, the Brent East MP declared he had always supported "direct action".

And, in an example of dry Livingstone humour which may come back to haunt him, the leftwing MP pledged that, following the Seattle conference, he would never invite the World Trade Organisation to London "unless we get vast stocks in so we can throw stuff at them in an organised way".

Downing Street, dreading the increasingly plausible prospect of Mr Livingstone as Labour mayoral candidate, seized on the comments as evidence of the former GLC leader's unfitness to run London. Sources close to Tony Blair described it as "the sort of gesture politics the prime minister has made it absolutely clear he does not want to see the Labour party go back to". Mr Livingstone would now have to explain himself, the sources added.

In the interview Mr Livingstone said: "I've always been in favour of direct action. One of my fondest memories was chasing the inspector of the Archway Road inquiry out on to the roof at Central Hall."

Downing Street's approved candidate, Frank Dobson, said last night: "These comments are quite disgraceful from anyone seeking to be mayor of London with responsibility for the police."

fields.headline: The gold rush for genes
fields.standfirst:
It must be stopped: they belong to us

Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Human genes should not be the subject of patents. Processes and applications that arise from their discovery yes: but the genes themselves, never. And if the law - in Britain or Europe - is capable of being interpreted otherwise then the law must be changed. In a civilised world it should not be necessary even to have a discussion about this: but it is both necessary and urgent because of the imperialistic way some American biology companies are trying to claim the products of evolution.
fields.body:
Human genes should not be the subject of patents. Processes and applications that arise from their discovery yes: but the genes themselves, never. And if the law - in Britain or Europe - is capable of being interpreted otherwise then the law must be changed. In a civilised world it should not be necessary even to have a discussion about this: but it is both necessary and urgent because of the imperialistic way some American biology companies are trying to claim the products of evolution. The latest, as reported in this paper yesterday, is the Salt Lake City corporation, Myriad Genetics, which claims to have "patented" two genes for breast-cancer screening (BRCA and BRCA2) and is moving in on the European market to exploit what they hope will be a monopoly position. A European directive on patents, to be incorporated in British law in the summer, is ambiguous on the topic. In this instance, Myriad's claims are themselves in dispute because of the pioneering work done in this country by Cambridge's prestigious Sanger Institute and the Institute of Cancer Research (which claims that it discovered one of the genes first).

Either way it should not be patentable and especially not by privately owned corporations which often come on to the scene late in the day after the huge cost of basic research has been done by publicly funded institutes like Sanger, which put their discoveries into the public domain for free. This is altruism, but it also makes business sense because all the pharmaceutical and biotech companies can then have access to all of the research. If they then devise processes using those gene sequences to make themselves lots of money, that is fine. It can take a decade and hundreds of millions of pounds to bring one of these discoveries to market and most are abandoned long before they get that far.

Corporations rightly require profits proportionate to the big risks they take. No one argues with that. But it does not mean they can rush in at the last minute and patent the rights to the basic ingredients of human life. It is like a company joining a gold rush after all the research and mining has been done to snap up all the nuggets lying around. Who owns the blueprints of life is one of the most important issues to be faced during a century expected to witness an explosion of activity in biotech industries. The ground rules of this revolution must be established hard and fast: and now.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText:
Free
An internet site opened yesterday promising investors free share dealing - and notched up more than 1,000 trades. Deal4free.com is based on "contracts for difference", financial instruments with a real-time price link to specific shares. Investors do not own the shares but bet a minimum of £5,000 on their movements.
fields.body:
Free
An internet site opened yesterday promising investors free share dealing - and notched up more than 1,000 trades. Deal4free.com is based on "contracts for difference", financial instruments with a real-time price link to specific shares. Investors do not own the shares but bet a minimum of £5,000 on their movements.

Mobiles
Aim-listed internet company On-line plc said it had added a wireless application protocol (WAP) feature to its web-based Advanced Financial Network investor service. The Alerts feature allows prospective investors to register an interest in particular shares and set criteria for receiving an alert on their PC screens or mobile phones.

Investing
Advertising group WPP said yesterday it had invested in three media companies through its subsidiary wwp.com. The group has spent £5m purchasing a 20% stake in new venture e-Rewards. It is also investing in TWIinteractive, the new media and technology arm of Mark McCormack's International Management Group, and making a £4.9m investment in Concept! a German new media company.

fields.headline: Vivendi boosts backing for Scoot
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Scoot.com has issued ambitious new subscriber number forecasts after winning increased financial backing from French group Vivendi.
fields.body:
Scoot.com has issued ambitious new subscriber number forecasts after winning increased financial backing from French group Vivendi.

The internet directory service, which says it is the victim of a smear campaign after "anonymous and malicious" claims about its subscriber figures, predicted that Vivendi's support and a strategic shift will enable it to increase subscriber numbers from the current level of 19,000 to 60,000 by the end of 2000. By December 2002 Scoot believes it will have 200,000 subscribers.

Vivendi has decided to increase its investment in Scoot to £110m over three years and secure an option to increase its shareholding to as much as 15.6% at a later date - despite being sent a copy of the mysterious dossier.

"We wouldn't be making such a commitment if we hadn't looked very closely at the Scoot business model," said Vivendi's Ariane de Lamaze.

Scoot chief executive Robert Bonnier said the launch of new technology, the adoption of indirect sales channels and a European expansion in conjunction with Vivendi will be crucial to the company hitting its targets.

Vivendi's wide ranging communications assets - which include stakes in television broadcasters BSkyB and Canal Plus - will be used to accelerate Scoot's brand recognition and subscriber penetration.

Mr Bonnier said that Scoot had employed a private detective agency to find the source of the 100-page dossier. Sources close to the company believe that it could be the work of a disgruntled former employee.

In the full year ending last September, Scoot's revenues fell by 14% to £15.9m but losses were cut from £19.4m to £16.8m. Scoot shares, cheered by Vivendi's commitment, climbed 9% to 156.75p.

webTitle: Six on shortlist to take over dome

fields.headline: Six on shortlist to take over dome
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday announced a shortlist of six bids to take over the Millennium Dome, which is likely to be relaunched as a permanent visitor attraction after its 365 days as the centrepiece of Britain's millennium celebrations.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The government yesterday announced a shortlist of six bids to take over the Millennium Dome, which is likely to be relaunched as a permanent visitor attraction after its 365 days as the centrepiece of Britain's millennium celebrations.

Undaunted by the dwindling crowds and swelling criticism, six consortia have announced plans for the site, mostly envisaging it as a futuristic theme park, with attached hotels, shops and restaurants.

Lord Falconer, the minister responsible for the the dome, said all the bids were of high quality.

He said more detail will now be sought from the shortlisted consortia, and two or three will then be invited to develop full proposals.

The proposals are:

 City of the Future, a technology theme park, with the largest covered water features and rides in Europe. The dome would be the centre of a 120-acre complex. The consortium includes the South African property and leisure group Monex, and MEPC, the UK real estate group, who project 6-12m visitors a year;

 Dome Europe, a leisure, business and technology centre, which would retain and upgrade most of the present zones, and add new development, including an international trade centre. The backers include the Japanese Nomura group;

 Greenwich Media World, which would redevelop the dome as Media City, with a flexible auditorium and entertainment and education facilities based on film, television and the internet. Media City projects 2m visitors a year, and is backed by Sir Robert McAlpine and the Tussauds Group;

 International Merchandise and Culture Centre, a global one stop shop for goods, technology and tourism services, with a "cybertainment" centre. The consortium suggests it will attract up to 20m visitors a year, and has Malaysian and South African backers;

 Legacy PLC, which sees a phased transition from the present dome facilities to a flexible workspace/business centre, possibly with residential units inside the dome itself;

 Sports Dome 2001, which promises facilities for a huge array of sports, including an indoor 22,000 seat arena, and Peninsula City on the remaining land with a sports institute and educational facilties, hotels and convention centres and housing. The backers have the most ambitious visitor projections of any of the schemes, up to 40m visitors, and include property company Chelsfield, and sports sponsorship consultant John Taylor International.

British Airways last night said the delay-hit millennium wheel would now not be open to paying members of the public until March 1.

webTitle: Pay rises will put squeeze on NHS

fields.headline: Pay rises will put squeeze on NHS
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Hospitals are being told they must bear the full cost of the inflation-plus pay rises announced yesterday for all their staff, including 7.8% for experienced ward nurses, as the NHS seeks to recover from the ravages of the flu outbreak.
fields.body:
Hospitals are being told they must bear the full cost of the inflation-plus pay rises announced yesterday for all their staff, including 7.8% for experienced ward nurses, as the NHS seeks to recover from the ravages of the flu outbreak.

Ministers made clear there would be no extra funding for the rises over and above the increase of 6.8% in cash terms, or 4.3% after allowing for inflation, already allocated to local health authorities.

Health managers admitted they did have enough money to cope. But they warned there would be little left to invest in the kind of new, improved services demanded by Tony Blair as hard evidence of the government's commitment to modernise the health service.

Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation, which represents health authorities and trusts, said the coming financial year would be "one of our toughest on record".

The pay awards and offers for almost 1m health workers were largely well received and last night appeared to have bought the government a breathing space after the past fortnight's torrent of criticism of the state of health care.

However, a Guardian/ICM opinion poll today shows strong public backing for further pay rises for nurses, doctors and ambulance crews, as well as teachers, and pay cuts for ministers, MPs and senior civil servants.

Yesterday's rises, effective from April, represent government acceptance in full of pay review body recommendations for nurses, midwives, health visitors and therapists, who get 3.4%, and doctors and dentists, who get 3.3%. Inflation is currently 2.2%.

In addition, the government confirmed it was offering other health workers a radical, three-year pay deal, backdated to last April, giving them an above-inflation increase each year. The overall impact on hospitals is likely to be an increase of 3.6% in their pay bills for 2000/01, accounting for a quarter of their increased funds. But John Denham, health minister, said they would get no additional government help.

"We made an allocation, a good one well ahead of inflation, for the health service at local level from which they have to meet all of their expenses," Mr Denham said. "It's nonsense to suggest there is any contradiction between paying staff and paying for the rest of the health service.

"If a local hospital is able to avoid staffing difficulties, if it can recruit and retain its nurses, then it is delivering extra services to patients with those extra resources."

Ministers were yesterday refusing to be drawn on what the NHS could get in cash terms if the government succeeds in achieving Mr Blair's ambition, revealed on Sunday, to get British health spending in line with the European average within the next six years. Estimates stretch to £16bn, more than a third as much again as the current budget.

The TUC is suggesting that the government could spend an extra £31bn on public services as a whole over the next three years without breaking the treasury's rules for balancing its books. In its submission to the government's next three-year spending round, the TUC says the cash is available because the treasury has revised upwards its estimate of how fast the economy can grow while re-basing its spending projections on a lower limit.

The big winners from yesterday's pay awards will be 60,000 staff nurses stuck at the top of their grade E scale. Through the creation of an extra scale point they will get a 7.8% rise, worth almost £1,400 a year, which will put them on a basic £19,220. The health department says that, on average, such nurses earn an extra £2,000 from allowances.

Also benefiting from the creation of extra scale points are 5,500 long-serving enrolled nurses and nursing auxiliaries stuck at the top of grade C, who similarly get a 7% rise, and 4,500 experienced physiotherapists, occupational therapists and others who get 8.4%.

After last year's pay awards helped boost recruitment to nursing by raising starting pay substantially, this year's are seen as a move to improve the retention of existing staff. There are about 15,000 nursing vacancies.

Andrew Foster, human resources director of the NHS Confederation, said a qualified nurse working full time, with a typical range of allowances, would be earning well over £20,000 a year.

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said it was "encouraging" that nurses would be getting an above-inflation rise, paid in full, for a second successive year.

fields.headline: NHS bonanza...
fields.standfirst:
As long as Tony Blair keeps his pledge

Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The media's fury over the underfunding of the national health service is almost 1,000 days too late. The fuss should have been made - as it was in these columns - in the first and second years of this government. That was Labour's biggest mistake, when it stuck to Conservative spending targets - targets which the Tories would never have followed - producing the biggest squeeze on the health service since the late 1980s.
fields.body:
The media's fury over the underfunding of the national health service is almost 1,000 days too late. The fuss should have been made - as it was in these columns - in the first and second years of this government. That was Labour's biggest mistake, when it stuck to Conservative spending targets - targets which the Tories would never have followed - producing the biggest squeeze on the health service since the late 1980s. Pay awards were not just below inflation, but staged. Services were seriously curtailed, waiting lists rose and staff and patient morale plummeted. It was in this period that Labour lost its crucial political asset: public confidence in its ability to handle the health service. By last September, a Guardian/ICM poll found 41% of the public believed the health service was getting worse - and only 14% could see any improvement. Ironically, by last September, resuscitation had already belatedly begun. Labour's three-year spending programme, which began last April, is giving the health service a serious injection of resources.

Even so, the £9bn real increase over this next three years, is not enough. Even the prime minister has belatedly said so. He could not have been more specific in his Sunday morning television interview: the health service was not getting enough; Germany had a better service because it was spending much more; it would take time to cure the NHS, but he promised by 2006 UK health spending would have been lifted to the average for the European Union. Put that in your pipe and smoke it, Gordon Brown. Not even a chancellor of the exchequer will be able to challenge such a publicly pronounced change of policy. Time for friends of the NHS to celebrate.

The precise size of this new injection is difficult to calculate. Downing Street estimates it would require a 5% real increase for each of the next six years, lifting spending by £9bn in real terms. OECD statistics, which show UK spending 6.8% of national income compared to Europe's 8%, would require a £12bn increase to close the gap. An independent analyst yesterday suggested the gap was 1.8% requiring a £16 bn increase. It may be narrower because French and German spending, much higher than ours, is coming down. The moving target may be imprecise, but it remains a good one.

Congratulations are due on other fronts. Mr Blair was right to reject charges and private insurance. The first are administratively expensive and the second would not help the people most in need: the elderly. Even more important, he was not bounced into just concentrating on hospitals. One danger of the current row, like earlier ones where the spotlight was on hospitals, was that primary care which deals with nine out of 10 NHS patients, would get forgotten. It has not been, although Labour is in danger of falling into the same trap as the Tories, expanding pilot programmes - in this case walk-in clinics and the new NHS telephone helpline - before a proper evaluation has been made.

Yesterday's pay settlement is not as generous as last year's, but it sensibly fills in gaps that last year's left. The big question is whether Mr Blair's ambitious six-year target can be achieved. There could not be a better time to make such a spending commitment, with this year's budget surplus as high as £14bn and next year's even higher. Even rightwing commentators like Patrick Minford have urged higher expenditure. Remember, the Blair government is still on line to reduce public expenditure to a lower proportion of national income than any time in the last 35 years. Time to change.

fields.headline: Why they stick with NHS
fields.standfirst:
Staff on highs and lows of jobs

Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Liz Corbett, 28. Staff nurse in coronary care/medical admissions. North Yorkshire. £17,000 basic salary:
fields.body:
Liz Corbett, 28. Staff nurse in coronary care/medical admissions. North Yorkshire. £17,000 basic salary:

"Nurses are taken for granted. Traditionally, we have been the handmaidens of the health service. We never strike, we are always there. I think the government do take us for granted. But it seems they have listened this time. I feel guilty to ask for more money and then you feel grateful for whatever you get.

"I love what I do and I desperately don't want to leave the NHS."

Lorna Wood, 42. Midwife at Liverpool women's hospital with 13 years experience. Mother of two. Earns between £17,000 and £19,000 for a 34-hour week:

"It's pretty stressful. It's very busy and you have to make clinical decisions on the hoof and you may not have the medical back-up. It has got much busier. The ultimate decisions are left to you much more. I went into it basically because I was interested in children and in women's health. That's what keeps me here, giving them a good deal.

"I think we are undervalued. I don't earn much. I feel jealous of teachers. They get much more but we all have degrees now."

Jill Laing, 32. Paramedic with 10 years experience, at ambulance divisional HQ in Motherwell. Married, one child. £19,000 raised to £23,000 for training:

"It is an incredibly stressful job. We deal with absolutely anything: road accidents, house fires, emergency medical conditions. What keeps me in it is that for difficult 10 jobs that don't have good outcomes there's always one where you feel you have really made a difference. I would like more money, but the job security is there in the way it sometimes isn't in the private sector.

Dr Simon Minkoff, 25. Senior house officer in paediatrics. St Mary's hospital, Manchester. £20,645 basic salary with £8,000 overtime:

"I work the full lot, 72 hours of duty a week on average. For example, I'm working 9am to 5pm today, covering until 9am tomorrow and then working 9am to 5pm again; 32 hours in a row.

"The current system pays us half of our statutory rate for working antisocial, long, hard hours. We have waited for years for the government to honour a gentleman's agreement to reduce the hours and that has not been done.

"What keeps me in it? It is a rewarding job. I love what I'm doing."

 Interviews: Kirsty Scott

webTitle: Not much left to play with in the health kitty

fields.headline: Not much left to play with in the health kitty
fields.standfirst:
Assorted pressures mounting up for NHS finance managers mean that working out the sums will be a complicated matter

Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The calculators were out in health authorities and trusts across the country last night as finance managers sought to work out how much will be left in the kitty after settling the bill for yesterday's pay awards for nurses, doctors and therapists. The answer in most cases will have been: not much.
fields.body:
The calculators were out in health authorities and trusts across the country last night as finance managers sought to work out how much will be left in the kitty after settling the bill for yesterday's pay awards for nurses, doctors and therapists. The answer in most cases will have been: not much.

In real terms, after allowing for inflation, authorities (which fund trusts) are being given an average 4.3% increase in their budgets for 2000-01. So the cost of the pay awards, at only 1.1% above the same inflation assumption, looks eminently affordable at face value.

However, the NHS faces substantial other pressures. Hospital and community trusts have to find an extra 1% in employers' pension contributions from April and the impact of the European working time directive will account for a further 0.5%.

Allowing for deficits carried over from this financial year and adding in other pay costs, such as discretionary salary points for doctors and nurses and a £50m package for hospital consultants facing the greatest intensity of work, this means that there will be perhaps 1.3% of the health authorities' real increase to play with.

But then there is the spiralling drugs bill. The cost of medicines bought by the NHS is racing ahead. Estimates suggest this could eat up 1% of the real increase in funding next year, leaving just 0.3% for investment in new services.

Juggling act

"Juggling all this is going to be very difficult for NHS finance directors," said Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation, representing health authorities and trusts.

One of the key points made by the confederation in recent days is that the service at local level is running so close to the edge that it can no longer be expected to find 3% efficiency savings required annually by Whitehall. That view gains weighty support from the nurses' and therapists' pay review body in its new reports. webTitle: Council of Europe threatens Russia over Chechnya

fields.headline: Council of Europe threatens Russia over Chechnya
fields.standfirst:
The threat of suspension from Europe's most powerful human rights body hung over Russia last night, as a delegation from the Council of Europe made an emergency visit to Moscow to discuss the military offensive in Chechnya.
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: With several council members said to be "appalled" by Russia's handling of the war, particularly the indiscriminate shelling of towns and villages, Lord Russell-Johnston, president of the parliamentary delegation of the Council of Europe, indicated that the question of Russia's suspension would be debated by the members at a specially convened summit next week.
fields.body:
With several council members said to be "appalled" by Russia's handling of the war, particularly the indiscriminate shelling of towns and villages, Lord Russell-Johnston, president of the parliamentary delegation of the Council of Europe, indicated that the question of Russia's suspension would be debated by the members at a specially convened summit next week.

Lord Russell-Johnston admitted that suspension had been discussed during a three-hour meeting with Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, and senior Russian officials.

"We want a ceasefire, we want negotiations, we want the intolerable situation with refugees to be stopped," he said.

Opening the first talks on Chechnya with the west since he succeeded Boris Yeltsin, Mr Putin appealed for greater understanding of Russia's position and urged delegates to withhold judgment until they had seen the situation in the north Caucasus for themselves, rather than allowing themselves to be swayed by "propaganda".

He admitted that the situation was "not easy", but insisted that it was "under control". On Saturday he had admitted that Russia could be fighting in the breakaway republic for some time to come.

For the first time Mr Putin signalled that he would accept an "international presence... in Ingushetia and parts of Chechnya" to enable information to flow to the world's media. Until now journalists' movements in the region have been restricted.

The council delegation is to embark on a fact-finding mission to the north Caucasus today.

The prospect of further diplomatic recriminations appeared when a senior official from Portugal - which currently chairs the European Union - said that the EU would debate possible sanctions against Russia because of its actions in Chechnya at a meeting on January 24.

Meanwhile Chechnya declared a minor diplomatic coup after winning formal diplomatic recognition from Afghanistan's Taliban government. Afghanistan is the first country to recognise Chechnya as an independent state, but the Taliban itself is still struggling for international recognition. Russia responded immediately by urging further sanctions against the Afghan government.

As human rights issues were debated in Moscow, there were claims of a new humanitarian outrage in Chechnya as eyewitnesses said Russian troops near Urus-Martan had opened fire yesterday on a bus carrying refugees, killing the driver and three passengers.

It was not known what had prompted the shooting, but Nikolai Koshman, the Kremlin's top political representative in Chechnya, said the perpetrators would be punished.

"As soon as we find out who did this, they will be shot and killed in public," he said.

Meanwhile the assault on Chechnya continued unabated yesterday, as Russia's high command claimed it had subjected the country to some of the heaviest air strikes in weeks, with pilots flying some 110 raids over 24 hours.

A military spokesman said the operation had killed up to 50 Chechen rebels and destroyed several of their strongholds in the mountain gorge of Argun, which leads south through the rebel-held mountains to Georgia. Pilots were said to have deliberately created avalanches to make passes inaccessible to fleeing rebels, but there was no way of verifying these claims.

Warplanes once again subjected the capital, Grozny, to heavy bombardment. One rebel commander, Isa Munayev, claimed that at least 18 civilians had died in the latest raids on the city, but with journalists and human rights monitors officially excluded from the war zone, this claim was also impossible to check.

In a display of the military command's confidence, the army yesterday began to move its main headquarters from the security of North Ossetia to Khankala, a suburb in the east of Grozny.

The senior military commander in Chechnya, General Gennady Troshev said the army's offensive on the capital had reached a "decisive phase".

However, with doubts about the wisdom of the five month-long war beginning to surface in Moscow, morale among some troops on the ground also appeared to be souring.

"If the Chechens come today we will be easily defeated," said Alexei Migulin, a Russian soldier serving near Vedeno. He said the 150 troops stationed with him only had enough ammunition to last 10 minutes.

Andrei Vorobyov, a Russian sniper, complained that rebels were being tipped off about planned house searches. "The fighters leave, and people hide the weapons ... Sometimes it is impossible to find even a kitchen knife. Then, two days later, the fighters come back bringing their wounded."

webTitle: Steve Norris could still be the man to rescue his party

fields.headline: Steve Norris could still be the man to rescue his party
fields.standfirst:
If he becomes mayor, the Tories might begin their return to credibility
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: It is true to say the government is presiding over more calamities than at any time since it got to power. It is also true to say that nothing of importance will happen to it as a result. The crises come rolling in, the evidence of setback collects. Sonorous columnists, eager to anticipate historians, are fond of alerting readers that such-and-such a moment will be seen as a turning-point in the fortunes of a leader. So it is now, with Mr Blair. The dire rotundities of doom are spilling out all over. But it is plain that they're laughably premature.
fields.body:
It is true to say the government is presiding over more calamities than at any time since it got to power. It is also true to say that nothing of importance will happen to it as a result. The crises come rolling in, the evidence of setback collects. Sonorous columnists, eager to anticipate historians, are fond of alerting readers that such-and-such a moment will be seen as a turning-point in the fortunes of a leader. So it is now, with Mr Blair. The dire rotundities of doom are spilling out all over. But it is plain that they're laughably premature.

The crises that history recognises are crises of politics not substance, and there isn't the faintest sign of a political crisis now. Doubt about the life of the government, the pre-condition for such a crisis, does not exist. I'm not aware of one practitioner in the field, whether politician or commentator, whose language challenges the premise all find otiose to state, that this life will extend far beyond the next election. If we're at a turning-point, the deviation is of the most insignificant variety - and for a reason that should truly interest historians. The agent of political crisis, otherwise known as the Conservative opposition, is barely present in the minds of voters who put Mr Blair where he is.

In a better functioning political system, the government would be in the sort of trouble over the health service that threatened its entire credibility. Here is the project closest to the heart of Labour, binding new and old. Its inadequacy stares us in the face. Individual scandals of human misery are heaped on structural weaknesses putting this country's healthcare behind half of Europe's. The resources which one of the half-dozen wealthiest countries in the world can find to spend on health are shown for what they are: mean, thin-spread, and defensible only by the promise of something better soon which, when Mr Blair made it on Sunday, called on the last reserves alike of his sincerity and our toleration.

The shocking state of the NHS provokes discussion. The media don't hold back. Sometimes there are outbursts of genuine fury. But these, in the end, are propelled into the desert air. They surge into a political vaccuum. They pose a threat of disillusion, but never of destruction. They can't rouse anyone to believe other people might do better. They do not get past the terrain commanded by cosmetic spin: by statistics disarmingly cited, promises sincerely made, the 18-year inheritance hauled yet again into the breach. The irresistible fact of calamity is nowhere near meeting the immovable object of retribution.

So it is that Jack Straw, another contributor to the worst week the government yet experienced, needs nothing more than a thick skin to enable him to survive. Survival, even embarrassment, is not among his concerns. A week that he began by trailing the partial abolition of jury-trial and ended by using his discretion, at the behest of Frank Warren and BSkyB, to let in the world champion heavyweight rapist for a boxing match, should have called forth an outcry that would make him think. But the Tories, even when he is not mimicking them, cannot make him think. There is an outcry. But it does not touch him. He has nothing to fear. The caravan will move on, down a road where all turning-points are a mirage.

The reason the Tories cannot make the government think is partly that they have deplorably little to say. They're complicit in their own exile from the public mind. They seem to be as aware as everyone else that they will not return to power, and the proof of this is their lack of preparation for doing so. On health, they have nothing to offer but vague waftings in the direction of private insurance. On all home office questions, they speak with faltering voice, the bellows of their famous spokesman compromised by the legacy she is obliged to defend. By their want of substance, they do much to help falsify all these prophecies that Mr Blair's charmed life is ending and that he's about to face an appointment with historic destiny.

But emptiness is not their main problem. They have a broader lack of credibility. Even a policy programme that matched the wisdom of Jefferson and the moral vigour of Gladstone would struggle for an audience, at a time when so few people believe William Hague and his party are at a phase in the political cycle where anyone must pay them attention. This may be a circular puzzle. Which comes first, the message or the audience that is ready to hear it? At present, it is hard not to be impressed by the cavernous void of belief that attends Mr Hague's very existence as a leader: the axiomatic public indifference to anything he says: the power of his political failure to be a self-fulfilling guarantee of its continuation.

Yet until the Tories crack this, the government's impunity will continue. It is a profoundly undesirable situation, which makes one see more clearly what should happen in the London mayoral contest. By winning it, Steve Norris could begin to retrieve the Tory party from being a non-event, something the system badly needs. Though not a front-rank figure, he has several qualities, the first of which is that he is not an anti-European right-wing lunatic, wedded to doctrines or buried in feuds that disqualify him from public acceptance. He's a pragmatic, loud-voiced, human and humorous figure who knows a lot about transport, the problem he will have most power to do something about. As an individual with talents relevant to London, not mired in the sub-textual political battles that any of the Labour candidates will spend half their time fighting inside their party, he would come to the job with clean hands.

He would also be able to take on the government, within the limited field the law leaves open, in a way mayoral devolution is meant to allow for. Londoners would be witness to the kind of political dialogue, between rival legitimacies, that gives life to democracy. Norris would make a better job of this than Ken Livingstone, whose arguments against the treasury would be laced with bitter personal animus on both sides. Livingstone as mayor will be barely more acceptable to the Blairite nervous-system than Livingstone as candidate, and offer nothing, by way of compensation, to the quality of politics.

Frank Dobson, for his part, will never rise above the feeble toady. This is what the government wants - which is becoming a bad reason, ex hypothesi , for supporting it. Steve Norris, on the other hand, would become the most important Conservative after William Hague: not, perhaps, an irresistible eminence, but one from which the Tories might start to leverage their return towards sanity and credibility, a democratic force of which ministers one day had genuine reason to be apprehensive.

fields.headline: Limits on question time attacked
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw will be accused today of "dirty tricks" to deny the public access to government information by imposing artificial limits on the time officials will spend looking for it.
fields.body:
Jack Straw will be accused today of "dirty tricks" to deny the public access to government information by imposing artificial limits on the time officials will spend looking for it.

Labour's Mark Fisher and the Liberal Democrat constitutional affairs spokesman, Robert Maclennan, are demanding changes to the freedom of information bill after the home secretary slipped in a new series of hurdles to hinder the public getting documents. They will challenge Mike O'Brien, the home office minister in charge of the bill, in a committee hearing in parliament today.

Under the initial legislation the government had already set a £500 ceiling on the cost of getting information - equivalent to some 25 hours junior officials work. The public would be charged 10% of the cost - a maximum of £50 - for its retrieval. But ministers have added two new hurdles. The £500 limit will now also apply to the time spent by more senior officials examining whether information should be released. This will limit the time considerably, as senior staff are more expensive to employ. But MPs are most critical of a further proposal to combine separate applications from outside organisations into one application.

The home office said yesterday this had been introduced to prevent organisations trying to get around the £500 ceiling by splitting up requests for the same information into a series of smaller requests. Maurice Frankel, director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, said: " These artificial restrictions do not exist in other freedom of information laws elsewhere. If people wished to pay more they are allowed to do so.

"But the real impact of this law will hit organisations like Friends of the Earth, Greenpeace and other campaigning groups which may want to put in detailed requests. It allows ministers to refuse to supply information which would otherwise be available purely on the grounds of cost. "

webTitle: Tyson issue is not black and white

fields.headline: Tyson issue is not black and white
fields.trailText: Why is it that law-abiding, elderly people have to jump through hoops in order to enter the country to live with their families, but a man who is a confirmed rapist is allowed into the country to beat up a fellow human being?
fields.body:
I have just carried out two housing inspections for immigration purposes. One was for an elderly lady who needed to re-apply because she had overrun her permission to stay. The second was for a 60-year-old man who wanted to live with his son and his family. It was clear that the sponsors of these individuals had a lot to offer society. Why is it that law-abiding, elderly people have to jump through hoops in order to enter the country to live with their families, but a man who is a confirmed rapist is allowed into the country to beat up a fellow human being? (Enter Tyson, adored by fans, January 17).
Steph Harrison
Hemel Hempstead

 Banning Mike Tyson would have sent a clear message that putting him in a boxing ring to make money for himself and others is not acceptable. Allowing him entry to this country sends the reverse message. Do we now open the doors to other undesirables - drug dealers and terrorists? Do we continue to propagate the myth that sportsmen are under some sort of pressure which makes beating up wives and girlfriends acceptable because they have talent and earn lots of money?
Sue Doughty
Guildford, Surrey
orcharddoughty@cix.co.uk

 There's something about the Tyson immigration regulations affair and the response to it that puzzles me. I thought that once convicted people served their time in prison, they had paid their debt to society; that the slate's wiped clean. Doesn't this mean all crimes - from petty crooks to murderers and rapists? Back to being presumed capable of acting lawfully? If this isn't so, maybe we'd best return to branding or some other means of detecting the eternally bad ones amongst us.
Miriam Steiner
Manchester

 Mike Tyson was convicted by an all-white jury. No black jury in the US, this country or Africa would have convicted him. Feminists and most Guardian readers will, quite understandably, be infuriated by that view. But, regrettably, it is the truth. And the majority of black people will never regard him as a rapist, on the basis of that verdict.
GZ Opadia-Kadime
Nottingham

fields.headline: Options for new funding
fields.trailText: The only promise Labour seems determined to keep is the one not to increase income tax (Blair's £12bn pledge to NHS, January 17). Party managers are, understandably, terrified of repeating the debacle of the 1992.
fields.body:
The only promise Labour seems determined to keep is the one not to increase income tax . Party managers are, understandably, terrified of repeating the debacle of the 1992. It's even possible that one of the reasons the Tories were thrown out in 1997 was because they raised taxes.

Have the voters changed their stupid short-sighted attitude? I don't think so. Given the chance, most vote to turn their building societies into banks for a pathetic short-term windfall. What the Daily Mail-reading voters of middle England need to realise is that it is they who have done best out of the welfare state. Our health will soon become dependent upon private insurance unless we raise taxes. But it is the middle classes who will suffer most if that happens, since the poorest have never been as well provided for.
Laura Marcus
Leek, Staffs.
Lawls@compuserve.com

 Over the past 18 months I have been working in one of London's teaching hospital's. I have witnessed daily crises resulting in the cancellation of major surgical procedures on the critically sick (Letters, Janaury 17). Often these patients have endured full pre-operative preparation, including fasting, and are often only informed of their cancellation half an hour before their scheduled appointment in theatre. This is not even taking into account the immense psychological strain that the already highly anxious patient has been subjected to. It is only due to huge efforts, particularly on the part of intensivists and senior anaesthetic personnel, that any of these critically ill patients receive adequate treatment at all.

The simple fact is that there are insufficient beds to enable us to treat patients when there is no flu epidemic. There have been London hospitals utilising operating theatres as makeshift intensive care units, purely due to the lack of adequate facilities. Much of the responsibility for this lies not with government, but with individual trusts. The combined incompetence of trust executives and the lack of budget managerial experience at departmental level lie at the heart of this, and many of the other problems that the NHS faces. It is not simply a matter of reviewing the funding of the NHS, but also some serious probing into the day-to-day workings of the hospital departments.
Name and address supplied

 The problem of funding the health service could be solved at a stroke by removing the upper limit on national insurance contributions for the high earners.
R Harmer
New Milton, Hants
gannahar@care4free.net

 Raising tax is not an option that New Labour seems willing to contemplate. Another simple way of raising more money would be to ask patients to pay for their accommodation during their stay in hospital. The NHS is pledged to provide free medical attention, but there is no mention of providing free board and lodgings. People on benefits and pensioners lose part of their entitlement after a period in hospital, so are already contributing. Why not all?
James Foreman
Wakefield, W Yorks

 Perhaps we should reflect on our own personal responsibilities. The costs arising from smoking, drugs and alcohol abuse, from being overweight and taking insufficient exercise absorb a considerable proportion of the NHS budget. By acting upon the widely available messages of prevention and health promotion we could over time considerably reduce our demands on the service.
Hugh Hawkins.
Rochester, Kent

fields.headline: Lords and mandarins
fields.trailText: Views of mine you quoted are apparently taken from my letter to the freedom of information unit of July 12 1999, written in my capacity as chairman of the lord chancellor's advisory council on public records. It is wrong to describe, as the article does, my letter as an "attack" on the home secretary.
fields.body:
Views of mine you quoted (Attack on Straw over extension of secrecy, January 17) are apparently taken from my letter to the freedom of information unit of July 12 1999, written in my capacity as chairman of the lord chancellor's advisory council on public records. It is wrong to describe, as the article does, my letter as an "attack" on the home secretary. It was written as part of the consultation exercise on the draft freedom of information bill.

Since my letter, the situation has changed considerably. The proposal to introduce a class exemption of 75 years for communications with the monarch was dropped. In addition, the concept of a new code of practice has been accepted and developed. The question of closure of records relating to honours is still being discussed. I have no reason to think it will be anything other than constructive.

The advisory council exists to give advice on issues of this nature and, as a result of the council's advice, steps have been taken and are being taken which will have the effect of improving the bill considerably. I look forward to further developments.
Lord Woolf
Royal Courts of Justice

 As minister for energy and Europe, Helen Liddell would not normally be involved in the department of trade and industry's companies investigation branch (Minister barred from DTI investigation, January 15). In addition, Mrs Liddle decided herself that in view of her previous employment at Mirror Group Newspapers she would take steps to ensure that she saw no papers in the DTI in relation to the Mirror Group inquiry. I did not "bar" her from sight of these papers
Sir Michael Scholar
Permanent secretary, Dept of Trade and Industry

fields.headline: Femophobia down under
fields.trailText: Margaret Simons is a bit soft on the sexism of Australia. My experiences on a book promotion tour a few years ago suggest it'd be safe to rank Oz next to Afghanistan for primitive femophobia.
fields.body:
Margaret Simons is a bit soft on the sexism of Australia (Who'd be a Sheila?, G2, January 17). My experiences on a book promotion tour a few years ago suggest it'd be safe to rank Oz next to Afghanistan for primitive femophobia. TV stations where I went to be interviewed assumed I was a secretary looking for a job, hotels where I checked in assumed I was a male guest's wife and the stewardesses on the domestic Ansett Airlines ignored me while they fawned over the male passengers.

Worst of all, my Australian publishers promoted my book - just a regular girly novel of its times - as an outrageous work of pornography, and told me I should be grateful when I complained. So no surprise that Australian feminists are having a tough time, or that they have been criticised for focusing on the issue of sex and power. Beautiful country, but I'm not rushing to go back.
Celia Brayfield
London

 So "no woman has ever been voted in as a political leader at state or federal level" in Australia. When I visited Canberra (my home town) last August, the elected chief minister of the Australian capital territory was called Kate Carnell. Funny name for a bloke. It's true that Senator Cheryl Kernott didn't become the leader of the Australian Democrats, the political party she defected to from Labor. That was because incumbent Meg Ryan and her deputy, Natasha Stott-Despoja, were too busy running the show. So which Pommy party has two women at the helm?

As further damning evidence, Ms Simons quotes an Aussie tabloid making a sexist remark about some swimwear models. Struth! Makes a Sheila feel grateful to be here in cutting-edge Britain, where she has the Sun and the Sport to fight for her rights ...
Cathy Coote
Norwich

fields.headline: Life after Pinochet
fields.standfirst:
Chile elects first socialist since Allende

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The victory of moderate socialist Ricardo Lagos in Chile's presidential election increases the chances that the country's former dictator, General Augusto Pinochet, may yet be called to account in a court of law. But only slightly. Jack Straw's deadline for final submissions concerning Spain's long-standing extradition request expires today. If the home secretary remains inclined to follow medical advice that Gen Pinochet is too ill to stand trial, the 84-year-old could be home by the end of the week.
fields.body:
The victory of moderate socialist Ricardo Lagos in Chile's presidential election increases the chances that the country's former dictator, General Augusto Pinochet, may yet be called to account in a court of law. But only slightly. Jack Straw's deadline for final submissions concerning Spain's long-standing extradition request expires today. If the home secretary remains inclined to follow medical advice that Gen Pinochet is too ill to stand trial, the 84-year-old could be home by the end of the week.

Mr Lagos has promised that over 50 civil actions brought against Gen Pinochet on behalf of the approximately 3,000 people who were murdered or disappeared under his rule from 1973 to 1990 will proceed unimpeded. It is suggested that military files hitherto kept secret may be opened; and that, for the first time in Chile, Gen Pinochet may be ordered to face official questioning about the killing, torture and repression which followed the assassination of the country's last socialist president, Salvador Allende, in the US-backed coup. If a prosecution ensues, Mr Lagos says he is ready to amend the constitution to lift the general's parliamentary immunity.

All the same, the legal process is likely to be at least as protracted as Britain's and could well outlast the general himself. And while Chile's new president has pledged to safeguard the judicial inquiries, he and a majority of his compatriots have other priorities after a forward-looking election which focused on economic and social problems. The campaign revealed broad agreement about the most pressing issues. It also demonstrated, in a close finish between Mr Lagos and his rightwing rival, Joaquin Lavin, that legitimate conservatism, as opposed to Gen Pinochet's illegitimate variety, is regaining its strength. These are signs of a healthy democracy. After the horrors of the past, it was all refreshingly normal. Small political earthquake in Chile, nobody dead.

fields.headline: Kosovan girl 'killed by US soldier'
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The top US military official in Kosovo has sent his condolences to the family of an 11-year-old ethnic Albanian girl who was allegedly sexually assaulted and killed by an American soldier serving in Kosovo.
fields.body:
The top US military official in Kosovo has sent his condolences to the family of an 11-year-old ethnic Albanian girl who was allegedly sexually assaulted and killed by an American soldier serving in Kosovo.

"On behalf of K-For and the US military presence in Kosovo, I want to express to you our most heartfelt sympathy on the death of your daughter," read a letter from Brigadier General Ricardo Sanchez, released on Monday.

Frank Ronghi, serving with the international peacekeeping force in Kosovo (K-For), was charged on Sunday with sexually assaulting and killing an 11-year-old ethnic Albanian girl, the US military said.

It is the first time a peacekeeper has been accused of such serious crimes since the 50,000-strong Nato-led peacekeeping force entered the province on June 12, 1999.

"I did not know your daughter but as a father I feel a deep sense of loss and can imagine your pain," the letter said. "I cannot say I know how you feel but I know how I feel."

It added: " The army will spare no effort in bringing this matter to justice."

The incident threatens relations between the Americans and Kosovo civilians whom the peacekeepers were sent to protect after a Nato bombing campaign forced Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic to halt his bloody crackdown against Kosovo's ethnic Albanian majority.

"We don't want them here to give us security if they are going to do this," said Muharram Samakova, a neighbour of the girl's family.

Sgt Ronghi, 35, is a weapons squad leader assigned to A Company, 3rd Battalion, 504th Parachute Infantry Regiment from Fort Bragg, North Carolina. He has been transferred to the army's confinement facility in Mannheim, Germany.

The girl's body was found late on Thursday in the countryside near the city of Vitina, 45 miles southeast of the provincial capital, Pristina, the army said.

A UN official who asked not to be named said that the girl appeared to have been raped before she was killed.

The girl's father, Hamdi Shabiu, said he last saw his daughter early on Thursday when she left to go to the market. Neighbours in an apartment block across the street said she had been killed in the basement of the building. AP

webTitle: Middle East peace talks put on hold

fields.headline: Middle East peace talks put on hold
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Peace talks between Israel and Syria have been postponed indefinitely, the office of the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, announced last night, suspending plans for talks to resume in the US tomorrow.
fields.body:
Peace talks between Israel and Syria have been postponed indefinitely, the office of the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, announced last night, suspending plans for talks to resume in the US tomorrow.

"The next round of talks has been postponed. The prime minister will not travel to the US tomorrow," a statement said.

An official source said no new date had been set for a for a meeting between Mr Barak and the Syrian foreign minister, Mr Farouk al-Shara'a.

On Sunday Syria said it was "reassessing" its plans to return to the US for new talks. Through its state-run media, Syria voiced reluctance to go back to the negotiations because of what it called Israel's refusal to commit to full withdrawal from the Golan Heights - seized from Syria in 1967 - before discussing other issues in the conflict.

The newspaper Ha'aretz, Israel's prominent leftwing daily, said Syria's stance caught Mr Barak by surprise. Reacting on Sunday to the reports of Syria's plans to delay the talks, the Israeli leader said in a statement: "We know nothing about a plan to postpone the round of talks. If the Syrians want to postpone them, we don't have a problem with that. When they decide they are ready, they should let us know."

Mr Barak was expected to meet the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, later yesterday for previously unscheduled talks on their troubled peace negotiations, diplomatic sources said.

Negotiations in Shepherdstown, West Virginia, ended on a tense note last week when a copy of the "working document" that US President Bill Clinton presented to the parties was leaked to Ha'aretz, which published it.

Syrian officials were unhappy about the leak of the document, which was meant to form the basis of a peace treaty. One Syrian government spokesman said the release of the working paper to the Israeli media showed that Mr Barak was not sincere about making peace.

fields.headline: Being there
fields.standfirst: The news that childbirth guru Michel Odent thinks women are better off doing it without men has sent shock waves round the delivery room. Sarah Boseley talks to the man himself; five experts consider the implications
fields.trailText: The news that childbirth guru Michel Odent thinks women are better off doing it without men has sent shock waves round the delivery room. Sarah Boseley talks to the man himself; five experts consider the implications
fields.body:
Michel Odent may be 70 but he is still making waves, if you'll pardon the pun, over 30 years after he pioneered the water birth. Now he says giving birth is strictly women's business. Men would be better off out of the way.

Dr Odent is that rare thing, an obstetrician who opposes medical intervention in childbirth, who wants the lights turned down, the heating turned up, and for the woman in labour to listen only to what her body is telling her to do. Intellect and logic have no place.

A woman who is giving birth needs to retreat into the primitive part of her brain, he says: "She is going to another planet, she is going to scream." Odent's philosophy is that, to achieve the primal state she needs, a woman must have no stress. Relaxed, she will produce high levels of a hormone called oxytocin which speeds up labour. She may be better off with a woman who has been through it than a man who, in his anxiety for her, will try to talk rationally, distracting her and passing on his fear.

Odent knows he is challenging what has become an orthodoxy - 90% of men are now there in the delivery room until the cord is cut. He admits there is little scientific evidence for his view that men can be a hindrance rather than a help, but he has plenty of the anecdotal variety.

"The labour may be going slowly, slowly, and suddenly, for some unexpected reason, the man has to go out. As soon as he is gone, the woman starts to scream and shout, and when he comes back, the baby has been born. I have many stories where the woman says everything was wonderful but unfortunately my husband was not there. It is as if women have two languages. They are convinced they cannot give birth without the participation of the baby's father. But on the day of the birth, they said something different with their body language."

The presence of the man in the delivery room can lead to other problems, too, Odent believes: "There are issues about the future sex life of the couple." Older women who gave birth when men were expected to stay in the pub are often appalled, he says, at the idea of their partner witnessing the physical spectacle of delivery. "Sexual attraction is mysterious. Perhaps it needs a bit of mystery."

At his Primal Health Research Centre in London, Odent has interviewed couples years after the birth for his research into its effect on the lives of both the child and its parents. "I have seen so many couples who had wonderful births according to the present criteria, yet several years later they divorced. They have remained good friends, but they are not sexual partners any more."

Finally, he speculates on the existence of a male post-natal depression. "Are we sure all men can cope with the strong emotional reaction they can have when their wife is in labour? In most cultures, they have rituals for keeping a man busy while his partner is in labour. It is called couvade - hatching." Modern birthing practice, he says, makes little allowance for this.

In Odent's philosophy, our neglect of the primitive side of our natures is causing sorrow beyond the delivery suite. Birth, love and sexuality are all triggered by the same primal part of the brain. In his recent book, The Scientification of Love, he says oxytocin, the hormone that speeds delivery, is also responsible for falling in love and fulfilling sex. The argument is the same: adrenaline and stress are the enemies of relaxation and sexual arousal. To give birth or to make love, we need soft lighting and gentle music. We need to put our rational thinking sides away.

Throughout his life, from the 60s at his radical birthing centre in Pithiviers, France, where he first introduced water as a way of relaxing women in order to reduce drug use and caesareans, to his recent proposal that women should fast before trying to conceive as a way of reducing the chemicals in their bodies, Odent has been controversial. But he has been right before: water births are now accepted and popular. He will be pilloried for his views on men, but he genuinely believes we are at another turning point in childbirth.

Sean French, novelist and columnist
I can see all the arguments against men being present. For a start, it's so typical of men, isn't it? Childbirth was one of life's great experiences from which they were excluded and they wanted to gain admission. Why couldn't they begin with other exclusively female activities, like ironing?

I know all the stories about men fainting and needing more attention than their wives, or taking photos all the way through, or being pressured into it against their will. In reality (and I've checked this with my wife and I'm allowed to say this), it felt intensely important for both of us that I was there. For nine months, the child had been hers. She had been the one throwing up and wobbling around. Now, from the moment the baby was born, it was going to be ours. It's wrong to be dogmatic about this. It must be the woman's choice and she should be able to assess freely what her needs are. How, for example, is her partner emotionally? Many men are frightened by agonising pain and blood, and some end up siding with the obstetricians to help control the "little woman". That makes it very tough on her.

Women are often socially isolated now, with even their mothers reluctant to get involved, so the person closest to a pregnant woman may be her partner. The birth is not a time suddenly to wheel him in. He's not a voyeur or there to keep her in hand, he's there to understand. I've seen classes in the US where men turn up with stopwatches and are referred to as "coaches" as if they're preparing for a boxing ring. This is missing out on the love and tenderness that can flow between a couple in childbirth.

Anthony Silverstone, obstetrician/gynaecologist
Childbirth is a complicated issue and there are so many variables involved, but people should have the confidence to choose who is present. Of course fathers should not be stigmatised for not attending, but I believe most fathers want to be there and most mothers want them there.

It used to be routine to ask the father to leave - I was sent out of the room when my first child was born - but now that's exceptional. Of course there are times when it's not advisable, or when he can be vulnerable and his presence not helpful, but generally I think it's a good thing. If you ask him to leave, he misses out and she misses him. It's one of the most important moments in a couple's life together and they should share it.

As for the increase in caesareans, I'm not convinced it is related to more fathers attending births. When I was a young doctor, the caesarean rate was 9-10%, now it's up to 20-21%. Fathers or no fathers, things have changed out of all recognition.

 Anthony Silverstone is consultant obstetrician and gynaecologist at University College London Hospital.

Anne Woollett, psychologist
No woman should feel obliged to have the man there. It's an emotionally charged situation and it depends on the dynamic between the couple. If the woman is the one who does the looking after, he's not going to be much use because he's not got any experience of how to look after her.

Childbirth is scary and men are often very anxious. They want to find solutions to her pain and when they can't, they feel powerless. What matters is whether they listen to what she wants and are sympathetic.

Another dynamic is the fact that her genitals are exposed to the world. In a relationship, they are exposed only to him. It is hard for some men to share that with a male doctor and it can affect a couple's sex life.

One thing we're more aware of now is domestic violence in pregnancy. The birth of a first child is a shift from a twosome to a threesome and some men feel emotionally shaky when they see their partner more engrossed with her body and the baby than with him. In this case, it is not right for him to be at the birth.

 Anne Woollett is Professor of Developmental Psychology at the University of East London.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: • Watch out! You may wake up one day soon to discover that you are surplus to requirements and that a much trimmer, quieter and more youthful woman has taken your place. Don't tut that it's already happened. This is different. We're talking about the curse of the cyber woman. First we had Lara Croft, the Tomb Raider heroine whose breasts grew in relation to the profits of the company who created her. Then came Webbie Tookay, the digitally composed "woman" signed up by a model agency. And now we have the world's first "virtual" newsreader, Ananova. Modelled on a combination of Posh Spice, Kylie Minogue and Carol Vorderman,   she will give reports on sport, shares, weather and travel on her website, to be launched later this year. She is 28, tall and, er... that's it really. No, wait, she does have a personality. Her makers say she likes Oasis and the Simpsons.

webTitle: Drug raises hopes for cold cure

fields.headline: Drug raises hopes for cold cure
fields.trailText: A small US company believes it is half way down the road to one of the holy grails of medical research - a cure for the common cold.
fields.body:
A small US company believes it is half way down the road to one of the holy grails of medical research - a cure for the common cold.

ViroPharma, based in Philadelphia, has released data from a preliminary clinical trial showing that people with a cold used 40% fewer tissues after three days of taking their new drug Pleconaril. This may sound like bad news for tissue manufacturers, but is in fact one of the few ways of measuring the impact of medicines on colds.

There is anticipation in the US that the news will send shares in ViroPharma soaring when Wall Street re-opens today after a public holiday.

Like Relenza, Glaxo Wellcome's flu treatment which reduces a bout by a couple of days, the drug is not a cure, but reduces the length and severity of the cold. ViroPharma reckons it will cut out three or four days of sniffles.

The new drug is designed to be taken as a pill or a nasal spray. It works by blocking the ability of the cold virus to infect human cells. ViroPharma now has to put it through far bigger clinical trials to test whether it works on large numbers of the population.

It is highly unlikely that the national institute for clinical excellence in the UK would approve Pleconaril to shorten colds on the cash-strapped NHS since it ruled against Relenza for flu, which is a far more dangerous illness. It is thought the drug might sell privately for between £30 and £60 to treat a single infection.

But more important are the other possibilities of the viral research that has resulted in a potentially money-spinning drug for the common cold. Colds are caused by ribonucleic acid viruses, which are also responsible for more serious diseases such as polio, viral meningitis, hepatitis C and infections that kill newborn babies. The company believes its work on the common cold may lead to treatments for some of these as well.

webTitle: Bradley uses web to snare votes

fields.headline: Bradley uses web to snare votes
fields.standfirst:
The internet is revolutionising the way US presidential candidates campaign and raise cash

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: With just one week to go before the first votes are cast in the 2000 American presidential nomination process, the Democratic challenger Bill Bradley has turned to the internet to boost his campaign against the party frontrunner, Vice-President Al Gore.
fields.body:
With just one week to go before the first votes are cast in the 2000 American presidential nomination process, the Democratic challenger Bill Bradley has turned to the internet to boost his campaign against the party frontrunner, Vice-President Al Gore.

In a clear sign of the mounting importance of the internet in American elections, the Bradley campaign has deployed the resources of the information revolution to launch waves of emails at internet users in Iowa, where the state caucuses next Monday mark the first hurdle in the race to succeed Bill Clinton.

Iowa users of the Juno and Microsoft Hotmail email services are being bombarded with last ditch pleas, as Mr Bradley spends $800,000 (£489,300) this month trying to narrow Mr Gore's current lead in the state, currently 46% to 29% according to a weekend poll.

"For us to do better than expected in Iowa, we have to bring in new voters," says Lynn Reed, internet adviser to the Bradley campaign.

The move is just the latest in the rapid redefinition of American election tactics brought about by the internet, a process in which Mr Bradley, the former New Jersey senator, is a pacesetter.

The Bradley campaign has raised $1.3m online so far, more than any other candidate of either main party, and has pioneered the campaign use of streaming video. Click on Mr Bradley's ad, and up pops the senator in a red jumper to talk about his health care plans.

Yet Mr Bradley is far from alone in his campaign embrace of the internet. Every candidate in this year's races can claim some sort of a first.

Republican front runner George W Bush was the first to put details of all his 171,000 camapign contributors on the internet. His rival John McCain was the first candidate to purchase banner advertising spaces on other websites.

Meanwhile the tech-savvy Mr Gore is about to become the first candidate submit to subject himself to an interactive online grilling by gay and lesbian voters on the Gay.com website.

Sometime this year, the number of American households with access to the internet is expected to surpass the number without it. By election day in November as many as 60-70% of voting age Americans could be online.

As a result, an election battle that used to marked mainly by mailshots and television arvertising, is now also being joined online, with all the candidates spending heavily.

"In the last campaign in 1996, the web was not even a line item in the budget. This time it is its own section with its own line items," says Bill Dal Col, campaign manager for the Republican millionaire candidate Steve Forbes, who even announced his candidature on the internet

The online campaign has centred on three main issues: money-raising, political advertising, and rapid response.

At the end of 1999, the candidates had raised $3.3m online, with Mr Bradley and Mr McCain the top internet fundraisers. Mr Gore is not far behind, though, having raised 20% of his last quarter's campaign income online.

Political software manufacturers Aristotle estimate that the candidates will have raised as much as $30m online by November. Online spending, on the other hand, could be much lower, as internet advertising costs are significantly below television rates.

Unlike the approach used by Mr Bradley in Iowa, the McCain and Bush campaigns are making use of sophisticated data sifting techniques to target very specific groups of voters on the internet with banner advertising.

The internet has also played a key role in the daily battles for the news agenda. When Mr McCain was under fire two weeks ago over a letter he wrote to the US government on behalf of a campaign contributor, his campaign team posted the full text of the letter on the McCain website and fired off 43,000 explanatory emails to supporters.

"I'm convinced that the locus of political campaigning is going from the television to the internet," says Dick Morris, Mr Clinton's former consultant, who has just published a book entitled Vote.com.

"It's a little bit like TV affecting the 1960 election, when it was just beginning to do it. By the election of 2008, it's going to be a totally online election.

Enthusiasts like Mr Morris think that even voting itself will soon move online. Already, the Arizona Democratic primary in March will allow voters to cast their ballots on the internet. "You'll probably be able to vote from home in your pyjamas by 2010," says Warren Slocum, a returning officer for San Mateo county in California.

But sceptics say that the privacy and computer security issues involved in internet voting have not yet been properly addressed.

Others caution that internet enthusiasts are getting carried away. The Republican pollster Frank Luntz says: "Here's the problem. Americans don't like politics, So when they get on the web, politics is the last thing they want to read."

In Iowa, meanwhile, this week's campaigns face a more practical hurdle. The voters who take part of next Monday's caucuses are generally older and less web-savvy.

"If your state-of-the-art website doesn't get read by the average 54-year-old white guy in Iowa, then what good is it going to do?" one campaign aide told the Des Moines Register this week.
