fields.headline: Dollar beware
fields.standfirst:
Because of unprecedented consumer and import debts that surround its success, the US economy is as stable as a bubble in a cauldron
The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: As the Iowa caucuses and the first presidential primary in New Hampshire beckon, it is a measure of the success of the American economy that candidates should be arguing not, as is traditional on these occasions, about the tough measures needed to put federal finances in order, but how to spend the surplus which has accumulated in government coffers during the economic boom.
fields.body:
As the Iowa caucuses and the first presidential primary in New Hampshire beckon, it is a measure of the success of the American economy that candidates should be arguing not, as is traditional on these occasions, about the tough measures needed to put federal finances in order, but how to spend the surplus which has accumulated in government coffers during the economic boom.

But the terms of debate will have to change. By the time Bill Clinton's successor is inaugurated in Washington next January, the considerations of American political economy are unlikely to be as luxurious.

The headlines tell of unrivalled prosperity and rapid gains in productivity on the back of new technology. But behind them, facts speak differently. The American economy, biggest in the world, stands on the edge of a cliff. Expansion has gone on for nearly nine years without interruption, recently pushing up to over 4% a year. Next month this will become the longest upswing in the country's history. But, meanwhile, huge economic imbalances have accumulated.

Figures show the current account deficit - the difference between export and import earnings - expressed as a proportion of gross domestic product as well as the net of American lending and borrowing abroad. Last year, the payments deficit was a whopping 3.5-3.7% of GDP. Consumers stopped saving in the early 90s and are now up to their eyeballs in debt. Wall Street has lost touch with reality, with share prices rising much faster than the underlying earnings of the companies on which they are based.

In short, the American economy is displaying all the symptoms of a classic bubble. If it were Korea, Thailand or Indonesia, it would by now have investors running for the exit. Yet still they are piling money into American financial assets. That has to do with the Greenspan factor. The staying power of investors rests on the belief that Alan Greenspan, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, America's independent central bank, will be able to engineer a soft landing, a slowdown in growth without tipping the economy over into recession; he will apply a few gentle touches on the monetary brakes. The consensus in the markets is that Greenspan - recently reappointed as chairman - will raise interest rates three or four times this year to a peak of about 6.5%. The first increase of a quarter of one per cent is expected next month.

In that dream scenario the economy behaves like a well-oiled engine. If gentle slowing down takes place, Greenspan's status as a miracle-worker will have been cemented for life - and thereafter. The new president will begin his term with worries about the economy on the back burner.

But economies rarely perform as predicted and in America's case there are numerous reasons why the story may not have a happy ending.

The principal danger is a stock market crash. Lombard Street Research's Tim Congdon points out that in the five years until to the third quarter of 1999, the S&P 500 index climbed in value by 192.7%. Yet company profits increased by only 64.9%. At some point there needs to be a realignment between the two figures. The only question is whether it happens gradually or in one swift movement.

The surge in stock prices is helping to give rise to the second major economic imbalance - unprecedented levels of consumer debt. Together with rising house prices, higher share prices have meant a jump of over $16trillion in the value of household assets since 1994, prompting consumers to spend and borrow more to finance consumption. The personal sector is in the red by 1% of GDP compared to a positive net savings ratio of 5% in the mid-80s.

As long as share prices go on rising, consumers are likely to feel bold enough to go on spending. But if there is a significant fall in the stock market it will lead to a sharp retrenchment in household spending with all its knock-on effects. Economic boom will turn into bust.

The third big imbalance is the yawning current account deficit, now averaging about $25bn a month. This approaches the 5% speed limit which the International Monetary Fund regards as safe in developing countries. With domestic production unable to satisfy demand, consumers and business have been importing goods and services from abroad in record volumes, putting the American economy deeply in debt to the rest of the world.

The insatiable appetite among foreign investors for US assets has ensured that, at least until now, there has been a ready supply of foreign currency to pay for these imports.

But sentiment in financial markets is notoriously volatile. The worry is that the supply of foreign capital will dry up if investors suddenly lose confidence in the US economy. Part of the reason for the wide availability of foreign funds has been that the rest of the global economy has been performing relatively badly, leaving investors with few alternative parking places for their cash.

Now that economic prospects are improving in both Europe and Japan, money could soon start flowing in the opposite direction out of the United States, forcing interest rates higher in order to attract capital and prevent the dollar going into freefall.

A revival in world growth also poses a risk for America on the inflation front. The good inflation performance in recent years has, in part, been due to the deflationary impact of subdued growth in Europe and Asia. Now that excess global capacity is being mopped up by rising world demand, there will be upwards pressure on prices. Again, higher interest rates would have to be the answer, perhaps higher than financial markets are now anticipating.

All in all, it looks like there will be a rocky ride ahead for whoever wins control of the White House this year. Worse still, the bubble might burst even before the elections are over. Then the candidates really will have something to argue about.

webTitle: TV gardeners put a bloom on horticulture business

fields.headline: TV gardeners put a bloom on horticulture business
fields.trailText: Britain's flower and shrub industry is blooming on the back of the gardening craze with sales up by 42% in 10 years, the National Farmers' Union said yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's flower and shrub industry is blooming on the back of the gardening craze with sales up by 42% in 10 years, the National Farmers' Union said yesterday.

Television presenters such as Charlie Dimmock and Alan Titchmarsh may have helped produce a new generation of green-fingered enthusiasts, but the unsung heroes of the reawakening of interest were commercial growers behind the £642m a year success story.

Bedding plants alone accounted for £142m of that to tal, with pot plants worth £59m, shrubs including Christmas trees £43m, roses £28m and cut flowers grown under glass £32m.

A survey by the NFU, to be published at the HortEx trade exhibition in Telford, Shropshire, today, reveals continuing confidence among growers despite the strong pound hitting exports and the threat of glasshouse business being hit by the climate change levy designed to reduce production of carbon dioxide.

Ben Gill, NFU president, said the government needed to "nurture these shoots, not strip them of life".

webTitle: Regions lose out in art's dash for cash

fields.headline: Regions lose out in art's dash for cash
fields.standfirst: Outlook poor, and getting worse, for groups outside the capital
fields.trailText: London is swallowing nearly half of all arts sponsorship, leaving cash-strapped theatres and museums in the rest of the country to fight for crumbs.
fields.body:
London is swallowing nearly half of all arts sponsorship, leaving cash-strapped theatres and museums in the rest of the country to fight for crumbs.

Sixteen of the 23 organisations that managed to raise £1m or more from business last year were London-based. And it is relatively rich and well-connected institutions such as the Tate Gallery and the Royal Opera House that are getting the biggest slice of the cake.

The divide between the haves and have-nots, has never been so wide, figures released today by the Art & Business group reveal.

Northern Ireland and the north did worst, netting barely £2.5m between them of the £141m spent on UK arts sponsorship last year. London attracted £64.45m.

The richest 3% of organisations - which employ teams of full-time fundraisers - took more than half of all business sponsorship. With the government pressuring the arts to raise more private money, the divide is expected to widen.

The inequalities are particularly worrying given how two large lottery-funded projects in the north have struggled to squeeze cash from private donors. The Royal Armouries, in Leeds, and Sheffield's Centre For Popular Music have both failed to attract the expected number of visitors and are in deep financial trouble.

In stark contrast, the Royal Opera House has managed to persuade philanthropists and corporate patrons to part with more than £100m to help rebuild its Covent Garden home.

Colin Tweedy, chief executive of Arts & Business, who compiled the study, said the divide was not just a regional one, it was also a question of size. Bigger organisations were gobbling up more of the available sponsorship because they had the resources to chase it.

"The Tate has 34 full-time fundraisers. Smaller arts organisations can only afford to devote a person here or there. How can they compete?"

Mr Tweedy said it was a "tragic, but inevitable", that Opera North and the Welsh National Opera, which put an emphasis on taking opera to places it would never normally be seen, would suffer because of the Royal Opera House.

"We have to find ways that great companies like this are not squeezed out."

Mr Tweedy said with spon sorship up nearly a quarter on 1998, the UK was moving ever closer to the US model, where arts were funded through a generous tax write-off system.

He said the introduction of a similar scheme in the UK, from April, where a donation of just £200,000 could be worth up to £1m to an art organisation, was a radical step. "We have to find ways to help the smaller organisations take advantage of this. Maybe they will have to pool resources."

Although committed to state funding, the government was increasingly looking across the Atlantic for ideas, Mr Tweedy said. "There is no option but to change, but it will be hard, especially at a time when business needs more and more convincing that the arts are relevant to them."

Alan Howarth, the arts minister, saw only encouraging signs in the figures. "The arts now have access to more investment than ever," he said.

 Eleven regional museums have been given grants totalling £500,000 to fund information technology projects.

The money will be used for projects including a website promoting the "Jewels of Milton Keynes" and a virtual gallery about Coventry's motor and aircraft industries.

webTitle: Tunnel toll row holds up ambulance patient

fields.headline: Tunnel toll row holds up ambulance patient
fields.standfirst: Crew spend 15 minutes arguing before being made to pay £1.20 fee
fields.trailText: An inquiry has been launched after an ambulance with a seriously ill patient on board was delayed for 15 minutes in the Mersey Tunnel while an attendant made the crew search for £1.20 to pay the toll.
fields.body:
An inquiry has been launched after an ambulance with a seriously ill patient on board was delayed for 15 minutes in the Mersey Tunnel while an attendant made the crew search for £1.20 to pay the toll.

The patient, a 74-year-old woman with breathing difficulties, was being transferred from Ormskirk hospital in Lancashire to a hospital in Chester. A nurse and doctor were also on board.

The ambulance crew were held up as they tried to leave the tunnel in Wallasey, Birkenhead. While the crew hunted for loose change, the batteries on their medical equipment failed and the patient was put on a back-up ventilator.

A spokesman for Lancashire ambulance service said they did not use the tunnel very often but were aware they had to pay in non-emergencies.

"The paramedic explained to the attendant that he had a seriously ill patient on board. He assumed that the Mersey tunnel company would allow the ambulance through, take the relevant details and submit an invoice," he said.

"The Mersey tunnel attendant and supervisor, however, refused to allow the ambulance through the barrier without payment, suggesting that the ambulance would have to find an alternative route to Chester.

"The ambulance was delayed by around 15 minutes, while the paramedic tried to reason with the tunnel staff."

David Hill, chief executive of Lancashire ambulance service, said: "I appreciate that the tunnel attendant would be following orders but I would have hoped that in such circumstances reason would prevail in the best interests of the patient.

"The ambulance was clearly marked and identifiable, the crew were in uniform and the paramedic explained that there was a very sick patient on board, accompanied by a nurse and doctor.

"As it happened, the patient's condition did not deteriorate during the ambulance journey as a result of the delay."

A spokesman for the NHS regional executive said: "Although the facts are still being investigated, this sounds like an extremely unfortunate incident which should not have happened.

"All concerned in these circumstances should be aware that the well-being of a very sick patient must come before other considerations."

But John Gillard, general manager of Mersey Tunnels, said an investigation was taking place. He said: "Normally there are two procedures which take place. First, the ambulance service notifies us as soon as it can that they are coming and they are given priority treatment.

"If they cannot contact us -and are on a blue light - then they are also given top priority. These measures work extremely well but on this occasion neither of these happened. We are very sorry that it did happen, and we don't yet understand why it happened.

"It is believed that the ambulance was not showing its blue light."

webTitle: £1m pay-out to roofer left brain damaged by fall at work

fields.headline: £1m pay-out to roofer left brain damaged by fall at work
fields.trailText: A former roofer who suffered brain damage in a 40ft fall yesterday won a near record £1m compensation and was given the go ahead to appeal for a higher amount.
fields.body:
A former roofer who suffered brain damage in a 40ft fall yesterday won a near record £1m compensation and was given the go ahead to appeal for a higher amount.

Neville Edwards, 29, of Newcastle upon Tyne, was left virtually unable to communicate and needing 24-hour care after the accident in October 1993.

Recorder Ben Nolan QC awarded Mr Edwards a total of £985,620 in a case the worker's solicitors claimed had major implications for other injured employees.

He was given leave to ask the court of appeal to double £88,400 awarded for pain and suffering calculated under the current system.

And the recorder also increased the sum covering his future loss of earnings to £703,500 after accepting investments would grow by 2% above inflation rather than the 3% normally accepted.

Philip Davison of Thompsons Solicitors, who represented Mr Edwards, predicted the total could reach seven-figures and force firms to take safety far more seriously.

"The courts need to recognise that the current awards for pain and suffering are massively out of date and the sooner that they award realistic compensation, for what victims like Neville will have to live with for the rest of their lives, the better," he said.

The case is by far the biggest of four involving compensation for pain and suffering the appeal court will consider after a law commission proposal two years ago that amounts should be doubled.

Courts now calculate awards from judicial guidelines that would put a maximum £125,000 on a case involving a victim left in a permanent vegetative state.

Mr Edwards was also awarded £156,500 for losses during his 76-month legal battle and other sums totaling £37,220.

He plummeted 40 ft from a pitched roof while stripping asbestos without any safety equipment.

A spokesman for his former employer, Team Roofing, could not be contacted last night.

Mr Edwards was backed throughout his legal fight by the AEEU engineering union."I could never have fought without the backing of my union," he said.

Sir Ken Jackson, AEEU general secretary, said: "No amount of compensation can ever make up for the pain and suffering caused to Neville. However, the judge has recognised the exceptional circumstances behind this case."

fields.headline: Prep school head 'was serial abuser'
fields.trailText: A teacher preparing boys for one of Britain's leading Catholic public schools betrayed his pupils' trust and became a serial abuser, a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A teacher preparing boys for one of Britain's leading Catholic public schools betrayed his pupils' trust and became a serial abuser, a court was told yesterday.

But on the first day of his trial, one of Robert "Rory" O'Brien's alleged victims admitted lying in statements to police and acknowledged that his schooldays had been "a complete disaster" until the head helped him to cope.

O'Brien, 57 and a father of five, denies preying on children at St Mary's Hall prep school in Lancashire, which is the main feeder school for nearby Stonyhurst College. He pleaded not guilty to six charges of indecent assault on four pupils going back to 1972.

The former head of the prep school was described at Preston crown court as a teacher whose double life was an abuse of his position.

Prosecutor Elizabeth Nicholls said that O'Brien had even contacted one of his alleged victims 20 years later, to see if he had made a complaint - "pivotal evidence for the crown," she said.

The court heard that police found semen traces from O'Brien and one of the boys after a forensic search of the head's study at St Mary's, following a complaint two years ago from a man who had been at the school in the early 1970s. Following the investigation, two boys, now aged 15 and 17, contacted police and a fourth alleged victim, a pupil in the 1970s, also came forward.

Ms Nicholls said that O'Brien, from Hurst Green, Lancashire, was suspended after the accusations and later took early retirement.

She told the jury of five men and seven women: "At the conclusion of this trial you will have no doubt that Robert O'Brien was a devoted and charismatic teacher.

"Therein lies the tragedy, for Mr O'Brien abused his position of trust and authority and subjected four young boys to sexual abuse."

The court heard that the first alleged victim, now in his 30s, had been assaulted in a dormitory at the age of 10.

O'Brien, who was made head of St Mary's in 1990 after some 20 years' teaching at the school, which takes boys aged six to 13, later used night security patrols to select his victims, Ms Nicholls said.

The two teenagers claimed, in separate complaints to police, that the headmaster came into their dormitories when they were aged 12 and 13, shone a torch in their eyes, and took them to his study to indecently assault them.

The fourth alleged victim, now in his 30s, told police that he was assaulted until the time he moved on to Stonyhurst, and had been invited back from the college to the prep school for a final meeting with O'Brien.

Cross-examined on video-link by defence barrister John Jackson, the 17-year-old boy said that he had lied in a police interview. The boy said that his claim that abuse had only stopped when he hit O'Brien, shortly before leaving for Stonyhurst, had been false. He lied, he said, because he was scared of O'Brien.

The case continues.

The boy said that his claim that abuse had only stopped when he hit O'Brien, shortly before leaving for Stonyhurst, had been false. He lied, he said, because he was scared of O'Brien. webTitle: Big Issue seller killed for his savings

fields.headline: Big Issue seller killed for his savings
fields.trailText: A Big Issue seller, who built up tens of thousands of pounds in savings by spending long hours selling the magazine on the streets of Cardiff, was bludgeoned to death on a south Wales beach by a "greedy" flatmate who later took money from his bank account.
fields.body:
A Big Issue seller, who built up tens of thousands of pounds in savings by spending long hours selling the magazine on the streets of Cardiff, was bludgeoned to death on a south Wales beach by a "greedy" flatmate who later took money from his bank account.

Wayne Aird, 30, was yesterday jailed for life after pleading guilty at Swansea crown court to the murder of 37-year-old university graduate Timothy Pincott in June last year.

The court heard that Mr Pincott, a Cardiff university biology graduate, had had a number of jobs before returning to the city in the early 1990s. He began selling the Big Issue, which is aimed at helping homeless people, in 1995.

Jane Macdonald, prosecuting, said Mr Pincott had worked hard, selling the magazine 12 hours a day. By the end of 1998 he had amassed £47,000 in a Co-op bank account and £10,000 in a Tessa account.

Aird, also a Big Issue seller, is said to have plotted the murder after moving into Mr Pincott's Cardiff flat last spring and learning of his savings.

Witnesses recalled him having talked of killing his flatmate for the money. But they dismissed his stories as fantasy.

The court heard that on the night of June 23 last year the two men went for a drink on a beach at Rhoose, near Cardiff, where Aird battered Mr Pincott over the head with a rock before dragging his body into nearby salt marshes.

A police investigation was launched after Mr Pincott's body was discovered floating in the sea almost 10 days later. Aird, who had left Cardiff after the killing, was arrested on July 7 and charged with murder.

He told police he had rowed with Mr Pincott and had thrown a rock which hit him on the head. But prosecutors said his account was not consistent with the injuries to Mr Pincott's face.

After leaving Cardiff, Aird made numerous withdrawals from Mr Pincott's bank account, using the £5,000 he took out to travel around the UK and buy presents for his friends, the court heard.

John Rees QC, defending, said Aird disputed that Mr Pincott's death was a premeditated killing for money. He told the court that Aird had taken money from the account which he thought was rightfully his. "He and the deceased were homosexual lovers and the deceased told him their relationship was at an end," Mr Rees told the court.

But Ms Macdonald said the murder had been motivated by the defendant's "greed for money".

She rejected Aird's claim that his flatmate was a homosexual and said he had started seeing a woman in Nottingham.

Sentencing Aird to life imprisonment, Mr Justice Turner said: "You have committed a brutal murder, I am quite satisfied, in order to obtain access to substantial funds that Mr Pincott had accumulated by dint of hard work."

webTitle: Judge's last ditch attempt in pursuit of Pinochet

fields.headline: Judge's last ditch attempt in pursuit of Pinochet
fields.trailText: The Spanish government yesterday forwarded a request from the judge responsible for Augusto Pinochet's arrest demanding he undergo further medical tests in a last ditch attempt to keep the legal case against the former Chilean dictator alive.
fields.body:
The Spanish government yesterday forwarded a request from the judge responsible for Augusto Pinochet's arrest demanding he undergo further medical tests in a last ditch attempt to keep the legal case against the former Chilean dictator alive.

Spain's foreign ministry said it had forwarded the petition from Judge Baltasar Garzon, asking for medical tests to be carried out by doctors of his choice. The request follows last week's announcement by the home secretary, Jack Straw, that he was "minded" to halt extradition proceedings against the general on medical grounds.

The campaigning Spanish judge has also reiterated his demand, first made when Gen Pinochet was arrested in October 1998, to be allowed to question the general in person about crimes committed under his 17-year regime.

However the request appears to be little more than a final throw of the dice by Judge Garzon.

The Spanish government, which has never been comfortable about being caught in the middle of the Pinochet affair, said it had reaffirmed to London that it would not appeal Mr Straw's ruling.

In response Chilean sources said Gen Pinochet would never accept a new request for fresh medical tests carried out by doctors chosen by the Spanish prosecutor.

"Gen Pinochet and the Chilean government have never recognised that Judge Garzon has jurisdiction in this matter," the source said.

"There is no way he will undergo further medical tests at his or anybody else's request."

Mr Straw has given interested parties until 5pm today to present submissions objecting to his decision.

The home office said it could take several days for Mr Straw to make a final ruling on the Gen Pinochet case, depending on the size and number of the representations received.

The Chilean government is clearly not expecting an immediate decision.

The air force jet, which has routinely arrived in Britain whenever there has been the semblance of a chance of Gen Pinochet being released, is still in Santiago .

Pablo Cabrera, the Chilean ambassador in London, said: "We have not dispatched any aeroplane yet. We have been wondering whether to do it but we have been behaving very prudently in order not to give any impression of pressure or anxiety."

Amnesty International and other human rights groups said that they would deliver their formal submissions to the home office at 10.30am today.

The representations will concentrate on the fact that Spain and other interested parties have not been given access to the medical reports, allowed to challenge them, or to obtain an independent medical opinion.

However any chance of mounting a legal challenge to the medical evidence appeared to be diminishing yesterday when Sir John Grimley Evans, the gerontologist who led the medical team which examined Pinochet, scotched reports that Mr Straw had misled the House of Commons about the reports findings.

In a letter to the home office Sir John wrote: "I consider the home secretary's statements about the report's findings to have been entirely correct and appropriate."

In London, relatives of the "disappeared" urged the Metropolitan police to bring criminal charges against Gen Pinochet if the extradition case against him were to be dropped.

A delegation, led by Labour MP Jeremy Corbyn, met Assistant Commissioner David Veness to lobby for an investigation into Gen Pinochet under UK law. Campaigners hope a case brought by Scotland Yard would stop the general leaving the country.

Mr Corbyn said Mr Veness had confirmed that Scotland Yard had a file on the general and was considering whether to take any action.

webTitle: Only one UK restaurant gets top rating

fields.headline: Only one UK restaurant gets top rating
fields.standfirst: Michelin guide decides none of London's luxurious dining rooms worthy of its coveted three stars
fields.trailText: For the first time in 15 years, Britain has only one restaurant worthy of the Michelin guide's coveted three stars, according to the latest edition of the gastronomic review.
fields.body:
For the first time in 15 years, Britain has only one restaurant worthy of the Michelin guide's coveted three stars, according to the latest edition of the gastronomic review.

The Waterside Inn in Bray, near Maidenhead, is now Britain's sole three-star establishment, with French chef-proprietor Michel Roux retaining his top culinary rating for the 16th year running.

Marco Pierre White's Oak Room at the Hotel Meridien, and Nico Ladenis's Chez Nico, at the Grosvenor House Hotel, both in central London, have both been dropped, after earning three stars in 1999.

The 100th Michelin Red Guide, published yesterday, leaves London - long considered Britain's culinary capital - with not a single dining room with three stars and only four two-star restaurants.

Last year, Britain had a trio of top-rated chefs, and while there is little hope of ever outnumbering France's 21 three-starred chefs, the new guide will leave a bad taste for many gourmet diners.

Michel Roux, whose luxurious restaurant sits on the banks of the Thames in picturesque Bray, is not the first member of his family to be the sole three-starred chef in Britain. The honour was last held in 1984 by his brother, Albert, at Le Gavroche in London's Mayfair.

Despite the loss of two top restaurants from the guide, there was good news for many other restaurateurs, including the Conran empire, which won its first Michelin star for Orrery, in Marylebone.

Marco Pierre White and Nico Ladenis contacted Michelin last September and asked to be removed from the guide after White announced that he was retiring from cooking to concentrate on managing his extensive restaurant business, while Ladenis said he was changing direction by bringing down prices and altering his menu.

White, the first British chef to win three stars five years ago, said: "Chasing three stars is more exciting than defending them. Now I have a family, my priorities are different. I wanted Michelin to take the Oak Room out of the guide so that when Robert Reid, the head chef, wins a star, it will be entirely earned by him."

British restaurants have reached a watershed, said Nico Ladenis: "People have become more sophisticated and they don't like the very high expense that Michelin stars unfortunately bring with them. I have not lost my stars. I just want to cook without the burdens that come with Michelin. I want to cook simpler food and become more accessible to more people."

Michelin spokesman Paul Cordle said: "We felt it wouldn't be right to include two restaurants when we weren't sure what they were going to be like. It is better to take them out of the guide altogether and reassess them for the 2001 guide."

While the three-stars, denoting "exceptional cuisine", may have dwindled in number, there remain 12 two-stars offering "excellent cooking", unchanged from last year.

Pied a Terre, in Bloomsbury, lost one of its two stars, although Michelin stressed that the change was not due to the departure last month of Tom Aikens, the youngest British chef to be awarded two Michelin stars, following allegations of violence in his kitchen.

Meanwhile, Le Champignon Sauvage, in Cheltenham, was upgraded to two stars.

A total of 86 establishments were awarded one star, up six from last year, with Ludlow in Shropshire retaining all three of its one-starred establishments. And 124 restaurants were placed in the "Bib Gourmand" category of good food at moderate prices, up 19 from last year.

The guide aims to give travellers a comprehensive selection of places to eat. But its critics claim its bias towards traditional French cuisine ignores the multi-cultural tastes which now dominate the British restaurant scene.

Matthew Fort, the Guardian's food critic, said: "The worry is not that Marco and Nico don't have three stars, but that no one else appears to be thought suitable to be awarded them. That will concern people in the industry."

Starstruck

Three stars:

Waterside Inn, Bray, near Maidenhead, Berkshire

Two stars:

England
Gidleigh Park, Chagford, Devon

Gordon Ramsay, Chelsea

La Tante Claire (at the Berkeley Hotel), Belgravia, London

Le Champignon Sauvage, Cheltenham (new)

Le Gavroche, Mayfair

Le Manoir aux Quat' Saisons, Oxford

Lettonie, Bath

L'Ortolan, Reading

The Square, Mayfair

Winteringham Fields, Winteringham, Lincolnshire

Scotland
Almaharrie Inn, Ullapool

Republic of Ireland
Patrick Guilbaud, Dublin

 Michelin Guide: Great Britain and Ireland 2000

webTitle: Dobson wife accused of race bias

fields.headline: Dobson wife accused of race bias
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Janet Dobson, wife of Labour's London mayor hopeful Frank Dobson, racially and sexually discriminated against a member of her staff, it was alleged at an employment tribunal yesterday.
fields.body:
Janet Dobson, wife of Labour's London mayor hopeful Frank Dobson, racially and sexually discriminated against a member of her staff, it was alleged at an employment tribunal yesterday.

Wangui Wa Goro, formerly an equality officer for Hackney council, east London, was suspended on full pay for nine months in 1994 after a "maliciously conceived" disciplinary action by Ms Dobson, then head of strategic support services for the council's education department, it was claimed.

Ms Dobson had alleged that Ms Wa Goro plagiarised a report on gender guidelines for schools, the tribunal in west London was told.

Gerry German, lay representative for Ms Wa Goro, said that while the report did rely heavily on a similar document produced by Lancashire county council, it was not plagiarism. Ms Wa Goro, a Kenyan citizen, is claiming sexual and racial discrimination against Hackney council. She is also claiming unfair selection for redundancy.

"The substance of the charge is false," Mr German argued when the hearing opened last August. "White people would not have been similarly treated. Because of her [Ms Dobson's] status in the borough council and the force with which she presented her opinion, other officers simply echoed her opinion."

Jane Connor, formerly the women's equality officer for Hackney council, told the tribunal that Ms Wa Goro had come to see her in 1994 in a "very distressed state". She complained of being undermined and picked on about aspects of her work.

In her witness statement, Ms Wa Goro said she was shocked when Ms Dobson revealed the allegation of plagiarism. "I sat there for some minutes completely stunned... I had never been in trouble all my working life." Ms Wa Goro returned to work in June 1995 following the suspension, but was made redundant in December 1996.

Ms Dobson, now a senior research fellow in the geography department at University College, London, was not at yesterday's hearing. She has been married to the former Labour health secretary for 32 years and they have three children. Ms Dobson is expected to give evidence later this week.

The hearing continues today.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Teacher pushed wife from cliff
fields.body:
Teacher pushed wife from cliff

A teacher yesterday admitted killing his wife by pushing her off a cliff.

Denis Day, 55, told Swansea crown court that he pushed his wife Ann from a coastal path in Freshwater East, Pembrokeshire, last April. He pleaded guilty to manslaughter and was granted bail pending pre-sentence reports.

Mrs Day's family backed a prosecution decision not to proceed with a charge of murder against Day.

Antisocial order on boy nuisance

A 15-year-old who has not been to school since he was 12 was made the subject of a two-year antisocial behaviour order yesterday after harassing his elderly neighbours.

The boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, subjected tenants on an estate in West Bromwich, West Midlands, to constant abuse and intimidation, the town's magistrates heard.

He was alleged to have set fire to clothes on a washing line and on other occasions threw bricks and stones.

Sandwell council took action under the crime and disorder act 1999.

Mallon to meet the Pope

The Northern Ireland deputy first minister, Seamus Mallon, is to have a private audience with the Pope this week, it was announced yesterday.

The audience, on Thursday, is understood to be in recognition of the SDLP deputy leader's work for peace and political stability in Northern Ireland.

While in Rome he will carry out a series of briefings at embassies and with the Italian government.

The Northern Ireland first minister, David Trimble, met the Pope at the Vatican last year, together with other Nobel prize winners.

Nurse jailed for scalding patient

A psychiatric nurse who forced a patient to drink scalding tea, which blistered his lips, was jailed for four months yesterday.

Ian Caine, a 48-year-old charge nurse, from Rotherham, was convicted last year of ill-treating Paul Blake, 25, at the town's psychiatric hospital.

At Sheffield crown court yesterday, Judge Alan Goldsack said Caine's behaviour and failure to accept responsibility forced him to impose a jail term.

Caine was said to have forced Mr Blake to drink scalding tea more than once and to have dug his elbows into the patient's chest.

He was brought to justice after colleagues complained about him and an investigation was launched.

webTitle: Millions likely for boy disabled by farm visit

fields.headline: Millions likely for boy disabled by farm visit
fields.trailText: A six-year-old boy may win millions of pounds in compensation after suffering brain damage from a bug he picked up on a school visit to a farm.
fields.body:
A six-year-old boy may win millions of pounds in compensation after suffering brain damage from a bug he picked up on a school visit to a farm.

Tom Dowling is confined to a wheelchair, cannot move his arms or legs, is fed by a tube through his stomach and can only communicate by blinking and smiling, after the accident in 1997 when he was four.

Bowmans Open Farm in Colney, near St Albans in Hertfordshire, and Barnet education authority yesterday admitted most of the liability at the high court in London and agreed to pay £200,000 towards Tom's 24-hour care before the case is heard to determine the final size of the settlement.

The court heard that there had been two other cases of similar poisoning at the farm in the previous six weeks - one involving the son of the managing director.

Tom, who has a younger brother Charlie, three, narrowly escaped death from the E.coli 0157 bacteria which attacked his kidneys and brain and left him in a coma for 12 days after the visit with Edgware infants school. He now attends a special school in Cambridge five days a week.

The department of education said it would be examining details of the court case to see whether further advice should be given to schools on visits to farms which attract 12m visitors of all ages each year.

Healthy cattle and other animals harbour the bugs and spread it through their droppings.

Lawyers said Tom's family had suffered severe financial hardship and his parents had broken up. They would be claiming "several million pounds" so that his mother could provide the house and care that Tom needed.

Tom's mother, Tracy Dowling, said last night: "This is a huge relief. I am hoping we can perhaps pick up again on life and can have Tom back again and that he gets what he deserves again carewise and everything else.

"He loved animals, children do, and it is hard for me to say children should not go to farms." But she had never been properly warned of the risks and allowed to make the choice of whether Tom went on the visit or not. Tom may not even have touched any animals but may have touched a fence or his footwear and then put his hands to his mouth.

Her solicitor Jill Greenfield said: "Stricter controls on open farms must be a priority and, if nothing else, this case should be seen as a warning to all open farms for the need to shape up and realise that young children visiting farms is a serious matter.

"Local authorities must give clear instructions to teachers and make sure that they are carried out. Four-year-old children cannot read signs warning to wash hands. They do not realise the dangers and nor do their parents."

Caroline Metcalf, solicitor for Bowmans Farms Ltd, said the farm management "deeply regrets" what happened to Tom.

It had closed voluntarily for five weeks after the incident and conceded there was doubt that information "customarily given" by both farm and school had been given on this occasion, she said.

"The farm has been subject to vigorous and exhaustive inspection by the health and safety executive who has made further recommendations, all of which have been implemented." More than 150,000 visitors had been to the farm since Tom.

Zurich Municipal, the insurers for Barnet education authority, said: "This was a tragic accident. We are not trying to stop this kind of visit. The world is full of risk but local authorities should take every possible precaution."

Virulent bacterium identified in early 1980s and common in intestine of healthy cattle. Spreads through contact with faeces as well as in raw or undercooked meat. Thought responsible for death of 20 people in worst outbreak linked to a butcher's shop in Lanarkshire in 1996. Thankfully rarely reaches humans because of food safety checks and other hygiene precautions.

Very small amounts can bring serious, sometimes fatal, consequences, especially for children and elderly people. Symptoms range from mild diarrhoea to huge changes in the body's fluids leading to severe brain damage.

Eradication or even control in animals thought unlikely to be possible, therefore risk of contamination by contact with animals, fences or even paths spattered with cow dung. Fear children especially may spread disease by putting unwashed hands to mouth, including after removing boots or shoes. Cooking meat at 70°C for two minutes should kill the bug. Occasionally finds its way into unpasteurised milk, fresh vegetables and even water.

webTitle: Sinn Fein stops visit by duchess

fields.headline: Sinn Fein stops visit by duchess
fields.standfirst:
Catholic school forced to cancel engagement
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein was accused of an own goal yesterday after it forced the cancellation of the Duchess of Abercorn's visit to a Catholic primary school, describing her as a member of the British royal family.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein was accused of an own goal yesterday after it forced the cancellation of the Duchess of Abercorn's visit to a Catholic primary school, describing her as a member of the British royal family.

The duchess was to visit St Mary's primary school in Pomeroy, near Omagh, Co Tyrone, to promote a creative writing programme in memory of her great-great-great grandfather, Alexander Pushkin, the Russian poet. Protestant and Catholic schools throughout Ireland have entered the competition for 12 years.

But Michael Harvey, the school's principal, suggested on Sunday that she postpone the visit. Sinn Fein councillor Finbarr Conway had told him that there was strong opposition among parents to a visit by a member of the royal family.

The duchess, who lives at Baronscourt, Newtownstewart, Co Tyrone, said yesterday that she was not a royal family member. "There is some misinformation going around, misinformation which seems to upset what could be very good and creative programmes."

Mr Conway insisted parents would be relieved the visit had been cancelled, adding: "For proud Irish people like those in Pomeroy, to be lumbered with a duchess did cause some concern. She carries a title and is associated with the royal family."

He said that her husband James Hamilton, the fifth Duke of Abercorn, was Lord Lieutenant of Co Tyrone, a Buckingham Palace appointment. He is a former Ulster Unionist MP.

The Pushkin Prizes Trust, whose patron is Derry poet Seamus Heaney, is this year welcoming entries in Irish, as well as English and Russian, for the first time. The Irish government is a strong supporter.

The SDLP was furious at Sinn Fein's move, and there were hints that Mr Harvey had feared intimidation. He refused to comment yesterday.

SDLP assembly member Denis Haughey, a junior minister at Stormont, labelled Sinn Fein's move "bigotry, simple straightforward bigotry." He said it was the latest in a series of incidents which illustrated Sinn Fein's insular small-mindedness.

They include an ongoing row in nearby Carrickmore, where several republicans are engaged in a campaign against the parish priest, Monsignor Denis Faul, after he attended an RUC-liason meeting in an attempt to crack down on crime on elderly residents. They want Monsignor Faul, a staunch critic of the IRA in recent years, removed. Several SDLP members, including assembly member Eugene McMenamin in Strabane, have had their homes targeted, with republican slogans daubed on the walls.

The principal of a Catholic primary school in Co Down complained last year after Sinn Fein voiced anger that RUC officers were invited to address children on road safety. He said he felt intimidated.

Sinn Fein's chief negotiator Martin McGuinness, education minister, said he had spoken to Mr Harvey and he hoped the matter could be resolved satisfactorily. That was an indication he hoped the duchess's visit would go ahead.

Mr Haughey, who called for a meeting with Mr McGuinness, said: "What about all Sinn Fein's talk of equality, a new future, freedom, and their favourite phrase, being inclusive, positive and constructive?

"What is positive and constructive about opposing a visit to the school by a person striving to bring literature into the lives of the young?"

Ian Paisley junior, a DUP assembly member, said: "If this episode wasn't so sad, it would be hilarious. Sinn Fein are pathetic."

webTitle: Couture 2000  Galliano stamps identity on Dior

fields.headline: Couture 2000  Galliano stamps identity on Dior
fields.trailText: Couturiers are often criticised for embellishing their creations with way too much detail, but John Galliano's collection for Christian Dior gave new meaning to the phrase "everything but the kitchen sink". Down the back of one pair of wide-cut linen trousers dangled a plug on a chain - alongside   some broken spectacles, a tin opener and a miniature bottle of Jack Daniels.
fields.byline: Laura Craik,  Fashion Editor, in Paris
fields.body:
Couturiers are often criticised for embellishing their creations with way too much detail, but John Galliano's collection for Christian Dior gave new meaning to the phrase "everything but the kitchen sink". Down the back of one pair of wide-cut linen trousers dangled a plug on a chain - alongside some broken spectacles, a tin opener and a miniature bottle of Jack Daniels.

This was less silly gimmickry than Galliano stamping his identity - and humour - on to Dior at a time when identity is more important than ever. The rash of mergers and takeovers within the fashion industry has changed the landscape radically: designers recognise they must fight for brand awareness more fiercely than ever.

At the spring/summer ready to wear collections, most responded by splashing logos on to their clothes, not least Galliano, who emblazoned dresses, jackets and accessories with Dior's "CD" logo. Mercifully, his spring/summer couture collection was almost logo-free.

This was true showmanship: boyish girls in wide check wool trousers, faces painted like Chaplin and dangling old kit bags from their arms, sirens in tomato-red beaded dresses with corsets and bondage-like buckles, and ballerinas in pleated chiffon evening dresses.

And what of the sausage-dog balloon hats and diaphanous linen gowns inspired by straitjackets? Not the work of a madman, but of a designer who knows clever styling can be as memorable as a hundred logos. It might bear no relation to Dior's original vision, but this is couture 2000 - brand new.

webTitle: Cyanide claim in death on the Nile case

fields.headline: Cyanide claim in death on the Nile case
fields.trailText: A businessman poisoned his wealthy lawyer girlfriend with cyanide during a Nile holiday to gain more than £400,000 from her will, a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A businessman poisoned his wealthy lawyer girlfriend with cyanide during a Nile holiday to gain more than £400,000 from her will, a court was told yesterday.

John Allan, 47, has pleaded not guilty to murdering his partner, Cheryl Lewis, at the New Winter Palace hotel in Luxor, Egypt, in October 1998.

Opening the case for the prosecution, David Steer, QC, told Liverpool crown court that two days before they were due to finish their week-long holiday, Ms Lewis, 43, a successful lawyer, was taken ill.

He told how Pamela Black, an American tourist, was at reception when the defendant said to the receptionist: "My wife needs a doctor. I think she's dying."

Ms Black, who had some first aid training, went with Allan to the room where she found Ms Lewis naked on the bed, sweating profusely, barely breathing and foaming from the mouth, Mr Steer said.

The authorities in Egypt thought she had died of a heart attack but a specialist in England determined that she had been killed by cyanide.

Allan, a businessman who was said to be financially reliant on Ms Lewis, told a holiday representative that he thought Curtis Warren, a drugs dealer, could have been behind the murder, the court heard.

However, Mr Steer alleged, Allan had poisoned his girlfriend to gain from the deceased's jewellery and more than £400,000 from her will.

He said police had found floppy disks at the couple's home with three different versions of the will.

The court was also told that when a Mercedes car, which had belonged to Ms Lewis, was searched by police, four briquettes of sodium cyanide were found.

Ms Lewis, who ran her own practice in the Wirral, lived at Oxton, Birkenhead, with the defendant, who she had been seeing for around seven years since separating from her husband, the court heard.

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Happy Sundays for party people
fields.trailText: The weekend will no longer need to stop on a Saturday night for clubbers who want to dance the night away as the government yesterday announced plans to remove a 220-year-old law banning Sunday dancing.
fields.body:
The weekend will no longer need to stop on a Saturday night for clubbers who want to dance the night away as the government yesterday announced plans to remove a 220-year-old law banning Sunday dancing.

The plans to remove the ban on commercially organised dancing on Sundays, published in a draft deregulation order laid before parliament yesterday, means that "Sunday night fever" could soon sweep the country, according to the government.

The order, which will also amend the licensing act 1964, would allow clubs to open their doors on a Sunday and sell alcohol until 12.30am on a Monday. But to meet the concerns of those worried about the relaxation of the Sunday observance act of 1780, the government's proposals include the introduction of a power for licensing authorities to make an order restricting the hours of selling of alcohol to any time they consider appropriate in the light of the special nature of Sunday.

These include safeguards such as revoking extended licensing hours if disturbances occur outside premises and imposing an absolute 'last orders' time of 12.30 am for the sale of alcohol.

The move brings regulations governing Sunday dancing into line with theatres, cinemas, concerts, amusements, art galleries, sporting events, and zoos.

The home office minister Mike O'Brien said: "This ban is antiquated and should have gone years ago. Our proposals will give freedom of choice for people as well as remove an unnecessary regulation on business. Be it line dancing, square dancing, ballroom or disco, it is plainly daft to have a ban on dancing because it is a Sunday. If people want a bit of Sunday night fever, that's fine with me.

"But we are also conscious of the need to safeguard residents from disturbance and recognise that some people consider Sunday a special day. Our proposals therefore include specific measures to control noise and nuisance, and a power for licensing authorities to take account of the special nature of Sunday."

The new regulations apply only to England and Wales. Scotland and Northern Ireland have separate laws regulating Sunday entertainment.

The move towards more freedom prompted criticism from the Keep Sunday Special campaign.

The group's spokesman, John Alexander, said the move would put pressure on young people to go out more at the weekend. "The temptation of yet another night's entertainment on a Sunday night will mean a lot of young people will be going to school or college the next morning a little bit worse for wear."

However, a consultation exercise last year showed that councils, police and courts all supported the proposals.

webTitle: Norris to carry Tory banner in mayor contest

fields.headline: Norris to carry Tory banner in mayor contest
fields.standfirst:
The London mayor: special report
Tories in opposition: special report

Battle for London Former transport minister emphasises independent line after overwhelming nomination victory
fields.trailText: Steve Norris, the colourful former transport minister, was overwhelmingly selected yesterday as the Tory candidate for London mayor in a result which humiliated senior Conservatives who had tried to block him.
fields.body:
Steve Norris, the colourful former transport minister, was overwhelmingly selected yesterday as the Tory candidate for London mayor in a result which humiliated senior Conservatives who had tried to block him.

To the delight of his supporters, who are barely on speaking terms with the party leadership, Mr Norris beat his rival Andrew Boff by 12,903 votes to 4,712.

Within minutes of the results Mr Norris set himself at odds with William Hague when he insisted that he would publish his own manifesto which would be beyond the control of central office. "We'll have a short, but friendly, discussion with the leadership over the manifesto just before publication," one Norris supporter said.

Mr Norris underlined his independent streak at a central office press conference where the result of the ballot of the Tory London membership was announced. He directed a carefully-prepared jibe at the senior party official, Tim Collins, who launched a ham-fisted attempt last year to block his candidacy with a whispering campaign against the philandering former minister. "It is for others to play games," Mr Norris said when asked about his relations with the party.

He claimed he would co-operate with the leadership over his own manifesto, but he left no doubt that it would be his own work. "William Hague has made clear that ultimately it is the mayor's manifesto," he said. "I am not the sort of person to be dictated to from outside."

Bernard Jenkin, hastily appointed as the shadow minister for London after Shaun Woodward's defection to Labour, attempted to play down the significance of such remarks. He said that the "main programme for London" would be drawn up the shadow cabinet, in consultation with Mr Norris and the assembly candidates, adding: "We expect Steve to have his own manifesto to put his own gloss on issues. These are devolved matters."

Mr Norris is likely to face his first conflict with the shadow transport secretary, John Red wood, over his support for funding the London Underground through bonds. One supporter said that Mr Norris would not be able to support this policy because he would "have to live" with the government's policy of reviving the tube through public-private partnership.

At the press conference, Mr Norris was well rehearsed for questions about the shambles over Jeffrey Archer. The millionaire novelist was overwhelmingly selected as the Tory candidate last October, beating Mr Norris into second place, but was forced to stand down the following month after he admitted asking a friend to lie in a libel case.

"That was at least a millennium ago," Mr Norris joked, going on to say that he was confident that his campaign would not come unstuck. Watched by his partner Emma Courtney, Mr Norris said: "As I have just about the most public private life of anyone I can think of, that is not an issue which disturbs me greatly."

Labour and the Liberal Democrats were quick to dismiss Mr Norris. One Labour source described Mr Norris as "ideologically footloose" because of his admiration for Michael Portillo while portraying himself as a one nation Tory.

Susan Kramer, the Lib Dem candidate for mayor, described Mr Norris as a "man of the past", adding: "His control of London Transport has left us with a legacy of delays, congestion and disruption."

The candidate's five pledges

 Transport Promises "wholesale change" in management of tube.

 Crime Will publish daily lists of crime figures and promises "zero tolerance of political correctness in policing".

 Education Will establish an education envoy to resolve the "pay up or move out" problem of parents in areas with poor schools.

 Civic pride Will encourage building developments which incorporate shops, houses and offices on brownfield sites. Aiming to reduce rush hour.

 Finance Will campaign for end to unfair treasury funding arrangements which deprive London of £16bn a year.

webTitle: Anger as UK fails to tighten arms laws

fields.headline: Anger as UK fails to tighten arms laws
fields.standfirst: Wartime emergency powers on exports 'should be scrapped'
fields.trailText: The author of a damning report exposing secret arms exports to Iraq, said yesterday the government had failed to implement key recommendations he made four years ago.
fields.body:
The author of a damning report exposing secret arms exports to Iraq, said yesterday the government had failed to implement key recommendations he made four years ago.

They include the scrapping of wartime emergency powers which are still in place to give parliament the right to approve or block weapons sales.

"I said in my report I thought it was extraordinary and quite unacceptable that for so long emergency legislation, brought into being with the view to the emergency of world war two, should still be relied on," Sir Richard Scott told BBC radio.

His intervention in the running controversy over arms exports was prompted by the Guardian's disclosure last week of a dispute within Whitehall over planned arms sales to Pakistan.

Export controls are still covered by powers enshrined in a 1939 act described by Sir Richard during his inquiry as " totalitarian in concept and in effect".

He added: "Nothing can in my opinion excuse the continued reliance by government on the emergency powers after the emergency had long since passed other than, if it be an excuse, the pursuit of the grail of administrative convenience".

He also recommended that responsibility for arms exports should lie with a single department, but that, too, had not been acted on. Sir Richard said most of the actions taken to implement his recommendations took place under the former Conservative government. "I have to say that most of the steps that were taken were taken some time ago and not very much has happened over the last year or so."

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, said since Labour made so much of Sir Richard's recommendations in opposi tion, people were entitled to expect they would make more of it in government. "Arms exports contain the seeds of embarrassment for all governments and Labour has been no exception with East Timor, Sierre Leone and, most recently, Pakistan."

Martin O'Neill, Labour chairman of the Commons trade and industry committee, said yesterday that legislation to implement Sir Richard's recommendations should be introduced before the next general election. However, Whitehall sources said there were no plans to include it in the government's existing legislative programme.

fields.headline: The strange story
fields.trailText: Gormenghast | Trouble Between The Covers
fields.body:
'And now for something a little different," as the World Service said, announcing the end of Guys And Dolls and the beginning of Jude The Obscure.

Mervyn Peake's Gormenghast (BBC 2), dramatised in four parts, is quite different from anything else on TV. Or on earth. Here are cloud-capped towers and gorgeous palaces. Grotesque people in gorgeous clothes move formally through them like living ornaments. Many shots are from the point of view of a passing bat, suggesting that these people are only toys in a huge doll's house and toys can be manipulated. Lady Groan, like Queen Anne too sumptuous for her small crown, is walking with her half-witted sisters-in-law, Cora and Candice. Being mirror images of each other, they are dressed like Siamese. Bossily leading the way is a snow white crow.

Gormenghast has the kind of credits you read from the bottom up. Who designed these shimmering sets? (Christopher Hobbs). Dreamed up these extraordinary costumes? (Odile Dicks-Mireaux) And what's the crow called? (Jimmy White) The richly mysterious and imperial effect was achieved on what the BBC calls a relative shoestring and most people call £10,000,000.

Any actor who can both stand up to and suit this magnificence has had plenty of practice.

Christopher Lee for one. All those years toiling in Transylvania have not been in vain. As Flay, Lord Groan's butler, he looks like someone inadvertently left unburied. This is the sort of thing that could easily happen in Gormenghast. His accent is common but his arrogance is towering. Tall and attentu ated as he is, when he says "Manservant to the earl!" he visibly grows several inches more. A degree of deformity is normal in Gormenghast. As Lord Groan says, when his son is born, "Have you ever delivered a more hideous child!" "Never, my lord, never!" The child was, in fact, charming, which would account for their sense of shock.

Ian Richardson is mellifluously lonely as Lord Groan. His cry "My son, my son! Oh, Gormenghast!" is a melancholy, long, withdrawing moan. The man is more or less waiting to go mad.

A rank outsider, coming up fast to steal a place, in a hat like a tippling pagoda, is June Brown. She is Dot Cotton in Albert Square and, to some extent, Dot Cotton here too, providing most of the humour going. I was entertained by her speech to the dun-coloured peasants living outside the castle walls, whom she addressed roundly as "Lowest of the low!", before asking a favour. Among other lip-smacking comic actors to come are Spike Milligan, Stephen Fry, Gregor Fisher and Martin Clunes.

Built on dead ritual like a coral reef, full of queer, if colourful, fish, Gormenghast will be an easy prey for Steerpike (Jonathan Rhys Meyers), a scullion on the make. Gormenghast could be a metaphor for many things, including the BBC.

Trouble Between The Covers (BBC 2) is an exhila ratingly silly account of the birth pangs of a laddish magazine called Front. "Contains strong language and nudity," as Radio Times mentioned superfluously.

The editor, Piers, had been sacked from his last job at Loaded magazine for being unpopular - a tantalising titbit which was not pursued - but his editor-in-chief has faith in him. "Gregarious would be a good word for Piers. He does good party. His nerve endings are right for it. He's it. It's there. He understands it. He's been there."

Quite.

Circulation has had a winning wheeze, a poster of a model over every other urinal in Granada service stations . ("I don't think any other man's mag has done that.") Piers has a vision for his magazine ("I don't want it to be in any way wholesome, obviously") and achieves this easily. In spite of free 3D specs for pop-up nipples and the prize of a pop singer's pop socks, Front is instantly taken off the shelves at Sainsbury's. Possibly something to do with Piers' exposé of hard core porn in Leatherhead. I imagine Sainsbury's are pretty big in Leatherhead.

The excitement of the launch has buoyed Piers up, though his father has had two heart attacks and his mother has been admitted to hospital with exhaustion. As he said, if he didn't have the magazine he'd have been really pissed off.

As a final gesture, he projects FRONT over the offices of his old magazine, Loaded. Thus making himself even more unpopular.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Revolting People | Beyond Bedlam
fields.body:
There are about three good laughs in the first episode of Andy Hamilton's new series Revolting People (6.30pm, Radio 4), which makes it stand out sharply in the otherwise featureless landscape of broadcast comedy. The setting is Baltimore in 1770, where Samuel Oliphant is trying to run his grocery shop in the face of three appalling offspring, the restlessness of his fellow colonists, and the strain of redcoat billeting regulations. So far, it's unlikely to splinter George Washington's wooden dentures.

The title of Raj Persaud's study of psychiatric hospitals, Beyond Bedlam (9.0pm, Radio 4), refers to the 13th-century madhouse whose unfortunate inmates were regularly put on exhibition. These programmes bring out, however, the acute sensitivity of present-day staff to their patients' often intractable problems. Not least of the difficulties is that the side effects of some treatments serve to discourage their continuation after discharge - and back the sufferers must come.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The River Thames | Lost In Space | Honey, I Shrunk The Kids | Total Recall
fields.body:
The River Thames 3.30pm, History Channel
At face value the programme is informative in a sort of grown-up Blue Peter way, if rather dull (not a great surprise). Your host, Prince Edward, travels the length of the river in a royal barge stopping off at obvious points of historical interest such as Greenwich, the Tower and Vauxhall. But it is difficult to forget, in spite of his casual clothing and affable, relaxed manner, that Edward Windsor is part of the royal family, and that we are still more used to seeing him strutting up and down in a suit on state occasions.
Frances Peel Yates

Lost In Space (Stephen Hopkins, 1998), 2pm, 8pm, Sky Premier
This big-screen updating of the 60s TV show starts out impressively: special effects in hyper-drive with interstellar battles and an invasion of mechanical spiders. And with William Hurt heading the family Robinson, lost in deep space, the human element holds up pretty well - though you'd think any self-respecting dad would question the wisdom of a project that has Matt LeBlanc - dopey Joey, of Friends - as pilot.

Honey, I Shrunk The Kids (Joe Johnston, 1989), 7pm, Disney
Walt Disney funtime with loopy inventor Rick Moranis building a molecular-wotsit which reduces his kids (Amy O'Neill, Robert Oliveri) and the bratpack next door to a size that makes The Borrowers look heavy. Dumped at the bottom of the garden with the rubbish, they face an incredible journey home, past enormous bugs and bees.

Total Recall (Paul Verhoeven, 1990) 10pm, Sci-Fi
Rounding off the evening's sci-fi theme, a spectacular, mega-budget adventure adapted from Philip K Dick's mind-bending tale. Arnold Schwarzenegger plays an ostensibly ordinary labourer who slowly recalls he was once a secret agent: powerful corporate forces have been messing with his mind. Cue dizzying paranoid delusions and state-of-the-art violence. Michael Ironside's hefty heavy and bad, bad woman Sharon Stone are a memorable pair, too.

webTitle: Passport Control Who's in town and why

fields.headline: Passport Control Who's in town and why
fields.trailText:
Work Hard, Play Hard
With the nation's eyes glued to Heathrow customs this weekend as onetime-champion-turned-one-man-freakshow Mike Tyson swaggered into the country, you could be forgiven for forgetting the trans-Atlantic treadmill doesn't begin and end with choleric pigeon-fancying ex-cons. Take John Lasseter, the wholly even-tempered creator of such animated delights as A Bug's Life, who is in the UK right this moment plugging his latest pixelated opus, Toy Story 2. Pitching up for two days - starting yesterday - he'll be entertaining the press until this evening, at which point he hops on his flight back to the States.

Take John Lasseter, the wholly even-tempered creator of such animated delights as A Bug's Life, who is in the UK right this moment plugging his latest pixelated opus, Toy Story 2. Pitching up for two days - starting yesterday - he'll be entertaining the press until this evening, at which point he hops on his flight back to the States.

Blood On The Carpet
On a rather different cinematic note, meanwhile, Danish wunderkind Nicolas Winding Refn arrives from the mean streets of Copenhagen any time now for a brief stint in support of his imminent Bleeder, probably the most brutally accomplished Euro-flick since well, since his last one, the 1997 narco-drama Pusher. The surprisingly charming Refn can be found lurking in an alleyway near you until the end of the week, before returning to Denmark (or possibly Rio, where he's currently working with inimitable novelist Hubert Selby Jr).

Dope Show
And throw your collective hands in the air for Kenny "Dope" Gonzalez, one half of seminal house production team Masters At Work, who rolls up towards the end of the week in time for the launch party of his latest album (the winningly titled Funk Spectrum 2) at London's The End. Which just leaves room for avant-garde thrash-jazz nabob John Zorn, whose seemingly arbitrary range of squealing and parping visits The Barbican next Tuesday on a triple bill with fellow New York crazies Masada and Bar Kokhba.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Castaway 2000 9.30pm, BBC1
Rather than being content to act as a fly on the wall, more documentary makers seem to be creating the situations themselves (viz C4's Shipwrecked and 1900 House). Now it's the BBC's turn to gather a group of people and leave them to get on with surviving a year in primitive conditions on a remote Hebridean island. The first four programmes cover the selection process, and what should be an enthralling update will be shown towards the end of the year. Before the final choice takes place, two groups of 30 go on a training exercise in Wales. This is where the fun starts, as selection of the most suitable participants comes as much of a surprise to them as it does to the viewer.

Graham Greene: The Beginning Of The End Of The Affair 9.30pm, BBC2
Write about what you know, as creative writing students are always told. So Graham Greene did just that when he wove the story of his 13-year adulterous relationship with Catherine Walston into his 1951 novel The End Of The Affair. As Neil Jordan's film of the novel opens shortly, now seems a good time to explore that complex and very public relationship with the help of Walston's son and daughter. Son Oliver finds it all very fascinating, while daughter Anne is coldly disapproving of her mother's involvement with someone she regarded as selfish and demanding. Greene didn't help matters by naming his fictional cuckolded husband Henry; Walston Snr was called Harry.

webTitle: Controllers to abandon search for Mars Polar Lander

fields.headline: Controllers to abandon search for Mars Polar Lander
fields.trailText: The fruitless search for any sign of life from Nasa's Mars Polar Lander is being abandoned, ending any hope that the $165 million mission to the Red Planet can be saved.
fields.body:
The fruitless search for any sign of life from Nasa's Mars Polar Lander is being abandoned, ending any hope that the $165 million mission to the Red Planet can be saved.

The three-legged lander was to have touched down December 3 for a 90-day mission near Mars' south pole to study the atmosphere and dig for ice. It was last heard from minutes before beginning its descent.

Instead of revelling in new pictures and science, controllers have been methodically testing different scenarios to explain the silence.

Their last attempt ends at 8am local time Monday (1600 GMT), said Richard Cook, the lander's project manager at Nasa's Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

"In a way, we feel somewhat complete in the sense that we did go through the things we thought were reasonable," he said. "Obviously at this point none of that panned out, but we gave it a good shot."

Investigators will continue to seek an explanation for the failure and have launched a review of the Mars program, which also lost an orbiter in September. Another lander and orbiter are set to be launched next year, but at least part of the mission is now in doubt.

"The orbiter for sure will happen. There's no issue there," Cook said. "The lander they're still talking about."

Mars Polar Lander could have touched down on the side of a vast canyon and toppled over. Or it could have exploded before entering the atmosphere. Its radio systems might have failed. Or it could have sunk in Martian dust.

So far, attempts to capture a picture of the lander's parachute from the orbiting Mars Global Surveyor have been unsuccessful. Engineers are attempting to spot the Mars Pathfinder parachute to determine if the lander's parachute can be seen by the orbiting camera.

It's possible the reason for the mission's failure may never be known, but investigators will make recommendations for future missions. A likely recommendation will be the addition of a radio that maintains contact with Earth during the difficult entry and landing phases - something missing from last year's batch of spacecraft. The review boards are expected to release their findings in mid-March.

"I know they have lots of theories and ideas, but I don't know that they're any closer to nailing things down," Cook said.

Mission controllers have attempted to contact the lander with each communications window since December 3, and with each failure eliminated a possible failure scenario.

At first, the possible problems were simple. Perhaps the spacecraft's computers went into a safe mode or one of its two radios failed. After a week, controllers said it was very unlikely that they would ever hear from the spacecraft.

Since Jan. 6, controllers were working under the assumption that somehow the spacecraft's clock was scrambled, Cook said. Every two hours, the orbiting Mars Global Surveyor passed over the landing site and listened for a signal - just in case. Though untried possibilities remain, controllers decided to end the search.

"The way it works is that you can spend forever continuing to do things," said Nasa's Cook. "It could be this thing went wrong plus that thing went wrong plus another thing went wrong. But the likelihood is extremely remote and so we sort of draw the line."

webTitle: Jail was start of Lagos's climb to top

fields.headline: Jail was start of Lagos's climb to top
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Aside from a much-needed fillip for the leftwing arm of the ailing  Concertacion ruling alliance, Chile's election to the presidency Sunday of socialist candidate Ricardo Lagos was a personal victory of considerable magnitude.
fields.body:
Aside from a much-needed fillip for the leftwing arm of the ailing Concertacion ruling alliance, Chile's election to the presidency Sunday of socialist candidate Ricardo Lagos was a personal victory of considerable magnitude.

The country has, for the first time since Salvador Allende was overthrown in 1973, elected a staunch adversary of General Augusto Pinochet.

When armed gunman attempted to kill Gen Pinochet on September 7 1986, Mr Lagos was one of 44 prominent dissidents immediately arrested by the military regime. He was held for three weeks and, although he was never tortured, his brief encounter with state-sponsored thugs provided ample motivation for his next move.

fields.headline: Spin tussle over Lords reform
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Wakeham's royal commission report on the future of the House of Lords will not be sent to Tony Blair until shortly before its publication on Thursday morning because members of the commission want to prevent it being rubbished by Downing Street spin doctors.
fields.body:
Lord Wakeham's royal commission report on the future of the House of Lords will not be sent to Tony Blair until shortly before its publication on Thursday morning because members of the commission want to prevent it being rubbished by Downing Street spin doctors.

The 180-page report is the product of a year of difficult negotiation by the former Tory cabinet minister to produce a unanimous report, subtle enough to satisify radicals who want a wholly-elected upper house while cautious enough to appease No 10.

Lord Wakeham wants ministers, most of whom want no threat to their power to come from a "democratised" Lords, to think carefully about the report. Mr Blair is expected to offer a "warm" welcome on Thursday, without indicating how far he plans to accept it.

To ensure that happens Lord Wakeham will not send Mr Blair an advance copy, as he did the Queen last month, until Thursday morning "about 10 minutes before the press get it," one source said.

Another insider explained: "Wakeham wants his day in the sun, he does not want it to be (Alastair) Campbelled" - a reference to the tough tactics adopted by the prime minister's spokesman.

The report covers the structure and powers of the half-reformed house. But on the sensitive question of how to complete Lords reform, now that all but 92 of the hereditary peers have been retired, the commission is believed to be recommending three options.

They range from direct elections for up to 200 peers, election for half that number or an even smaller number indirectly elected from the regions. The house, currently around 661 members instead of 1,200, will end up around the 500 mark - though Lord Wakeham will delicately not suggest retirement for older life peers because they would block further form altogether.

The three options arose, as a means of retaining unity, because some commission members, led by Labour veteran, Gerald Kaufman MP, were adamantly against any elected peers.

Mr Blair himself does not go that far, though senior colleagues do.

Others like Lord (Douglas) Hurd, the Tory ex-foreign secretary, and Professor Dawn Oliver, a constitutional expert and ardent Lib Dem, wanted 100% per cent election.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Dancers. Plans to lift the 220-year ban on Sunday dancing were unveiled by the government. The home office minister, Mike O'Brien, said: "Be it line dancing, square dancing, ballroom dancing or disco, it is plainly daft to have a ban on dancing because it is a Sunday.

If people want a bit of Sunday Night Fever, that's fine by me."

Goodbye day

Liz Davies. The leftwing barrister has decided not to stand for re-election to Labour's ruling national executive committee. Ms Davies, who was once selected to fight Leeds NE and then promptly deselected, cited personal reasons for the decision.

Bad day

MPs in general. Exasperated Commons speaker Betty Boothroyd rapped them over the knuckles for asking ministers long and rambling questions. She added: "The government should answer questions far more briskly. Backbenchers too should take it upon themselves to sit in that tearoom at lunchtime and go through their question so that it is precise to the minister because many of them are rambling on."

Today

Tory-initiated debate on the governnment's management of health care. Short backbench debate on nerve gas poisoning. In the Lords the armed forces discipline bill is at report stage and the care standards bill at committee stage.
