fields.headline: Orazio Costa
fields.trailText: The Italian theatre director and drama teacher Orazio Costa, who has died aged 88, was maestro and mentor for generations of actors and directors, including the film stars Monica Vitti, Gian Maria Volonte and Vittorio Gassman. But, as a Catholic in the political climate of post-war Italy, he inevitably took third place to leftists like Giorgio Strehler and Luchino Visconti.
fields.body:
The Italian theatre director and drama teacher Orazio Costa, who has died aged 88, was maestro and mentor for generations of actors and directors, including the film stars Monica Vitti, Gian Maria Volonte and Vittorio Gassman. But, as a Catholic in the political climate of post-war Italy, he inevitably took third place to leftists like Giorgio Strehler and Luchino Visconti.

Costa was born in Rome and, at 14, gave up ambitions to be a nautical engineer after his success in a family production of a Goldoni play. He took evening acting classes and was introduced to Silvio d'Amico, Italy's leading drama critic and director of the Rome theatre school which became the National Academy of Dramatic Art. The director was sceptical about Orazio's acting chances - he spoke with a defective "r" - but eventually the young man was admitted to a D'Amico direction course, where he studied under Tatiana Pavlova, the doyenne of Italian drama teachers.

Costa soon rebelled against her traditional methods. In the mid-1940s, before Strehler and Visconti had started revolutionising the Italian stage, he had already experimented with his own approach on plays by Ibsen. After two years at the academy, D'Amico arranged for him to spend a year in Paris with Jacques Copeau, the great teacher of mimic performance - and in whom Costa found a kindred spirit.

Back in Rome, he worked with academy students, developing a method which encouraged directors to analyse plays more profoundly than was usual at Italian rehearsals, highlighting dramatic climaxes and guiding actors to use their bodies as well as their voices, which in Italian acting was often too inclined towards operatic tones. Vittorio Gassman never finished his academy course, but in later years acknowledged how much he had learned from Costa.

A year after Strehler and Paolo Grassi founded the Piccolo Teatro in Milan in 1947, Costa set up a similar institution in Rome, which, although it could not compete with the commercial circuits, lasted until 1954. He continued to direct, working with, among others, two of Italy's best stage actors, Tino Carraro and Salvo Randone, in the greatest role of the modern Italian dramatic repertoire, Pirandello's Henry IV. Invited by Strehler to direct at the Milan Piccolo, Costa also scored a notable success with one of the most controversial plays of the 1950s, Trial Of Jesus, by the Catholic writer Diego Fabbri.

Costa's interest in sacred texts led him to several medieval passion plays, and he was one of the first to direct on the steps of the church at San Miniato in Tuscany, where he staged Bernanos's Dialogues Of The Carmelites in 1952. He continued to teach at the academy until the 1970s, when he founded his own school in Florence, where he taught until the early 1990s. He would occasionally accept offers to act, and published La luna in casa (The Moon At Home), a selection of his poems.

John Francis Lane

webTitle: Chilean vote aligns South American leaders

fields.headline: Chilean vote aligns South American leaders
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The victory of Chilean socialist Ricardo Lagos on Sunday has brought about such symmetry in the political philosophies of some of South America's leaders that politicians and political analysts are already trumpeting a historic opportunity to build economic and cultural bridges in the southern portion of Latin America.
fields.body:
The victory of Chilean socialist Ricardo Lagos on Sunday has brought about such symmetry in the political philosophies of some of South America's leaders that politicians and political analysts are already trumpeting a historic opportunity to build economic and cultural bridges in the southern portion of Latin America.

"The election of Ricardo Lagos is going to mean a strong consolidation of the [South American trading bloc] Mercosur," said the Chilean foreign minister, Juan Gabriel Valdes.

"This is the news that both [Brazilian President Fernando Henrique] Cardoso and [Argentine President Fernando] de la Rua have been awaiting all week. [Lagos's administration] will be a government that consolidates its integration with Latin America and emphasises the macroeconomic co-ordination of the Southern Cone.

"Without a question, [Brazil, Argentina and Chile] are the three countries that have moved farthest in market reform, consolidation of democracy and respect for civil liberties," said Andres Velasco, director of the Latin American studies department at New York university. "As Ecuador, Colombia and Venezuela are having tremendously difficult times, it is good to have solid examples in the south."

Mr Velasco stressed that the biographies of the leaders of Brazil, Argentina and Chile provided an opportunity to take political reform beyond merely market and financial reform. Because each country is now ruled by a politician in his 60s, with extensive connections with grass-roots organisations, Mr Velasco said, the three countries serve as both a symbol of Latin American unity and a powerful example for other countries in the region seeking economic and political stability.

"Lagos is part of a new generation of politician that we are seeing in Latin America. These are politicians who have a commitment to social issues, but [who] have also accepted the open market," said Karen Poniachik, with the New York-based Council of the Americas. "The days of the paternalistic state or individualistic state are over. Now we are entering an era of fraternal co-operation."

Not since the mid 70s have the three economic powers of the south been so aligned - and that alliance was one of terror and torture. It is those difficult years that have been the basis for the long-term friendship that exists among the three.

When Mr Cardoso was exiled from Brazil in the 1960s, for example, he spent years in Chile, where he forged a tight bond with Mr Lagos. The Brazilian was among the first foreign leaders to call on Mr Lagos after Sunday's victory.

"Clearly, you have three leaders who come from a similar space in the political spectrum. And Cardoso and Lagos, in particular, share a common story," said Nelson Cunningham from the consulting firm Kissinger McLarty. "They were both exiled, both professors, and both moved from the left to the centre over the course of their careers."

The dividends of these friendships became clear last October, when Mr de la Rua won the Argentine presidency and shared his election stage with the Mr Lagos, who was in a tight race for the Chilean presidency, and who benefitted from the image that he was the president presumptive.

"This could be the impetus to more integration in the Southern Cone and more generally in Latin America," said Jorge Heine, a former Chilean cabinet minister. "Ricardo Lagos has a very strong commitment to the region and that is destined to be one of the strengths of his government."

fields.headline: Edmund Colledge
fields.trailText: Edmund Colledge, who has died aged 89, belonged to an era that saw in England a flowering of medieval scholarship. His most outstanding published work - produced with Fr James Walsh, SJ - was a full, critical edition of the revelations of Julian of Norwich, published as A Book Of Showings To The Anchoress Julian Of Norwich (1978) and accompanied by a modern version, Julian Of Norwich Showings.
fields.body:
Edmund Colledge, who has died aged 89, belonged to an era that saw in England a flowering of medieval scholarship. His most outstanding published work - produced with Fr James Walsh, SJ - was a full, critical edition of the revelations of Julian of Norwich, published as A Book Of Showings To The Anchoress Julian Of Norwich (1978) and accompanied by a modern version, Julian Of Norwich Showings. The latter was chosen by the Paulist Fathers as the first in their Classics Of Western Spirituality series, with sales topping 50,000.

Colledge contributed much to the understanding of English medieval women mystics and of their counterparts, male and female, in Germany and the Low Countries. In 1952, he published an edition of a treatise by the Dutch mystic, John Ruysbroek, The Perfection Of The Sons Of God, as well as an edition of Ruysbroek's Spiritual Espousals. In 1957, Colledge and Joyce Bazire, his Liver- pool university colleague, produced an edition of the 14th-century English spiritual treatise, The Chastising Of God's Children. Four years later came an anthology of English spiritual writers, The Medieval Mystics Of England. This was his last major publication before leaving Liverpool and joining the Augustinian order, the "Austin friars", as a novitiate at Claire Priory, Suffolk.

Colledge was born in Tynemouth, and was christened Eric, although half a century later he exchanged this for Edmund when he entered the Austin friars, in memory of St Edmund Rich of Canterbury. In 1932, he graduated with first-class honours in English from Liverpool university and won a studentship to the University of Munich. Back in Liverpool, he took his MA, and in 1935 was appointed assistant lecturer in English language and philology. Fluent in French, German and Dutch, he served with military intelligence during the second world war, and from 1945-46 was on the Allied Control Commission in Berlin, supervising the reopening of German universities.

Colledge returned to Liverpool in 1946 as a lecturer, rising to reader by 1961. While a devoted, no-nonsense teacher, there was also another, man-about-town side to him, at any rate in his younger days, when he sported flamboyant waistcoats and spats. A splendid host, he was highly entertaining, though, on occasion, liable to make enemies by a turn of caustic wit. He could have carved out a stage career; instead, he encouraged others, such as Patricia Routledge, to take up acting.

Colledge had been an Anglican, but was received into the Catholic church in 1949. Fourteen years later came the Austin Friars. After taking vows in 1964, he studied at Beda College, Rome. In 1967, he was ordained as a priest and appointed to St Monica's, Hoxton Square, in London's east end, where he combined pastoral and scholarly interests. He was invited to lecture at the Pontifical Institute of Medieval Studies in Toronto, and became a full professor there before retiring in 1977. It was in Toronto that The Book Of Showings was published.

Colledge's penultimate publication was an edition in English of Suso's Horologium Sapientiae. Virtually confined to bed, he still managed to correct the proofs of The Mirror Of Simple Souls (1999) by Margaret Porette, who had been burned as a relapsed heretic in Paris in 1310. Colledge, Professor Jack Marler and Judith Grant, of Auckland university, had laboured long and hard on the work. It was a fitting end to an outstanding literary and scholarly life.

Benedict Hackett

fields.headline: Taking liberties
fields.standfirst:
Pinochet's claim of sickness should be placed before a judge
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Despite the result of Sunday's election, General Pinochet is as likely to go to trial in Chile as he is to go to heaven. His supporters plan a hero's welcome in Santiago, where prospects for a miraculous recovery cannot be excluded. In these circumstances, the home secretary would be well advised to allow the final decision to release him on medical grounds to be made by the high court.
fields.body:
Despite the result of Sunday's election, General Pinochet is as likely to go to trial in Chile as he is to go to heaven. His supporters plan a hero's welcome in Santiago, where prospects for a miraculous recovery cannot be excluded. In these circumstances, the home secretary would be well advised to allow the final decision to release him on medical grounds to be made by the high court.

On principle, no trial can properly proceed if the defendant is "unfit to plead" - ie, is too senile to understand the evidence or instruct his lawyers. Extradition in these circumstances would necessarily be oppressive. Under section 11 (3) of the extradition act, the high court is empowered to order the release of a person on this ground if the passage of time since the commission of his offences has rendered him unfit to plead. This was established by the Davies case in 1997, where doctors on all sides confirmed to the court's satisfaction that the applicant was unfit to plead, and he was released - even though his mental condition had been triggered by fear of extradition.

It follows that the home secretary, rather than himself ordering Pinochet's release after privately considering the medical evidence, could instead place that evidence before the high court as early as next week and invite the judge to discharge the prisoner. This procedure would ensure that the medical evidence becomes public, and that the decision, made after arguments from interested parties, is recognised as judicial rather than political.

A similar procedure was adopted in the controversial case of Roisin McAliskey (see solicitor Gareth Pierce's letter in the Guardian on Monday). No sensible person could question Mr Straw's good faith, but a decision made by a court rather than a minister would be a more fitting conclusion to a momentous case in which the rule of international law was permitted to triumph over diplomacy and realpolitik.

The home secretary may have been wrongly advised that the medical reports on Pinochet are confidential. Every week in court such reports are publicly examined, whether to assess claims for compensation, or the defence of diminished responsibility, or the plea of unfitness for trial. Reports prepared by doctors to enable decisions on prisoners in a public justice process lose confidentiality - if their contents are in the public interest. The public interest in understanding a torturer's claim to be immune from trial on health grounds is compelling.

fields.headline: Bernhard Wicki
fields.standfirst: Film director who rescued German cinema from mediocrity
fields.trailText: During the 1950s, West Germany produced possibly the worst films in Europe, "educational" sex movies, crass comedies and saccharine romances. Yet in 1959, out of this morass of mediocrity, came The Bridge, a powerful and moving anti-war film directed by Bernhard Wicki, who has died aged 80.
fields.body:
During the 1950s, West Germany produced possibly the worst films in Europe, "educational" sex movies, crass comedies and saccharine romances. Yet in 1959, out of this morass of mediocrity, came The Bridge, a powerful and moving anti-war film directed by Bernhard Wicki, who has died aged 80. It linked the "Papas Kino" and the new wave of young film-makers such as Rainer Werner Fassbinder.

Based on an autobiographical novel by Manfred Gregor, The Bridge concerned seven Bavarian schoolboys who faced death defending an insignificant bridge against an American attack in the last days of the second world war. Several directors rejected the script before Wicki, a well-known stage and screen actor, took it on as his first directorial feature.

Made in a semi-documentary style, the film vividly portrays the boys' personal lives before they joyfully discover they are being drafted into the Wehrmacht in order to defend a local bridge. Unknown to the boys, the colonel who has given them this assignment plans to withdraw them before blowing up the bridge; due to a mishap, however, the boys are not withdrawn, and all but one die defending it.

In America, the film was nominated for an Academy award and won the Golden Globe award. Its success led to Wicki's co-directing assignment on Darryl F Zanuck's war epic, The Longest Day (1962), about the allied landings in Normandy in June 1944. The best parts of the 180-minute film were the German sections directed by Wicki, and featuring Gert Frobe, Curt Jurgens and Wolfgang Preiss. It was Wicki's last international success. "Such lucky breaks, when the material and the feel of the times come together so well, were difficult to repeat," he said some years later.

Wicki was born in Austria to Swiss-Hungarian parents, and always held Swiss nationality. He grew up in Vienna, where he attended the Reinhardt drama school and the Berlin state drama school under Gustaf Gruendgens. In the early 1940s, because of his membership of a communist organisation, he was sent to Sachsenhausen concentration camp, only to be released after 10 months, thanks to the help of Gruendgens.

He spent the early post-war years as an actor, making his screen debut in 1950. Among his best roles were as Johann Strauss in The Eternal Waltz (1955) and as the aristocrat who marries a much younger girl in Effi Briest (1955). In the same year that he directed The Bridge, Wicki gave a splendid performance in All Night Through, an otherwise badly-shot "good German" drama, as a Protestant pastor called to administer the last rites to a German soldier about to be shot for desertion.

His second film as director was The Miracle Of Mala- chias (1961), a funny and sharp satire on Germany's postwar economic recovery. The "miracle" of the title comes about when Father Malachias prays for the destruction of a gambling casino near his monastery. God obliges, but the situation deteriorates as the press, big business - one banker resembles the then German chancellor Konrad Adenauer - and the church profit from the event.

Though continuing to tackle serious subjects, Wicki's two American films were less satisfactory. The Visit (1964), starring Ingrid Bergman and Anthony Quinn, was a rather plodding version of Frederic Durrenmatt's play about the destructive nature of greed, and the equally heavy-handed The Saboteur, Code Name Morituri (1965), had Marlon Brando playing a rich anti-Nazi German, who is really a spy for Hitler.

Wicki appeared in better films as an actor. In Michel- angelo Antonioni's La Notte (1961), he was the dying friend whom Marcello Mastrioanni and Jeanne Moreau visited during a crisis in their marriage. In Ivan Passer's Crime And Passion (1976) he played a wealthy industrialist bent on murdering his wife (Karen Black) and her lover (Omar Sharif). He also appeared in playwright Peter Handke's first film as director, The Left-Handed Woman (1977).

As a film director, Wicki made a comeback with The Spider's Web (1990), based on Joseph Roth's novel about the prelude to Nazism. However, during its filming in Prague, he suffered a cerebral haemorrhage and, although he completed the movie, he never fully recovered. In the last years, he was looked after by his wife Elisabet Endriss.

Ronald Bergan

fields.headline: Grete Stern
fields.standfirst: Photographer exploring artistic parameters old and new
fields.trailText: The work of the photographer Grete Stern, who has died aged 95, spanned two distinct periods, styles and continents.
fields.body:
The work of the photographer Grete Stern, who has died aged 95, spanned two distinct periods, styles and continents.

Born into imperial Germany, in Wuppertal-Elberfeld, she spent three years studying graphic arts in Stuttgart, and a further two apprenticed to the photographer and fine arts lecturer Walter Peterhans during the time of the Weimar republic. Then, in Berlin at the end of the 1920s, she encountered the starkly dramatic Bauhaus style, which marked such a break with the flowery decadence that had preceded it.

Enthused and encouraged by Peterhans, one of the great teachers and innovators of his time, Stern was offered his studio when he became head of photography at the Dessau Bauhaus. In 1929 she opened it with her friend and colleague, the sculptor Ellen Auerbach, under their joint childhood nicknames of "Ringl" and "Pit".

The diversity of their artistic backgrounds was assisted by a period in which photography functioned as an adjunct of other disciplines, as well as a rich source of experimentation in its own right. Artistically speaking, it was an international language, with the Paris-based American Man Ray experimenting in solarisation, and the Hungarian Moholy-Nagy, having fled his home country, incorporating many images more familiar to cubism and early modernism. Renger-Patzsch and Umbo, Lotte Jacobi and Florence Henri were among others of Ringl & Pit's contemporaries and influences.

For three years before the Nazi takeover, which brought about Stern and Auerbach's permanent exile, the studio became a cultural centre that afforded the two women the choicest subjects from among the avant-garde. While portraits, such as the famous one of Bertolt Brecht - as starkly clipped as his haircut - extolled the characteristic, and often deceptive, simplicity of the Bauhaus neue sachlichkeit, or "new objectivity", many other subjects, such as nudes and still lives, took off into the realms of the surreal.

Increasingly, Ringl & Pit took on advertising, where their hallmark was an ironically suggestive, frequently confusing doll/dummy, often with a collaged array of items in positive and negative surrounds.

Just as Grete Stern won the Brussels international photography prize, she was forced to close the studio and leave her country. She settled first in London, where she made "photo-propaganda" with her companion and colleague, latterly her husband, Horacio Coppola.

By 1936 the pair had decided to move on to his native country of Argentina. That year Stern and Coppola opened a studio in Buenos Aires, where their advertising work retained the Bauhaus style Stern had made her own, and the portraits were intended "to combine what's striking in the 'new vision' of Edward Weston and Paul Strand with the style of old masters such as Hans Holbein and Albrecht Durer."

Once in Buenos Aires, Stern became more widely published and exhibited, began lecturing and held ground-breaking exhibitions with Coppola in the city centre. In 1940, she decided to make a break and established a studio in the provincial town of Ramos Mejía. There she successfully reproduced something of the atmosphere of her Berlin days, as an artistic vanguard gathered at the house, which doubled as a studio and exhibition centre. A new expression - "going to Ramos" - was born and the place of pilgrimage became synonymous with a new cultural mecca.

Increasingly, however, Stern was developing a project she had started with the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes to document the remaining indigenous peoples of Argen- tina. She has left a huge body of work on the Chaco Indians, a people few had previously bothered to record.

Stern has also left a legacy of work in direct succession to her late mentor, the German portraitist August Sander; her own theories of light, as exemplified in her Ramos house filled with natural sunlight and whitewashed walls, without studio lamps; a love of the arts and, as the catalogue for a 1950 show of hers (in Washington) described it: "A bitter realism . . . neither shouting nor showy. It is something more intimate and real. Her desire is to enhance things, teaching the eye to rest on them, not looking but admiring so that what's most insignificant can be seen for what it truly is: marvellous."

Amanda Hopkinson

fields.headline: Leighton Reynolds
fields.standfirst: He spent a fruitful life in Oxford casting light on Latin texts
fields.trailText: Professor Leighton Reynolds, who has died of cancer aged 69, set new standards for the editing of Latin texts and the study of their transmission.
fields.body:
Professor Leighton Reynolds, who has died of cancer aged 69, set new standards for the editing of Latin texts and the study of their transmission.

A Welshman, educated at Caerphilly grammar school, he graduated with first-class honours from University College, Cardiff, where he struck up a lifelong friendship with the Latinist, RG Austin. He took a further classics degree at St John's College, Cambridge, where he won two more firsts, and was elected to a Craven fellowship. After service in the RAF, during which he qualified as a Russian interpreter, he became, in 1954, junior research fellow at Queen's College, Oxford, where he took up work on the manuscripts of Seneca's Letters. In 1957, he was elected fellow and tutor in classics at Brasenose College, Oxford.

In 1965, Reynolds's Oxford classical text of Seneca was published, and the companion monograph, The Medieval Tradition Of Seneca's Letters, provided a lucid account of the relationship of the manuscripts, with convincing solutions to a number of textual problems. In particular, it told an enthralling story of the transmission of the text that brought to life a long line of scribes and scholars, from Walafrid Strabo at 9th-century Reichenau to the modern period, participants in a process that Reynolds was the first to see as a whole. The secret, shared with the Oxford professor of Latin, Roger Mynors, was to examine as many manuscripts as possible: old or more recent, they might fit into the picture.

The same methods produced further Oxford classical texts, of Seneca's Dialogues, Sallust and Cicero's De Finibus. But a wider audience was addressed in Scribes And Scholars (1968), in which Reynolds and NG Wilson provided "a guide to the transmission of Greek and Latin literature", a wonderfully lucid account of how classical texts have come down to us. No less indispensable is Texts And Transmission (1983), a tribute to Mynors on his 80th birthday, bringing together discussions of the transmission of a large number of Latin texts.

There were 14 contributors, but Reynolds, as editor, wrote many of the pieces himself, laboured on the indexes, and supplied a magisterial introduction. His ability to write elegantly and wittily on technical matters is seen at its best in this volume.

Reynolds was well-known in the libraries of Europe, and enjoyed travel for its own sake. But the centres of his life were in Oxford. Brasenose was very important to him, and he twice acted as its principal. He drew out his pupils' talents, and was rewarded by their enduring affection.

While still a sixth-former, he had published on Welsh regional flora, and his fascination for botany was lifelong. At Boars Hill, outside Oxford, he and his wife Susan, whose shared passion for plants was one of the foundations of their happiness, created an idyllic garden. A sequoia seedling he planted is now shouldering its way up above the other trees. His carpentry skills enabled him to build a tree-house for his grandchildren.

Tall, and misleadingly austere in appearance, Reynolds loved to entertain. He worked almost to the end, and all who talked to him recognised the inner strength of the best kind of Stoic. His distinction was recognised in 1987 by election to the British Academy, and in 1996 by the conferment of the title of Oxford professor of classical languages and literature. He is survived by Susan, their three children, and four grandsons.

Michael Winterbottom

webTitle: US and S Korea accused of war atrocities

fields.headline: US and S Korea accused of war atrocities
fields.standfirst:
Inquiry uncovers secret of series of attacks by South on North

The AP report - 'Bridge at No Gun Ri'
fields.trailText: South Korean troops attacked the North a year before the Korean war broke out, researchers have claimed in the latest disturbing revelation about the conflict which almost led to global war.
fields.byline: John Gittings  in Hong Kong and  Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
South Korean troops attacked the North a year before the Korean war broke out, researchers have claimed in the latest disturbing revelation about the conflict which almost led to global war.

More than 250 guerrillas from the South are said to have launched an attack on North Korean villages along the east coast in June 1949. Some reached the town of Wonsan, although all but 50 were killed in two weeks. The incident has been confirmed by a South Korean army official.

It was only one of numerous small-scale conflicts instigated by the South as well as by the North, according to a new book by Professor Kim Kwi-ok of Seoul National university.

The story supports the argument of some historians that the North's invasion of the South in June 1950 must be seen in the context of a steady build-up of hostilities from both sides.

It will add to public concern in Seoul after a string of recent revelations about war atrocities committed by South Korean and US forces in the south early in the Korean war.

Last week, the South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, urged the US to conduct a thorough inquiry into the alleged mass killing of Korean civilian refugees by US soldiers. He told the US army secretary, Louis Caldera, who was visiting Seoul, that the "truth should be clearly brought out so that South Korea-US relations should not be damaged and will instead be enhanced".

Mr Caldera's visit to South Korea follows a recent investigation by the Associated Press news agency into a number of horrifying incidents. Its reports have shattered the conventional picture that all the atrocities in the Korean war were committed by the North Koreans or their Chinese allies.

US veterans interviewed by AP said they machine-gunned hundreds of helpless civilians under a railway bridge at No Gun Ri on July 26, 1950.

A week later, according to other veterans, a US general ordered the destruction of two strategic bridges across the Naktong River killing hundreds of civilians.

"It was a tough decision," wrote Hobart Gay, the 1st Cavalry Division commander, in a now-declassified document, "because up in the air with the bridge went hundreds of refugees."

The AP investigation documents other incidents in 1950-51 when US jets repeatedly attacked groups of Koreans in civilian clothes on the suspicion that they harboured enemy infiltrators.

In one strike, US firebombs are said to have killed 300 civilians trapped in a cave. Some pilots expressed concern that they were machinegunning innocent people.

Korean newspapers have called for a full investigation of all allegations. The defence ministry in Seoul is reported to have heard of nearly 40 similar cases of alleged civilian killings by US forces.

Korean commentators say that the incidents have long been known. But while South Korea was under military dictatorship the victims and their family members had to keep silent, fearing punishment if they spoke out.

Allegations occasionally surfaced in the US but the Pentagon always denied that there were grounds for inquiry. The situation only changed when an AP reporter, Charles Hanley began to investigate the No Gun Ri story in 1997.

US veterans who had lived with their secret for nearly half a century started to come forward. One of the most convincing witnesses was Ed Daily, now living in rural Tennessee, who was a 19-year-old volunteer with the 1st Cavalry division at the start of the Korean war.

He described how his unit surrounded several hundred civilians and penned them under a railway arch. Sporadic fire then came from under the arch, and his unit was ordered to "shoot them all."

They fired for more than 30 minutes: Mr Daily says he saw women and children and old men in his sights. He claimed up to 200 people had been killed by the time it was over.

"It started to torment many of us," Mr Daily told a television interviewer last month. "By the 1980s we started contacting one another, and we were all having the same mental problems. Over the years I went hearing a baby cry, or a woman scream, [and] it triggers a flashback."

Historically, the US has opposed attempts to establish a permanent international war crimes investigation network, and remains opposed to any system which would make the US military answerable to any other jurisdiction.

But last October President Bill Clinton and the defence secretary, William Cohen, ordered a full scale investigation under the US army inspector-general, Lieutenant General Michael Ackerman and a seven-man advisory group.

Some US veterans admit the atrocities but argue that they were inevitable in the heat of war. Some claim they were partly justified because North Korean agents may have been concealed among genuine civilians. They also say that the US troops, who were in disorganised retreat at the time, were pitifully unprepared.

Others point out that many more Korean civilians were killed by US bombing later in the war, particularly during the saturation bombing of Pyongyang in 1952.

Official war histories record that 10,000 litres of napalm and 697 tons of bombs were dropped, resulting in the deaths of almost 8,000 people.

It is unclear how far the US government is willing to investigate beyond the No Gun Ri allegations. Last week Mr Caldera said that the US will not investigate every claim that there was a loss of innocent lives. "If you begin down that path you'll never end because all war by definition is extremely violent," he said.

But a US embassy spokesman said later that further investigation had not been ruled out.

North Korea, whose own atrocities during the war are well documented, last week seized on the issue to accuse the US of a cover up.

In a separate revelation, the newspaper Hankook Ilbo in Seoul has alleged that some 1,800 political prisoners held in Taejon, south of Seoul, on charges of being communist sympathisers were executed in July 1950 by South Korean military police.

It also noted that North Korean troops later massacred a large number of rightwing prisoners in revenge.

"Our government is now urged to ascertain the number of prisoners, irrespective of ideology, massacred during the war and to identify them," the Korean Times wrote in an editorial. "In addition, the government is called upon to reveal who was in a position to order the terrible massacres."

webTitle: Vagrant deaths cast a pall over jubilee

fields.headline: Vagrant deaths cast a pall over jubilee
fields.trailText: The Vatican has pledged to feed the homeless from Rome's basilicas after the deaths of seven vagrants in two weeks threatened to overshadow today's unprecedented ecumenical ceremony to mark the church's jubilee year.
fields.body:
The Vatican has pledged to feed the homeless from Rome's basilicas after the deaths of seven vagrants in two weeks threatened to overshadow today's unprecedented ecumenical ceremony to mark the church's jubilee year.

Hours after another frozen corpse was found a stone's throw from a church, the Pope promised that 500 meals would be served to the needy every day for the rest of 2000. Homeless people are to be welcomed and fed at Rome's four main pilgrimage sites: the basilicas of St Peter, St John Lateran, St Mary Major and St Paul Outside the Walls.

"It is a tangible sign of solidarity from the holy father to help our brothers in need," said Archbishop Crescenzio Sepe, head of the church's jubilee committee. It was not clear whether the food would be served inside, or in front of, the basilicas.

The news was welcomed by homeless charities but Aldo Morrone, in charge of a walk-in clinic at the San Gallicano hospital, warned that the jubilee - which is expected to draw 23m pilgrims to Rome - was attracting more vagrants without a corresponding increase in resources.

Rome has fewer than 800 beds for a homeless population estimated at between 1,800 and 4,000. It is thought that around 60,000 people are homeless across the country.

Most of the seven vagrants to have died have been foreigners. The latest victim was a Tunisian, Ben Chaar Zouhaier, 50, who was found frozen to death on Sunday in the fashionable district of Trastevere. On Saturday a man in his 30s died in an upper class suburb beside the Vatican.

The sub-zero temperatures have claimed two Polish men and, on January 3, a Swiss woman in her 60s was found in a doorway off Via della Conciliazione, the boulevard leading to St Peter's square and the Vatican boundary.

Outrage and shock at the deaths has been threatening to turn public opinion against the Vatican, which has spent millions of pounds on facilities for holy year pilgrims.

During today's jubilee ceremony, more than 20 non-Catholic representatives, including the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, will join the Vatican in promoting closer relations among Christian denominations.

webTitle: Churches burn as Indonesian riots spread

fields.headline: Churches burn as Indonesian riots spread
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Sectarian fighting that has ravaged Indonesia's Molucca islands for the last year spread to the tourist island of Lombok yesterday when Muslim rioters rampaged through two towns, setting fire to buildings including seven churches.
fields.body:
Sectarian fighting that has ravaged Indonesia's Molucca islands for the last year spread to the tourist island of Lombok yesterday when Muslim rioters rampaged through two towns, setting fire to buildings including seven churches.

The violence, which has also affected the island of Sulawesi, erupted as military chiefs in Jakarta again denied speculation that the army is about to stage a coup. Rumours intensified at the weekend when Richard Holbrooke, the US ambassador to the UN, warned the Indonesian army against "military adventurism".

Muslim youths began attacking churches in Mataram, the main town on Lombok, after being whipped into a frenzy of religious fanaticism at a rally in which protesters demanded speedier government action to end sectarian fighting in the Moluccas, often known as the Spice islands.

About 1,000 people have been killed in the Moluccas in the last three weeks, with unbalanced local media reports reinforcing the perception that Muslims have been for the most part innocent victims of Christian brutality. On Saturday the influential Indonesian Council of Ulemas backed calls for a jihad, or holy war, to defend Muslim interests.

After the attacks in Mataram, the Lombok mob grew to several thousand people. They moved to the nearby town of Ampenan in search of more churches and threw stones at police and soldiers deployed to restore order. They in turn fired on the rioters.

More than a dozen people were taken to hospital with gunshot wounds. There were no reports of deaths but the clashes continued until well after dark, with many areas blocked off as the police and army struggled to gain control.

Residents blamed outside agitators for the violence.

"Lombok has been very quiet for the last two years," said a lecturer at the Mataram university. "Yes, there are fanatical Muslims here but there's no way this would have happened without outside intervention."

Agitators are being held responsible for many of the country's current woes, from the violent separatist conflict in Aceh to political infighting in Jakarta and the sectarian clashes in eastern Indonesia.

Many observers pin the blame on the army, whose all-powerful generals are seeing their grip weaken. They are allocated 38 of the 500 seats in the parliament - a quarter of their quota during the Suharto era, which ended in 1998.

Some generals are thought to be considering a coup because of the government's failure to stem the nationwide unrest, and because of rumours that the president, Abdurrahman Wahid, intends to purge his cabinet of generals. There are also fears among army chiefs that numerous commanders are about to be tried for human rights violations in East Timor last year.

Much of the attention is focused on General Wiranto, the former armed forces commander who is now chief security minister. His relations with President Wahid have deteriorated in recent weeks and there is talk that he is to be fired. He also looks likely to face prosecution for events in East Timor, where hundreds were murdered as Indonesian soldiers and local militia thugs destroyed most of the territory following a vote for independence .

In a surprisingly strong intervention into domestic politics, Mr Holbrooke said Indonesia would become an international outcast if the army seized power.

"Any Indonesian army officers or any military officers who are thinking of military adventurism have forgotten that we are now in the 21st century," he warned. "The damage to Indonesia would be unbelievable."

"It's not what any rational or progressive Indonesian would want. No one in the world would want it except the few people trying to protect their own skin."

Indonesia's new armed forces commander, Admiral Widodo, who is not tainted by East Timor or links to President Suharto, yesterday denied that elements in the military planned to seize power.

"The rumours about a coup d'état should not be listened to," he said. "The military has never had any thoughts about staging a coup."

Many analysts are also sceptical about the likelihood of a return to military rule.

Munir, a member of the human rights commission investigating the military's role in East Timor, said: "The possibility of a coup is small because the army does not have the support of the people. Without the support of the people they would only bring down themselves."

But he said the conditions for a coup prevailed because the process of reform had stalled. "Democratisation has stopped at the [presidential] palace," he said. "It still has a long way to go."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Karachi bomb kills eight
A bomb hidden in a fruit cart ripped through a Karachi district yesterday, killing at least eight people and wounding 31, police said. There were no immediate claims of responsibility.
fields.body:
Karachi bomb kills eight
A bomb hidden in a fruit cart ripped through a Karachi district yesterday, killing at least eight people and wounding 31, police said. There were no immediate claims of responsibility.

Pakistan has been rocked by several bombings in recent weeks. The military government has blamed the attacks on India but Delhi denies any involvement.
AP, Karachi

Assassination suspect held
A prisoner was yesterday named by Latvian police as a suspect in the 1998 assassination of the outspoken Russian reformist politician Galina Starovoitova.

Konstantin Nikulin, 32, allegedly owns the same kind of rare gun used to shoot Staravoitova near her St Petersburg apartment. Bullets and shell casings will now be sent for forensic testing.
AP, Riga

Terrorist jailed for Berlin attack
A former Red Army Faction member was sentenced to life in prison yesterday after being found guilty of murder and attempted murder over the 1983 bombing of a French cultural centre in the then West Berlin that left one dead and 23 injured.

Johannes Weinrich, 52, who headed European operations for the terrorist Carlos the Jackal in the 1970s and 80s, is to appeal, his lawyer said.
AP, Berlin

UN keeps Arkan record a secret
The United Nations chief war crimes prosecutor, Carla del Ponte, refused yesterday to release details of a secret indictment against the assassinated Serb warlord Zeljko Raznatovic (Arkan) so as not to jeopardise related investigations into his associates.
Reuters, the Hague

Ex-CIA chief in plane crash
A former director of the CIA has been injured in a plane crash near the Costa Rican capital, San Jose, in which his wife and three others died. Stansfield Turner, 76, who headed the CIA under Jimmy Carter is said to be in critical condition.
Duncan Campbell, Los Angeles

fields.headline: Singer hit by drug claim
fields.trailText: Singer and actor Whitney Houston has been found in possession of cannabis at an airport in Hawaii, it was claimed yesterday. Houston left on a plane before police arrived and has not yet been charged with any offence.
fields.body:
Singer and actor Whitney Houston has been found in possession of cannabis at an airport in Hawaii, it was claimed yesterday. Houston left on a plane before police arrived and has not yet been charged with any offence.

According to the Hawaiian press, Houston was searched by a security officer employed by a private firm, Wackenhut, at the Keahole-Kona airport last Tuesday as she was about to board a plane to San Francisco.

It is understood that 15.2g (about half an ounce) of cannabis were found.

Private security guards only have the power of arrest for breaches of airport security rules. The police were called but took 45 minutes to reach the airport, by which time the 36-year-old star had departed, according to the police.

Neither Wackenhut nor Houston's publicist have commented on the incident. Under Hawaiian drugs laws, the amount of cannabis allegedly found could lead to 30 days jail and/or a fine of $1,000 (£610).

The matter is now in the hands of the Hawaiian county police prosecutor. Hawaiian authorities may not be anxious to pursue the matter as the islands reputedly have a fairly relaxed attitude to soft drugs.

The news comes as the issue of drugs and show business is under scrutiny. It emerged last week that some television shows, such as ER and Chicago Hope, have had their scripts submitted to the anti-drugs unit at the White House.

If the programme contained an anti-drug message, the network was excused from running government public service announcements in that segment of their broadcast, thus saving the network valuable airtime.

webTitle: Germany's CDU meets in crisis over scandal

fields.headline: Germany's CDU meets in crisis over scandal
fields.trailText: The beleaguered leader of the German opposition, Wolfgang Schäuble, will today face the biggest challenge yet to his survival when he confronts fellow party bosses at an emergency meeting to discuss who should be sacrificed to quell the scandal raging through the party about widespread illegal funding.
fields.body:
The beleaguered leader of the German opposition, Wolfgang Schäuble, will today face the biggest challenge yet to his survival when he confronts fellow party bosses at an emergency meeting to discuss who should be sacrificed to quell the scandal raging through the party about widespread illegal funding.

Late last night Helmut Kohl's former interior minister resigned his seat in parliament, the first victim of the Christian Democrats' growing campaign funding scandal. Christian Democrat spokesman Christian Schnee said Manfred Kanther had decided to give up his parliament seat.

Amid a chorus of calls for resignations of Christian Democratic Union (CDU) leaders, Mr Kanther has been under pressure since admitting on Friday that he funnelled millions to the party's coffers in Hesse state from a Swiss account and falsely reported the money as bequests.

Mr Kanther, 60, ran the party apparatus in Hesse for most of the 1990s and joined Mr Kohl's government as a tough law-and-order advocate.

The conservatives' leader, Wolfgang Schäuble, has so far held out against a barrage of demands for his resignation, but it was clear that his future would be under discussion. Reports last night said that at least one party baron who has admitted being involved in the scandal will be told to go.

The latest revelations in the scandal, touched off by the former chancellor Helmut Kohl, focused on Hesse, where former party officials admitted at the weekend that they had channelled millions of marks into the party's treasury from a Swiss bank account.

In a sick twist, the regional party treasurer concealed the source of the funds by saying that the donations were from grateful Holocaust survivors with accounts in offshore tax-havens. Michel Friedman, a Frankfurt Jew and member of the CDU, called the ploy "disgusting".

Whether Mr Kanther's head will satisfy the growing number of critics baying for blood is doubtful. Mr Schäuble, who was booed and heckled at a rally at the weekend, faces a press which is all but united in demanding his departure, and a swelling phalanx of increasingly authoritative party critics.

Two leading conservative dailies, Die Welt and Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, yesterday demanded that Mr Schäuble quit. Die Welt ran a front-page headline screaming "Resign", while the Frankfurter Allgemeine said the well-being of democracy was at stake.

"The CDU must break with its sleazy past and put untainted politicians at its head," the newspaper argued. "this is no longer about whether the CDU loses the next election. There is much more at stake - whether this great party can recover."

Last week, Mr Schäuble confessed to taking a donation in cash from the German-Canadian businessman whose disclosures set off the scandal. Yet in an earlier statement to parliament, in which he acknowledged having met the man, he made no mention of the fact that the businessman had given him a bag stuffed with banknotes the following day.

webTitle: Goodness gracious, great balls of ice

fields.headline: Goodness gracious, great balls of ice
fields.trailText: Ice balls the size of melons have been bombarding southern Spain in a phenomenon that has baffled scientists.
fields.body:
Ice balls the size of melons have been bombarding southern Spain in a phenomenon that has baffled scientists.

A national inquiry launched by a team of scientists has been wrestling with conflicting theories: Are they pieces of a comet, human excrement ejected from high-flying aircraft, or an elaborate hoax?

Enrique Martinez, head of a team at the Higher Council of Scientific Investigation, said the excrement theory was rejected. The ice balls, or aerolites, "lack the typical colouring and texture we find in those cases," he said.

One man in southern Spain narrowly escaped injury last week when an ice ball 20cm (eight inches) across, weighing 4kg (nine pounds), smashed into his car.

A total of 11 have landed so far. Local authorities have been told to preserve any others in their freezers, so that they can be examined by the team of astrophysicists, meteorologists and geologists put together by Spain's leading centre for scientific research.

"We're looking at a highly dense, very white, very pure mass of what appear to be tightly packed fragments of glass that we're going to have to analyse very carefully," said Professor Jesus Martinez Frias, a scientist.

The most plausible explanation is that they are fragments of a comet that broke up outside the earth's atmosphere.

"It would be made up of water frozen at temperatures between minus 50C and minus 60C that would melt extremely slowly. Nevertheless the balls could originally have been up to 100 times bigger than their size when they landed," he said.

But the scientists are puzzled that all the balls should have descended on Spain. "We've checked with France and Portugal and there's been nothing there," said Manuel Gonzalez, of the weather centre in Valencia, where four of the balls were discovered.

One of the 10 biblical plagues brought down on Egypt involved great hail from the heavens, but there are more recently documented cases. In 1973, Wilmslow in Cheshire was hit by a lump of ice so big that a weather researcher managed to get 22 ounces of it home and into the fridge. In Derbyshire in 1811 chunks of ice one foot square were reported falling from the skies. In 1950 a farm in Devon was showered with ice, one lump of which sliced the neck of an unfortunate sheep. In 1974, an ice block 18 inches square crashed into a car in Pinner, Middlesex.

The possibility of a hoax has not been ruled out. "There is no precedent of a natural phenomenon on this scale," said Javier Armentia, director of the planetarium in Pamplona. "I'm convinced we're dealing with a joker who decided to follow nature's example after the first couple of balls fell."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A panel accompanying our front page report about British arms sales to Pakistan published on January 12 was misleading. The list of exports should have made it clear that many of the items were components for planes and warships rather than the entire things.
fields.body:
A panel accompanying our front page report about British arms sales to Pakistan published on January 12 was misleading. The list of exports should have made it clear that many of the items were components for planes and warships rather than the entire things.

A caption on page 6, yesterday, began, "A radiographer scans mammograms for cancer signs..." A radiologist interprets the radiographer's pictures.

In a report headed Croats jailed for ethnic slaughter, page 17, January 15, we referred to the Nazi concentrration camp at Dachau "in Poland". Dachau, established shortly after Hitler became chancellor, is near Munich in Germany.

The actor Lloyd Bridges made a posthumous appearance in our Birthdays column, page 26, January 15. He died on March 10, 1998, aged 85.

In a correction, page 25, January 15, we referred to habeas corpus but spelt it wrongly.

It is Princes Street (not Prince's) in Edinburgh (a leader, page 19, yesterday).

Homophone corner, from our profile of Lord Wakeham, page 7, January 15, "The Lords has got to be complimentary to the Commons ..."

fields.headline: It's criminal
fields.standfirst:
There seems no end to the list of leading Labourites ready to dish the dirt on the former GLC leader
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: In the run-up to the millennium, Radio 4 was canvassing listeners for their nominations for the greatest villain of the 20th century. After reading many articles by Neil Kinnock, Ken Jackson, Margaret Hodge, Michael Cashman, and - most recently in the Guardian this week, Clare Short - I see you can forget Hitler, Stalin or Mao. The obvious choice of villain is that tyrannical bastard Ken Livingstone.
fields.body:
In the run-up to the millennium, Radio 4 was canvassing listeners for their nominations for the greatest villain of the 20th century. After reading many articles by Neil Kinnock, Ken Jackson, Margaret Hodge, Michael Cashman, and - most recently in the Guardian this week, Clare Short - I see you can forget Hitler, Stalin or Mao. The obvious choice of villain is that tyrannical bastard Ken Livingstone.

I realise now that Livingstone had a hand in virtually every affliction which was visited upon the northern hemisphere in the latter half of the 20th century. I even have my doubts now about his so-called alibi that he was at school in south London when Kennedy was shot.

Originally his opponents were able to rest easy in the knowledge that London would be saved from the recurrence of the biblical pestilence of Livingstone by the sound common sense and independence of mind of the panel set up to interview and draw up a shortlist of Labour candidates.

Now, however, they apparently feel that the whole idea of setting up a panel to block Livingstone was just part of a cunning plan encouraged by Livingstone himself so that he could stand as an independent candidate and appeal in the mayoral election to the British sense of fair play and sympathy for the underdog. How low can this man stoop? I never cease to be amazed at his deviousness.

To match his duplicity, the Stop Livingstone Conspiracy have had to fall back on the risky plan of allowing him to run but ensuring they win the ballot against him. At least someone had the foresight to introduce an electoral college.

Controlling the wild, radical and fiercely independent spirit of Labour MPs and MEPs is not difficult. They can be convinced to see Livingstone as a force for conservatism which has to be defeated. The problem rests with all those individual members of the party and trade union members who will insist on exercising their right to vote for a candidate of their choice.

The focus groups have confirmed that the only hope is to blitz the media with a level of personal abuse not seen since Thatcher set the press on the old GLC. During the ballot for the Labour candidate one may be able to sow enough doubt about Livingstone's character and political record so that even if he wins in the members' section of the electoral college it will not be on such a scale as to call into question the whole selection process.

Some of the best dirt on Livingstone can be gained from his former colleagues during those terrible days of the GLC period. So to do my bit to stop Livingstone, I submit this confession.

I confess that I was a GLC councillor. Mea culpa , I was Ken Livingstone's deputy. Mea maxima culpa, I was also the chair of the GLC's finance committee. So it was me who was responsible for delivering the resources to fund Livingstone's lunatic environmental policies, like reducing bus and tube fares, letting pensioners ride free on public transport, investing to modernise the London fire brigade and completing the construction of the Thames Barrier.

Because I established the GLC's grants policy programme, it was also me who gave the grants to black, lesbian and gay, and women's groups. I did so because that swine Livingstone insisted that we did not discriminate on grounds of race, gender, age, disability, religion or sexual orientation in the distribution of the GLC's resources.

Deviously he implicated all of us in his plans by creating a team of chairs of committees and giving them responsibility for implementing the detailed election manifesto upon which we were elected. Coordinating this team he perfidiously supported Paul Boateng in developing ultra-left policies demanding the setting up a police authority for London to tackle issues such as police accountability and racism in the Met.

The way he allowed Tony Banks the opportunity to make his name by pumping money into arts and sports in the capital was clearly, with hindsight, just setting Tony up to lead future campaigns to bring the World Cup and the Olympics to Britain. How cruel can you get?

The result of the GLC's political deviance was that, at a time when Labour was meant to be losing out electorally and thus preparing the ground for the emergence of New Labour, the Labour party in London was polling consistently 10-20% ahead of Labour nationally. But this just shows that you can't even rely on Livingstone to conform to the rewriting of the history of the period. He is just uncontrollable.

The worst thing about him, though, is that he shares with Frank Dobson a sincerity and personal kindness rare among politicians, which makes it really difficult to launch and sustain any credible personal attacks.

Maybe it would be best if the next month was spent on simply debating policies rather than personality. Most rank and file members of the Labour party in London fear that if the coming weeks turn out to be a litany of more abuse against Livingstone, whoever is the victor, it won't be the Labour party.

John McDonnell is Labour MP for Hayes and Harlington.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: A surge in the price of Vodafone AirTouch , up 24p at 351p, kept the London market in positive territory. The mobile phone group accounted for some 34 FTSE 100 index points, with the premier indicator closing 11.3 higher at 6669.5. Against this, the damp reaction to the Glaxo Wellcome/SmithKline Beecham merger erased 30 Footsie points, with these two drugs groups falling 86p to £17.32 and 58p to 788p, respectively.
fields.body:
A surge in the price of Vodafone AirTouch , up 24p at 351p, kept the London market in positive territory. The mobile phone group accounted for some 34 FTSE 100 index points, with the premier indicator closing 11.3 higher at 6669.5. Against this, the damp reaction to the Glaxo Wellcome/SmithKline Beecham merger erased 30 Footsie points, with these two drugs groups falling 86p to £17.32 and 58p to 788p, respectively.

As Vodafone romped ahead the "discount" between the value of its paper bid for Germany's Mannesmann widened slightly, with Mannesmann's share price slow to catch up. While most market operators are convinced the British company has all but secured victory over its German rival, some City number crunchers are not so sure.

One group of arbitrageurs reckons that as things stand Vodafone is likely to get 55% support. This would hand it victory but the narrowness of the margin is too close for some speculators to play.

Tech stocks were still in heavy demand, leading the techMARK 100 index above 4000 for the first time since its launch in early November, up 204 points at 4165.2.

This reflected a jump in Logica from £18.54 to £20.11, while fellow software group Misys added 25p to 893p and Sema firmed 40p to £11.10. But the tremendous move by the index (up more than 5%) was also down to Druid Group , up from £20.37 to £32.60, and FI , 110p higher at 875p - two constituents which are merging.

GEO Interactive , another techMARK constituent, was extraordinarily strong, putting on 497p to £23.90 after a trading statement and further placing of new stock.

There was similar excitement at the smallest end of the market, where the FTSE Small Cap indicator closed at 3263.8 - the sixth straight record close.

Shares in biotechnology company Oxford Biomedica, run by Alan Kingsman and his wife Sue, grew wings, rising 73% to end up 33.25p at 78p. This followed the offering of just under 14m new shares to raise £5m net which was heavily oversubscribed as institutions piled into a company working on treatments for cancer and Parkinson's disease.

The money will be used to fund ongoing research plus clinical trials, and the fund-raising follows good clinical trial results from its LentiVectorT programme which could have significant implications for the treatment of cancer.

Oxford Biomedica has recently been building new alliances with partners such as Rhone Poulenc of France.

fields.headline: EMI attracts some upbeat attention
fields.trailText: EMI shares bobbed up almost 2% yesterday, but whether the rise owed more to a report that Germany's Bertelsmann has the British group in its sights or to an uprating by Commerzbank analysts is open to question.
fields.body:
EMI shares bobbed up almost 2% yesterday, but whether the rise owed more to a report that Germany's Bertelsmann has the British group in its sights or to an uprating by Commerzbank analysts is open to question.

EMI displayed the straightest of bats in responding to the report in Der Spiegel, which linked Bertelsmann with EMI or Sony Music.

"We don't comment on these sort of reports," was the only reaction from EMI's head office.

The German group nurtures ambitions to become number one in the music business this year, and will have up to DM20bn (£6.4bn) burning a hole in its pockets over the next couple of years. But although EMI would be a handy stepping stone - to say the least - the market remains unconvinced that Bertelsmann would be prepared to pay the likely required premium over yesterday's 703p closing price.

The AOL-Time Warner merger is expected to mean more music being delivered via the net, but Commerzbank Global Equities says the deal has also highlighted the value of consumer content relative to internet distribution.

Music retailers are seeking to sell CDs at lower prices via the internet, and Commerzbank reckons that "cutting out the bricks and mortar, the retailer lowers the price and increases record company margins".

Its note said: "Lower prices would be more than compensated for by increased volumes."

Upgrading its investment to "buy", Commerzbank valued EMI at 698p and said that net alliances or the prospect of EMI content being offered for streaming raises this value to 767p.

webTitle: FI deal puts e-males on board

fields.headline: FI deal puts e-males on board
fields.trailText: Women who steered the software consultancy FI Group into the top 250 index of UK companies have opted to share more of their success with men after agreeing a £670m takeover of rival Druid.
fields.body:
Women who steered the software consultancy FI Group into the top 250 index of UK companies have opted to share more of their success with men after agreeing a £670m takeover of rival Druid.

Four of the five executive directors at FI are women, led by chairman Hillary Cropper. But, under the terms of the deal with Druid, two men from that company will join the combined board.

FI shares closed last night at 875p, up 110p. Thirty-two per cent of the enlarged equity, worth more than £2.5bn, will be owned by employees with 25% owned by staff below board level. Druid's shares rose 60%, by £12.22 to £32.59. In November the firm issued a profits warning.

FI said the merger would create a leading business technology service group with global reach and poised to grow through acquisition.

FI also beat expectations yesterday with a 51% rise in first-half pre-tax profits to £11.4m on sales up 34% at £145.4m and offered an interim dividend of 0.9p per share.

FI said the tie-up with Druid was motivated by a potential to cross-sell services rather than find synergies or consolidate.

fields.headline: Reuters' information chief quits
fields.standfirst: Board member said to be unhappy at being passed over
fields.trailText: News and information group Reuters last night parted company unexpectedly with one of its most senior executives.
fields.body:
News and information group Reuters last night parted company unexpectedly with one of its most senior executives.

John Parcell, chief executive of Reuters Information and a member of the company board, quit amid suggestions that he was unhappy about being passed over for the chief executive's post when Peter Job retires in July next year.

Mr Parcell was tipped at one time as Mr Job's successor. A former journalist, he joined Reuters' main board in October 1996 with responsibility for running its core financial information product lines.

He took on his present role a year ago. The company said his departure was for personal reasons, and did not reflect on the business's performance.

A spokesman added that a further announcement about his replacement would be made in due course. Reuters is due to publish its next set of year-end financial results on February 8, and will also unveil a restructuring plan aimed at revitalising the group's strategy for the internet age.

One insider indicated that Mr Parcell may have felt unhappy about his future role in the group, and that this sentiment had coincided with the realisation that he was unlikely to succeed Mr Job. At the age of 53, Mr Parcell is young enough to quit a post of this sort and aspire to another senior role elsewhere.

Mr Parcell is on two years' notice and participates in the company's share incentive scheme for senior executives. He will receive compensation of about £750,000.

The information division will be run on a day to day basis by Thomas Glocer, president of Reuters America, who will join its senior management committee as a result.

Mr Parcell said he had given "much thought" to his goals and aspirations, and had decided "that this is a very good time to make a significant change" after 30 years at Reuters.

Investors reacted calmly to the announcement, and Reuters shares continued upwards, accelerated by the rerating of the media sector which followed the announcement of the Time Warner-AOL merger. Reuters shares closed 86.5p higher at 987.5p.

News of Mr Parcell's departure came as it emerged that Reuters had set up a committee to defend itself against hostile takeovers; it was established by Pehr Gyllenhammar, chairman of the trustees who are custodians of the "golden share" which guarantees Reuters' independence.

webTitle: SFO steps aside to allow DTI inquiry into TransTec

fields.headline: SFO steps aside to allow DTI inquiry into TransTec
fields.trailText: The Serious Fraud Office is dropping the idea of a full investigation into the collapsed TransTec engineering group, clearing the field for a department of trade and industry inquiry.
fields.body:
The Serious Fraud Office is dropping the idea of a full investigation into the collapsed TransTec engineering group, clearing the field for a department of trade and industry inquiry.

An announcement is expected this week, although a DTI source stressed last night that "we're looking at our options".

Despite the fact that the concealment of a £12m liability in TransTec's accounts would have fitted the SFO's criteria for investigation, it is thought the office believes these are matters best looked at within the framework of a Companies Act inquiry, the responsibility of the DTI.

Under a long-standing inter-agency agreement, public bodies do not duplicate each other's efforts in the investiga tion of possible financial wrongdoing.

Meanwhile, the Conservative opposition yesterday called for the DTI and all its agencies to hand over any investigation to an outside body. Given that TransTec's founder was former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson, "the whole thing is far too incestuous", Tory trade and industry spokeswoman Angela Browning said.

Expanding on earlier calls for a public inquiry, she said the DTI and its corps of official receivers - who would normally be expected to comb the wreckage of TransTec for evidence of any wrongdoing - ought to be excluded from investigating the company.

Also excluded would be the directors' disqualification unit (DDU), which looks into cases in which executives of failed companies can be barred from holding boardroom positions, provided a court agrees.

Mrs Browning's demand came as she prepared to table a barrage of further questions to the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, about TransTec and other companies that have been associated with Mr Robinson.

TransTec, from which Mr Robinson resigned after his ministerial appointment in May 1997, went into receiver ship just before Christmas after it admitted having concealed in its 1997 and 1998 accounts both the fact that one of its customers, Ford, the motor group, had been demanding £12m compensation for allegedly late delivery of vehicle components and the further fact that TransTec had paid £8m of this claim.

HSBC, TransTec's banker, have appointed accountants Arthur Andersen as receivers.

webTitle: Booming sales of crease-free clothing suit Ted Baker

fields.headline: Booming sales of crease-free clothing suit Ted Baker
fields.standfirst: Burgeoning sales of a crease-free, endurance business suit helped drive up business at trendy clothing firm Ted Baker in the run-up to Christmas
fields.trailText: Ray Kelvin, founder and chief executive, said the £299 "suit in a box" had proved one of its most pop ular lines. The company, which refuses to conduct advertising campaigns, said its sales in the weeks between November 1 and December 24 were 51% ahead of the same period last year.
fields.body:
Ray Kelvin, founder and chief executive, said the £299 "suit in a box" had proved one of its most pop ular lines. The company, which refuses to conduct advertising campaigns, said its sales in the weeks between November 1 and December 24 were 51% ahead of the same period last year.

Floated on the stock market three years ago, the retailer now has 10 stores across the country, concessions in three department stores and arrangements with 600 "trustees" - independent retailers in Britain and the United States who are entrusted to "take care of Ted". It is also starting to sell clothes on-line through a new internet service set up three months ago.

Mr Kelvin said the group had started selling shoes for the first time this season but had no major plans to roll out any new lines. It has seven current collections, in addition to underwear and perfume.

Outside of Britain, the group has a concession in Zurich and distributors in France and Sweden and said it is continuing to watch the wider European market closely.

The company recently appointed its first wholesaler in Canada and has opened a retail showroom in New York. Shares touched a high of 407p before ending the day at 402p, up 13.5p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Healthy profit at First Leisure
fields.body:
Healthy profit at First Leisure

First Leisure Corporation led by chief executive Michael Grade yesterday disclosed a 7% fourth quarter increase at its health and fitness division, to be listed from next month on the stock exchange as Esporta.

The company also announced the launch of Eden, a new brand developed to address a perceived gap in the over-40s market for premium, adult-only clubs with the first facility opening in August at Chislehurst, Kent. New Esporta clubs opened last year, such as the one in Edinburgh, exceeded their membership targets and total users now stand at 116,000. Investors in First Leisure will receive one Esporta share and £1.03 in cash for each of their shares.

Bass buys Pacific hotels

Bass, owner of the Holiday Inn, Crowne Plaza and Intercontinental hotel brands, has snapped up Australia's Southern Pacific Hotels group for £130m. The deal includes 24 hotels in Australia, 13 in New Zealand, eight in the southern Pacific Islands and 14 in Asia.

Bass, forced to reduce its pub portfolio after a monopolies commission investigation in 1968, said the acquisition would make it Australia's second largest hotel company.

Americans look again at UB

The American group bidding for Britain's United Biscuits yesterday said it would reserve the right to increase its bid after studying details of an offer from French-led Finalrealm group valuing UB at 265p a share, or £1.26bn. Earlier, Hicks Muse & Fuse, acting for the Burlington Biscuit group, had posted an offer of 254p a share.

Snook fails in top job attempt

Hans Snook, chief executive of Orange, the mobile phone operator, has failed to be elected a member of the full management board (Vorstand) of Mannesmann, the German group that bought his company for £19.5bn last autumn. Mr Snook is instead one of several new executive directors of a new management board set up by Mannesmann's supervisory board. Mannesmann is currently the object of a hostile bid from Britain's Vodafone.

MCI chief stands down

Michael Butler has stepped down as UK operations managing director of MCI WorldCom after his division failed to meet its revenue targets for the year ending this month, company sources said. He will take up a post in the international division. His replacement is understood to be Lucy Woods, senior vice-president of European operations.

Setback for TotalFina plan

TotalFina's plans to merge with fellow French oil giant Elf Aquitaine were given a jolt yesterday when the European Commission said insufficient undertakings had been given by the companies.
