webTitle: Super egos shake hands on the money shot

fields.headline: Super egos shake hands on the money shot
fields.standfirst: Big deal saves science base
fields.trailText: So finally, after 22 months of inaction, we get the money shot. Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham are injecting some pride into UK plc, coming together to create the world's biggest drugs combine. Look, we're actually top at something and it's emphatically not second division stuff.
fields.body:
So finally, after 22 months of inaction, we get the money shot. Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham are injecting some pride into UK plc, coming together to create the world's biggest drugs combine. Look, we're actually top at something and it's emphatically not second division stuff.

Yet the market's limp reaction yesterday suggests this particular deal is not wowing the viewing public in quite the way all the pre-publicity promised. Maybe too much of the plot was known in advance, but the fact is when this deal was eventually signed over the weekend the new Glaxo SmithKline ranked as Britain's largest company, while by yesterday evening it had slipped back to third position (behind Vodafone and BP Amoco), worth £107bn.

These are still exceptionally large numbers, and yet it is almost impossible to resist the thought that the delay in putting these ideal marriage partners together was caused simply by the super egos among the two companies' boardrooms.

In the industry itself, the competitive backdrop has certainly intensified and the readiness of rival Pfizer to mount a hostile bid for Warner-Lambert gives an indication of how rapidly the temperature is rising. In the past couple of years alone about a half of the world's 25 largest drug players have been involved in corporate activity.

But this is not new and was clearly the reality of the marketplace when SmithKline and Glaxo last tried to merge. Then, too, it was apparent that the US trend to advertise direct to patients to encourage them to demand certain prescription drugs would spread to other developed countries.

Changes to product marketing, pressures on national healthcare budgets and shifts in the wider social and economic environment were making corporate activity in the sector impossible to resist. And advances in science and technology were already opening the way, not only for new treatments but for an entirely new way of looking at the whole business of prophylaxis.

The only substantive change has been of personality: Jan Leschly, SmithKline chief executive, recently decided to retire in April, while Sir Richard Sykes has agreed to move into a non-executive position and will possibly shuffle off into the world of academia soon.

We should be relieved now that a deal is in place and should look forward to the potential benefits which such a drugs behemoth should shower on shareholders. But it is extraordinary that the personal predilections of two executives should have been allowed to stand in the way of a deal which is now being trumpeted as the saviour of Britain's science base.

Awestruck four

It is difficult to believe that anyone really thought the so-called Awesome Foursome, consisting of hi-fi salesman Julian Ritcher, semi-retired retailer and wannabe political heavyweight Archie Norman, property tycoon Nick Leslau and serial smaller company deal-maker Nigel Wray, were really going to pull together a £12bn-plus bid for Marks and Spencer.

When they floated Knutsford, their corporate cash shell, it was valued at £5m -just the latest in a string of little shell companies put together by Manchester United director Michael Edelson, each of which has been named after a Cheshire village. But the issue coincided with the extraordinary bout of amateur stock market speculation that gripped the nation before Christmas. All of a sudden the quartet were running a company worth almost £1bn (once options were taken into account) and the backward logic of the markets insisted that in order to "justify" this valuation - imposed by outsiders - Archie et al would have to pull off a big one.

Knutsford should have done more to dampen this exuberance, but now it appears to be letting its excitable shareholders down slowly, unveiling a rather more digestible plan to take over Wassall and then, at the same time, promising further deals in the pipeline.

As for poor Marks & Spencer, with Tesco making it pretty clear yesterday that it would much prefer to concentrate on developing a global presence (and therefore securing its future) rather than getting bogged down rescuing an old-fashioned fixture of the British high street, speculative investors appear to be left with little other than the putative bid plans of one Monaco resident Philip Green.

Mr Green knows about the cheap and cheerful end of retailing. At the same time, the man has shown himself in the past to be a little short on the airs and graces that top flight management demands. It is probably best to think of him as the opposite of Knutsford - a little man, puffing himself up, encouraging exuberance among his followers in the hope that heavyweight financing will follow. The Barclay brothers, Mr Green's Monaco friends, backed his last highly successful venture in breaking up Sears. But they are not funding an M&S escapade. That sounds like a bad reference.

fields.body:
Knutsford, the bid vehicle for a group of entrepreneurs led by former Asda chairman Archie Norman, has confirmed it is in talks with Wassall, the mini-conglomerate turned venture capital group.

A spokesman for Aim-listed Knutsford, which was set up to bid for ailing retail groups, said any deal for Wassall would be a "staging post" on the way towards a bigger prize. He emphasised that there was no guarantee that an agreement between the two parties would be reached.

Wassall's assets include the TLG lighting business, a bottle tops firm and an Asian automotive company. However, analysts believe Knutsford is most attracted by Wassall's £350m cash reserves against which it would it be able to borrow to fund future and larger deals. Buying Wassall would also widen Knutsford's institutional share base.

Shares in Wassall climbed 10p to 360p but Knutsford edged back 5p to 260p.

Mr Norman and associates Nigel Wray, Nick Leslau and Julian Richer bought into Knutsford in November when it was just an obscure leather business. They said they wanted to use the company to bid for ailing high street retailers and the resultant surge in the company's share price led to them being dubbed the "Awesome Foursome".

Marks & Spencer had been touted as a target but analysts believe GUS, owners of Argos and Storehouse, tops their list.

fields.headline: Classical
fields.trailText: Joshua Bell, Steven Isserlis And Alexander Longquich
fields.body:
Joshua Bell, Steven Isserlis And Alexander Longquich

The annual chamber music festival hosted by the American violinist Joshua Bell this year focuses on the twin giants of Brahms and Mendelssohn, born 24 years apart but equally important pillars of the German romantic movement. Bell is joined by the cellist Steven Isserlis, pianist Alexander Lonquich, and the Vellinger Quartet in a series of three recitals at the Wigmore Hall that includes not only music by the main protagonists but by the Schumanns, both Robert and Clara, whose domestic life was inextricably entwined with Brahms, and Mendelssohn's beloved sister Fanny. Tonight's recital includes the early version of the piano trio no 1 in B by Brahms and Mendelssohn's E flat string quartet op12.

Wigmore Hall, Wigmore St, W1 (0171-935 2141) 7.30pm, £10-£19.

An Evening With Evelyn Glennie

The world's first full-time solo percussionist has been such a commercial success that her work in revealing percussive capabilities is almost taken for granted. No one batted an eyelid, for instance, when Adrian Spillet romped home as BBC Young Musician Of The Year playing an instrument that ten years before would scarcely have been recognised. Glennie's prowess has also inspired countless new compositions, witness her recital tonight, given in aid of Voluntary Service Overseas, which includes The Cheese And The Worms by Stewart Wallace, Prism Rhapsody by Keiko Abe, and Objects UFO by Michael Daugherty. She also plans to play the bagpipes.

Queen's Hall, Clerk St, Edinburgh (0131-668 2019) 7.30pm, £12-£20.

Donohoe Plays Beethoven

Concert 5 in Peter Donohoe's impressive project to play the complete piano sonatas, this one includes the Tempest (op 31 no 2) and the Waldstein (op. 53).

RNCM, Oxford Rd, Manchester (0161-907 5278) 7.30pm, £11, concessions £6.

Johann Strauss Orchestra

Traditional Viennese titbits conducted from the violin by Christopher Warren-Green, with the Johann Strauss Dancers.

North Wales Theatre, Llandudno (01492-872000) 7.30pm, phone for prices.

CBSO

First of two concerts conducted by Sakari Oramo which include the famous Planets Suite by Holst and Saint-Saëns' glittery 4th piano concerto.

Symphony Hall, Broad St, Birmingham (0121-212 3333) 7.30pm, £6-£31.

fields.headline: Rock, pop & jazz
fields.trailText: Ryoji Ikeda & zoviet*france
fields.body:
Ryoji Ikeda & zoviet*france

This evening's double bill should have electronic music fans salivating. Japan's top avant-garde, digital-minimalist composer Ryoji Ikeda returns to the capital after his immensely successful performance of Dumbtype. Like much of his work, including the acclaimed Dumbtype - a fusion of mixed tones, beeps, clicks, pulses and frequencies - pushes the boundaries of electronic music and re-affirms his position at the epicentre of "the wildest music coming out of Japan".

Supporting Ikeda is the legendary British underground electro group zoviet*france. The Geordie duo have been one of the most original, reclusive and prolific groups in the UK. With more than 20 albums to their name zoviet*france's hypnotic fusion of low-tech electronics and minimal percussion have dumbfounded fans and critics alike for more than two decades. Providing the visuals for these two cultish, leftfield electronic improvisers is the groundbreaking video artist Takayuki Fujimoto - a South Bank soiree which captures the essence of industrial loft living.

Queen Elizabeth Hall, South Bank, SE1 (0171-960 4242) 7.30pm, £12.50.

NME Premier Tour

Shack are certainly the grand old dames of this NME tour. The Liverpudlian quartet are old enough to have parented that red-haired whippersnapper Les Rythmes Digitales and those still-wet-behind-the-ears Oxford grads Coldplay. Thank goodness that the bon chic, bon genre Campag Velocet are there to provide Shack with some adult conversation. Underpinning Shack is the commercially underrated musical partnership of brothers Mick and John Head. Formerly in The Pale Fountains, the brothers have their musical roots in the thriving pop scene of 80s Merseyside. NME have for years waxed lyrical about the brothers' immense talents; Mick has been described as "a lost genius", who is among the "most gifted British songwriters of his generation", while John's "prodigious" guitar playing breathes life into the band's songs. But for a decade Shack's fusion of 60s American West Coast psychedelic rock with the tradition of Liverpool's "starry-eyed pop" and the aesthetics of 90s layered harmonies have gone relatively unnoticed by Joe Public. However, with last year's acclaimed "mercurial" album HMS Fable under their belts, this should be a good year for Shack.

Leeds Metropolitan University, Calverley St, Leeds (0113-244 4600) 7.30pm, £8.50.

fields.headline: The rest...
fields.trailText: The MacMillan Inheritance
fields.body:
The MacMillan Inheritance

Another chance to catch this celebration of the innovative Sir Kenneth MacMillan who died in 1992. The Royal Ballet explores the emotional depth and range of their former principal choreographer's work with performances of Concerto, Rituals and Gloria.

Royal Opera House, Bow St, WC2 (0171-304 4000) 7.30pm, £6-£45.

Moseley Mayhem

Comedy duo Parsons and Naylor are among the finest on the circuit - "absolutely hilarious" say the critics. This evening former Footlights president Henry Naylor makes a rare solo outing supported by Rachel New and Sarf London comic Harry Denford.

Jug Of Ale, Alcester Rd, Birmingham (0121-449 1082) 9pm, £5, concessions £4.

Dancebase

Lose that guilt of festive excess and go dancing. Numerous dance centres including Edinburgh's Dancebase are offering courses of up to 5 weeks in anything from classical ballet to breakdancing, from ceilidh to Indian dance.

Dancebase, Assembly Rooms, George St, Edinburgh (0131-225 5525) phone for details.

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst:
Getting personal with... director Stephen Sommers
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? No. When someone's hunting me down, that's when I'll do it.
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? No. When someone's hunting me down, that's when I'll do it.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? All the time. It has nothing to do with the business.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Handsome, wealthy FILM DIRECTOR, etc etc. But I'm happily married, so I don't do that kind of thing... a lot.

What was the last illegal thing you did? Oh man, I'm not even 40 years old and I can't remember the last illegal thing I did. That's really sad. I think I'll go downtown and buy a joint or something.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? I've had a good year, so I've been a little extra charitable lately.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?Greg Michael, my second unit director. He's also the nicest person I've ever met.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?BH, which is Bruce Hendrix, head of production at Disney. I can't stand that guy.

Has a critic ever made you cry?No. Made me furious, yes. If murder weren't illegal I'd probably have killed a few of them by now.

What would you advertise without a fee?Something charitable I guess - there's a few charities I've always given to.

What would you never advertise?Tobacco.

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning?Bruce Hendrix.

What takes you to a "happy place"?My kid.

Stephen Sommers' The Mummy is available to rent from 31 January on Universal

fields.headline: Kurt call
fields.standfirst: The audience roared for Ute Lemper at the Kurt Weill weekend but  Tim Ashley was more impressed by the composer's lost masterpiece
fields.trailText: The audience roared for Ute Lemper at the Kurt Weill weekend but Tim Ashley was more impressed by the composer's lost masterpiece
fields.body:
The BBC's fascinating, problematic Kurt Weill weekend of concerts, films and talks at the Barbican ended where it began - with sexual intrigue and erotic shenanigans played out between quartets of feuding lovers. Der Protagonist - Weill's first opera, premiered in Dresden in 1926 - is about an actor who confuses illusion with reality and murders the sister he incestuously fancies when the quadrangular, partner-swapping drama in which he is acting runs hideously out of control. The Firebrand of Florence (New York, 1944) exposes the sculptor Benvenuto Cellini and his self-assured, if ditsy girlfriend Angela to the machinations of the philandering Duke of Florence and his alienated, sex-starved duchess.

Whatever their inherent quality, both works confound expectations and are, to some extent, out on an artistic limb. Given its subject matter, one expects Der Protagonist to be an expressionistic scream-out, but its hysteria is shot through with whiffs of cool irony and edgy humour. Firebrand, hampered by a less than perfect Ira Gershwin text, aspires in places to a density and weight for which the Broadway musical wasn't ready. Both works have something else in common - they've slipped from view behind our abiding fascination with Weill's collaboration with Brecht, behind the image of Weill as the composer who defined the world of the Weimar republic.

The image stuck in Weill's lifetime and remains unshakeable. It led to tension during his collaboration with Fritz Lang on the 1938 film You and Me. Weill wanted assimilation and acceptance in America; Lang filmed a tribute to the Berlin years.

The only event during the weekend that was, significantly, packed to the rafters was Ute Lemper's late-night cabaret concert with the Matrix Ensemble and Robert Ziegler. Shedding a black velvet coat part-way through to mutate into a spangled deco diva, Lemper belted her way through a catalogue of Weill's best-known numbers, while a divinely decadent-looking audience yelled its head off.

Elsewhere, the weekend was a journey through the unknown, the lost, the abandoned Weill, with variable results. The 1927 one-acter Royal Palace, with a text by the surrealist poet Iwan Goll, proved to be a genuine lost masterpiece. A feminist tragi-comedy, it focuses on the figure of Dejanira (named after the mythic wife of Hercules), who rejects the selfishness of past, present and future lovers before teasingly transforming herself into a mermaid, a siren who will return to haunt the men who have abused her. The score, full of poised waltzes and ending with one of the best tangos ever written, is to die for - and it got a performance to match, glowingly conducted by Andrew Davis, with a radiant Janice Watson triumphant in the title role. It took everyone by surprise and deflected attention from the two events that were clearly planned as the weekend's main events: the unearthing of Firebrand and the resurrection of the 1934 operetta Der Kuhhandel.

The latter, which received a botched premiere in English at London's Savoy theatre, is one of Weill's weakest scores. He took Offenbach as his model, but where Offenbach is concise, Weill sprawls. Every number is at least one verse too long, dangerously blunting its grim arms-race satire, which neither a brilliant new translation by Jeremy Sams nor a punchy performance under Robert Ziegler could quite disguise. Firebrand, despite the presence of the amazing Rodney Gilfry - every inch the "famous stud" of the libretto - is a better score, though it's uneven and one wonders why it was chosen to represent Weill's Broadway years when the infinitely superior One Touch of Venus (written for Marlene Dietrich, though she never performed it) remains undiscovered by British audiences.

The Brecht collaboration was represented by two works more talked about than performed, the harrowing Berlin Requiem (composed for the 10th anniversary of the assassination of Rosa Luxemburg) and Das Lindberghflug, a nailbiting adventure story about the famous first flight across the Atlantic. Both were sung with considerable ferocity by the BBC Symphony Chorus, while the excellent Thomas Randle was an eloquent Lindbergh who mourned "Red Rosa's" demise with heartfelt grief. Both works should be restored to the mainstream repertoire as soon as possible.Like Royal Palace, they belong there.

fields.headline: Exhibitions
fields.trailText: Martin Boyce
fields.body:
Martin Boyce

Glasgow artist Martin Boyce, is precise in his evocations of architecture, design and modernism. He has papered the gallery with When Now Is Night, a wallpaper that suggests the grid of a glass-clad city building. Fluorescent strip lights illuminate the space.

Jerwood Space, Union St, SE1 (0171-654 0171) until February 27.

Sarah Tripp

The Glasgow artist has made a documentary film about the art of conversation. Commissioned as an installation by CCA this is her first major solo work. Tripp interviews a series of people who nominate the next person for her to talk to, from a lawyer to a group of Carmelite nuns.

CCA, McLellan Galleries, Sauchiehall St, Glasgow (0141-332 7521) until January 29.

Edward Weston

The sculptural and surreal, photographer has been compared to Mapplethorpe for the way his pictures mutate the human body - one of photography's great originals. This new exhibition contains images as perturbing as anything being created today.

MAC, Cannon Hill Park, Birmingham (0121-440 3838) until February 6.

fields.headline: Theatre
fields.trailText: Deadly
fields.body:
Deadly

To a range of music from classical and choral through to techno, a man and a woman play out their relationship within the framework of the seven deadly sins. You see the highs and lows as they swing through the air in ecstasy or trample upon each other's bodies in contempt. This is a devilishly good show: sexy and confident, it marries circus skills to drama to stupendous effect.

Purcell Room, Belvedere Rd, SE1 (0207-960 4242) 8pm, £10.

Hamlet: First Cut

You won't find a more accessible production of Hamlet. Using the first Quarto, a pirated version of the play, this is a production to make you look and listen to the play completely afresh. Good to see Red Shift in such stunning form.

Bloomsbury, Gorden St, WC1 (0207-388 8822) 7.30pm, £12.

Frankenstein: The Final Blasphemy

Mutant love story from ace adult puppeteers and techno wizards Doo-Cot based on the famous gothic story. But as usual this innovative company take an off-the-wall approach as they explore the boundaries between the lover and the loved, the creator and the monster, the artist and the muse.

Warwick Arts Centre, Gibbet Hill Rd, Coventry (0247-652 4524) 7.45pm, £8.

The Real Thing

Transfer of acclaimed Donmar production of Tom Stoppard's early 80s play about the nature of love and art. Stephen Dillane and Jennifer Ehle reprise their much-admired performances as writer Henry and his lover Annie in David Leveaux's production.

Albery, St Martins La, WC1 (0171-369 1761) 7.30pm, £12-£32.50.

Mother Goose

Gerard Kelly (Callum Finnegan in Brookside) reprises the "daft boy" role that he has made his own over the years. Admired Scots actress Barbara Rafferty will be bringing a bit of class to the role of Mother Goose, and making her first ever panto appearance, as the wicked witch, is the excellent Maureen Beattie, daughter of legendary Scottish variety performer Johnny.

King's, Bath St, Glasgow (0141-287 7000) 1pm , 7pm, £3-£15.50.

Bert's Big Night Out

The acclaimed Northern Stage provide visual surprises, invention and interaction for young theatre-goers as they follow the paw-prints and help Roberta solve the mystery of Bert Bear's whereabouts.

Newcastle Playhouse, Barras Bridge, Newcastle upon Tyne (0191-230 5151) 1.30pm, £6.50.

webTitle: Sack race contenders still to leave their blocks

fields.headline: Sack race contenders still to leave their blocks
fields.trailText: By this time last season several Premiership managers had either been sacked, resigned or were a matter of days away from their P45. So why is this season shaping up as the year of living safely?
fields.body:
Notice anything different about the Premiership this year? It's January, the season is more than half complete and a dozen clubs are either in relegation trouble or (when measured against expectations and/or the money spent pre-season on new players) can said to be having a bad time. Fans are malcontent, club chairmen are twitchy - so what's new you say - but look closer and you'll find there's something missing.

Still don't know? Here's a few clues: Christian Gross, Roy Hodgson, Roy Evans, Dave Bassett and Kenny Dalglish. That's right: by this time last season, all had either been sacked, resigned or were a matter of days away from their P45. Meanwhile, the Ron Atkinson revival roadshow, like a 1975 Ford Capri with gearbox trouble, was getting ready to come coughing and spluttering out of the garage for one last tour.

This year, Big Ron hasn't had a look-in due to the sudden demise of one of the game's most enduring spectacles: the managerial cull. Sure, yesterday's papers made unpleasant reading for Bryan Robson at Middlesbrough, and the four Sheffield stooges continue their efforts to get Danny Wilson kicked out of Hillsborough but it's highly unlikely that either will go - Robson because of his close personal friendship with the chairman Steve Gibson, Wilson because debt-ridden Wednesday couldn't afford to pay him off.

In past years David Jones at Southampton, Jim Smith at Derby, Egil Olsen at Wimbledon, Gianluca Vialli at Chelsea and John Gregory at Villa might have justifiably been nervous by this stage of the season but - for a variety of reasons - will probably be safe until the summer at least. This would leave Ruud Gullit as the season's only managerial casualty.

There are a couple of different ways of interpreting this change. It's true that some managers are currently unsackable. Alex Ferguson is in with the brickwork at Old Trafford, despite hellish relations with his nominal boss, Martin Edwards; Arsène Wenger will remain at Highbury for as long as he wishes.

Meanwhile, the charges pending against him mean Jones will remain at Southampton for the foreseeable future. Alternatively, it could be argued that those who run clubs - even Doug Ellis at Villa - have at long last come to appreciate that it might take the new man more than a fortnight to turn the squad of deadbeats assembled by the last numbskull he employed into a team of world-beaters. It might also be the case that some chairmen have come to the conclusion that while their club is at the wrong end of the table, the manager is doing his best given the available resources - as Lionel Pickering at Derby appears to have done with Jim Smith.

This, of course, requires a benevolent view of football club chairmen. A cynic's view is that Pickering is the exception and the truth is that chairmen love to sack managers; always have done, always will. After all, how else do they show who is really in charge?

These days, however, if a chairman sacks his manager he faces a real difficulty, and it's a problem for British football as a whole; where is the pool of managerial talent from which to pluck a replacement?

You only have to look at the list of names that are regularly floated when there is speculation about a managerial vacancy to appreciate the extent of the problem. Terry Venables, Glenn Hoddle, Graeme Souness and, naturally, Atkinson - all of them tainted in one way or another. Look at what happened at Blackburn after Brian Kidd was sacked where, despite Jack Walker's millions and limitless ambitions, the job finally went to the perennial caretaker, reliable old Tony Parkes.

Other ambitious clubs in the First Division - which, don't forget, should be a breeding ground for talent - face the same problem. A number of the leading clubs are managed by old-stagers with a record of scraping promotion, rather than young guns with ambitions to become the next Sir Alex Ferguson. Of the rest, with the exception of Charlton's Alan Curbishley or, going down another division, David Moyes at Preston, it is hard to imagine many of them in charge of a Premiership club. This might be good news for the likes of Robson but ought to worry anyone with an interest in the game's future.

webTitle: MPs to debate cash machine charges

fields.headline: MPs to debate cash machine charges
fields.trailText: The controversy over charging for withdrawing money from cash machines will be aired in parliament today when an early day motion will attack the "greed" of financial firms and their scant regard for financial exclusion.
fields.body:
The controversy over charging for withdrawing money from cash machines will be aired in parliament today when an early day motion will attack the "greed" of financial firms and their scant regard for financial exclusion.

The issue has dogged the Link network since Barclays tried four months ago to introduce a £1 surcharge for other firms' customers using its machines.

Barclays, in the face of legal action from Nationwide, has yet to introduce the charge. It threatened to change the dynamics of Link, which had previously been offered free or worked on the basis of "disloyalty" fees levied by financial firms on their customers when they used others' machines.

Barclays has scrapped its disloyalty fee at a cost of £2m a month, and wants to recoup some of this via the surcharge on other banks' customers.

Nationwide, the loudest opponent of the £1 fee, yesterday produced research showing that 91% of the public do not believe they should be surcharged for withdrawing their own money.

If surcharges were introduced, the NOP poll for Nationwide found that only 7% of people would carry on using the surcharging machines.

David Chidgey, Liberal Democrat MP for Eastleigh, said his early day motion would attempt to draw attention to the different approach to charging between banks and building societies - some of which continue to offer free access to the Link network.

fields.headline: Oreste and Oresteia
fields.standfirst: Linbury Studio Theatre, Covent Garden, London
fields.trailText: Linbury Studio Theatre, Covent Garden, London
fields.body:
We've learned that Handel's operas can be made as dramatically involving as any in the repertory, and that non-specialist audiences need all the help they can get when contemporary music is being performed, but the message clearly hasn't reached the English Bach Festival. Its latest offering of Handel's Oreste and Xenakis's Oresteia, given on successive evenings in the Royal Opera House's studio theatre, pairs treatments of different aspects of the Orestes myth separated by more than two centuries. Handel's pasticcio, patched together from already composed music to plug a gap in his Covent Garden season in 1734, hasn't been seen in this country since, while the Xenakis was composed in 1966, and was being staged in Britain for the first time.

It's an intriguing juxtaposition, but that's as far as the interest goes. It simply won't do nowadays to present a Handel opera in such a wooden way as this production by Tom Hawkes, which affects stock 18th-century gestures and tired rococo frocks rather than attempting to say anything remotely perceptive about the work itself, or to play the score with the raw-toned dutifulness that is all the English Bach Festival Baroque Orchestra can summon under Howard Williams. Some of the singing - Louise Winter's Oreste, Lynda Russell's Ermione - is decent, but the bone-dry acoustic of the Linbury Studio helps nobody.

The libretto is sung in often indistinct Italian, without surtitles, yet the programme synopsis is unreadable between the scenes because no one thought of putting the houselights up. Even that thoughtlessness pales alongside the presentation of the Xenakis, which is sung in classical Greek, with a full translation printed in the programme, and the auditorium kept in Stygian gloom. Whether understanding precisely what was going on would have made much difference is debatable: Xenakis's chanted choruses, and occasional kabuki-like scenes for the protagonists, aren't ever involving. The most interest comes from the typically abrasive instrumental writing, which Guy Protheroe conducts authoritatively; but that cannot compensate for the aching boredom of the rest.

 Further performances tonight, tomorrow and Friday (Xenakis), and next Saturday and Sunday (Handel): 0171 304 4000.

fields.headline: Gene
fields.standfirst: Forum, London
fields.trailText: Forum, London
fields.body:
As the music industry struggles to acclimatise to the brave new online era, it's somehow fitting that the first major gig of the year should see the Forum sold out by a band without a record deal. That the band should be Gene, for years routinely scorned by the pop cognoscenti and correspondingly adored by the sort of people for whom ridicule is positively nothing to be scared of, is rich indeed. It would be hard to conceive of a less revolutionary torch-bearer for this new-millennium malarkey.

Gene probably appreciate the irony. This is, after all, the band who last year pre-empted an invite to the opening of the Dome with the vehemently off-message romp As Good as it Gets, introduced here with typical understatement by Martin Rossiter. "In my dreams, this is the national anthem," gasps Gene's determinedly quotable frontman. Considering his group's backs-to-the-wall situation and his fondness for striking pugilistic poses, Rossiter is surprisingly reticent, which suggests either quiet confidence in his eventual vindication, or else is testimony to the mellowing properties of age and fatherhood upon this once Most Punchable Man In Pop. As Rozzer minds his language, the stage is set for his colleagues to demonstrate why Gene have endured beyond many of their mid-90s contemporaries: they are a great live band.

Indeed, bald statistics suggest that there are people who regularly see them play but do not buy their records. There's no doubt that if any of Gene's three albums rocked as hard, ached as keenly or were as uninhibited as this performance, then their creators might have surfed the Britpop wave more successfully. Among a brace of new compositions, You stands out as quintessential quality Gene: overwrought, unafraid of flaunting its heart and with huge melodic swells from guitarist Steve Mason. So exhilarating is his sweat-flecked, scissor-kicking belief in the redemptive qualities of rock 'n' roll that he remains the band's chief weapon against their detractors.

Dodgy's Matthew Priest guests on drums for a few numbers, but otherwise there are few surprises. It's the way Gene's people prefer it. They like the new songs, but they like the old ones better. And tellingly, Gene don't mind playing the old ones at all. Time moves on, politicians' promises wither, but Be my Light, Be my Guide still gets them going. We could all meet up again same time, next year. Who needs a record deal anyway?

webTitle: US puts Lara on losing side

fields.headline: US puts Lara on losing side
fields.trailText: Lara Croft, the gun-toting heroine of the bestselling Tomb Raider series of computer games, is facing her toughest assignment.
fields.body:
Lara Croft, the gun-toting heroine of the bestselling Tomb Raider series of computer games, is facing her toughest assignment.

Fears have begun to emerge that the feisty character is beginning to lose her popularity - a challenge more potent for games publisher Eidos than any number of animated villains.

After reaching £63 at the end of November the company's shares have collapsed to £38.55.

According to figures compiled for games trade magazine CTW, the fourth instalment of Ms Croft's adventures made it to the top spot in sales over Christmas. It has also been the best selling game in France and Germany.

Investors have been more anxious, however, about sales in the US which from early numbers appear to have been disappointing. A note from Merrill Lynch last week put Tomb Raider IV at only 25th in the chart of best selling games in the weeks after launch.

Anecdotes cited by Merrill suggest that in some US stores sales of Tomb Raider IV were 50% lower than its forerunner.

While many hi-tech stocks began the year on the slide, with Eidos the sell-off might have been exaggerated by the speed of its ascent. In little more than 12 months the share price climbed from £6 to £63, inviting profit takers to cash in.

Eidos has had other difficulties, however. Downbeat trading statements from retailers Dixons and Electronics Boutique had a knock-on effect. Both complained of reduced margins as the price of games were discounted.

"Unit sales have been healthy across the market but the value of the market is not what had been expected be cause of some savage discounting by retailers," said CTW editor Ronnie Dungan.

The note from Merrill Lynch and one from Warburgs recommend Eidos as a long term buy because help might be at hand for our heroine.

Lara Croft comics and a movie based on the character due for release at the end of next year should renew interest in the licence. Eidos has kept control of the project by insisting on being an executive producer, aiming to avoid disastrous celluloid outings for cult characters such as Tank Girl and Barb Wire.

The number of Sony PlayStations and therefore the potential market for Tomb Raider has also continued to grow strongly, aided by the fall in console prices from £300 to £80. Since the release of Tomb Raider III the installed base has swollen from 40m to 70m worldwide.

Analysts say the market, awaiting the arrival of PlayStation II at the end of this year, has dipped slightly but maintained growth, suggesting the market has matured beyond a cyclical pattern.

Longer term, as Warburg points out and many noted in the aftermath of the blockbusting America Online/Time Warner deal, those companies which can provide sought-after content are in a powerful position.

"The emergence of electronic distribution as broadband technology is introduced will expose gaming to the mass market," said Warburg analyst Kean Marden.

Interactive television services, the internet and, potentially the most explosive growth platform, internet-enabled mobile phones, could attract new players to Tomb Raider and Eidos's other properties. Games are also expected to benefit from the growth of e-commerce.

"It may be difficult to keep rolling Lara Croft out into new adventures and maintain momentum but there is a lot of scope for moving the game sideways into other formats," Mr Dungan added.

Eidos has invested to ensure it shares in the growth of new distribution methods. Other franchises are being developed, too, including football game Championship Manager which was the fourth best seller in Britain over Christmas. Industry pundits also like the Commandoes game and Eidos has the contract to produce a game tied to Disney's forthcoming 102 Dalmations.

fields.headline: No1 on the world stage
fields.trailText: Glaxo SmithKline, which will become the world's biggest drugs group after the planned £107bn merger of Britain's two largest pharmaceuticals companies, said yesterday it will use its enhanced financial muscle to mount takeovers and become increasingly dominant on the global stage.
fields.body:
Glaxo SmithKline, which will become the world's biggest drugs group after the planned £107bn merger of Britain's two largest pharmaceuticals companies, said yesterday it will use its enhanced financial muscle to mount takeovers and become increasingly dominant on the global stage.

Sir Richard Sykes, who will become chairman of the enlarged group, said: "We will have unbelievable financial firepower, and if there are opportunities to drive on the business we will be in a very strong position to take them."

The group will have debts of only £2.8bn and will generate some £2bn a year in cash, enabling it to contemplate some huge acquisitions.

The prospect that takeovers will be lined up before the ink is dry on its merger underlines the pace of consolidation in the market. Other deals such as Pfizer's hostile assault on Warner-Lambert gave impetus to the deal when attempts to secure a partnership two years ago foundered due to personality and culture clashes.

Jan Leschly - the head of SmithKline whose retirement in April was seen as opening the way for a merger by easing boardroom tensions - described past failure to cement a deal as "irrelevant", and said he will remain a long-term shareholder in the enlarged group rather than cashing in the £90m of shares and options to which he is entitled.

The new group, which will have sales of £15bn a year and account for 7.3% of the global pharmaceuticals market, will be headed by Jean-Pierre Garner, Mr Leschly's number two at SmithKline Beecham, who said the deal was a merger of "the strong with the strong".

A joint research and development budget of £2.5bn would place the group head and shoulders above its nearest rival, he said, and the 40,000-strong sales force would create an unrivalled ability to get drugs into the market.

In the United States alone, the group will be able to target 250,000 physicians a week.

Kevin Wilson, pharmaceuticals analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said he expected the group to achieve long-term growth of about 12% a year.

He predicted that the combined group will sell some antiviral and anti-emetic products to ensure a smooth regulatory passage for the deal. Although Glaxo SmithKline intends to create a new operational headquarters in the US, which accounts for 50% of sales, Mr Garnier said the corporate headquarters would remain in Britain, where some 85% of the shares are owned.

It is understood the companies did not seek the approval of Downing Street for their deal, even though a large slice of the promised £1bn-plus of annual savings are expected to come from a rumoured 15,000 job losses - some 2,000 of which are said to be expected in Britain, which could hit the UK's science base.

The MSF union, which sees the cuts falling mainly in manufacturing, is seeking assurances R&D facilities will not be cut. "Both companies have big US operations, which gives them every reason and excuse to phase out their operations in the UK," an official said. But Sir Richard said there was no intention to change R&D.

Shares in both firms fell after their recent gains, reflecting disappointment that savings will not be higher. SmithKline investors will own 41.25% of the new group, with Glaxo's being given one new share for every existing share.

Sir Richard Sykes, who will become chairman of the enlarged group, said: "We will have unbelievable financial firepower, and if there are opportunities to drive on the business we will be in a very strong position to take them." The group will have debts of only £2.8bn and will generate some £2bn a year in cash, enabling it to contemplate some huge acquisitions. The prospect that takeovers will be lined up before the ink is dry on its merger underlines the pace of consolidation in the market. Other deals such as Pfizer's hostile assault on Warner-Lambert gave impetus to the deal when attempts to secure a partnership two years ago foundered due to personality and culture clashes. Jan Leschly - the head of SmithKline whose retirement in April was seen as opening the way for a merger by easing boardroom tensions - described past failure to cement a deal as "irrelevant", and said he will remain a long-term shareholder in the enlarged group rather than cashing in the £90m of shares and options to which he is entitled. The new group, which will have sales of £15bn a year and account for 7.3% of the global pharmaceuticals market, will be headed by Jean-Pierre Garner, Mr Leschly's number two at SmithKline Beecham, who said the deal was a merger of "the strong with the strong". A joint research and development budget of £2.5bn would place the group head and shoulders above its nearest rival, he said, and the 40,000-strong sales force would create an unrivalled ability to get drugs into the market. In the United States alone, the group will be able to target 250,000 physicians a week. Kevin Wilson, pharmaceuticals analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said he expected the group to achieve long-term growth of about 12% a year. He predicted that the combined group will sell some antiviral and anti-emetic products to ensure a smooth regulatory passage for the deal. Although Glaxo SmithKline intends to create a new operational headquarters in the US, which accounts for 50% of sales, Mr Garnier said the corporate headquarters would remain in Britain, where some 85% of the shares are owned. It is understood the companies did not seek the approval of Downing Street for their deal, even though a large slice of the promised £1bn-plus of annual savings are expected to come from a rumoured 15,000 job losses - some 2,000 of which are said to be expected in Britain, which could hit the UK's science base. The MSF union, which sees the cuts falling mainly in manufacturing, is seeking assurances R&D facilities will not be cut. "Both companies have big US operations, which gives them every reason and excuse to phase out their operations in the UK," an official said. But Sir Richard said there was no intention to change R&D. Shares in both firms fell after their recent gains, reflecting disappointment that savings will not be higher. SmithKline investors will own 41.25% of the new group, with Glaxo's being given one new share for every existing share.

fields.headline: In Suspension
fields.standfirst: London International Mime Festival/touring
fields.trailText: London International Mime Festival/touring
fields.body:
Puppetry for adults is still a rarity in this country, although companies such as Doo Cot and visitors from abroad such as Ronnie Burkett are proving that complex ideas and emotions can be expressed in the form. Stephen Mottram is a leader in the field: his extraordinary and visionary production of The Seed Carriers, inspired by Richard Dawkins's The Selfish Gene, is one of the best pieces of puppet theatre I've ever seen.

This series of six short pieces doesn't have the sustained brilliance or intellectual and emotional depth of that performance, but the combi nation of Mottram's skill with marionettes and Glyn Perrin's superb electronic music, which mixes hurdy gurdy with stone and metal or interweaves sampled elements with field recordings, creates tiny complete worlds full of suspense, surprise and sometimes foreboding.

Each of the six pieces is separate but there appears to be a common thread, a sense of wonder at the world conjured through a series of magic tricks. In Animata, a figure crawls on all fours and in a superhuman effort walks on its hands; a tightrope walker makes precarious progress and a trapeze artist suspended only by the toes flies through the air. In Bird, the body of an ostrich-like creature becomes an egg that opens to reveal a baby bird. Troubled Repose is a sightless dream in which the sleeper is attacked by a glittering belly-dancing fly. In one of the segments the puppet is there but not there; in another a white rabbit appears out of a hat.

What's interesting about the performance is the way it creates a recognisably human world using marionettes that are often as blank as dummies. Somewhere in the space between the action and the music, it is the audience's own imaginative response that brings this strange, eerie world fully and gloriously alive.

 Tonight at the Pleasance, London N7 (0171 609 1800) and tomorrow at the Swan, High Wycombe (01494 512000).

webTitle: Toyota spent £1.5bn building two British factories. So why threaten to close them?

fields.headline: Toyota spent £1.5bn building two British factories. So why threaten to close them?
fields.standfirst: Carmaker joins growing clamour from industry for Britain to set an early date to adopt the euro
fields.trailText: Britain faces an exodus of foreign money and the loss of more than a million jobs unless the government signs up for the single currency within the next 30 months, leading overseas investors have warned.
fields.body:
Britain faces an exodus of foreign money and the loss of more than a million jobs unless the government signs up for the single currency within the next 30 months, leading overseas investors have warned.

Toyota, the Japanese carmaker which has invested £1.5bn in Britain where it employs 3,300 staff in Derbyshire and North Wales, yesterday threatened to pull out of the UK unless the government set an early timetable for joining the single currency.

Honorary chairman Syoichiro Toyoda's warning goes further than previous public statements from top companies but is said by insiders to reflect even stronger signals about disenchantment with Britain's detachment from euroland given to ministers in private.

For inward investors one of the UK's strongest attractions has been the combination of flexible labour markets and strong trading links with Europe - up to 60% of exports - but the strength of the pound vis-à-vis the euro is undermining the competitiveness of British-based manufacturers.

Supporters of the single currency hope that definite plans for British membership would remove the uncertainties created by exchange rate fluctuations and help bring the pound down to a more competitive level - the equivalent of 2.65/2.80 German marks rather than the present DM3.14.

The government faces an acute dilemma over how soon it can stage a vote on when to join the euro. Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, has already conceded that the UK is coming under strong pressure from inward investors - notably the Japanese - to make a decision on the euro early in the next parliament.

But Labour tacticians are acutely aware that a commitment to hold an early referendum could allow the Conservatives to turn the general election campaign into a national vote on Britain in Europe.

The prime minister has warned industry not to expect the government to be sympathetic towards calls for a weaker pound. "Business cannot rely on perpetual devaluation to give us a leading edge," Mr Blair said recently.

But Sir Ken Jackson, leader of the Amalgamated Electrical and Engineering Union, and a prominent supporter of early euro entry, said scores of British and foreign firms were warning privately they would leave the UK unless it joined the euro within the next two to two-and-a-half years.

American anxieties about the likelihood of Britain joining the euro were underlined by Joseph Quinlan, senior global economist at US investment house Morgan Stanley. "The UK has long been viewed by US multinationals... as a springboard to continental Europe. The UK's decision on whether or not to join (monetary union) will be a key determinant of just how much bounce this springboard has left," he said.

But Nick Herbert, chief executive of Business for Sterling, the anti-euro campaign, dismissed the warnings as an undisguised plea for a devaluation of the pound.

Eurosceptics said car companies were expert in disguising demands for state aid as exchange rate issues. "It's just a bid for more grants," said one. "Carmakers have that hold on the psyche of governments."

Mr Herbert said: "There's no guarantee we would join at a cheaper rate. And it's the worst of all reasons for joining - any gain would be short term because we argue that the impact of monetary union would be higher taxes and higher costs."

He noted that inward investment to the UK reached record levels in 1998 when the pound was strong.

Whether Toyota would ever pursue the option of total withdrawal is a moot point, though it claims to be suffering heavy losses - and sent a frisson through government two years ago when, with heavy subsidies from the French state, it invested £350m in a plant in Valenciennes. Its aim was to be at the heart of euroland.

But the more pressing question is whether Britain's continued ambivalence towards the euro will damage future investment projects.

Jac Nasser, Ford's president and chief executive, said recently: "When we sit down and think about a major investment our assumption is that the UK will be within the eurozone at least some time within the lifetime of that investment."

Unfortunately, for Messrs Blair and Byers, the electoral cycle is a lot shorter than that.

fields.headline: Diary, Cornerhouse, Manchester
fields.body:
There are signs that artists are once again playing the creative game with the facts and fictions of their own lives. The public expect it. The most popular artists are those who make creative myths of their own extraordinary images - Warhol, Beuys, Bourgeois, Gilbert and George. But most of the international array of artists in this timely exhibition go to great democratic pains to show they live lives as banal as the rest of us.

There will be disappointment here for wild-at-heart visitors expecting psychic profiles of transgression and transcendental struggle. The fascination tends to be with the diary format itself: systematic lists and traceries, the selective inaccuracies of memory and, above all, a touching lamentation of the fact that so few of us bother to record the personal facts of our lives any more.

There are some all too familiar inclusions: Mary Kelly's maternal inscriptions on slate, Richard Long's textual records of interminable country walks, Tracey Emin's video confessions of abortion and bedsit mess. Ian Breakwell's Walking Man Diary from the 70s, a photo-surveillance of aimless urban ramblings of an anonymous old character, still stands out as an innovative document of an everyday theatre of the absurd.

It's in the nature of diaries that they do not have to be formally or professionally finished off and several works resort to the cop-out of equating amateurishness with casual intimacy. Pastel doodlings, scrawled self-portraits, tediously illustrated dream memoirs, laddish Batman cartoons, walls pasted with family snaps, caricature confessions, day-by-day wardrobe inventories - all these simply drag the show towards dilettante indulgence. In comparison, good old Tracey Emin's A Week From Hell, a thumbnail sketch of an emotionally ruptured nude, embodies a sensitive touch of exquisite precision. Yes, she can draw.

It's perhaps significant, however, that the most convincing work tends to have very little to do with the personal, existential theme of diaries at all. Darren Almond presents huge grids of tiny photos of a clinical corner of a design studio, taken every minute over 24 hours on the longest and shortest days of the year. This is Impressionism brought up to date, a bland and beautiful perspective on the minimalist repetitions of a state-of-the-art environment.

But it's Hiroshi Sugimoto who proves that virtual ordinariness can still frame the marvellous. His photographs of cinemas in Paris, Tokyo and New York show blank screens of blinding white light, captured by leaving the aperture of his camera open for the duration of the film. There's nothing there to be seen, but that nothing somehow suspends disbelief more convincingly than all the autobiography and auto-gossip of the rest of the exhibition.

 Manchester until March 12, then at Colchester from March 25 to May 20.

webTitle: Is this what they call pop art?

fields.headline: Is this what they call pop art?
fields.standfirst: Balloons, Blu-Tack and a crumpled sheet of paper: all part of the wacky works of Martin Creed. By  Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: Balloons, Blu-Tack and a crumpled sheet of paper: all part of the wacky works of Martin Creed. By Adrian Searle
fields.body:
I can hear muffled whoops, squeals, the pop of bursting balloons coming from inside the room. It's party time. I blunder in, assailed by whiteness and the sensation of being suddenly lost, wading through balloons, my hair frizzing in the static charge, the tart, sweet, rubbery smell assaulting my nose, catching in the back of my throat, the balloons jostling and seething and doing a wobbly dance around me and over my head. I barge through, my body displacing these hundreds of white balloons and causing them to ride up into the clear air above. They squeak and rub together, snag my clothing and occasionally burst underfoot. Some float up to the ceiling and stick there, or rank themselves into neat grids high against the wall. Somewhere at the far end of the room is another door, if I can only get to it.

Being in here is fun, but purposeless. You don't feel entirely adult. A sculptor like Richard Serra might make you aware of the mass and volume of space, and of your own body in relation to it, but he has to threaten you with tons of steel and the possibility of being crushed to death in order to do it. Martin Creed makes you aware of space and volume too, but he does it with balloons.

This is Work #200, Half the Air in a Given Space, currently filling (or rather half-filling) a room at Southampton City Art Gallery as part of a survey of Creed's work. "Choose a space," says the artist's note. "Calculate the volume of the space. Using air, blow up white, 12-inch balloons until they occupy half the volume of the space... As usual the space should be full of air, but half of it should be inside balloons. Extra balloons may be added over time to maintain the volume of the work, or else the balloons may be left to deflate naturally."

It is a good wheeze, but what, if anything, does it signify? It gives pleasure. The gallery is in a building that also houses a court, a library and council offices. Glum-looking local government officials sneak out of their open-plan dens and into Creed's room full of balloons, to emerge refreshed and tousled. Perhaps every office should have a room like this.

Creed is a specialist in nothing. He has nothing to say, and that's what he goes on saying, over and over. One of his CDs, recorded with his band Owada (named after the trio's Japanese bass player), is even called Nothing, and the title track repeats the word, over and over, during five minutes of angular drum'n'bass and jangly lead guitar.

Owada are about as stripped down as minimal art-pop gets. Their music lingers in your head but leaves you with little more than a syncopated sense of nothing. But it is intelligent nothing. Creed's work isn't about the ponderous nothingness of the void, the terror of the meta-physical zilch, or the hideous ennui of existential nada . It is just, well, nothing. Or, more accurately, something and nothing, like the froth on a cappuccino, or like a room with the lights going on and off (Work #127), or like a torn-up sheet of paper. It's there and it's not there, it's formal and it's formless. It's like trying to catch smoke.

On my way out of the room, some of the balloons make a sneaky escape with me, bouncing and slithering their way across a gallery crammed with sculpture. They bat around an early Bill Woodrow, almost impale themselves on a Richard Deacon and do a header off a Degas bronze. Work #128: All the Sculpture in a Collection. Creed has shunted almost the entire sculpture collection of Southampton City Art Gallery into one room, from Rodin's Eve to a ghastly study of the late Max Wall. There they all are, dozens upon dozens of museum purchases, bequests, gifts and mistakes. Of course, the sculpture looks pitiful displayed like this, but I guess that's the point. The only work that's missing is the collection's Richard Long, a floor piece consisting of dozens of chalky flint lumps.

Long's work, displayed elsewhere in the museum, isn't so far conceptually from Creed's. Both frequently use commonplace or found materials that are transformed by the artist's attention to them - by an act of ordering and display, rather than by carving or modelling. But while Long's work is evocative of nature (the Long walk, the circle of sub-arctic driftwood, a line of pebbles or a splash of mud), Creed's is essentially urban, interior, even desk-bound.

Hang on a minute ( sounds of frenzied scrabbling and cursing as writer bangs head on underside of desk and stabs himself with dead ballpoint pen in search for crumpled notes, which he has earlier scrunched into a ball and tossed in the rubbish basket ): I might have chucked out a work of art. A few years ago, Creed mailed out "a sheet of A4 paper crumpled into a ball", his Work #88. Here it is again, under perspex and on a plinth. And, similarly displayed, his sheet of torn-up A4 paper, looking wan and futile in its perfect vitrine, under the glare of the gallery lights. Now this really is nearly nothing, but formally and conceptually it isn't so far from Long's chunks of flint. Both cast nice shadows, both rely on the niceties of presentation to transform them from the commonplace.

What's the point, you ask? Look to Creed's dictum: "The whole world + the work = the whole world". This statement was briefly emblazoned on a huge billboard on Farringdon Road, opposite the Guardian office, as part of the ad campaign for Matthew Collings's This Is Modern Art TV series. I would stand, smoking and musing, gazing across the street at this phrase, taking a break from the day's yard of art crit. Creed's statement isn't exactly Wittgenstein, but Wittgenstein had no sense of humour.

Creed's works accrue into an attitude rather than an oeuvre of meaningful objects; his project is a stance rather than a production line of sleek art works. It manifests itself in small, apparently trivial gestures: "a row of 39 metronomes beating time, one at every speed", a blob of Blu-Tack pressed on to the wall, a small typed statement that reads "oh no", or "something on the left, just as you come in, not too high or low". When he makes things that are more crafted they fall flat. His protrusions from a wall - disconcertingly pregnant-looking or breast-like bulges painted the same white as the wall itself - are too like Anish Kapoor's 1992 work When I Am Pregnant.

The work I like best, that leaves me with more than a little jolt and a wry smile, is "a door opening and closing and a light going on and off", installed here in a little office in a vestibule at the beginning of the show. The door opens, the light comes on, the light goes off and the door closes. Then it does it again. There is a glimpse of filing cabinets and in-trays, suddenly illuminated. There's no one there, but I feel a little uneasy. DON'T WORRY, reads a new neon sign work. Another reads THINGS, in virulent red light. Things? What things? Creed's neon works stop you in your tracks. That's all they do. They're feel-good signs, but they're also slightly unhinged. EVERYTHING IS GOING TO BE ALRIGHT says the sign he placed, to the initial bemusement of the locals, on some abandoned arches in east London. If only.

This sign also hangs on Times Square in New York. I like the idea of its presence there among the wretched advertising slogans. Like Lawrence Weiner's mural statements, Creed's work has a benign accessibility. Weiner, you might say, got there first, and cares a great deal about whether what he does is art. I don't think Creed cares about that so much. He wants to give us pleasure, while Weiner can be irritating and drearily obtuse. Creed never forgets that there has to be a viewer, a listener or a reader, someone out there to sustain the work. The way he works looks simple, but it's hard to do and harder still to sustain. He's interrupting the daily grind, making us pause for a moment. It's nearly nothing, but it's almost enough.

 Martin Creed Works is at Southampton City Art Gallery (01703 832743) till March 26, then touring.

But while Long's work is evocative of nature (the Long walk, the circle of sub-arctic driftwood, a line of pebbles or a splash of mud), Creed's is essentially urban, interior, even desk-bound. Hang on a minute ( sounds of frenzied scrabbling and cursing as writer bangs head on underside of desk and stabs himself with dead ballpoint pen in search for crumpled notes, which he has earlier scrunched into a ball and tossed in the rubbish basket ): I might have chucked out a work of art. A few years ago, Creed mailed out "a sheet of A4 paper crumpled into a ball", his Work #88. Here it is again, under perspex and on a plinth. And, similarly displayed, his sheet of torn-up A4 paper, looking wan and futile in its perfect vitrine, under the glare of the gallery lights. Now this really is nearly nothing, but formally and conceptually it isn't so far from Long's chunks of flint. Both cast nice shadows, both rely on the niceties of presentation to transform them from the commonplace. What's the point, you ask? Look to Creed's dictum: "The whole world + the work = the whole world". This statement was briefly emblazoned on a huge billboard on Farringdon Road, opposite the Guardian office, as part of the ad campaign for Matthew Collings's This Is Modern Art TV series. I would stand, smoking and musing, gazing across the street at this phrase, taking a break from the day's yard of art crit. Creed's statement isn't exactly Wittgenstein, but Wittgenstein had no sense of humour. Creed's works accrue into an attitude rather than an oeuvre of meaningful objects; his project is a stance rather than a production line of sleek art works. It manifests itself in small, apparently trivial gestures: "a row of 39 metronomes beating time, one at every speed", a blob of Blu-Tack pressed on to the wall, a small typed statement that reads "oh no", or "something on the left, just as you come in, not too high or low". When he makes things that are more crafted they fall flat. His protrusions from a wall - disconcertingly pregnant-looking or breast-like bulges painted the same white as the wall itself - are too like Anish Kapoor's 1992 work When I Am Pregnant. The work I like best, that leaves me with more than a little jolt and a wry smile, is "a door opening and closing and a light going on and off", installed here in a little office in a vestibule at the beginning of the show. The door opens, the light comes on, the light goes off and the door closes. Then it does it again. There is a glimpse of filing cabinets and in-trays, suddenly illuminated. There's no one there, but I feel a little uneasy. DON'T WORRY, reads a new neon sign work. Another reads THINGS, in virulent red light. Things? What things? Creed's neon works stop you in your tracks. That's all they do. They're feel-good signs, but they're also slightly unhinged. EVERYTHING IS GOING TO BE ALRIGHT says the sign he placed, to the initial bemusement of the locals, on some abandoned arches in east London. If only. This sign also hangs on Times Square in New York. I like the idea of its presence there among the wretched advertising slogans. Like Lawrence Weiner's mural statements, Creed's work has a benign accessibility. Weiner, you might say, got there first, and cares a great deal about whether what he does is art. I don't think Creed cares about that so much. He wants to give us pleasure, while Weiner can be irritating and drearily obtuse. Creed never forgets that there has to be a viewer, a listener or a reader, someone out there to sustain the work. The way he works looks simple, but it's hard to do and harder still to sustain. He's interrupting the daily grind, making us pause for a moment. It's nearly nothing, but it's almost enough.  Martin Creed Works is at Southampton City Art Gallery (01703 832743) till March 26, then touring.

webTitle: Tie-ups the prescription for success, say drugs firms

fields.headline: Tie-ups the prescription for success, say drugs firms
fields.standfirst: Corporate marriages exceed £200bn as European companies scramble to increase efficacy in US
fields.trailText: A wave of mergers and acquisitions worth over £200bn has swept the pharmaceutical sector in little over a year as leading drug companies fight to maintain sales and revenue growth while research and development soaks up cash.
fields.body:
A wave of mergers and acquisitions worth over £200bn has swept the pharmaceutical sector in little over a year as leading drug companies fight to maintain sales and revenue growth while research and development soaks up cash.

Product prices are under pressure as governments try to stem a rise in national health care costs while product launches have slowed at a time when patents on some of the decade's best sellers are expiring.

New methods such as genomics plus innovative screening systems are revolutionising the drug discovery process. But the price of finding another blockbuster such as Glaxo Welcome's anti-herpes treatment Zovirax now can cost $500m.

Industry leaders are convinced that bigger is better and this applies as much to R&D budgets as it does to getting the drug to market via ever-larger sales forces.

This has triggered an unprecedented period of consolidation with up to half of the top 25 industry leaders involved in some kind of corporate tie-up over the past 24 months. Accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers estimates that $133bn worth of M&A deals were concluded in 1999.

Among those opting for consolidation are US group Pfizer by trying to take over rival Warner-Lambert and Monsanto which wants a deal with Pharmacia and Upjohn while, in Europe, Hoechst of Germany is joining forces with Rhone-Poulenc of France to create Aventis and Astra of Sweden merged with Zeneca of Britain. In smaller deals, Roche of Switzerland is spinning off its fragrances and flavours division into a separate company, Givaudan, while AstraZeneca and Novartis have decided to spin off their agrochemical divisions to form Syngenta.

Takeovers and mergers are seen by some as a quick way to cut costs by rationalising overlapping activities but also offer the opportunity to increase resources for R&D. Not everyone is convinced that mergers are the way to success. Critics believe that profits can be boosted in the short term but say it is no substitute for original research for new products.

But the industry giants are not just marrying each other. Many of the new R&D breakthroughs are in the biotechnology field and smaller biotech companies are being hunted and bought up by big drug companies. Much of the corporate consolidation has been in Europe where local companies are trying to increase their firepower in an effort to be more effective in the vital North American market.

The corporate research boutique Evaluate notes how European companies have fallen behind those in the US where in the past 10 years firms' share of the top selling 50 drugs has increased from 19 in 1988 to 32 in 1998. By 2002 20 of the top 25 selling drugs will be marketed by US-based firms.

This would be a major blow, not only to European drug industry bosses, but also to investors and governments who see the pharmaceutical sector as one in which Europe can compete with the world's best. The pressure on European companies will intensify as "patient empowerment" - the trend to advertise drugs directly to individuals in the hope they will demand their doctors prescribe a certain product - spreads from the US.

Jonathan de Pass managing director of Evaluate says: "With the advantage of the industry's most profitable products, US companies will be able to outspend their European peers. The trends highlight the pressure on European companies to consider more mergers."

Analysts at merchant bank, CSFB, say that pharmaceutical companies have had to come to terms with the fact that their operating environment has changed over the last decade. "The playing field used to be flat and R&D successes were largely based on luck. But now more cash means more products at a time when there have been huge breakthroughs in all sorts of areas such as genetics, rational drug design and combinatorial chemistry," said one. He believes investors have been looking at the internet but the real breakthroughs have been in biology.
